Text: The increasing complexity of software and communication interfaces in Internet of Things (IoT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) has made them more susceptible to various attacks, leading to significant privacy and security concerns. Effective cybersecurity measures are essential to mitigate these threats, as breaches can result in severe consequences. Common security risks associated with IoT and CPS include inadequate vulnerability testing, unpatched vulnerabilities, reliance on default passwords, and outdated firmware, which collectively create an expanded attack surface for malicious actors. Moreover, the interconnected nature of these systems complicates traditional security approaches, necessitating robust cybersecurity solutions that address both the digital and physical aspects of these environments. Organizations must prioritize the implementation of comprehensive security strategies to safeguard their IoT and CPS infrastructures against evolving threats.

The study highlights key differences in vendor characteristics across sourcing strategies, noting that single-sourcing providers are typically larger, more established firms with greater cybersecurity resources and capabilities, enabling stronger system protection and vulnerability management [17]. In contrast, best-of-breed (BoB) vendors often consist of smaller niche players with limited resources, increasing their susceptibility to business instability and weaker cybersecurity practices due to constrained threat detection and mitigation efforts [4]. Furthermore, larger vendors exhibit heightened cybersecurity awareness and more consistent secure behaviors compared to smaller firms, reinforcing the link between vendor size, stability, and cybersecurity performance. These findings underscore the trade-offs between sourcing strategies, where vendor reliability and security posture vary significantly based on organizational scale and market positioning.

The microprocessor used in this system is 8-bit PSoC 
(Programmable System on Chip) device. There are three 
reasons to use this device. Firstly, it makes the design easier 
and reduces system cost. It has configurable analog and digital 
blocks, as well as programmable interconnects logic. This 
architecture allows users to create customized peripherals such 
as filters, amplifiers, analog to digital converters, 
communication interfaces and so on. Secondly, this device has 
a sleep timer and SMP (Switch Mode Pump) circuit, which are 
useful to reduce power consumption. Thirdly, there is a special 
PSoC device which reduces the design complexity of 
capacitive sensor keyboard in the system
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: The issue of poor cybersecurity skills is worsened by the transient nature of volunteers, reducing the long-term impact of any training provided. Additionally, SEs' close involvement with disadvantaged and vulnerable individuals increases their susceptibility to social engineering attacks, which are inherently difficult to prevent. This supports RQ1 by demonstrating that owner-managers acknowledge how the unique characteristics of SEs may expose them to cyber threats, particularly those relying on social engineering tactics.

In the next section, we show that our closed loop load following controller actually acts as a local supplementary control to bring back to zero the deviation in frequency due to the variation in load when there is no centralized AGC. This is true only if all the load variations in the system are supplied through bilateral contracts. Of course, it is unlikely that the power system can perform adequately without classical supplementary control. Still, even considering a scenario in which all the load variations are supplied through contracts, the system will require centralized control to address such concerns as losses, that cannot be completely included in a bilateral contract.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: The Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC), promulgated by the National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA), constitute a meticulously structured set of guidelines intended to fortify the cybersecurity infrastructure of organizations, these controls are strategically formulated to attenuate a broad spectrum of cyber threats, thereby fostering a secure and resilient digital ecosystem, the comprehensive scope of the ECC necessitates a sophisticated comprehension and implementation strategy, positioning it as a global standard for cybersecurity best practices.

Facilitating internal knowledge flows is challenging, as the cost of ambidexterity increases when firms struggle to realize the full potential of their knowledge. Managers may hesitate to share function-specific insights due to resource competition or concerns about promoting other units' ideas. Differences in thought processes and organizational culture further complicate knowledge sharing, potentially hindering collaboration and innovation within the firm.

The increasing global demand for cybersecurity experts has led standard bodies and governments to continuously monitor workforce requirements and develop frameworks to address the shortage. These initiatives have resulted in work role frameworks and comprehensive reports on workforce needs, providing guidance for bridging the skills gap in the cybersecurity industry.

Cybersecurity concerns, including malware attacks, denial-of-service attacks, phishing, unauthorized data access, and SQL injections, pose significant threats. These issues can compromise the performance of medical care applications within the Industrial Internet of Healthcare Things (IIoHT) architecture and system, potentially leading to severe consequences for consumers and patients. These cybersecurity challenges are particularly critical and distinct from conventional issues. For example, software must be protected from malware, wireless networks from viruses, and servers from anomalous activities. While known cyberattacks on data are readily detectable within a network, undetected attacks residing at various layers of the IIoHT mechanism for medical applications can cause substantial problems [8], [9], [10], [11]. Cyber-physical system (CPS)-based computational methodologies offer automated detection of cybersecurity issues within IIoHT-based applications. These methods are designed to be autonomous, self-adaptive, and self-learning within the fog cloud environment, enabling them to accommodate dynamic environmental changes.

Traditionally, manufacturing plants were siloed with air-gapped security, but Digital Manufacturing (DM) relies on interconnected sensors and devices to optimize production, introducing new cybersecurity risks. DM workflows, involving design, simulation, and machine programming, heavily depend on computational resources and networks, making them vulnerable to cyber threats. Hybrid manufacturing (HM) tools serve as a key example of this interconnected system, requiring continuous connectivity across the process chain. This article examines cybersecurity risks in DM, develops an attack taxonomy, and proposes innovative security solutions to safeguard cyber-physical manufacturing systems.

The feasibility study evaluates how the new generation affects system performance under both normal and contingency scenarios. Contingency analysis assesses how this new generation influences transmission facility loading and bus voltage during outages involving transmission lines, autotransformers, and generators. For this study, the latest version of the Southwest Power Pool's 2005 summer peak base case was utilized.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: Regulatory must-run units, like hydropower plants, are designed to ensure equitable competition in deregulated energy markets. Hydropower plants often serve dual purposes, providing both electricity and irrigation, and their participation in open markets could negatively impact their agricultural role. Additionally, their minimal or nonexistent fuel costs give them a potential unfair advantage in scheduling markets, necessitating the creation of specific market regulations.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: Recent reports from global associations, European organizations, and projects have emphasized the significance of addressing cybersecurity education challenges. ENISA has suggested that many of these issues could be mitigated by redesigning educational and training pathways, while ECSO has highlighted that cybersecurity is often treated as a specialization within computer science rather than as an interdisciplinary field. However, despite these reports, the exact reasons behind the persistent shortage of cybersecurity professionals remain unclear. Challenges differ across countries and sectors, making it difficult to pinpoint the root causes and their interconnections, further complicating efforts to develop effective solutions.

The rapid proliferation of IoT ecosystems?ueled by ubiquitous internet connectivity, wireless communication, smart devices, and IP-based sensor networks?as dramatically expanded the attack surface, necessitating next-generation cybersecurity frameworks that address the unique vulnerabilities of interconnected devices. Where traditional security protocols fail to meet IoT's scalability and integrity demands, emerging solutions like blockchain technology offer decentralized protection for device networks while ensuring data privacy compliance with evolving regulations [18,19]. This paradigm shift recognizes that IoT cybersecurity must simultaneously: (1) safeguard organizational assets and user privacy, (2) maintain interoperability across heterogeneous devices, and (3) provide audit-ready compliance?bjectives achievable only through adaptive architectures that replace obsolete perimeter-based defenses with distributed, cryptographic security layers tailored for massive IoT deployments.

In an asymmetric system, for the embedded watermark to be detected using the standard correlation test, there must be some correlation between the detector's reference watermark and the embedding watermarks. There are various methods to generate signals that differ from but maintain a fixed correlation with a given reference watermark. One straightforward approach is to create a weighted sum of the watermark and random noise. Hartung and Girod [2] suggested substituting part of the watermark with random noise. Here, we introduce a new method that utilizes the phase-shift-transform (PST).
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: In a chaotic communication system using lasers with delayed optical feedback, data protection traditionally relies on the need for nearly identical transmitter and receiver devices. In this study, we assume this requirement is no longer met (i.e., the eavesdropper has an identical receiver). The proposed security scheme is based on a predefined variation of the feedback phase, leveraging the inherent limitations of synchronization temporal response. The feedback phase acts as a shared key between the transmitter and receiver for synchronization. While one might compare this to algorithmic encryption before encoding data onto the chaotic carrier, the two approaches differ significantly. Algorithmic encryption increases processing power requirements and is vulnerable to decryption attacks. In contrast, the proposed method requires no additional processing power and relies on fundamental physical limitations for security.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text:
The CAS typically operates in a three-level hierarchy for key distribution. The server selects a random variable, known as the Control Word (CW), as the seed for a pseudo-random generator (PRG). The pseudo-random sequence generated by the PRG is used to scramble the transported stream (TS). Simultaneously, the CW is encrypted with an authorization key (AK) to create an Entitlement Control Message (ECM). The AK and other entitlement information are encrypted together using the Master Private Key (MPK) to form an Entitlement Management Message (EMM). The ECM, EMM, and scrambled TS stream are then multiplexed into a new TS stream and transmitted to subscribers via the broadcasting channel. To prevent malicious modifications, the ECM and EMM must be transferred with their respective digital signatures.
The Subscribers Management System (SMS) manages customers' access rights to protected services, such as adding or removing access rights by generating or updating the MPK stored in the smartcard. To enhance system security, the CAS can frequently change the CWs or use more complex symmetric encryption algorithms to scramble the program. In a typical CAS, CWs are changed every 5 to 20 seconds, significantly reducing the risk of known-plaintext attacks.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: The reliability evaluation of EIS must consider not only the adequacy evaluation of the system, but also the security anal ysis in order to define the system response to several distur bances [3]. Current reliability techniques model disturbances in a probabilistic way; however, they do not model the stochastic response of the power system [4] and the system is analyzed under steady-state conditions after the disturbances occur [5]. Such techniques are: zone branch [6], cut set [7], go [8] and re liability block diagram [9]. So, using these techniques, it is not possible to define indicators that include the temporal response of the EIS when sudden disturbances occur.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text:
There are a large number of contingency combinations that
could have great impacts to the system, but the probability of occurrence of most of these rare but severe events is normally low.
In order to maintain the complexity of the SPS at a reasonable
level, a list of the most credible situations should be identified.
For the selection of the contingency cases to be included in the
design of a transient stability SPS, this letter presents a framework that could account for uncertainty in event occurrence and
its consequence and combines them as a product to obtain a risk
index for contingency selection.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: The load shedding scheme incurs costs for customers, influenced by outage costs and the generator's forced outage rate. Customer outage costs can be approximated using a power disconnection or damage function. The system failure rate plays a crucial role in determining these costs, as each load shedding event results in an interruption cost. For estimating these costs, power interruption costs (measured in $/MW) appear more representative than nonsupplied energy costs (measured in $/MWh).
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: The paper presents the Automated Android Malware Detection using Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach for Cybersecurity (AAMD-OELAC) technique, which aims to enhance the automated classification and identification of Android malware. The AAMD-OELAC technique initiates with data preprocessing to improve data quality and follows an ensemble learning process that incorporates three machine learning models: Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), kernel extreme learning machine (KELM), and Regularized random vector functional link neural network (RRVFLN). Additionally, the hunter-prey optimization (HPO) algorithm is utilized for optimal parameter tuning of these models, leading to improved malware detection results. A comprehensive experimental analysis is conducted to demonstrate the superiority of the AAMD-OELAC approach over existing methods. The findings indicate that the AAMD-OELAC technique effectively addresses the challenges posed by evolving malware variants, making it a significant contribution to cybersecurity practices in the realm of Android applications.

This paper presents a detailed approach to designing and selecting current wind power technologies for Thailand's power system. It utilizes existing power system data and recent wind resource assessments to determine the optimal integration of wind power generation into the system. The study thoroughly examines the appropriate penetration levels and turbine sizing for Thailand, which is classified as a low to medium wind speed country.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: Our scheme is applied to audio watermarking in the time domain using a jazz music clip sampled at 44.1 kHz with 16-bit resolution. Four independent random noise signals serve as reference watermarks, which are modified in the DFT domain to match the magnitude spectrum of the cover audio, ensuring they are inaudible while maximizing detectable energy. Private keys consist of 1000 m-sequences, each 1023 bits long. The audio sequence is divided into frames of a specified length, and an embedding watermark is inserted into each frame using a scaling factor to maintain inaudibility. The same embedding watermark is used for every set of 32 consecutive frames. To test robustness, the watermarked audio undergoes 96-kb/s MP3 compression and decompression as an example of potential attacks.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: User authentication is a component of a broader security system, which can be classified as strong or weak based on the cost of an attack versus the potential gain for the attacker. Various authenticators provide different levels of defense against various types of attacks, which can occur at the client, during transmission, or at the host. This discussion focuses on client and host vulnerabilities. To strengthen security, multiple authenticator types can be combined through a process known as multifactor authentication. Additionally, the paper explains how user authentication integrates into comprehensive authentication systems like RADIUS, Kerberos, and Single Sign-On (SSO).
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: As depicted in Fig. 3, the frequency initially drops due to an increase in load but eventually returns to zero. The overshoot occurs because generators G1, G4, and G5 all contribute to restoring the frequency deviation by increasing their power output. Each generator participates in primary control, and since G1 and G4 are under AGC, they also assist in supplementary control. The second plot in Fig. 3 displays the power outputs in Control Area 1 (CA1), with a similar situation in CA2. After the transient phase, the power outputs of generators G2 and G3 match their respective bilateral load variations, while G1 shows a minor initial variation before stabilizing at zero.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: The Demand-Side System (DSS) can be applied in two scenarios. In the first, utilities offer interruptible tariffs to customers when they have surplus power capacity, aiming to reduce operational costs during peak periods by minimizing generation costs and maximizing customer benefits. In the second scenario, where the system faces capacity shortages, the goal is to maintain system reliability while minimizing load interruption disruptions. This requires balancing customer satisfaction with system security. The problem is well-suited for load interruption solutions due to their clear and efficient effects.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: The study in [24] focuses on identifying scientific papers that discuss cybersecurity frameworks, standards, guidelines, best practices, and other protective measures specifically for the nuclear sector. However, it does not cover safety issues, nor does it address the co-engineering of cybersecurity and safety, limiting its scope to cybersecurity measures within the domain.

Railways have been one of the primary commodities to move passengers and freight since at least the late 19th century. Yet, railway operators continuously face constant pressure to increase performance and the availability of their services[1]. Despite the recent technological advances, however, increasing the performance of such well-tuned systems without compromising their already excellent safety characteristics is nothing short of a titanic challenge. This is even more true if one considers the high degree of control that the general public (which is both a final user and one of the biggest sponsors for much infrastructure) imposes on railway industry players.

To handle unpredictable real-world scenarios, electric vehicles (EVs) have become integral to a vast network of interconnected entities, known as Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs). These intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) facilitate communication with other vehicles, infrastructure, and pedestrians through various modes, including V2X (which encompasses V2N, V2V, V2I, and V2P) and Dedicated Short-Range Communication (DSRC). However, ICVs face significant security and complexity challenges. Research has explored different communication technologies, such as DSRC and C-V2X, highlighting their architectures and vulnerabilities. Additionally, studies have examined the evolution of V2X communication and the rise of the Internet of Vehicles (IoV). Security threats targeting ICVs include attacks on traffic light infrastructure, communication channels, and sensor manipulation, alongside broader concerns related to DSRC and C-V2X communication security. Given the cyber-physical nature of ICVs, their vulnerabilities extend beyond communication networks, as adversaries can compromise power systems, manipulate vehicle controllers, and pose risks to pedestrian safety by injecting malware or executing unauthorized code. Therefore, ensuring a secure transportation ecosystem requires a comprehensive approach that addresses both the physical and digital security aspects of ICVs.

These Delphi processes are integral components of a broader initiative, the educational Cybersecurity Assessment Tools (CATS), accessible at 

http://www.cisa.umbc.edu/cats/index.html, which seeks to develop a Cybersecurity Concept Inventory (CCI) and a Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment (CCA), the CCI is designed to evaluate students completing introductory cybersecurity courses, while the CCA targets graduating college students transitioning into professional cybersecurity roles, consequently, the project executed two distinct Delphi processes concurrently, one dedicated to the CCI and the other to the CCA.

The proposed circuit can be built using approximately 20 CMOS gates and some passive components. The astable multivibrator operated at 5V, the 1-bit counter used a 16 MHz clock, and the output random number rate was 50 kb/s. All tests were conducted at room temperature. Since this RNG is made with discrete components, the supply voltage is higher than what's needed for mobile devices. However, with appropriate fabrication techniques, the circuit's supply voltage can be reduced to 1.5V or less. Also, this random number generation method is adaptable to other fluctuating signals, not just MOS-SBD signals, as long as the fluctuations are sufficiently large.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: The main objective of the NICE framework is to deliver a unified lexicon for defining different cybersecurity work roles. To this end, the framework classifies the work duties into seven main categories. Furthermore, the NICE framework divides these 7 categories into specialty areas and work roles. The framework contains extensive details on the knowledge, skills, and abilities that the individuals are required to obtain for becoming able to carry out cybersecurity tasks in each job position.

The utilization of cloud computing platforms presents a compelling avenue for delivering course assignments and facilitating students' acquisition of essential practical skills; specifically, cloud environments provide instructors and students, irrespective of geographic location, with on-demand, scalable, dedicated, isolated, and highly configurable virtual machine resources, thereby offering significant advantages over traditional laboratory settings that often impede pedagogical objectives and exhibit limited scalability; this study documents the implementation of a cloud-based approach for teaching a senior-level cybersecurity course across two campuses via a virtual classroom equipped with real-time audio and video communication, and based upon this experience, proposes guidelines for the instruction of similar computer science and engineering disciplines; the efficacy of cloud-based laboratory exercises in fostering critical cybersecurity and cloud computing proficiencies, both highly sought-after in contemporary professional environments, is demonstrated; while the Amazon Web Services (AWS) public cloud served as the platform for this specific implementation, the presented use cases and methodologies are transferable to other cloud platforms, including Rackspace and Google Compute Engine, among others.

It is clear that a hash bit serves to preserve the relationship be tween the selected DCT coefficients in a given block pair. The hash bits generated for each block are concatenated to form the digest of the input image. This digest can then be either em bedded into the image itself or appended as a tag. The authen tication procedure at the receiving end involves the extraction of embedded digest. The digest for the received image is gen erated as at the encoder and compared with the extracted and decrypted digest.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: Fast spinning reserve, power delivered within seconds of a frequency drop, is crucial for immediate system stabilization. Slower spinning reserve, while helpful for overall power deficit reduction, reacts too slowly to prevent critical minimum frequency dips. To model this, a portion of the fast spinning reserve, determined by a reserve factor, is considered equivalent to load shedding in its impact on system response. Equation (1) reflects this dynamic relationship, where Em, a function of the minimum frequency (fmin), must exceed a threshold. This ensures that low-frequency transients don't trigger further unit trips, preventing a cascading system collapse.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text:
In the proposed system, when the system needs to refreshes 
a new group key, only a few encryption/decryption operations 
are needed. Two primary operations may be performed by the 
system or members: multiplication and addition, in which 
computation load is very low. For every subscriber, they can 
get one head group key, HRGK , from the transport stream. 
According to HRGK and secret keys held by them, they will 
be able to work out the corresponding group keys and 
authorization keys. Moreover, when someone joins/leaves one 
group, the system will simply broadcast one package 
containing the new secret group key. Moreover, in order to 
improve the security of system, generally, AK should be 
refreshed every day. Since the changing of HRGK can result 
in refreshing of all AKs in our scheme , the system simply 
broadcasts single one package only containing the new 
HRGK to all users to carry out refreshing all AKs, which 
can greatly reduce the everyday computation overhead of the 
system.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: The progressive integration of internet and wireless communication, intelligent devices and objects, IP protocol, and sensor network technologies has significantly expanded the scope of network-based entities within the domain of IoT cybersecurity, these technological advancements are exerting a profound influence on emerging Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) and the Industry 4.0 paradigm, cybersecurity, in this context, permeates the IoT network, a globally interconnected infrastructure comprising heterogeneous smart devices that amalgamate sensory, communication, networking, and information processing capabilities, furthermore, the cybersecurity landscape of IoT is influenced by a multitude of supplementary technologies and devices, including barcodes, smartphones, social networks, and cloud computing, each contributing to the multifaceted nature of IoT security.

Ethics, which establish moral standards to distinguish right from wrong, are fundamental to cybersecurity due to its direct impact on human well-being, guiding the responsible use of technology to protect individuals and uphold societal values [1]?4]. Despite the seemingly straightforward mandate to "shield good actors and block malicious ones," cybersecurity ethics prove deeply complex [5], as illustrated by this paper's Horizon Scanning study, which identifies both mainstream concerns (e.g., data privacy) and underrecognized emerging dilemmas (e.g., AI-driven surveillance biases) that could redefine ethical boundaries in digital security.

Impact analysis assesses the effects of cyber intrusions on SCADA systems, evaluating potential consequences. The method described aims to determine network and power system vulnerabilities, including potential load loss resulting from cyberattacks. A successful attack that manipulates switching actions can severely damage a power system, particularly if it targets the control center network connected to substations. 1  This could lead to load loss or equipment damage. 2  To address this, an integrated risk modeling approach has been developed, capturing both control system vulnerabilities and their impact on real-time power system operations. This approach involves four key steps.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Raising security awareness for emerging technologies is essential to preventing cyberattacks. Ensuring information security within an open system architecture presents challenges, particularly in addressing potential threats while maintaining confidentiality, integrity, availability, and accountability [33]. The ISO/IEC 17779 standard provides a set of critical controls for managing information security [34]. A virtual enterprise serves as an effective approach for facilitating collaboration among networked enterprises by enabling remote coordination, control, and communication across different roles and user types [35]. In response to the growing connectivity of control networks, governments have taken measures to enhance national preparedness [4].
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: With the advancement of vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (VII) communication technologies, road systems could be upgraded to enhance traffic management. For instance, vehicle-to-roadside communication—already in use for automatic toll collection—could be expanded to monitor vehicle speed, location, origin, and destination at frequent intervals. These innovations could transform highways into intelligent traffic networks, as depicted in Fig. 7, where vehicles actively function as sensors and actuators within a high-level traffic management system rather than merely being passive users of the road.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text:
There were a few researchers who tried to leverage the
advantages of the LVC interoperable simulation [2]?[4].
However, most of the research projects simply interconnected
heterogeneous models, making merely limited use of the
other model. Specifically, in most cases, benign packets are
interpreted and transferred seamlessly between the different models while threat packets are not allowed to roam
between the models. Even in cases where threat packets
are allowed to be transferred between the models, the other
model only works as a relay node or a network segment
that simply returns the received threat packets to its originating model. Since analyzing the impact of a cyber threat
is one of the most important reasons to utilize cybersecurity
simulation, the aforementioned limitations have kept us
from using LVC interoperable simulation in a practical sense
Journal Name:
Cy-Through: Toward a Cybersecurity Simulation
for Supporting Live, Virtual, and Constructive
Interoperability

Text: When the injection strength in the slave laser significantly exceeds the feedback strength, the receiver reproduces the injected waveform through strong injection-locking synchronization. In this case, the synchronization recovery time is much shorter and remains constant, regardless of system complexity or external cavity length. However, no reported values have been lower than 200 ps, meaning that phase variations at this scale can still prevent eavesdropping. Furthermore, under these conditions, the receiver essentially functions as an open-loop system, losing phase sensitivity and demonstrating poor decoding performance for low-amplitude messages (as shown in Fig. 2).
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: The fault location system pinpointed the fault at 67.28 miles from the station, with a calculated range between 66.33 and 67.36 miles. Historically, actual faults have consistently fallen within this range. The system's distance estimate showed a minimal error of 0.27% compared to the reported value. In addition to location, the system provided comprehensive data, including the maximum RMS currents and corresponding voltages for each phase of the faulted transmission line. It also calculated and reported the impedance and angle of the faulted line up to the fault location. Finally, the system estimated the fault duration to be 97.76 milliseconds.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: To ensure comprehensiveness, this study synthesizes diverse reports and articles on cybersecurity education, with the PESTLE analysis serving as a consolidated summary of current research trends and gaps. While prior works have applied PESTLE frameworks to dissect sector-specific challenges (e.g., policy or technological barriers), this section specifically highlights PESTLE-centric studies, deferring broader literature on curricular or pedagogical issues to Sections III and IV. By anchoring the analysis in this methodology, the paper systematizes fragmented insights into a unified taxonomy, enabling targeted interventions for workforce development.

Researchers in the field of information and communication technology concur that information security (InfoSec) holds paramount importance [7]. Consequently, numerous studies have endeavored to address this concern through the implementation of enhanced techniques and technological solutions, including malware detection systems, intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDPS), advanced firewall configurations, and data encryption algorithms. While certain studies posit that InfoSec challenges can be effectively managed through a focus on human behavior [10], others contend that a singular emphasis on human behavior is inadequate [3]. Notably, the sheer volume of information processed by most organizations necessitates significant automation [12]. Therefore, an appropriate equilibrium between human intervention, technological implementation, and policy management is essential within organizational security practices.

This paper introduces a basic mathematical framework for the hybrid market and demonstrates its feasibility through simulations. Section II-A outlines the method and its underlying assumptions, while Section II-B explains one iteration of the trading process. Section III-A graphically illustrates the general properties of the trading process using an example network topology with five out of ten lines constrained. Section III-C discusses the overall trends observed from simulating the method on 102 different network topologies. Finally, Section IV concludes the paper and outlines directions for future research.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text:
Cybersecurity training is a critical prerequisite to the
military being fully cyberized. The military has attempted
to build its own specialized cybersecurity training system, or the cyber range. SIMTEX (Simulator Training
Exercise Network) [2] is one of the earliest examples of
military-developed cybersecurity training systems. SIMTEX
was designed initially for the US Air Force?s training purposes and later selected as the operational platform for
US military-hosted cybersecurity exercises such as Black
Daemon and Cyber Flag. SIMTEX offered virtualized hosts
to simulate the information assets targeted by cyber attacks
and a VPN tunnel to isolate attack flow across remote sites
for the exercises.
Journal Name:
ICSTASY: An Integrated Cybersecurity Training
System for Military Personnel

Text: Advancements in technology over the past decade have led to the refinement of protocols, enhancing their flexibility in interoperability and maintainability, particularly within open architectures featuring high-speed communications [12], [18]. However, the evolution of SCADA systems has also heightened concerns regarding cyber vulnerabilities [2], [13]. Additionally, the growing interdependence between computing, communication, and power infrastructures has increased risks due to the complexity of these integrated systems [19]. While these advancements offer significant benefits for operations, control, business, and analysis, they also introduce new security challenges. Nevertheless, technological progress holds the potential to mitigate the shortcomings of current power and communication systems [20].
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: This paper outlines a foundational mathematical framework for a hybrid market and demonstrates its feasibility through simulation. The framework is detailed in Section II, where the method and its assumptions are described, followed by an explanation of the trading process. Section III provides visual insights into the trading process using a sample network and discusses trends observed across 102 different network topologies. The paper concludes in Section IV by summarizing findings and highlighting areas for future research.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: To prepare for the emerging electric power market, this paper proposes an Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) system with bidirectional communication capabilities. This system allows utilities to operate cost-effectively and offer flexible pricing options as demanded by the market. By leveraging advanced communication media like GSM and GPRS, the AMI system can rapidly and accurately collect meter data. It can be integrated into existing billing and management systems, reducing labor costs and enhancing meter-reading accuracy. The system provides customers with statistical load usage and consumption profiles, helping them manage their energy consumption patterns. Additionally, it will offer real-time pricing information when available, making it a crucial component for the future deregulated utility industry.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text:
At the first communication level, the protocol used depends on the meter or device providing the data. Digital meters in power systems typically communicate using protocols designed in accordance with national regulations. For example, the DL/T645-1997 protocol was implemented on June 1, 1998. However, some meters use proprietary protocols, while other controllable devices operate with industrial protocols like MODBUS.
At the second communication level, both international and national protocols are utilized in power systems, such as IEC 60870-5-101 and Q/GDW 130-2005, which is specifically designed for load management systems. Additionally, some utilities establish their own remote data exchange protocols, meaning the choice of protocol varies based on utility requirements.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: Information security (InfoSec) is recognized as a primary concern by researchers in information and communication technology, prompting numerous studies to adopt improved techniques and technological artifacts, such as malware detectors, intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDPS), sophisticated firewall setups, and data encryption algorithms. While some studies suggest that InfoSec issues can be effectively managed by focusing on human behavior, others argue that this approach alone is insufficient. The sheer volume of information handled by organizations necessitates considerable automation to enhance security measures. Therefore, a balanced approach that integrates human factors, technology, and policy management is essential for effective organizational security activities. This balance is crucial for addressing the complexities of cybersecurity threats while ensuring robust protection of sensitive information across various platforms.

The rapid expansion of the Internet is fostering the emergence of a cyber society characterized by diverse communications, including the sharing of personal information and business transactions. However, this growth has also led to an increase in cyber threats, which now target a wide range of entities from individuals to private companies and critical infrastructures like nuclear power plants, with objectives that vary from financial gain to political motives. As a result, there is a pressing need for enhanced cybersecurity operations to mitigate these evolving threats. Cybersecurity measures are crucial in protecting sensitive data and maintaining trust in online interactions, especially as the cost of cybercrime is projected to rise significantly in the coming years. This underscores the importance of proactive strategies and international collaboration to ensure a secure digital environment for all users.

Despite the rise of mobile and internet-based voice communication, landline telephony remains a significant and cost-effective communication medium. Historically, landline phones have been used to control home appliances by dialing extra digits, as shown in previous work. An extension card connected to the telephone line interprets these digits, decodes them, and then controls the switching of electrical appliances, as illustrated in Figure 5.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: A load resource that can offer regulation service by adjusting consumption up or down under dispatch control (similar to AGC) and responds instantly to frequency changes (like generator governor action) is termed CLD in LaaR service. Under the current ERCOT market design, ERCOT sends generation control signals to Qualified Scheduling Entities (QSEs) based on real-time system area control error to keep the target system frequency stable. Each QSE then manages its individual unit output to meet these control requirements. ERCOT does not directly control individual unit outputs. This control logic applies not only to generators but also to loads, provided the load can adjust consumption in response to the control signal. Fig. 2 illustrates a real-world example of CLD response to a QSE dispatch signal, demonstrating that the tested CLD can precisely adjust its load consumption in line with the control signal. Thus, CLD offers a valuable opportunity for load entities to support system security by following AGC and governor control mechanisms.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

The ECC was introduced to establish a unified cybersecurity baseline that applies to all government entities, vital
sectors, and digital service providers. These controls are
carefully crafted to address a wide range of cyber risks and
vulnerabilities, ensuring that organizations can withstand and
respond effectively to cyber incidents
Journal Name:
Optimal Job Role Allocation for Compliance
With NCA-ECC Controls Using the Saudi
Cybersecurity Workforce Framework

Text: The Delphi processes conducted in this study establish a crucial foundation for developing educational cybersecurity assessment tools that provide a robust, evidence-based framework to guide educators on effective strategies for engaging, informing, educating, nurturing, and retaining cybersecurity students. Additionally, these processes help structure curricula to better prepare professionals for careers in the cybersecurity field. The numerical ratings derived from the expert assessments serve as a valuable resource for prioritizing key concepts and content when creating curricula, learning exercises, and other educational materials and policies. By identifying core concepts that are essential for both introductory courses and professional readiness, this research aims to enhance the overall quality of cybersecurity education and ensure that it meets the evolving demands of the industry.

We propose an asymmetric watermarking scheme that utilizes a reference watermark along with multiple embedding watermarks. These embedding watermarks are derived from the reference watermark and specific keys by applying phase shifts in the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) domain. While they remain correlated with each other, the correlation is controlled to prevent confusion with other keys.This design enables both asymmetric detection using the reference key and symmetric detection for key information extraction. Since the energy spectra of the reference and embedding watermarks are identical, the proposed method ensures a consistent asymmetric-to-symmetric detection statistic ratio in correlation tests using prewhitening filtering.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

standard bodies and governments to monitor the workforce
requirements constantly and to initiate framework developments. Moreover, these initiatives resulted in work role
frameworks and comprehensive reports on workforce needs.
Next, we present a review of the initiatives that are most
relevant to this work.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: Remark 1: In this approach, we use a magnifying-glass technique to transform the chaotic state variables, which serve as the key sequence before being XORed with the plaintext. If there is a small mismatch causing perturbations, the signal passing through the amplifier will be significantly amplified. Since the parameter is a large number, the signal is magnified many times, indicating that even a minor parameter mismatch will result in a substantial decryption error. This leads to a decryption key sequence that differs from the encryption key signal, preventing the recovery of the plaintext signal. Consequently, the security of the chaotic communication system is enhanced.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: Furthermore, we investigate the security of the proposed scheme. Two SLs having identical parameters as those of the legitimate SLs are used as the hypothetical attackers who listen in the broadcast channel and mutual exchange channel, respec tively. The two attackers are, respectively, locked to Laser3 and Laser1 by amplifying the corresponding channel signals. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the-factor values of the eavesdropped messages degrade quickly as the bit rate increases. Therefore, high security can be maintained by increasing the bit rate moderately. Moreover, we propose to use the message coded by Laser3 as an encryption/decryption key (EDK), to reduce the risk that the messages exchanged between the MCSLs are intercepted. In such a scheme, the messages transmitted be tween Laser1 and Laser2 are not the plaintexts to be exchanged, but the ciphertexts encrypted with the EDK, then, even though these ciphertexts are intercepted, the attacker cannot get useful information without the simultaneous knowledge of the EDK and the specified encryption operation. For an instance, as shown in Fig. 4(b), the original messages are encrypted with the EDK by an AND operation before being uploaded to the public channel, and recovered by a corresponding AND opera tion after the ciphertexts being decrypted at the receiver end. The attackers can eavesdrop the correct messages if and only if they simultaneously know the AND operation and the EDK transmitted from another channel.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: The Kc is assigned to each content unit and is multiplexed with the content as part of an ECM section, referred to as the Kc distribution ECM. The Kc is contained within a variable unit of this ECM, allowing flexible selection of the encryption algorithm and key length. Additionally, transmitting the DRMI along with the Kc enables advanced access control for stored content on a per-unit basis. The Kc distribution ECM includes a tampering-detection code within the encrypted area to prevent illegal interference with key information and other data. This system uses a detection code based on the SHA-1 hash function. The Kc distribution ECM can be transmitted with the encrypted content or separately for specific viewing times. The proposed DRM system is well-suited for content distribution in digital satellite and terrestrial broadcasting, as the Kc can be sent to multiple receivers using the Kc distribution ECM.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: This paper presents an innovative enhancement to the Facility Cybersecurity Framework (FCF) [3] tool suite through the introduction of the Network Defense Training Game (NDTG), which offers three key contributions: first, the development and demonstration of gamified cybersecurity training aimed at bolstering operational technology (OT) resilience in critical infrastructure facilities; second, the modeling of realistic industrial control system (ICS) cyberattack scenarios aligned with the NICE Framework workforce roles as established by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST); and third, the design and illustration of autonomous cyberattack mechanisms that dynamically adapt to player decisions, thereby fostering formative learning. The central research question guiding these advancements examines how gamification and adaptive attack simulations can effectively enhance cybersecurity preparedness and response strategies within critical infrastructure environments.

Cybersecurity plays a crucial role in fostering technological growth, enabling innovation, and maintaining competitive marketplaces that drive efficiency and economic prosperity. In our modern era, the goal is to simplify life through adaptable, affordable, and efficient technological advancements while ensuring trust in cybersecurity. Public trust has become a valuable commodity for companies and governments alike, as seen with tech giants like Amazon and Facebook, underscoring the critical importance of robust cybersecurity measures.

Standardization of instruction across the four sections was achieved through the utilization of a uniform textbook and core instructional content. Assignments and examinations were identical, and presentation materials were consistent, with exceptions as specified. The curriculum encompassed threats and countermeasures applicable to a range of nonspecific cybersecurity threats to systems and applications, in accordance with the CSEC framework. At key instructional moments, students were prompted to provide responses or propose remediations for programming code, firewalls, open ports, and related elements. Group projects and a group presentation were incorporated. Laboratory exercises involved the practical application of intrusion detection systems, threat modeling tools, network analyzers, infrastructure monitors, log analyzers, port scanners, penetration testers, and vulnerability scanners, as well as the development of cryptographic programs and the execution of static and dynamic code analyzers on student-generated code.

The rapid growth of the computer and information industry has led to the development of numerous new peripheral devices that can be connected to business computer terminals, particularly through USB ports. The USB port has become a standard feature in modern computer hardware due to its convenience and ease of use. Its primary advantage is providing a single interface for connecting a variety of devices to a computer, including hard disks, flash drives, printers, keyboards, and PDA devices.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: The system identified the fault at 67.28 miles from the station, with the maximum and minimum locations being 67.36 and 66.33 miles, respectively. Experience indicates that the actual fault is always within these calculated distances. The error in the fault distance estimate was 0.27%. The results also include the maximum RMS currents during the fault and the corresponding voltage for each monitored phase of the faulted transmission. Additionally, the system reports the impedance of the faulted line up to the fault location, including the line angle. The fault duration was estimated to be 97.76 milliseconds.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: An electronic dialing circuit connected to a home telephone can be triggered by an actuating signal from any type of detector circuit. When activated, this signal performs two functions: it operates a relay circuit to close the cradle for a predetermined time, allowing the dial tone to be received and dialing to commence, and it provides an enable signal to a sequential logic circuit that injects pulses corresponding to specific digits into the telephone lines. This facility is used to dial the resident's mobile number when a fire detector is activated. Upon detecting a fire, the circuit initiates a call to the resident's mobile, alerting them to the situation. The resident can then dial back to their home telephone using an additional digit, which triggers a relay circuit to operate a solenoid valve connected to a fire extinguisher. This allows the extinguisher to be activated electromechanically. The extinguisher is located at a chosen spot in the flat and can also be operated manually. If the resident is at home and receives the call, they can choose to extinguish the fire manually or by responding to the call.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: Random number generators (RNGs) that utilize white noise, such as thermal noise or shot noise from Si devices, are already available commercially [1]. While these can produce high-quality random numbers, their physical size is substantial because thermal noise is inherently weak, requiring significant amplification of the noise signal. This makes them unsuitable for mobile device integration. In comparison, RNGs using the dual-oscillator technique with minimal amplification have been developed [2], [3]. However, these random numbers retain bit-to-bit correlation, necessitating post-processing that results in unstable bit rates.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text:
Security systems incorporate closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras, acting as constant, discreet observers in locations such as city centers, underground and railway stations, banks, hospitals, and critical production facilities. These cameras continuously record and transmit real-time data within microseconds to law enforcement and security personnel stationed at monitoring centers.

Additionally, some systems restrict access to rooms or buildings by verifying fingerprints. If an individual's fingerprint is not found in the database of authorized users, entry is denied.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: The structure of this paper is as follows: Section II explores related research on cybersecurity education, while Section III outlines the cybersecurity skills framework used to establish best-practice curricula. Section IV analyzes existing Bachelor's and Master's programs in cybersecurity, and Section V details the methodology for developing new curricula, including best-practice models and a web application for curriculum design. Finally, the concluding section summarizes key insights and findings.

In 2019, Mouheb et al. performed a survey on the efforts that have been made on cybersecurity curriculum design [27]. Mouheb et al. showed the different approaches that are taken by the universities to design and update the curriculum. These approaches were categorized based on the main focus that the educational body has taken, i.e., educational, industrial, and defense. Therefore, the methods to design the curricula that were adopted by these universities were based on their internal strategies, and thus, these methods (and consequently the curriculum) may not be suitable for other universities.

It is important to highlight that protected transactions are also part of the specifications outlined by the Open Core Protocol International Partnership (OCP-IP) Association [34]. The standard OCP interface can be expanded through a layered profile, enabling the creation of a secure domain within the System-on-Chip (SoC). This domain enhances protection against software vulnerabilities and certain hardware attacks. Components such as the CPU, memory, and I/O can be safeguarded through a combination of hardware and software security measures, including secure interrupts, protected memory, and specialized instructions that allow access to the processor's secure mode.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Simulation has been a powerful tool allowing cybersecurity researchers to explore different scenarios of cyber phenomenon to analyze and assess cyber threats efficiently.
Due to the strengths of simulation, such as easy-to-construct
scenarios, reproducibility, and traceability, simulation techniques are widely used in academia and the industry for
evaluating the impact of cyber threats and the resiliency of

a weak link in various cyber environments. For example, it is
fairly inefficient in time and effort to deploy hundreds of real
hosts when finding out the most resilient network topology
and configurations against a DDoS attack. Instead, we can
attain the optimal topology and configurations by simply exploring various scenarios consisting of hundreds of host
and network models.

Cy-Through: Toward a Cybersecurity Simulation

Text: The proposed hard partitioning process simplifies complex constraint factor (CF) spaces into an ITDA space with three discrete scales: "desirable," "less determinative," and "undesirable." These scales reflect the impact on different constraints, as summarized in Table III. This approach allows for easy classification of individual DR characteristics for congestion management.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: The rapid expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) has brought significant benefits but also poses substantial cybersecurity challenges. As the number of connected devices grows, so does the potential for security attacks and malicious activities that can disrupt the global IoT network. Recent years have seen an exponential increase in IoT-related cybersecurity publications, reflecting a growing awareness of these issues. This paper undertakes a comprehensive literature review of relevant articles from five major academic databases?EEE Xplore, Web of Science, ACM Digital Library, INSPEC, and ScienceDirect?o assess the current landscape and future research directions in IoT cybersecurity. The review identifies various countermeasures and techniques employed across different industries while highlighting the ongoing challenges and opportunities for researchers and practitioners in this field. A total of 433 articles from IEEE Xplore published since 2013 were selected for analysis, revealing that cybersecurity is becoming an increasingly prominent topic within IoT research. Key challenges include a vast attack surface due to the proliferation of devices, weak authentication mechanisms, insufficient data encryption, and the lack of timely security updates. Addressing these vulnerabilities is crucial for ensuring the integrity and security of IoT systems as they continue to evolve and integrate into everyday life.

A Room Transfer Function (RTF) is measured by analyzing the correlation between an acoustic source signal and the received signal at a specific position. Selecting an appropriate source signal is crucial. Traditionally, impulse signals such as a gunshot have been used. However, in this study, we utilized white noise. The advantage of using white noise for sound measurement is its high repeatability and the ability to improve the signal-to-noise ratio through repeated measurements, compared to methods that use sound radiated into a room via a speaker.In an ideal environment, such as an anechoic chamber, no signals are received after the first peak value. However, due to the quality of the room environment, reflected signals are captured, leading to prolonged reverberation, as shown in Fig. 1.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text:
The knowledge of the location of a fault (transient or permanent) is beneficial to the proper operation of a power system.
Accurate location of a transmission line fault helps to shorten
repair time and consequently decreases the outage time of the
faulted line. Weak spots (such as weak and dirty insulators) that
often cause transient faults can be identified and eliminated.
Fault location is also valuable in the analysis of protective relaying schemes. It allows the zero sequence impedance, which
is difficult to calculate, to be accurately determined.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: The proposed attack relies on two key factors: the availability of multiple images with known digests and the use of the same secret mapping function for authentication. The creators of the SARI system may have anticipated such an attack, as they suggested including the mean value of DCT coefficients for each selected position across all blocks in the digest. However, this measure only partially mitigates the attack, making it more challenging but not impossible for an attacker to forge an image. To succeed, the attacker must now preserve both the DCT coefficient relationships and the mean values of the DCT coefficients after tampering with the image. While this adds complexity, it also increases the digest size without providing significant security benefits.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: To effectively reduce peak loads, interruptible load groups are divided into two categories. The first category, scheduled offline using Improved Dynamic Programming (IDP), is called ILGS. The second category, used to adjust IDP results through Hierarchical Intelligent Rule (HIR), is called ILGA. Optimal or near-optimal ILGS scheduling can be achieved through IDP. However, practical system load uncertainties affect the load reduction results from this schedule. Therefore, HIR is employed in real-time to adjust the schedule, enhancing its robustness against uncertainties.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: Over the past century, significant changes have occurred both "beneath the hood" and inside the vehicle cabin. These advancements have been driven by progress in electrical, electronics, and software technologies, as illustrated in Fig. 2. A brief overview of automotive history highlights the expanding role of these technologies in enabling vehicle-level features. Examples of such features are shown in the top part of the figure, with arrows indicating the approximate dates when these applications first appeared in the market.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: An experiment was conducted to examine how the presence of an intruder affects room transfer functions (RTFs). The intruder was positioned near Channel 1 (CH.1), with speaker intervals of 1 meter (Case 1) and an unspecified "50 ?" point (Case 2). The results, depicted in Figure 5, show the RTF changes at CH.1 and CH.2 (close to the intruder) and at CH.5 and CH.6 (further away). The metric used for analysis was the Spectral Centroid mean, which reflects the frequency distribution within the RTF. The reference RTF for CH.1 had a Spectral Centroid mean of 94.567. When the intruder was present, the Spectral Centroid mean for CH.1 dropped to 70.231 in Case 1 and 68.377 in Case 2, indicating a noticeable change in the room's acoustic response.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: In our third security measure, training program adoption, we found little difference between high and low computerized or ganizations, regarding actual implementation of a program. We did find, however, some differences regarding planned imple mentation ofsuchprograms.Surprisingly, wefindthatprimarily paper-based organizations were more likely to have plans for implementation of a training program. Many of the organiza tions examined were in a transition phase from paper to com puterized patient data systems.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: System dispatch with spinning reserve impacts deliverable energy and represents a steady-state cost. The cost of load shedding is primarily borne by customers and occurs only during emergencies when loads are disconnected. Conversely, reducing these costs can affect system reliability, leading to greater economic damage for generator companies and users. This impact depends on market regulator rules, interruption cost behavior, and commercial agreements.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

The microcontroller board includes a power-supply board, a microcontroller, and an industrial communication module, such as a GSM modem or a GPRS modem, as shown in Fig. 2. The power-supply board provides DC power to both the microcontroller and the communication module.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: Direct Load Control (DLC) has been widely used to reduce peak system loads. Techniques such as multipass dynamic programming and fuzzy logic-based demand control strategies have been proposed to optimize DLC. These methods aim to encourage customer participation by offering feasible solutions. However, implementing DLC can sometimes create a second peak load due to energy feedback when interrupted loads reconnect to the system, limiting the effectiveness of peak load reduction.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: We have demonstrated that the SARI image authentication scheme is vulnerable when the same key is used to authenticate even a small number of images. To address this issue, we propose a simple "salting" mechanism, similar to the one used in UNIX password authentication. By appending a salt to the image digest, an attacker would need an impractically large number of images authenticated with the same key to create counterfeit images. The salt's bit length can be adjusted based on the application to render the attack infeasible. Our proposed salting mechanism is straightforward, adds minimal overhead to the SARI digest, and is broadly applicable to various authentication techniques, helping to prevent attacks like the one described here and in [11].
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: A biometric cryptosystem able to provide security and re newability to a function based on-line signature representation is presented. A method for selecting the most reliable signature traits is also introduced. The proposed protected system guar antees performances comparable with those of unprotected sys tems, and far better than those offered by protection methods relying on parametric signature features.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: Providing practical cybersecurity training for both local and remote students presents significant challenges. Traditionally, a cybersecurity lab consists of machines equipped with relevant security tools and software, interconnected via an isolated network, either physically or through firewalls. However, replicating this setup across multiple university campuses for remote students is costly and difficult to manage. Coordinating, maintaining, and ensuring consistent learning experiences across campuses require scalable and efficient solutions, such as cloud-based labs, which can provide flexible, on-demand access to cybersecurity exercises without the logistical and financial burdens of traditional setups.

The Privacy Act of 1974 requires federal information systems to ensure the confidentiality of personally identifiable data [7]. However, these mandates offer limited guidance on the specific structures and functions needed at the organizational level to meet such requirements. Unlike many service industries, health-care organizations face increasingly severe penalties for failing to implement adequate security measures [8]–[10]. In health care, the consequences of noncompliance with security regulations are particularly high. While information models have been used to address organization-specific security issues, there has been little exploration of industry-wide or institutional trends. The rise of industry-wide regulations and penalties for noncompliance may provide a broader perspective, especially when regulatory or cross-market influences counteract behaviors within specific organizations. Additionally, there is limited research on how information technology impacts the clinical health-care environment. Historically, physicians have viewed information management as an administrative task, leading to limited expertise in this area despite the universal requirements imposed by HIPAA and the Privacy Act [11], [12].
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: One solution to reduce design complexity and the gap between advances in the development of manufacturing technology and those of synthesis and compiler technology has been foreseen in the reuse of previously developed Intellectual Propriety (IP), which will constitute the basic blocks for the designers. However, the design of this type of heterogeneous systems raises the problem of having tools for synthesis and compilation that could efficiently exploit the large number of resources available to designers.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

To achieve this, the impulsive intervals should be as small as possible. Therefore, the constant  is selected to be as large as possible. Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: A defining characteristic of reinforcement learning (RL) that sets it apart from other learning algorithms is the balance between exploration and exploitation. Essentially, an RL agent aims to maximize rewards while interacting with its environment, requiring it to exploit existing knowledge based on past experiences and obtained rewards. However, to discover potentially better actions that yield higher rewards in the future, the agent must also explore new possibilities. This challenge, known as the exploration-exploitation dilemma, is a fundamental aspect of RL, as it requires careful strategy to optimize long-term decision-making.

The goal of the problem is to maximize the expected social welfare value, with "expected" used in the conventional probabilistic sense and the expectation covering all contingencies and the pre-contingency state. We consider load as price-sensitive demand, and define social welfare as consumer benefit minus producer costs. The OPF objective function includes pre-contingency social welfare, each post-contingency state's social welfare, generator ramping costs, and load interruption costs (with [7] providing an example of an interruptible load market). Each post-contingency state's social welfare function is weighted by the probability of its associated contingency occurring. When formulating the expected value of the social welfare function, we make approximations regarding probabilities; we neglect terms involving products of independent contingency probabilities in the expected value function because these products are small enough.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: The assessment's second component consisted of a hands-on laboratory exercise requiring participants to conduct comprehensive scanning of systems, log files, routers, and firewalls to identify ten major vulnerabilities within a web application and implement appropriate remediation measures. This practical assessment carried a potential score of five hundred points, and while participants received T-shirts and coffee mugs as rewards for their performance, these scores were not incorporated into their academic grades. The overall evaluation structure divided points equally between case studies and laboratory work, with each component representing half of the total available points. In the subsequent data analysis, these performance scores served as the dependent variables when evaluating the effectiveness of different instructional approaches.

This study investigates the cybersecurity priorities for networked manufacturing systems by analyzing the distinct data protection needs of additive (layer-by-layer construction) and subtractive (material-removal) production technologies?oth widely used in aerospace, automotive, and medical sectors. While additive manufacturing enables complex geometries and design flexibility, it creates unique digital vulnerabilities in 3D model files and printer controls. Conversely, subtractive methods preserve material integrity for enhanced product durability but require safeguarding of precision toolpath data and CNC machine commands. The research evaluates how breaches of these technology-specific datasets impact business operations, proposing tailored defense strategies that address each method? cyber risks without compromising their complementary industrial advantages.

Harmonized standards delineate technical specifications for adherence to essential requirements within a designated European Union legal act. These standards are applicable across all EU member states, superseding any conflicting national standards [50]. The correct application of harmonized standards confers a presumption of conformity with legal requirements. Consequently, manufacturers and service providers, through the implementation of a harmonized standard, can demonstrate compliance with pertinent EU legislation. Only harmonized standards referenced and published in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJEU) [51] are recognized.

To fully realize the economic and efficiency advantages of Digital Manufacturing (DM), it is imperative to identify and secure vulnerable nodes within the supporting infrastructures. The following section delineates key components of our use-case Hybrid Manufacturing (HM) system and explores potential vulnerabilities within the DM context. The discussion of these identified HM vulnerabilities serves as a rationale for the development of a comprehensive taxonomy and corresponding solutions for DM vulnerabilities, which are addressed in the subsequent sections of this article

Research indicates that cyberattacks are becoming more frequent, with a growing body of literature offering instruments for assessing cyber risks. While the severity of these attacks appears to have plateaued, a single cyberattack is estimated to cost an average of $229,000, contributing to global cybercrime costs that may reach several hundreds of billions of dollars. Consequently, one-third of organizations are considering cyber insurance as a protective measure. However, this option may not be viable for social enterprises (SEs), which often face significant financial constraints. Additionally, financial compensation for cybercrime may not provide meaningful support for SEs, whose missions are typically socially driven rather than profit-oriented. SEs are evaluated not only on financial performance but also on their societal value, making it challenging to measure the total impact of cybercrime and therefore difficult to insure against these risks effectively. As SEs continue to grow in prominence and vulnerability, it is crucial to develop tailored strategies that address their unique challenges in cybersecurity.

Addressing a different aspect of security, we examine the levels of professional training reported across security programs (Table III). We found information systems training to be the most highly preferred, followed closely by health information management. There existed little difference across computeri zation levels regarding preferences for individuals possessing training in these areas. We did find a significant difference be tween high and low computer adopters regarding the use of physicians as security officers. As organizations migrated from paper-based to computer-based records, they were much less likely to have physicians oversee information security. Other wise, greater adoption of computer-based records did not result in greater use of systems-based security officers.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management
