Security awareness for emerging technologies is critical to
prevent cyberattacks. Information security in an open system
architecture, with respect to potential threats and goals (in terms
of confidentiality, integrity, availability, and accountability), is
a challenging task [33]. ISO/IEC 17779 recommends a list of
important controls on the information security management
system [34]. A virtual enterprise is one way to promote a
collaborative group of managing existing network enterprises
by coordinating, controlling, and communicating remotely to
the networks with different roles and user types [35]. Governments have responded by increasing national readiness as the
connectivity of control networks increases [4].
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Landline telephony has long been a primary medium for telecommunication. Despite the rise of cellular telephony and internet-based voice communication, landline networks remain popular due to their simplicity and cost-effectiveness for subscribers. Home automation controls can be issued via landline telephones by dialing additional digits to switch electrical appliances on or off. An extension card connected to the home telephone identifies and decodes these digits, then controls the switching of the appliances. The principle of this system is illustrated in Fig. 5.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: For future wind power investments in Thailand's electric power system, it is advisable to use the DFIG (Doubly Fed Induction Generator) type of wind farm. This is due to its minimal impact on system stability. Additionally, the capacity of the wind site should be capped at a level that ensures system security, as determined by impact studies, and this limit may vary depending on when the wind project is implemented.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: Our work builds on foundational studies by proposing a comprehensive model that integrates AI and blockchain for secure data sharing and transmission, known as the AICyber-Chain model. This model leverages blockchain? decentralized ledger to ensure data integrity while utilizing AI? analytical capabilities to dynamically enhance security measures. By combining these technologies, AICyber-Chain provides a multi-layered security strategy that addresses the vulnerabilities inherent in traditional centralized systems. The integration allows for real-time threat detection, automated responses through smart contracts, and a tamper-proof environment for sensitive data management. This innovative approach not only strengthens the overall cybersecurity framework but also promotes transparency and trust in data operations, making it a promising solution for modern digital security challenges.

In this paper, we present a key exchange protocol for secure communication between smart cards and STBs in DTV broadcasting, based on Schnorr’s digital signature protocol and a one-way hash function. The proposed protocol offers several advantages: enhanced security, dynamic session keys, mutual authentication, low computational and communication overhead, and user-friendly password management. Additionally, the scheme effectively addresses two major issues in DTV broadcasting: smart card cloning and McCormac Hack problems.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text:
Generally, the CAS operates in a three-level hierarchy for 
key distribution as follows[2][5][6][7]. The server chooses a 
random variable Control Word (CW) as the seed of a pseudo 
random generator (PRG). A pseudo random sequence 
generated by PRG can be used to scramble the transported 
stream (TS). At the same time, CW will be encrypted by 
authorization key (AK) to form Entitlement Control Message 
(ECM). And AK and other entitlement information will be 
encrypted together by Master Private Key (MPK) to form 
Entitlement Management Message (EMM). ECM, EMM and 
the scrambled TS stream will be multiplexed into a new TS 
stream and transferred to subscribers in the broadcasting 
channel. Here, the ECM and EMM should be transferred with 
their digital signature respectively in order to prevent the 
intruder from maliciously modifying. The Subscribers 
Management System (SMS) administrates the customers’ 
different access rights to protected services, e.g. to add or to 
remove the access rights to a protected service by generating 
the MPK to authorized subscriber or updating the MPK stored 
in the smartcard. In order to enhance the security of system, 
the CAS can frequently change the CWs or scramble the 
program with more complex symmetric encryption algorithm. 
For a typical CAS, CWs will be changed once per 5~20 
seconds[6], which will greatly reduce the risk of knownplaintext attacking
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: Practical experiences demonstrate the role and value of pumped storage units for FRR in isolated power systems, par ticularly the emergency conditions of a severe shortage of FRR. The pumped storage units are the most suitable for offering the FRR, which can be operated in generating mode with AGC to offer frequency regulation reserve or operated in pumping mode to offer emergency reserve. The comparative result of energy benefit showed that mode C is suitable for light load conditions (such as spring and winter) to reduce pumping energy costs and to offer emergency reserve, and mode D is suitable for heavy system load conditions (such as summer and autumn) to offer frequency regulation reserve. The actual operating experiences of pumped storage units provided in this paper can be used to evaluate the impact on the system security and to further define the role of pumped storage units in the ancillary services mar ket. After much verification, the Taiwan Power Company sys tem operation department confirmed the merits of the flexible dispatching schedules for pumped storage units, citing an im provement in power quality, a guarantee in system security and the value of pumped storage units for FRR in daily operation.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: The production cost of each power plant varies depending on factors such as its size, fuel type, location, and age. As energy demand rises throughout the day, the market clearing price increases until it aligns with the cost of the most expensive available supply. If a supply shortage occurs—whether genuine or artificially created—prices can skyrocket since consumers with inelastic demand must accept whatever price suppliers bid. During the 2000 California power crisis, the independent system operator (ISO) introduced price caps to curb market manipulation. However, energy prices quickly adjusted to these caps, creating a simple leader-follower dynamic without proper incentives. Additionally, the blackouts imposed by the California ISO unintentionally led to a form of retail price elasticity. Even under normal conditions, market manipulation can occur. For instance, an energy provider with multiple plants in a state could bid excessively high prices for one plant’s output to influence the overall market price at auction.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: Our analysis reveals inconsistencies in how healthcare organizations integrate information security personnel. While many institutions have developed systems for collecting and storing patient data, they have not necessarily established corresponding security teams, committees, or dedicated security managers. Overall, approximately 50% of hospital-based respondents reported having an information security officer, a significantly higher percentage compared to clinics (37%) and other practice settings (42%). Hospitals were found to be twice as likely as outpatient facilities to have designated security officers.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text:
With a single-sourcing approach, the single vendor is solely responsible for integrating
the organization?s IT systems [4]. The client organization?s all
IS maintenance and troubleshooting works are often outsourced
to the single vendor [4]. Client organizations do not need to retain
a large amount of expert in-house IT staff. The effective use of
IT systems in client organizations depends on a single vendor.
Furthermore, the client organization?s contract management is
less onerous [20], [21]. The scope and criticality of the single
vendor?s contracts are larger than those with multiple vendors.
Hence, the client organization?s operations, functionalities, and
implementation effectiveness highly rely on the single vendor,
creating high dependencies on the vendor [16].
Journal Name:
Information Systems Sourcing Strategies and
Organizational Cybersecurity Breaches

Text: The rapid advancement of Generative AI (GenAI) models like ChatGPT and Google Bard has marked a transformative shift in the digital landscape, bringing both unprecedented opportunities and significant cybersecurity challenges that demand careful examination?hile these tools demonstrate remarkable potential for enhancing defensive cybersecurity measures through automated threat detection, secure code generation, and improved incident response, they simultaneously introduce substantial risks as malicious actors exploit vulnerabilities through sophisticated attack vectors including jailbreak techniques, prompt injection attacks, and reverse psychology manipulations that bypass ethical safeguards, enabling the generation of sophisticated phishing campaigns, polymorphic malware, and automated hacking tools, necessitating urgent development of robust countermeasures, ethical frameworks, and regulatory guidelines to mitigate privacy violations, social engineering threats, and weaponization risks while harnessing GenAI's capabilities to strengthen cyber defenses, threat intelligence, and secure software development practices in an increasingly AI-driven security paradigm.

In Conditional Access Systems (CAS), security primarily relies on the scrambling algorithm and the key distribution scheme. CAS typically employs symmetric encryption algorithms to scramble program streams due to their high information rates and real-time requirements in DTV broadcasting. The frequent changes in private encryption keys, such as Control Words (CW), make attackers more likely to target the key distribution rather than the scrambling algorithm itself. Therefore, securely distributing descrambling keys to authorized subscribers is crucial for the success of CAS. This paper proposes a key distribution scheme based on a four-level key architecture and grouping access control. The proposed scheme is designed to be secure, reduce encryption computation, and is scalable to handle subscriber additions and removals. The paper is structured as follows: Section 2 reviews related work on key distribution for CAS, Section 3 details the proposed key distribution scheme, Section 4 compares it with other schemes and analyzes its security, and Section 5 presents the conclusions.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text:
We have presented a novel digital chaotic secure communication system by introducing a concept magnifying glass to enlarge observed errors due to parameter mismatch and an impulsive control strategy with piecewise-constant intervals to synchronize chaotic circuits. The proposed system is a combination
of a conventional cryptographic scheme and a chaotic secure
communication scheme. Our secure communication system is
shown to be very sensitive to parameter mismatch.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: One particular interesting scenario was observed in this December 22 event to explain the frequency is not universal in the system during disturbance. By observing the recorded operation data, as shown in Fig. 5, only part of LaaRs, which were equipped with faster breaker and close to the fault lo cation, tripped while system reach 59.7 Hz, and successfully catch the decay of the frequency. Therefore, other LaaRs with slow breaker operation time and away from the fault did not tripped by the high-set underfrequency relay. In order to recover the system frequency to the nominal setting point (60 Hz), operators manually dispatched this LaaRs to trip in 10 min to help the system frequency back to 60 Hz. Fig. 5 shows a very good example to prove the system frequency is not universal in the whole system during disturbance.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: Historically, power system engineers have relied heavily on maintenance crews to identify transmission line faults after protective relays have isolated the affected line. Additionally, many engineers have used and continue to use fault analysis programs to calculate the locations of shunt faults on transmission lines. While these methods are satisfactory in some cases, they can be time-consuming and complex. If faults are not quickly identified and corrected, the security, stability, and reliability of the power system may be compromised, impacting the utility's ability to provide high-quality, uninterrupted energy to customers. The advent of microprocessor-based technology for monitoring and protecting power systems has enabled the capture and storage of sufficient system data to analyze disturbances effectively. This technological advancement has prompted engineers to develop faster and more efficient methods for locating transmission line shunt faults.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: Cyber-physical systems (CPS), distinguished by their convergence of physical and cyber domains, hold transformative potential for critical infrastructure, albeit constrained by their vulnerability to cyberattacks that can precipitate widespread consequences across human, infrastructural, and environmental spheres; the inherent reliance on wireless communication for sensor-actuator data transmission amplifies the attack surface, necessitating a paradigm shift from traditional intrusion prevention to resilience-focused security strategies; specifically, the development of resilient CPS, capable of maintaining functionality amidst adversarial operations, has increasingly leveraged machine learning (ML) algorithms, however, the susceptibility of ML itself to adversarial manipulation necessitates the concurrent pursuit of resilient ML techniques for CPS security; this discourse provides a comprehensive overview of the interplay between ML-driven resilient CPS and resilient ML applications within CPS, culminating in the identification of emerging research trends and promising future directions, thereby furnishing readers with a thorough understanding of recent advancements in ML-based CPS security, the safeguarding of ML within CPS, and relevant countermeasures within this dynamic research domain.

Next, we analyze the synchronization of the two Chua? circuits, referred to as the driving system and the driven system in [7] and [14]. In an impulsive synchronization setup, the driving system follows equation (1), while the driven system operates according to equation (9).
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: When acquisition strategies prioritize task integration, the concurrent emphasis on human integration may obstruct the process and disrupt established organizational identity. Conversely, a primary focus on human integration can delay the realization of operational synergies [7]. Effective acquisition management necessitates a balanced approach between separation and coordination across diverse sectors. Separation enables individual units to retain a degree of autonomy for research and development of innovative concepts. Conversely, integration is essential to prevent process duplication and maintain an economically efficient organizational structure.

This paper aims to achieve two primary goals. Firstly, it seeks to develop a less restrictive condition for impulsive synchronization in Chua's circuit, allowing for a wider range of impulsive intervals and improving bandwidth efficiency. Secondly, it introduces the concept of a "magnifying glass" to enhance the parameter sensitivity of chaotic self-synchronization systems, thereby strengthening the security of chaotic-based cryptosystems. This magnifying glass technique amplifies and detects subtle parameter discrepancies, significantly increasing the system's sensitivity. By converting message signals into digital format, this system becomes versatile for various digital security applications, including text, image, and email transmissions. Audio transmission is used as a practical demonstration in this work.
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: Generation facilities designated as Reliability Must-Run (RMR) units are subject to must-run agreements, which impact tariff structures, dispatching schemes, and their opportunities to participate in competitive market processes. Inadequate selection of RMR units or incorrect RMR quantities can either compromise system security or impose financial burdens on the Independent System Operator (ISO) or generators. The proposed method in this paper determines the amount of generation capacity to be assigned as RMR, allowing RMR units to sell surplus capacity to the system. This approach provides the ISO with flexibility to define desired RMR units and quantities, ensuring system security while enabling Independent Power Producers (IPPs) to engage in market activities.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: The scenario titled "Quartet" was designed to simulate a fictitious operational technology (OT) network under siege by four distinct cyberattacks, requiring the player?cting as a facility manager?o defend the system through strategic network configuration and security policy implementation in a turn-based format. Within this simulation, the player is provided with a network architecture containing deliberate misconfigurations, such as inadequate segmentation, unauthorized devices, and absent firewalls, while facing an adaptive attacker programmed to execute a predefined sequence of attacks, thereby compelling the player to allocate limited resources toward the most critical defenses. Quartet serves as a training tool to evaluate players' ability to prioritize protective measures during an active cyber incident while fostering realistic awareness of potential security gaps. Future training scenarios will further educate facility operators and OT managers by demonstrating common network topologies that exemplify robust security practices.

Malware developers continuously evolve their techniques to evade detection, making Android malware identification increasingly challenging. To counter this, researchers have developed three primary detection methods: static, dynamic, and hybrid analysis. Static analysis examines an application's code without execution but struggles against code obfuscation techniques, while dynamic analysis identifies malware behavior during runtime. Hybrid methods combine both approaches for enhanced accuracy. Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models are now widely used for malware detection by analyzing Android Application Packages (APKs) and extracting relevant features. Similarly, vulnerability detection in software follows a two-stage process: training ML models on extracted features to identify security flaws and generating new features through code analysis.

The global demand for cybersecurity experts encouraged
standard bodies and governments to monitor the workforce
requirements constantly and to initiate framework developments. Moreover, these initiatives resulted in work role
frameworks and comprehensive reports on workforce needs.
Next, we present a review of the initiatives that are most
relevant to this work.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: The escalating intricacy of software and communication interfaces has rendered Internet of Things (IoT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) increasingly susceptible to diverse attack vectors, thereby amplifying the potential for cybersecurity breaches that can precipitate significant privacy and security compromises; consequently, the implementation of robust safety protocols and efficacious cybersecurity solutions is imperative to mitigate these threats, necessitating a systematic identification of common security risks inherent in IoT and CPS environments, particularly those where machine learning (ML) algorithms are predicated upon data acquired from such systems, thus underscoring the critical need for proactive security measures to safeguard these interconnected infrastructures.

This study proposes a blockchain-enhanced Cyber-Physical System (CPS) for securing Industrial Internet of Healthcare Things (IIoHT) applications, addressing both known and unknown malware threats through a novel dual-layer AI defense mechanism. The framework leverages supervised learning to identify labeled threats pre-execution, while employing reinforcement learning [15] to dynamically counter runtime attacks like passive/active intrusions that evade traditional detection. By integrating blockchain technology, the system ensures tamper-proof data transactions between healthcare providers, all while optimizing execution costs - a critical constraint in medical environments. This represents the first implementation of a cost-aware, blockchain-enabled CPS that combines static and dynamic AI defenses specifically tailored for IIoHT's unique security challenges, providing comprehensive protection against evolving healthcare cyberthreats from pre-deployment through runtime operation.

Various fire-detection techniques exist, including temperature sampling, relative humidity monitoring, smoke analysis, and ultraviolet and infrared detection. A video-based fire-alarming method is proposed in, but it is too costly for use in home security systems. In this system, each fire alarm node uses a temperature sensor to monitor environmental temperature and an infrared receiver to detect heat and flames. If the temperature or infrared levels exceed predefined thresholds, the node triggers an alarm signal. As illustrated in Figure 12, the design of the fire alarm node is straightforward, cost-effective, and well-suited for home use.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: The paper conducts a mapping study of safety and cybersecurity assessment techniques utilized in critical industries, including nuclear power plants, oil and gas, autonomous vehicles, and railways, with a specific focus on instrumentation and control systems (I&C). Given the complexity of modern I&Cs, which consist of thousands of components, ensuring their reliability and safety in critical applications poses significant challenges. The integration of Industry 4.0 technologies has further complicated this landscape by making these systems more interconnected with public networks and the Internet, thus introducing new cybersecurity and safety challenges. The study outlines research questions and analyzes data from 320 records collected between 2018 and 2022, ultimately narrowing down to 49 relevant papers after applying eligibility criteria. The analysis reveals that while many techniques are not novel and have been in use for decades, there are emerging trends in the field, particularly the development of unified safety and cybersecurity assessment techniques, which represent a promising area for future research.

Direct load control (DLC) has been commonly used in recent years to help reduce peak system load [4]–[6]. A multipass dynamic programming approach [4] has been suggested for implementing DLC, as it allows for quick convergence to a near-optimal solution. To encourage customer participation in DLC, a fuzzy logic-based demand control strategy [5] has been introduced for the periodic regulation of electrical water heaters and air conditioners, ensuring a feasible solution. Additionally, fuzzy dynamic programming [6] has been developed to achieve near-optimal results in DLC. Periodic on/off control of interruptible air-conditioning loads has been proposed in studies [7]–[9] as another method of implementing DLC. However, one challenge with DLC is the possibility of creating a secondary peak load. This occurs due to energy feedback when air-conditioning loads reconnect to the system, which in turn limits the effectiveness of the peak load reduction achieved through DLC.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: Future improvements could include developing alternative metrics for selecting the most reliable signature traits that have less impact on the entropy of the binary representation while providing stronger resistance to privacy attacks. Additionally, exploring different functions to represent captured online signatures could further enhance the system.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: Comparative test data from our experiment, shown in Figure 4, reveals the background vibration detected by our new position sensor within our research laboratory. During the tests, our 'hybrid SM-3' sensor was securely attached to the tiled floor of our second-floor experimental room. The data indicates a background vibration frequency of approximately 400 Hz, corresponding to a floor vibration amplitude of 40 nanometers [3]. Furthermore, Figure 4(a) demonstrates a significant difference in background vibration levels between weekdays and weekends/nights. Weekday vibrations are nearly four times higher. However, even the nighttime vibrations are still 50 to 100 times greater than the noise level of our test oscillator, which is around 1 to 2 Hz, as shown in Figure 4(b).
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: This paper presents a biometric cryptosystem that ensures security and renewability for function-based online signature representations. It also introduces a method for selecting the most reliable signature traits. The proposed system delivers performance comparable to unprotected systems and significantly better than protection methods relying on parametric signature features.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: Notifying users in real-time when alarm incidents occur has become a critical feature of home security systems. This can be achieved via the internet or GSM/GPRS, with GSM/GPRS being more convenient due to its widespread coverage, ensuring the system is almost always available. Additionally, the GSM/GPRS network has a high-security infrastructure that ensures the information sent or received cannot be monitored [8]. The networks mentioned in [3], [5], [6], and [7] send information to remote users via the internet. Examples [8] and [9] use the GSM/GPRS network for remote control of home systems. However, [8] only demonstrates GSM as a communication method between the remote user and the home network server without applying it to home security systems. The system in [9] uses GSM/GPRS technology for intrusion detection, but its communication is non-wireless.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text:
At the receiver end, the demultiplexer extracts the different PESs from the scrambled TS and filters out the control data (ECM and EMM). The EMM, verified by a legal signature, can be decrypted using the MPK in the legal smartcard to obtain the AK. The AK is then used to decrypt the ECM, also verified by a legal signature, to retrieve the CWs. These CWs are input into the same PRG as the server's to generate the same pseudo-random sequence, which is used to descramble the TS in sync with the synchronization signal from the server end.
The smartcard, inserted into the user's receiver, stores authorization data (such as the MPK) needed for decrypting control data. The MPK is initially written to the smartcard by the service providers who deliver the smartcard. Service providers can also refresh the smartcard's MPK online.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: The diverse sensors integrated into IoT and CPS devices?ncluding critical components like GPS, LiDAR, and IMU systems?ntroduce significant vulnerabilities, as adversaries can manipulate sensor data to disrupt operations or create hazardous safety conditions. By compromising these sensors, attackers can feed false signals (e.g., spoofed GPS coordinates or altered LiDAR measurements), leading to erroneous decision-making in autonomous systems, industrial controls, or smart infrastructure, thereby escalating risks of operational failures, accidents, or large-scale cyber-physical breaches. This underscores the urgent need for sensor-specific security measures, such as data integrity verification, anomaly detection algorithms, and tamper-resistant hardware designs, to mitigate exploitation risks in sensitive applications.

With increasing energy demands, Distributed Resources (DR's)—including distributed generation and energy storage devices—are becoming more prevalent throughout distribution and sub-transmission systems to provide load services. Projections indicate that DR's will account for 25% of load growth in North America over the next decade. In electricity markets, DR's typically operate independently from Independent System Operators (ISO) and DIStribution COmpanies (DISCO). Consequently, ISO's may lack comprehensive information about individual DR devices.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: Hybrid manufacturing tools commonly integrate both additive and subtractive manufacturing capabilities on a single platform [4], enabling process chains traditionally distributed across multiple machines (potentially located at different facilities) to be executed within one system. This consolidation proves particularly advantageous for custom component fabrication, delivering benefits in reduced setup times, lower material costs, and decreased handling errors. Industries increasingly consider hybrid manufacturing systems for remanufacturing and repairing high-value components, as well as for producing parts requiring complex process sequences. For offshore oil extraction pipe casings with critical surface features like fins and spiral coatings, implementing hybrid manufacturing demonstrated approximately 97.2% reduction in material costs alongside decreased tooling expenses [5]. Additional applications include customizing medical implants by milling the implant-abutment interface before printing patient-specific abutments [6], creating innovative injection molds with enhanced cooling performance compared to traditional fabrication methods [7], enabling surface patching for mold and die repair operations [8], and facilitating turbine blade restoration [9].

Vulnerable nodes in the supporting infrastructures must
be identified and secured to realize the economic and
efficiency benefits of DM. In the following, we describe
key components of our use-case HM and the possible
vulnerabilities in the context of DM. The discussion on the
identified vulnerabilities of the HM serves as a motivation
for the development of taxonomy and the solutions to the
vulnerabilities for DM in the rest of this article.
Journal Name:
A Survey of Cybersecurity of
Digital Manufacturing

Text: This paper aims to systematically review existing studies on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques for combating cyber-attacks, addressing the need for increasingly intelligent, flexible, and robust cyber defense mechanisms. As organizations face a growing array of sophisticated cyber threats, the adoption of AI technologies is becoming essential for effective monitoring and response. While some studies have summarized issues impacting cybersecurity, none have focused specifically on AI applications in a systematic manner. This review will explore various AI methods utilized in cybersecurity, highlighting their effectiveness in detecting and mitigating threats while also addressing challenges such as resource demands and vulnerabilities to adversarial attacks. By synthesizing current literature, this research seeks to provide insights into the state-of-the-art in AI applications for cybersecurity and inform future research directions in this critical area.

A simple wire loop of the same size as the Balise was then
used to simulate jamming. This loop was fed by a function
generator whose signal was first amplified. With this setup,

Continuous Wave (CW), i.e., a single frequency tone (see

Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Considerations for Communication
Based Train Control

Text: The feasibility study evaluates how the addition of new generation capacity impacts system performance under both normal and contingency scenarios. Contingency analysis examines the effects of new generation on transmission facility loading and bus voltage stability during outages affecting transmission lines, autotransformers, and generators. This study was conducted using the most recent Southwest Power Pool 2005 summer peak base case.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: A bilateral market structure offers several benefits. By allowing direct price negotiations between customers and suppliers, it ensures a fair allocation of payments for each customer. Additionally, it enhances competition in the ancillary services market, thereby mitigating supply shortages in load-following services. Generators engaged in bilateral contracts receive fair compensation for their contributions, which may encourage participation in the load-following market. Furthermore, competition increases as generators gain the ability to enter into bilateral contracts beyond their control areas, as discussed in the previous section. Achieving this, however, requires a robust communication network between different control areas.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: The escalating threat posed by large-scale phishing incursions has prompted a heightened focus on the analytical dissection of phishing kits, necessitating the establishment of robust datasets; however, the generation of such datasets presents considerable obstacles, with researchers often relying on established phishing repositories that, while providing kit samples, lack contextual linkage to actual attack deployments, thus compelling researchers to synthesize phishing websites from these samples, a practice that introduces potential bias and restricts the scope of evaluation, as the methodological choices inherent in sample collection and website creation can significantly influence the data's representativeness and consequently, the validity of subsequent analytical findings.

A vast number of contingency scenarios could significantly impact the system; however, the likelihood of most rare but severe events remains relatively low. To keep the complexity of the Special Protection System (SPS) manageable, it is essential to identify the most credible situations. This letter introduces a framework for selecting contingency cases in the design of a transient stability SPS. The approach considers both the uncertainty of event occurrence and its potential consequences, combining them into a risk index to guide contingency selection.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: The Network Defense Training Game (NDTG) enhances the Facility Cybersecurity Framework (FCF) tool suite by integrating gamified cybersecurity training tailored for operational technology (OT) resilience in critical infrastructure. This innovation addresses three key contributions: (1) deploying gamification to improve OT-specific threat response through scenario-based learning, (2) modeling industrial control system (ICS) cyberattacks using NIST? NICE Framework workforce roles to align training with real-world protocols, and (3) implementing adaptive, autonomous cyberattacks that dynamically adjust to player decisions, fostering formative skill development. The primary research question evaluates how these features collectively strengthen OT cybersecurity preparedness by bridging theoretical frameworks like FCF? maturity models and NIST CSF guidelines with hands-on, experiential learning. By simulating attacks such as ransomware or supply chain compromises?ommon threats to critical infrastructure?DTG complements FCF? existing self-assessment tools (e.g., FCF-Primer, IoT security controls) while addressing human-factor vulnerabilities through iterative training. This approach aligns with FCF? core functions (Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover), enabling facilities to progress toward higher maturity levels while adhering to federal directives like EO 13636 and the IoT Cybersecurity Improvement Act.

To demonstrate the proposed system's sensitivity, we analyzed its performance under parameter mismatches in Chua's circuit. Specifically, we examined scenarios where , , and m0 in the receiver had a 1% deviation. Figure 2 illustrates the resulting key sequence errors between the encrypter and decrypter. The error signals exhibited instability, indicating that the key sequences in the two systems diverged significantly. Consequently, the original speech signal could not be accurately reconstructed from the incorrect reflection coefficients and the residual signal in the receiver.
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: We aim for the proposed system to effectively prevent the loss of confidential files via USB removable storage devices. In our protocol design, file transfer through the USB interface is blocked unless the user successfully completes the remote server authentication process. All files transmitted to the storage device are encrypted with a key \( K \). Therefore, to access the original file on another computer, users must undergo the same verification process and obtain the same key \( K \) for decryption. The key \( K \) is generated based on the user ID and the filename \( Fn \), ensuring that different files or users produce unique keys.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

The Kc is assigned per content unit and is multiplexed with
the content as an ECM section (hereafter referred to as the Kc
distribution ECM). The Kc is held within a variable unit of the
Kc distribution ECM. Thus, the encryption algorithm and its
key length can be selected flexibly. Furthermore, sending out
the DRMI together with the Kc enables advanced access control
of stored content per content unit. In the Kc distribution ECM,
a tampering-detection code is contained within the encryption
area, thus preventing illegal interference with the key information and other data. This system adopts a detection code based
on the Hash function (SHA-1). The Kc distribution ECM can
be transmitted along with the encrypted content or can be transmitted separately for certain viewing time only. The proposed
DRM system is also suitable for content distribution in digital

to multiple receivers using the Kc distribution ECM
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: To avoid this problem, a layered neural network scheme has been proposed for password authentication [9]. According to [9], a desired binary integer vector (e.g., [0, 0,1,1]) is assigned to each user. A set of desired integer vectors along with the corresponding user IDs with encrypted passwords are used to train the layered neural network. After the training, only the weights of the neural network are stored online as reference for authentication. During the authentication process, the system retrieves the weights for the neural network, applies the user’s ID and encrypted password as the input for the neural network, and verifies that the generated output is the desired binary integer.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: In this section, we apply the stability results from Section II to design impulsive control for a class of nonlinear systems. We begin by presenting a formal definition of impulsive control, which is a slight modification of the definition in [6].Definition 4: Consider a plant ?? Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: The escalating digitization of societal infrastructure and the expanding spectrum of cyberattack targets have precipitated a substantial demand for cybersecurity professionals across industrial and institutional sectors, yet a persistent deficit in qualified experts and a misalignment between educational curricula and professional skill requirements remain prevalent; this study employs a political, economic, social, technological, legal, and environmental (PESTLE) analysis to examine the determinants influencing cybersecurity education within the European context, enabling the categorization and national- and European-level assessment of factors impacting cybersecurity skills development; the interconnectivity of these factors is explored through the lens of modularity from social network analysis, and the findings are validated via a European-level stakeholder survey; the analysis reveals a critical deficiency in societal cybersecurity awareness and the absence of standardized EU-level certification as significant impediments to effective education; furthermore, notable disparities in perceived factor influence across countries underscore the necessity for localized solutions to address the cybersecurity skills gap.

An electronic dialing circuit connected to a home telephone can be triggered by an actuating signal from any type of detector circuit [9]. This actuating signal performs two functions: (i) it activates a relay circuit to close the cradle for a predetermined time to receive a dial tone and initiate dialing, and (ii) it sends an enable signal to a sequential logic circuit that injects a series of pulses corresponding to the chosen digits into the telephone lines. 
We utilize this capability to dial the resident's mobile number whenever a fire detector is activated. Upon detecting a fire, the circuit initiates a call to the resident's mobile, alerting them with a ring. The resident immediately recognizes the call is from home and understands there is a fire. They can then dial back to the home telephone with an additional digit, as described in Section II.B, where the telephone has a relay board extension to control selected appliances. Receiving the additional digit at the home telephone triggers a relay circuit to operate a solenoid valve, which activates a fire extinguisher electromechanically. The fire extinguisher is positioned at a chosen location inside the flat and can also be operated manually. If the resident is at home and receives the call on their mobile, they can choose to extinguish the fire manually or by making a return call.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: The Delphi processes discussed are part of a broader initiative called educational Cybersecurity Assessment Tools (CATS), aimed at creating a Cybersecurity Concept Inventory (CCI) and a Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment (CCA). The CCI is designed for students completing their initial cybersecurity course, focusing on foundational knowledge, while the CCA targets graduating college students entering the cybersecurity workforce, emphasizing advanced skills and competencies. To meet these distinct educational levels, the project concurrently conducted two separate Delphi processes: one for CCI and another for CCA. The Cybersecurity Concept Inventory focuses on assessing the core concepts that students should understand after an introductory course, such as network security, cryptography, and risk management. The Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment, on the other hand, is geared towards evaluating the knowledge and skills acquired by graduating students preparing for careers in the field, covering topics like incident response, security architecture, and ethical hacking. Through this dual approach, the CATS project aims to establish a comprehensive framework for cybersecurity education and assessment, ensuring that students are well-prepared for both initial learning and professional practice.

Security systems often include closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras, which act as constant, hidden observers in locations such as city centers, underground and railway stations, banks, hospitals, and critical production plants. These cameras continuously record and transmit information about current events to law enforcement and security posts in real-time. Additionally, some systems restrict access to rooms or buildings by verifying fingerprints against a database of authorized individuals, denying entry if the fingerprint is not recognized.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: This section demonstrates the feasibility of a market based on bilateral contracts. The key concept involves implementing a form of "local supplementary control" on each generator participating in the bilateral market. When specific technical requirements (which will be detailed later) are met, each generator will operate with a closed loop load following controller.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: This paper introduces an asymmetric watermarking method that employs a single reference watermark and multiple derived embedding watermarks. These embedding watermarks are created by applying phase shifts in the Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) domain to the reference watermark, using specific keys. While these watermarks are correlated, the correlation is not strong enough to confuse them with other keys, enabling both asymmetric detection (using the reference watermark) and symmetric detection (to extract key information). Because the reference and embedding watermarks share identical energy spectra, the method ensures a consistent ratio between asymmetric and symmetric detection statistics during correlation tests using prewhitening filtering.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Analog transmission in DDF systems is inherently sensitive to channel noise, which amplifies synchronization errors. While complex nonlinear functions increase chaos dimensionality, they also heighten noise susceptibility. Future improvements will focus on digital transmission methods to mitigate these synchronization challenges and reduce error rates.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: After losing an online generator, maintaining system frequency without load shedding is essential. A method has been proposed to determine spinning reserve requirements based on the recovery frequency one minute after losing the largest unit. For isolated systems, a set amount of FRR must be available within a specific time margin to protect against sudden generator loss, unexpected load changes, or other disturbances. This time margin varies by utility, with the TPS requiring a 60-second response.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: The "Quartet" scenario, a simulation designed to replicate a multi-faceted cyberattack on a hypothetical Operational Technology (OT) network, positions the player as a facility manager tasked with network defense against adaptive adversaries, achieved through physical network configuration and security policy implementation within a turn-based framework. This simulation presents a network architecture replete with vulnerabilities, such as segmentation errors, unauthorized devices, and absent firewalls, against which a pre-programmed attacker executes a sequence of cyberattacks, compelling the player to strategically allocate resources for targeted defenses. The primary objective of Quartet is to evaluate and enhance the player's ability to identify and deploy protective measures during an active cyber incident, thereby fostering a realistic understanding of potential security breaches, with subsequent training scenarios intending to educate OT network managers on the importance of implementing robust security practices through illustrative examples.

DBD-Guardian and Privacy-Aware Near

Text: In this section, we propose a key exchange protocol with mutual authentication based on Schnorr’s signature and a one-way hash function for secure communication between the STB and the smart card. The protocol is divided into five phases: registration, login, mutual authentication, key agreement, and CW transmission. The secure communication process between the STB and the smart card is illustrated in Figure 3.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

meets those needs. We have also proposed a method for multiplexing scramble keys synchronously with the video packet of

Text: Each IoT and CPS device acts as a potential entry point for attackers, expanding the network's attack surface and enabling system-wide breaches if endpoints are compromised. Communication protocols like WiFi, Bluetooth, and GSM?espite enabling essential sensor connectivity?ften contain exploitable vulnerabilities that attackers leverage to infiltrate networks, manipulate data flows, or hijack control of interconnected systems. These inherent weaknesses underscore the need for stringent protocol hardening, continuous vulnerability patching, and intrusion-resistant authentication mechanisms to mitigate risks in increasingly interconnected environments.

To deter eavesdroppers, authorized users dynamically adjust the phase within the external cavity to maintain synchronization, making it significantly harder for adversaries to achieve synchronization. However, one might argue that the eavesdropper could detect phase variations at the transmitter’s side, as their receiver would alternate between synchronized and de-synchronized states based on relative phase values. The following analysis demonstrates that this is not feasible for rapid phase variations.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: The South Bangkok power plant is required to maintain a minimum reserve of 565.88 MW and 273.89 Mvar, as determined by a Reliability Must-Run (RMR) study, to ensure system stability. Failing to meet this requirement at this specific location could cause transmission system overloads and potential security breaches. To participate effectively in the competitive energy market, the plant should optimize its internal generation and sell any excess capacity beyond the RMR requirement.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: Blockchain technology has been widely explored for secure data sharing across various domains. Xu et al. proposed a blockchain-based framework for healthcare, ensuring data integrity and traceability. Similarly, Schlatt et al. developed a decentralized data-sharing platform addressing ownership and privacy concerns. In AI, secure data sharing is crucial for training robust models. Montasari introduced federated learning, enabling AI models to train on distributed data without exposing raw data, thus preserving privacy while ensuring collaborative learning across multiple parties.

We have identified the requirements for protecting content rights in DBHS and developed a DRM system that fulfills these needs. Additionally, we proposed a method for synchronously multiplexing scramble keys with MPEG-2 TS video packets and verified that trick-play functions perform at the same level as with non-encrypted content. Our innovative DRM system allows seamless viewing during live broadcasts while enabling controlled access to stored content. This system is also well-suited for broadcasting, facilitating one-to-many content transmission.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Cybersecurity training labs in the literature primarily adopt traditional physical setups?nterconnected machines, network devices, and security appliances like firewalls/IDS [1][5][32]?hich offer hands-on hardware experience but suffer from high overhead costs for configuration, maintenance, and scaling. While some solutions enable remote access to physical labs (e.g., [62]? tool for allocating/managing devices), these retain the core inefficiencies of hardware dependency (Section 5), making cloud-based alternatives superior for flexibility and cost-effectiveness.

Text: The load shedding scheme incurs costs for customers, which depend on outage costs and the generator's forced outage rate. User outage costs can be approximately defined based on the power disconnected or damage function. The system failure rate is crucial in determining this cost, as each instance of load shedding results in an interruption cost. Power interruption costs ($/MW) are generally more representative for this estimation than nonsupplied energy costs ($/MWh).
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: The smart grid structure is susceptible to four main categories of attacks: physical-based (e.g., damage to hardware), cyber-based (e.g., software or firmware modifications), communication-based (e.g., disruption of physical links), and network-based (e.g., Denial of Service). Table 2 provides a detailed classification of these attack types, outlining their impact on security aspects such as integrity, confidentiality, and availability. Among these threats, False Data Injection Attacks (FDIA) are particularly concerning, as they span all categories. At the physical layer, FDIA involves manipulating device inputs, while at the cyber layer, it entails falsifying application-level data without altering the code. Additionally, GPS data injection serves as a communication-layer attack scenario, and network packet manipulation is another form of FDIA, highlighting its pervasive risk to smart grid security.

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system, we examine its sensitivity to parameter mismatches in Chua’s circuit. Specifically, we investigate cases where \( \alpha \), \( \beta \), and \( m_0 \) each have a 1% mismatch in the receiver. Figure 2 displays the key sequence errors between the encrypter and the decrypter. It is evident that the error signals are unstable, meaning the key sequences in the encrypter and the decrypter are entirely different. Consequently, the original speech signal cannot be recovered from the incorrect reflection coefficients and the residual signal in the receiver.
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: During an acquisition, balancing task and human integration is crucial. Prioritizing task integration may disrupt organizational identity if human factors are overlooked, while focusing too much on human integration can delay operational synergies. Different sectors require a balance between separation and coordination?eparation fosters autonomy for innovation, while integration prevents redundancy and ensures cost-effectiveness.

Up to now, many algorithms for motion estimation have been 
presented [3]. Among published algorithms, most common and basic 
algorithms of the motion detection are basically successive image 
comparisons, where lots of image data has to be stored and moved 
around between circuit blocks. The above mentioned data storage 
and transfer will cause large amount of power consumptions. In 
addition, the hardware blocks are complicated, which cause high cost. 
For portable security applications, the low power motion detection 
is the most important and the simple architecture will lower the cost 
of the system as well. An efficient motion detection algorithm 
without sacrificing the detection accuracy is proposed, where only 
one thousandth or less of the image data compared to the 
conventional methods are used. The proposed method does not have 
to move around the large amounts of image data between blocks, and 
can use the conventional CMOS image sensors with some little 
modifications
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: The rapid evolution of Generative AI (GenAI) models, such as ChatGPT and Google Bard, has transformed the cybersecurity landscape, presenting both opportunities and risks. These tools have demonstrated their potential in enhancing cyber defense through automation, threat intelligence, secure code generation, and malware detection, but they have also been exploited by malicious actors for offensive purposes. Techniques like jailbreaks, prompt injection attacks, and reverse psychology have been used to bypass ethical constraints of GenAI models, enabling adversaries to exfiltrate sensitive information or generate attack payloads. Additionally, GenAI tools have facilitated cybercriminal activities such as phishing attacks, social engineering, automated hacking, and the creation of polymorphic malware that can evade detection. While these advancements offer significant benefits for cybersecurity professionals, they also raise ethical, social, and legal concerns regarding misuse. This paper underscores the importance of addressing these challenges by developing robust defenses against GenAI-driven threats while ensuring its safe and ethical deployment in cybersecurity applications.

Text: Over the past decade, the system has experienced significant growth due to the initiation of several mining projects. This expansion included the introduction of conventional coal-based thermal units and new combined cycle plants, which were installed following a natural gas agreement with Argentina. However, the substantial size of these new units relative to the overall system has led to operational challenges during their testing phase. Specifically, forced outages resulted in considerable frequency drops, prompting low-frequency relays to shed a substantial portion of the load.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: Several studies have explored the use of blockchain technology for secure data sharing. Xu et al. proposed a blockchain-based framework for secure and transparent data sharing in healthcare, ensuring data integrity and traceability, which are critical for sensitive health data. Similarly, Schlatt et al. developed a decentralized data sharing platform using blockchain to address issues of data ownership and privacy. In the realm of AI, secure data sharing is crucial for training robust models; Montasari introduced federated learning as a method to enable secure data sharing across multiple parties without exposing raw data. This technique allows AI models to be trained on distributed data while preserving data privacy, highlighting the complementary roles of blockchain and AI in enhancing security and efficiency in data management.

Due to technological changes over the last decade, protocols
have been refined to become more flexible in their interoperability and maintainability, specifically in an open architecture
with high-speed communications [12], [18]. The evolution of
SCADA systems has also raised concerns about cyber-related
vulnerabilities [2], [13]. In addition, interdependences among
computers, communication, and power infrastructures have increased the risks due to complexity of the integrated infrastructures [19]. Although the complex infrastructure provides great
capabilities for operation, control, business, and analysis, it
also increases security risks due to cyber-related vulnerabilities.
Technological advances can help to reduce the deficiencies of
current power and communication systems [20].
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Cybersecurity is fundamentally focused on ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and systems. This goal is achieved through the implementation of controls, policies, processes, and organizational frameworks aimed at systematically mitigating cyber risks. As cybersecurity challenges continue to evolve, the adoption of best practices, facilitated by security standards, plays a crucial role. These standards function as regulatory frameworks that define operational guidelines for organizations, and their adoption is driven by their proven effectiveness in establishing structured security requirements and controls. The widespread implementation of these standards justifies the investment of time and resources, with manufacturers and vendors increasingly aligning their products and services to meet compliance requirements. Additionally, governments and businesses are mandating adherence to these security frameworks. A 2022 Gartner, Inc. report highlights a substantial increase in security vendor consolidation, with 75% of organizations actively pursuing it, up from 29% in 2020. The need for secure integration and interoperability of ICT systems through standardized technical frameworks is becoming increasingly critical, especially in open markets where businesses rely on diverse equipment and services from multiple providers to optimize costs. The rapid expansion of IoT devices, cyber-physical systems, and AI-driven embedded technologies?uch as autonomous vehicles and digital twins?urther reinforces the necessity of security standardization. Cloud computing also depends on standardized hardware, software, and services to ensure interoperability, though its growing adoption introduces new cybersecurity threats. In response, more organizations are actively contributing to the development of cybersecurity standards, leading to a steady increase in established security frameworks. This trend is expected to persist, driving the continued evolution of security regulations to address emerging technological challenges.
Journal Name: Chatgpt

Text: The proposed method involves an independent entity, the Market Monitoring Board (MMB), that would proactively assess market competitiveness. This entity would calculate and distribute Market Conduct Factors (MCFs) to market participants. These MCFs would establish limits on market behavior to prevent manipulation and ensure the reliability and security of the power system.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: In the evolving landscape of critical infrastructure security, the increasing sophistication of cyber threats presents significant challenges, particularly for the power grid's new technology infrastructure. Power transformers, once considered passive components, are now enhanced with smart technologies and intelligent monitoring systems that improve asset management but also elevate their vulnerability to cyber threats. While existing literature primarily addresses the cybersecurity of smart grids using model-based detection methods, there is a notable gap in research specifically focusing on the cybersecurity challenges faced by critical power components like transformers. This paper aims to fill that gap by examining the cybersecurity issues associated with smart transformers, introducing a comprehensive architecture and taxonomy of cyber-physical attacks relevant to these devices. We analyze the topology of smart transformers to identify vulnerable components and illustrate the potential consequences of cybersecurity breaches. Additionally, we discuss future cybersecurity challenges that may arise for smart transformers, emphasizing the need for advanced cybersecurity measures in online condition monitoring systems to protect against evolving threats and enhance the resilience of power grids.

The paper presents a mapping study of safety and cybersecurity assessment techniques
used in critical industries such as nuclear power plants, the oil and gas sector, autonomous vehicles,
railways, etc., with particular emphasis on instrumentation and control systems (I&C). Modern I&Cs are
complex electronic systems comprising thousands of components, therefore their reliability and safety when
employed in critical application domains are challenging. With the development and integration of Industry
4.0 technologies such systems become more open for communication and flexible usage due to gradual
interconnection with public networks and the Internet, but new cybersecurity and safety challenges are
introduced. This paper states research questions and provides analysis results of recent relevant sources.
Initially, 320 records (acquired between 2018 and 2022 inclusive) were identified. Later on, 187 studies
were processed to check eligibility criteria. Overall, this mapping study includes 49 papers, after examining
the pre-defined criteria and guidelines. The results of the analysis performed allow to systemize techniques
being utilized in practice right now, as well as to identify trends of further techniques development. In fact,
although the techniques used are not novel and most of them have been used for decades, our study shows
that there are still some new trends in this field. In particular, the unified safety and cybersecurity assessment
technique is a promising research direction, worth further investigation.
Journal Name:
Safety and Cybersecurity Assessment Techniques
for Critical Industries: A Mapping Study

Text: A key assumption in recent congestion management strategies is that energy flows in a specific direction—from generation sources to loads via transmission networks. It is also assumed that loads should be served while maintaining system security. However, with the increasing adoption of DRs, this traditional power flow model will shift towards a more localized load service approach, which can help reduce transmission congestion.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: Therefore, it is recommended that the DFIG type of wind farm be used if there will be a wind power investment in Thailand’s electric power system in the future. This is because it presents the least stability impact on the current system. In addition, the capacity of the wind site should be limited to the security level from the system impact study which is dependent on the time of implementation of the wind project.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Blockchain-Enabled Cybersecurity Efficient IIOHT
Cyber-Physical System for Medical Applications

Text: The AAMD-OELAC (Automated Android Malware Detection using Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach for Cybersecurity) technique enhances malware detection through data preprocessing and an ensemble learning model that integrates Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), Kernel Extreme Learning Machine (KELM), and Regularized Random Vector Functional Link Neural Network (RRVFLN). To optimize detection accuracy, it employs the Hunter-Prey Optimization (HPO) algorithm for fine-tuning model parameters. A comprehensive experimental analysis validates its effectiveness, demonstrating improved malware detection performance compared to existing methods.

In recent years, numerous researchers have focused on impulsive systems and impulsive control. Studies such as– have explored the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, which are required to be non-increasing across sequences of switchings. Yang's work in built upon earlier research in to establish sufficient conditions for impulsive control in nonlinear systems. Li et al. in further developed less conservative conditions for asymptotic stability in impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses, also leveraging results from. Additionally, impulsive control has been applied in chaotic secure communication and spread spectrum systems, as seen in–, with experimental methods detailed in.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: A defining characteristic of reinforcement learning (RL) is its inherent exploration-exploitation trade-off, where an agent must balance leveraging known rewarding actions (exploitation) with trying new actions (exploration) to maximize long-term rewards? fundamental challenge known as the exploration-exploitation dilemma. Unlike other ML paradigms, RL explicitly addresses this dynamic through algorithmic strategies like e-greedy policies or Thompson sampling, enabling agents to progressively refine decision-making in complex, uncertain environments such as autonomous systems or adaptive cybersecurity controls. This unique feature makes RL particularly suited for CPS applications requiring continuous interaction and adaptation, though it introduces computational and convergence challenges absent in supervised or unsupervised learning approaches.

The Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC), developed by the National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA), provide a structured framework to enhance organizational cybersecurity. These guidelines are designed to address various cyber threats, ensuring a robust and resilient security posture. By setting a global benchmark for cybersecurity practices, the ECC requires organizations to adopt a strategic approach to implementation, integrating these controls effectively to mitigate risks and strengthen overall cyber defenses.

With the advancement of internet and wireless communication, smart devices and things, and IP protocol and sensor
network technologies, more and more network-based objects
have been involved in IoT cybersecurity. These advanced

and on Industry 4.0 [9]. Cybersecurity is spread across the

Journal Name:
Internet of Things (IoT) Cybersecurity Research:
A Review of Current Research Topics

Text: In this article, we use the C-I-A triad as a security taxonomy to assess the business impacts of a breach of basic security goals (such as confidentiality, integrity, and availability) with reference to manufacturing systems 4.0. Of note, all other security properties derive from the C-I-A triad objectives and will be considered in future in-depth studies. To address the cybersecurity challenges that pervade Industry 4.0 environments, manufacturing companies need to strengthen their cyber risk management practices and define a strategy for their implementation. In this direction, the first step in addressing cybersecurity issues related to manufacturing systems is to perform an assessment of cyber risks, analyzing the main assets to be protected.

The Internet of Things (IoT) has experienced explosive growth, connecting approximately 4.9 billion devices in 2015 and projected to reach 25 billion by 2020. While IoT offers remarkable flexibility and scalability, this rapid expansion also introduces significant security challenges. As individuals connect more devices, the associated risks to personal privacy and network integrity increase, leading to heightened cybersecurity threats to global infrastructure. By 2020, the average person was expected to have around 6.58 devices, up from fewer than 0.08 in 2003. This proliferation of diverse devices?ncluding computers, smartphones, and smart appliances?reates numerous vulnerable points within the IoT ecosystem that cybercriminals can exploit. Current cybersecurity measures must ensure that these devices operate within secure environments while allowing users to utilize them safely. The IoT landscape encompasses a wide range of technologies, including RFID sensors and actuators that enable intelligent devices to make autonomous decisions and communicate information effectively. However, as highlighted by recent reports, IoT devices remain susceptible to various cyber threats such as DDoS attacks, ransomware, and unauthorized access due to weak security protocols and insufficient updates. Addressing these vulnerabilities is critical for maintaining the integrity of IoT networks and protecting sensitive data from malicious actors.

actual operating conditions are close to the base cases where

Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: A key aspect of protection systems in interconnected power grids is that current flows in both clockwise and counterclockwise directions during normal and fault conditions. Therefore, accurately modeling protection networks (PNs) requires careful coordination of protection devices. Specifically, defining protection zones for distance relays is crucial for specifying the correct sequence of operation for both primary and backup protection systems within transmission networks, when using PNs.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Cybersecurity is an inherently interdisciplinary field that intersects with computer science, engineering, information systems, networks, cryptology, human factors, and policy. Given the vast and diverse range of potential topics, identifying its core concepts requires a rigorous, consensus-driven approach. This paper details the methodology and findings of two Delphi processes conducted in fall 2014, which systematically aggregated expert opinions to distill foundational cybersecurity knowledge. By leveraging structured expert feedback on importance, difficulty, and timelessness, these Delphi studies provide a validated framework for defining essential concepts?erving as a critical reference point for curriculum development, educational standards, and workforce training in this rapidly evolving domain. The results offer an evidence-based foundation to align cybersecurity education with both academic rigor and real-world professional demands.

Practical experience highlights the value of pumped storage units for FRR in isolated power systems, especially during severe shortages. These units can operate in generating mode with AGC to offer frequency regulation or in pumping mode for emergency reserves. Comparative results show that different operating modes are suitable for different load conditions: Mode C for light loads (spring and winter) reduces pumping costs, while Mode D is better for heavy loads (summer and autumn) to provide frequency regulation. The Taiwan Power Company has verified the benefits of flexible dispatching schedules for pumped storage units, improving power quality and system security.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: The collaboration between cybersecurity educational institutions and industry has been researched before, see for example [17], [18]. However, to the best of our knowledge, most universities have not yet implemented an active collaboration with the industrial sector. Although the global cybersecurity workforce shortage was estimated to be 4 million in 2023 [19], there is no concrete plan to fill this gap. Moreover, some surveys suggest that the cybersecurity graduates from universities may not hold the skills that industry requires.

In principle, the hardware key could be any of the device’s control parameters, namely the bias current, feedback strength, and feedback phase. However, significant variation of bias cur rent or feedback strength can dramatically affect the chaotic at tractor characteristics and may be detected by the eavesdropper as power or attractors change. On the contrary, the variation of  feedback phase is not evident by observing time series or RF spectra of the chaotic signal [8]. Thus, only the feedback phase satisfies the condition of a hardware key that causes untraceable changes to the transmitted signal
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: We have successfully developed a new RNG that leverages the large fluctuating current of the MOS structure after soft breakdown. This RNG is a compact circuit consisting of around 20 logic gates and several passive components. The random numbers generated by this RNG have passed rigorous tests, confirming their high quality and closeness to true randomness. As a result, this RNG is a promising solution for cryptographic security applications in mobile network services.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: To maximize the comprehensiveness of the analytical framework, a thorough examination of pertinent reports and articles was conducted, enabling the presented PESTLE analysis to function as a consolidated representation of the current research landscape concerning cybersecurity education; this section will specifically address studies that have employed a PESTLE analysis methodology to investigate cybersecurity education, while a more extensive review of cybersecurity education-related publications is provided in subsequent sections, thereby ensuring a balanced and multifaceted exploration of the subject matter.

The cyber environment of a control center, as illustrated in Fig. 1, represents the connectivity of corporate networks, which are typically safeguarded by firewalls. These control center networks are linked to corporate networks, as well as substation and power plant networks managed by IT personnel. Given their high-security measures, direct infiltration of control center networks is considered unlikely. This study instead focuses on potential intrusions into control center networks via other entry points, such as substations or power plants.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text:
As a result of a myriad data breaches in recent times, new regulations such as Breach of Security Safeguards Regulations in
Canada and Europe?s General Data Protection Regulation
have been implemented. A crucial aspect of the GDPR is the
right to be forgotten, which gives an individual the power to
enforce the deletion of any information pertaining to him/
herself. A research trend we foresee here is self destructing
data. Previous work has however been done on this. [143] propose an architecture that aims to solve the issue of personal
data privacy. Their research was aimed at protecting the privacy of old data that has been stored on a centralized database
which can then be re-used or re-surfaced. Their architecture
made sure that copies of such data will become obsolete. This
is a research area that might see a lot of growth in years to
come, especially due to the emergence of blockchain and
decentralized data storage. There are still challenges for big
data regulation and policies including the situation where
data leaves the organization for cloud storage.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity in Big Data Era: From Securing
