Big Data to Data-Driven Security

Text:
Given this premise, it should be no surprise that the railway
industry has quickly become a massive user of the novel.networked and computerized systems to handle most aspects
of its operations, thus replacing the ancient electromechanical
systems onboard the train and off-board. Indeed, computerbased systems offer an almost unparalleled level of flexibility and performance, enabling operators to offer additional
services like infotainment to passengers. Moreover, using
this kind of technology, practitioners have access to a vast
array of off-the-shelf components already for affine industries, thus significantly bringing down costs and speeding up
deployments.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Considerations for Communication
Based Train Control

Text: Remark 1: In this approach, a magnifying-glass technique is used to transform chaotic state variables that serve as a key sequence before being XORed with the plaintext. If there is a slight mismatch leading to perturbations, the amplified signal will be significantly enlarged due to the large parameter value. This means that even a minor parameter mismatch will result in substantial decryption errors, causing the decryption key sequence to differ from the encryption key signal. Consequently, it becomes impossible to recover the original plaintext signal, thereby enhancing the security of the chaotic communication system.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: This document details the augmentation of the Facility Cybersecurity Framework (FCF) through the incorporation of the Network Defense Training Game (NDTG), a feature engineered to provide gamified cybersecurity training, specifically targeting the resilience of Operational Technology (OT) within critical infrastructure. The NDTG's innovative aspects encompass the simulation of authentic Industrial Control System (ICS) cyberattack scenarios, aligned with the NICE Framework workforce roles as delineated by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), and the implementation of autonomous cyberattacks, designed to adapt dynamically to player decisions, thereby fostering a formative learning environment, with the central inquiry focusing on the efficacy of these contributions.

As it is recognized by previous researchers and experts, it is
crucial to consult with the cybersecurity standards and frameworks to develop a comprehensive curriculum that meets the
workforce?s needs. Therefore, in this work, we present a novel
method to design university-level cybersecurity curriculum
that utilizes some of the internationally adopted cybersecurity
standards and frameworks as cornerstones.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: The adoption of modern technology in the railway industry has introduced new cybersecurity challenges. These advanced systems present a broader attack surface compared to traditional dedicated systems and require less specialized knowledge to exploit due to their shared components. The combination of low security awareness among industry players and the high-profile nature of railway infrastructure makes it an attractive target for attackers, ranging from amateur hackers to state-sponsored entities. Numerous cyber-attacks have already been carried out against railway systems, including the 2008 incident in L?z, Poland, where a teenager used a replay attack to derail four trams.

Cybersecurity training labs exist in various forms, with traditional lab settings consisting of interconnected physical machines, network devices, and security appliances like firewalls and intrusion detection systems. These setups offer hands-on experience with real hardware, enhancing realism. Some platforms provide remote access to such labs, allowing students to allocate, configure, and manage physical machines remotely. However, this classical approach has significant overhead costs and challenges related to setup, installation, scheduling, and equipment management, making it less scalable compared to cloud-based or virtualized alternatives.

Hybrid Manufacturing (HM) tools serve as exemplary models for a foundational element of Digital Manufacturing (DM). They illustrate the ongoing transformation of traditional manufacturing paradigms into DM. This transformation, however, introduces additional attack vectors within the DM ecosystem. Consequently, the HM tool serves as a case study for the identification, analysis, and mitigation of vulnerabilities stemming from these attack vectors, prior to the widespread implementation of DM.

The collaboration between cybersecurity educational institutions and industry has been researched before, see for example. However, to the best of our knowledge, most
universities have not yet implemented an active collaboration
with the industrial sector. Although the global cybersecurity
workforce shortage was estimated to be 4 million in 2023
, there is no concrete plan to fill this gap. Moreover,
some surveys suggest that the cybersecurity graduates from
universities may not hold the skills that industry requires
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: The critical infrastructure security landscape continues to evolve with escalating cyber threat sophistication, particularly challenging power grid technologies. Power transformers, once considered passive grid components, now incorporate smart technologies and intelligent monitoring systems. While these advancements improve asset management, they simultaneously create new cybersecurity vulnerabilities. Current research predominantly addresses smart grid cybersecurity using model-based detection approaches, but largely overlooks the specific cybersecurity concerns of critical power components?specially power transformers?ithin these networks. Our paper fills this significant research gap by examining smart transformer cybersecurity challenges. We develop a comprehensive architecture and structured taxonomy of cyber-physical attacks targeting smart transformers. Through detailed analysis of smart transformer topology, we identify vulnerable components and demonstrate potential cybersecurity breach impacts. Additionally, we explore anticipated future cybersecurity challenges for smart transformers. Our research highlights the critical necessity of embedding advanced cybersecurity measures within online condition monitoring system development to protect power transformers against emerging cyber threats and strengthen power grid resilience.

In chaotic communication systems using lasers with delayed optical feedback, data security traditionally depends on requiring nearly identical transmitter and receiver devices. Our study examines scenarios where this requirement is compromised (when an eavesdropper possesses an identical receiver). We propose a security scheme based on deliberately varying the feedback phase, exploiting the inherent limitations in synchronization response time. The feedback phase functions as a shared key required by both transmitter and receiver to achieve synchronization. While some might suggest algorithmic data encryption before encoding to the chaotic carrier as an alternative approach, this would increase processing requirements and remain vulnerable to algorithmic decryption attacks. In contrast, our technique requires no additional processing power and bases its security on fundamental physical limitations.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: The Privacy Act of 1974 requires federal information systems to protect the confidentiality of personally identifiable information. However, these mandates provide minimal direction regarding the specific organizational structures needed to fulfill such requirements at the local level. Unlike most service sectors, healthcare organizations face increasingly severe penalties for security failures. The stakes regarding security non-compliance in healthcare are undeniably high. Information models have typically been used to examine security issues specific to individual organizations, with little research addressing industry-wide or institutional patterns. The emergence of industry-wide information regulations and associated non-compliance penalties may offer a more comprehensive perspective when regulatory or cross-market influences counteract established behaviors within specific organizations. There is also limited research on information technology's impact on clinical healthcare environments. Historically, physicians have viewed information management as an administrative function and consequently developed minimal expertise in this area, despite the universal requirements now mandated by HIPAA and the Privacy Act.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text:
Typically in time-frequency analysis such as the STFT the 
signal is broken into small segments in time and the 
frequency content of each small segment is calculated. The 
frequency content can be represented as a magnitude 
spectrum that represents the energy distribution over 
frequency for that particular segment in time. Features based 
on the STFT are very common and have the advantage of fast 
calculation based on the Fast Fourier Transform algorithm. 
The following features are based on the short-time magnitude 
of the STFT transform of the signal.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text:
Cyber security is an important issue to be handled before
implementing protection system over the broadband network.
The main content of this article is constructing a context information-based real-time cyber security defense approach for a
protection system under the network context. The organization
of this article is as follows. Section II introduces the proposed
methodology. PNN is introduced and set up in Section III. Simulation and conclusions are given in Sections IV and V.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: For networks with fewer constrained lines, the Transmission Service Provider (TSP) requires an alternative objective function. An effective approach is to minimize the absolute value of transmission service charges, which works well empirically as it aligns with more uniform nodal prices. This contrasts with maximizing TSP revenue, which ensures increased social welfare and positive revenue. However, minimizing transmission charges may result in lower social welfare and negative revenue. Despite this, it facilitates achieving optimal power flow (OPF) in less constrained networks.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: In this note, we also examine impulsive control of nonlinear systems, similar to [7]. We first establish a new comparison theorem. Using this impulsive differential systems theory, we develop less conservative stability conditions for impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses, then apply these findings to design impulsive control laws for certain nonlinear systems. Our methodology is applicable to a broader range of nonlinear systems and can enhance existing technologies used in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications [8]-[13].
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: The proposed vulnerability assessment method is per formed in three levels: system, scenarios, and access points. The flow chart depicted in Fig. 3 illustrates the simulation procedures. The proposed method has been implemented in Visual Basic.NET with the interactions between SPNP [24] and MATLAB. An extensible markup language (XML) file that stores the models for simulation is used to automatically generate an intermediate file called C-Based SPNP Language (CSPL). This is prepared by an algorithm that builds a topology of the cyber-net according to the net definition of a network. The definition is composed of password and firewall models.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: The operation of Taiwan Power's (Taipower) transmission system frequently involves significant power transfers from major low-cost generation sources in the southern and central regions to load centers in the north. Following a major blackout in 1999, there has been a focus on deploying Special Protection Systems (SPS) to handle extreme situations. A defense plan was developed, incorporating three SPS to prevent angle instability, overloads, and voltage instability in certain areas of the transmission system. A wide-area SPS was planned for deployment and operation by 2006.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: This paper focuses on wind farm penetration levels of 10% and 20% of the peak demand. To achieve this, 22 and 44 sites, each with a 90-MW installed capacity, have been integrated into the conventional power system. These wind farms are connected via 115-kV transmission lines at various locations near load centers across the entire system.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: To realize DBHS, new CA systems are needed to prevent illegal copying and regulate the use of stored digital content by receivers. Additionally, since metadata makes it easy to edit and reconstruct programs, access control systems are required to allow broadcasters to regulate how content is used. In this paper, we refer to security systems that protect content rights and control access as digital rights management (DRM) systems [4]. DRM has been previously studied as a platform for rights protection and access control for internet content. The technical gap between CA for broadcasting and DRM for communication is gradually closing.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Several methods have been explored to manage power distribution and reduce peak loads. One effective approach [1] combined automated mapping with facilities management and geographic information systems to prevent transformer damage from overloading. Another technique [2] utilized a pulse-width-modulation control scheme for interruptible load management (ILM) to effectively reduce peak load. However, this method requires utilities to incentivize customers with price discounts or special rates to form interruptible load groups (ILGs), with appropriate incentive rates discussed in [3] and [4]. Additionally, a dynamic tariff strategy [5] was proposed for demand-side management (DSM), offering real-time pricing for industrial users to maximize profits.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: The article discusses the vulnerabilities of Internet of Things (IoT) devices due to inadequate cybersecurity measures, highlighting the importance of timely identification and detection of compromised devices. It explores a transferability approach based on transductive transfer learning for IoT device profiling and identification, proposing a three-component system that includes device type identification, vulnerability assessment, and a visualization module. The device type identification utilizes transductive transfer learning to test the trained model in a remote lab setting. Various machine learning models are evaluated for their performance based on metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score to identify the most effective methods for profiling. Additionally, the vulnerability of identified device types is assessed using databases like Vulners, the National Vulnerability Database (NVD), and IBM X-Force, with results visualized on a dashboard. This approach aims to enhance cybersecurity by improving the identification of IoT devices and assessing their vulnerabilities efficiently.

The system utilizes an 8-bit PSoC (Programmable System on Chip) microprocessor for three primary reasons. Firstly, it facilitates easier design and reduces system costs by offering configurable analog and digital blocks, along with programmable interconnect logic. This allows for the creation of customized peripherals such as filters, amplifiers, analog-to-digital converters, and communication interfaces. Secondly, the device includes a sleep timer and a Switch Mode Pump (SMP) circuit, which are beneficial for reducing power consumption. Thirdly, a specialized PSoC device is available that simplifies the design of capacitive sensor keyboards, thereby reducing overall system complexity.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: The paper's structure progresses systematically through five key sections: Section II examines existing literature and frameworks in cybersecurity education to establish foundational context; Section III details the SPARTA Cybersecurity Skills Framework that underpins our curriculum evaluation methodology; Section IV presents analytical findings from our comprehensive assessment of 89 Bachelor's and Master's programs worldwide; Section V introduces our innovative curriculum design methodology, showcases model programs demonstrating best practices, and demonstrates the functionality of our interactive web-based curriculum design tool; culminating in final conclusions that synthesize our contributions to advancing evidence-based cybersecurity education development through standardized frameworks, empirical program analysis, and practical digital tools for academic institutions.

Artificial intelligence algorithms have a leading role in the field of cybersecurity and attack
detection, being able to present better results in some scenarios than classic intrusion detection systems such
as Snort or Suricata. In this sense, this research focuses on the evaluation of characteristics for different
well-established Machine Leaning algorithms commonly applied to IDS scenarios. To do this, a categorization for cybersecurity data sets that groups its records into several groups is first considered. Making use of
this division, this work seeks to determine which neural network model (multilayer or recurrent), activation
function, and learning algorithm yield higher accuracy values, depending on the group of data. Finally,
the results are used to determine which group of data from a cybersecurity data set are more relevant and
representative for the intrusion detection, and the most suitable configuration of Machine Learning algorithm
to decrease the computational load of the system
Journal Name:
Evaluation of Cybersecurity Data Set Characteristics
for Their Applicability to Neural
Networks Algorithms Detecting
Cybersecurity Anomalies

Text: This paper will also investigate the impulsive control of nonlinear systems, similar to previous work. A new comparison theorem will be established. Using this theorem, we will derive improved stability criteria for impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses. These criteria will then be used to develop control laws for a specific class of nonlinear systems. Our approach is more broadly applicable to nonlinear systems and has the potential to enhance existing technologies in chaotic secure and spread spectrum communications.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: Cybersecurity threats continue to evolve in sophistication, creating substantial challenges for conventional security approaches. The integration of Artificial Intelligence with cybersecurity efforts aims to strengthen detection capabilities, threat analysis processes, and mitigation strategies. However, the centralized architecture common to many AI implementations introduces concerning vulnerabilities and creates potential single points of failure. Blockchain technology, with its decentralized structure and immutable ledger capabilities, offers promising enhancements to data security and integrity, positioning it as a potential solution for addressing these persistent cybersecurity challenges.

However, deep learning has some challenges in big data
[49]. Its adaptability can be used as a vulnerability when
attackers exploit the Machine Learning models. Adversarial
examples [50] are machine learning inputs specifically designed to trick the ML model into producing a different output.
Various works that have been done on this area try to refine
the models [51]. [52] however propose a different approach to
detecting adversarial examples. This approach is called feature squeezing which involves the reduction of the search
space available to an adversary by merging samples that correspond to many different feature vectors in the original space
into a single sample. With the advancement of Generative
Adversarial Networks and big data, attackers are using artifi-
cial intelligence to circumvent some of the machine-learning
automated processes. In lieu of this, a more effective approach
is the merging of human and machine elements. Vimod [53]
proposed an approach were humans and machine collaborate
together. They used high-functioning autistic graduates with
specific attributes to monitor networks and network flows.
The other work [54] that incorporated the use of big data to
assist humans studied data triage, and how helpful it is in
identifying true attack patterns in a noisy data. This approach
tries to automatically generate data triage automaton by tracing the actions of security analysts. This approach is different
from existing data triage automaton like SIEM, because unlike
SIEM, which requires analysts to manually generate event
correlation rules, their approach mines data triage rules out of
cybersecurity analysts? operation traces. It can be sheen that
attackers are using artificial intelligence to trick ML models.
Human and machine working together is one of the effective
ways to combat these attacks.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity in Big Data Era: From Securing
Big Data to Data-Driven Security

Text: Primary Surveillance Radar (PSR) detects targets by analyzing reflected signals without decoding transmitted data, inherently resisting message injection or modification?ommon threats in software-defined radio (SDR) attacks [19][20]. Its high transmission power further complicates jamming attempts [58], though not impossible (e.g., military-grade equipment could disrupt signals). Given these physical-layer protections and the specialized resources needed for exploitation, PSR's cybersecurity risks are deemed lower-priority in this study, shifting focus to more vulnerable aviation systems like ADS-B or GNSS.

The evolving Generative AI (GenAI) tools have emerged as a double-edged sword in cybersecurity, providing significant benefits to both defenders and attackers. Tools like ChatGPT can assist cyber defenders by leveraging large language models (LLMs) trained on extensive cyber threat intelligence data, which includes information on vulnerabilities, attack patterns, and indicators of compromise. This vast repository of knowledge enables defenders to enhance their threat intelligence capabilities, extract valuable insights, and identify emerging threats more effectively. Additionally, GenAI tools can automate the analysis of large volumes of log files, system outputs, or network traffic data during cyber incidents, thereby accelerating and streamlining the incident response process. Furthermore, these tools contribute to fostering security-aware human behavior by training personnel to recognize and respond to increasingly sophisticated attacks. GenAI also supports secure coding practices by generating secure code and producing test cases to validate the security of developed software. Moreover, LLMs can help formulate better ethical guidelines that strengthen cyber defenses within organizations. Overall, while GenAI tools present new challenges in the realm of cybersecurity, they also offer powerful resources for enhancing defensive strategies against malicious intrusions.

Cybersecurity is important in networked control systems.
Networked control systems are connected to information
networks used in factory automation and power grids for
supporting modern life. However, being connected to an
information network entails the risk of a cyberattack on
the control system. Furthermore, unlike in the case of
conventional information technology systems, cyberattacks
on control systems can cause physical damage. Stuxnet
destroyed centrifuges at an Iranian nuclear facility [1], and
Industroyer caused massive power outages in Ukraine [2]
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity-Enhanced Encrypted Control
System Using Keyed-Homomorphic
Public Key Encryption

Text: Load resource capable of providing regulation service by controllably reducing or increasing consumption under dispatch control (similar to AGC) and that immediately responds pro portionally to frequency changes (similar to generator governor action) is referred to as CLD in LaaR service. In the current ERCOT market design, ERCOT will send out the generation control signal to QSEs based on the real time system area control error in order to maintain the target ERCOT system frequency. Moreover, each QSE will self-dispatch their individ ual unit output to meet the generation control requirement. In the current ERCOT market structure, ERCOT do not directly control each unit’s generation output. The same control logic would be applied not only for generators, but also for load as long as the load is capable of changing the load consumption with respect to the generation control signal. Fig. 2 shows one real example of CLD response with respect to the QSE dispatch signal in the ERCOT system, which shows the tested CLD can exactly change their load consumption with respect to the QSE’s control signal. Therefore, CLD provides a good opportunity for load entity to maintain the system security by following AGC and governor control.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: The wind-farm penetration levels of 10% and 20% of the peak demand are the key interest in this paper. Therefore, 22 and 44 sites of a 90-MW installed-capacity wind farms have been integrated to the traditional system via 115-kV trans mission lines in different locations around load center areas throughout the whole system.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: Three case studies demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approaches. First, a 5-Interruptible Load Group (ILG) scheduling problem is implemented using IDP. This simple case is also executed using conventional Dynamic Programming (DP) to validate IDP's usefulness. Additionally, in case 2, a daily load pattern for a substation experiencing capacity shortage is modified using the Decision Support System (DSS). In this scenario, a 25-ILG scheduling problem is solved using IDP, with the results subsequently adjusted by HIR for application to the practical system load. These initial cases focus primarily on interruption load scheduling without considering incentive rates. The impact of incentive rates is examined in case 3.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: This section demonstrates the feasibility of a market operating with bilateral contracts. The key idea revolves around implementing a form of "local supplementary control" on each generator participating in the bilateral market. If specific technical conditions, which will be highlighted later, are met, each generator can be equipped with a closed-loop load-following controller.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: We conducted numerical simulations using the standard rate equations model for two unidirectionally coupled lasers, one acting as the emitter and the other as the receiver. The equations describe the slowly varying amplitude of the electric field E(t) and the carrier number N(t), assuming single-mode operation and low to moderate feedback strengths.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: The study explores anticipated and emerging ethical issues in cybersecurity, categorizing them into "strong signals," which represent mainstream concerns, and "weak signals," which are less-discussed but potentially significant future dilemmas. Key ethical challenges include balancing surveillance and privacy, addressing biases in AI algorithms, ensuring transparency and accountability in automated systems, and navigating the ethical boundaries of practices like ethical hacking. Comparisons with a similar experiment conducted two years ago reveal that some predicted dilemmas have materialized, highlighting the evolving complexity of cybersecurity ethics. The findings emphasize the importance of proactive ethical frameworks to address these issues as technology continues to advance.

This paper introduces an Automated Android Malware Detection using Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach for Cybersecurity (AAMD-OELAC) technique. The AAMD-OELAC technique initiates with data preprocessing. For the Android malware detection process, the AAMD-OELAC technique employs an ensemble learning methodology, utilizing three Machine Learning (ML) models: Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), kernel extreme learning machine (KELM), and Regularized random vector functional link neural network (RRVFLN). Subsequently, the hunter-prey optimization (HPO) algorithm is utilized for the optimal parameter tuning of these three Deep Learning (DL) models, resulting in enhanced malware detection performance. A comprehensive experimental analysis is conducted to demonstrate the superiority of the AAMD-OELAC approach.

CDA (Ciphertext-Domain Aggregation) end-to-end encryption offers greater adaptability to fluctuating network backbones across different time periods compared to hop-by-hop encryption. Unlike hop-by-hop, where only key-holding nodes can decrypt and aggregate data, CDA allows any node to function as an aggregator without needing to store decryption keys. This enables aggregator selection based solely on node energy levels, enhancing network flexibility. CDA's confidentiality, independent of specific aggregator selection algorithms, significantly improves the robustness and reliability of wireless sensor networks (WSNs).
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: Phishers are increasingly using phishing kits to deploy attacks more efficiently and at scale, making early detection of phishing campaigns critical. To address this, the PhiKitA dataset has been introduced, containing phishing kits and websites generated from these kits. This dataset enables deeper analysis of phishing threats and supports the development of detection methods. Experiments conducted on PhiKitA using MD5 hashes, fingerprints, and graph representation algorithms revealed promising results. The graph representation algorithm achieved 92.50% accuracy in detecting phishing websites, highlighting its effectiveness, while the MD5 hash representation had a lower 39.54% F1 score, indicating limitations in distinguishing phishing sources. PhiKitA provides valuable insights into phishing tactics and serves as a foundation for improving detection systems to combat phishing attacks more effectively.

Finally, Figure 4 shows eye diagrams of the recovered messages using chaos masking (CM) with a 5% message amplitude for the closed-loop (upper left) and open-loop (lower left) receivers. The closed-loop receiver perfectly recovers the message, while the open-loop receiver's recovery is very poor. On the right side, we display eye diagrams after applying a simple linear filtering process to the transmitted signal, PT(t), with (top) a 5% message amplitude and (bottom) a 7.5% amplitude. With 5% amplitude, linear filtering fails to detect the information, but it succeeds with 7.5% amplitude. This demonstrates that the information is not adequately concealed within the chaotic carrier at higher amplitudes.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text:
Organizational ambidexterity in its nature relies on the simultaneous completion of two activities, i.e., the balance between exploration and exploitation. This emphasizes the ability of organizations to exploit their existing competencies
while simultaneously exploring new opportunities. In the context of ambidextrous cybersecurity, two goals should be met:
the protection of data, systems, and networks, while fostering the rapid introduction of new technologies within a
company.
Journal Name:
Ambidextrous Cybersecurity: The Seven Pillars (7Ps)
of Cyber Resilience

Text: The proposed method incorporates a lightweight data preprocessing approach to structure task input data from various sensors efficiently. Data preprocessing ensures that raw data is transformed into a usable format, facilitating accurate processing. The study employs a data mining technique to format tasks appropriately based on their requirements. Additionally, tasks are prioritized using the earliest deadline first (EDF) algorithm, ensuring that critical tasks are processed in a timely manner, as demonstrated in Algorithm 1.

The generalization power of AI has successfully replaced traditional rule-based approaches with more advanced and intelligent technologies. However, as digital advancements continue, cyber threat actors are also becoming more sophisticated. Previously, cyberspace primarily dealt with high-volume but relatively unsophisticated intrusion attempts. With the emergence of AI-driven cyberattacks, a new era has begun, introducing both known and unknown transformations in attack strategies. AI and machine learning have significantly enhanced the effectiveness of cyber threats, empowering malicious actors more than ever before. As a result, Generative AI (GenAI) has drawn significant attention from the cybersecurity community, influencing both cyber defense and offensive strategies.

This correspondence provides a systematic analysis of brute-force break-ins targeting our palmprint system. By utilizing Competitive Code as the feature representation and angular distance as the matching method, we establish a projected multinomial distribution to model the relationship between the probability of false acceptance and the number of attack attempts. Our analysis indicates that when the system threshold is set below 0.39, brute-force attacks become computationally infeasible for breaching the palmprint system.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: Artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms play a crucial role in cybersecurity and attack detection, often outperforming traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS) like Snort and Suricata in certain scenarios. This research focuses on evaluating key characteristics of well-established machine learning algorithms commonly used in IDS applications. To achieve this, a categorization approach is applied to cybersecurity datasets, grouping records into distinct categories. Using this classification, the study aims to identify which neural network model?hether multilayer or recurrent?long with the most effective activation function and learning algorithm, yields the highest accuracy based on data groupings. The final results help determine which dataset segments are most relevant for intrusion detection while also identifying the optimal machine learning configurations that can reduce computational overhead in IDS implementations.

Controllable Load Resource (CLD) in Load-acting-as-a-Resource (LaaR) service refers to load resources that can provide regulation by systematically adjusting consumption under dispatch control (comparable to AGC) and responding immediately to frequency fluctuations (similar to generator governors). In the current ERCOT framework, ERCOT transmits generation control signals to Qualified Scheduling Entities (QSEs) based on real-time system area control error to maintain target frequency. Each QSE then self-dispatches their individual units to meet generation control requirements. Within this structure, ERCOT doesn't directly control individual generation outputs. This control approach applies equally to generators and loads, provided the loads can modify consumption according to generation control signals. Figure 2 presents an actual example of CLD response to QSE dispatch signals in the ERCOT system, demonstrating that the tested CLD precisely adjusts consumption according to the QSE's control signal. This capability offers load entities an opportunity to contribute to system security through AGC and governor control participation.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: The proposed motion detection scheme utilizes only one-bit image data from selected pixels and comprises frame latch blocks along with a signal difference detector, equivalent to the most significant bit (MSB) (see Figure 12). As previously mentioned, the frame latch block stores image data from the selected column line in digital form. The difference detector compares the current and previous image data. If the difference between the two frames exceeds a predefined motion detection threshold, the circuit identifies the presence of motion.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: In a chaotic communication system consisting of lasers subject to delayed optical feedback, the data protection is accomplished by the stringent requirement for almost identical transmitter and receiver devices. In this study, we assume that the above requirement no longer holds (i.e., the eavesdropper is equipped with an identical receiver). The proposed security scheme is based on a predetermined variation of the feedback phase and relies on the inherent limitation of the synchroniza tion temporal response. Hence, feedback phase plays the role of a key that both the transmitter and receiver should share in order to synchronize. One would argue that the application of an algorithmic encryption of the data before being encoded to the chaotic carrier would be a similar approach. This is not true, since the algorithmic encryption increases the required processing power and is vulnerable to possible algorithmic de cryption attacks. On the contrary, the proposed technique does not require any additional processing power, and its security relies on fundamental physical limitations.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text:
The system proposed in this paper includes three types of receivers, all utilizing RF signals based on the IEEE 802.15.4 standard, specifically the ZigBee protocol.As shown in Fig. 2, the RF to IR-RS232 receiver is designed for a lighting control system that operates using IR and UART communication protocols. This receiver receives control signals from the URC via RF protocol and converts them into RS232 signals. An RS485 converter is then used to transmit the converted RS232 signals to multiple locations, enabling efficient home lighting control.
Meanwhile, the RF to IR-Relay receiver, depicted in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, can be connected to various electronic appliances, such as motorized screens, curtains, and windows. This receiver, linked to the URC via RF signals, controls appliances using both AC and DC motors.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text:
Recent studies have shown that phishers are using phishing kits to deploy phishing attacks
faster, easier and more massive. Detecting phishing kits in deployed websites might help to detect phishing
campaigns earlier. To the best of our knowledge, there are no datasets providing a set of phishing kits that
are used in websites that were attacked by phishing. In this work, we propose PhiKitA, a novel dataset
that contains phishing kits and also phishing websites generated using these kits. We have applied MD5
hashes, fingerprints, and graph representation DOM algorithms to obtain baseline results in PhiKitA in three
experiments: familiarity analysis of phishing kit samples, phishing website detection and identifying the
source of a phishing website. In the familiarity analysis, we find evidence of different types of phishing
kits and a small phishing campaign. In the binary classification problem for phishing detection, the graph
representation algorithm achieved an accuracy of 92.50%, showing that the phishing kit data contain useful
information to classify phishing. Finally, the MD5 hash representation obtained a 39.54% F1 score, which
means that this algorithm does not extract enough information to distinguish phishing websites and their
phishing kit sources properly
Journal Name:
PhiKitA: Phishing Kit Attacks Dataset
for Phishing Websites Identification

Text:
In the last few years, a few survey papers have sought to discuss the issue of adversarial attacks and defense in ML models.
Ozdag [28] presented a sparse study on the subject. However,
it was limited to DNN and the defenses were only focused on
the Neural Information Processing System (NIPS) 2017 adversarial learning competition. Also, there was no focus on the
resiliency of physical systems. A more comprehensive survey
by Biggio and Roli [29] discussed the evolution of ML for
over a decade. However, it was limited to DL and there was
no attention on resiliency of CPS. Liang et al. [30] focused
on the good, bad and ugly use of ML for cybersecurity in
CPS/IoT. The paper highlighted the advantages and disadvantages of ML applications in networked systems. However,
it only presented a general overview of the subject. Finally,
Yuan et al. [31] presented an extensive survey on adversarial
attacks and defense in DL. Just like the others, the authors
did not dwell on RL, a commonly used approach in CPS.
Furthermore, it was limited to methods published before 2017.
Journal Name:
Resilient Machine Learning for Networked Cyber
Physical System

Text: With the increasing use of the Internet, wireless communication, smart devices, and sensor networking, IoT cybersecurity has become a critical concern for organizations and users. The goal is to mitigate cybersecurity risks by protecting IoT assets and ensuring privacy, while also complying with relevant standards and regulations. Traditional security protocols are inadequate due to the scalability and complexity of IoT systems, necessitating new methodologies and technologies. Blockchain, for example, offers a strong cybersecurity framework with enhanced privacy protection, making it a promising solution for securing IoT environments.

A considerable number of studies use Risk to represent the
outputs of assessment technique utilization. In most cases,
this metric represents the likelihood of the hazardous event
and the severity of its consequences. Typical examples of
what is used as a risk in the analysed studies are provided
below. In [1], [4], [7], and [9] traditional risk priority number (RPN) is used, which is determined by three indicators:
effect severity, occurrence probability, and detection difficulty. In [3] it is extended to cover risk interaction. In [5]
risk assessment objectivity and accuracy are enhanced by
the utilization of fuzzy confidence interval number (FCIN),
generalized trapezoidal fuzzy numbers (GTrFN) evaluation
model and the evaluation parameter sensitivity analysis. In [6]
risk is calculated using the severity of the hazard, the exposure of that particular situation and the controllability of the
system to mitigate hazardous situations. In [8] fairness risk
is also considered separately from safety risk. In [10] special
attention is given to considering assurance risks. In [12] risk
is computed using potential risk impact due to vulnerabilities/attacks and the likelihood of the risk. In [13] risk includes
attack cost, attack difficulty, and detected possibility.
Journal Name:
Safety and Cybersecurity Assessment Techniques
for Critical Industries: A Mapping Study

Text:
At the initial stage, data preprocessing is performed to
improve the quality of the actual data. As regards classification, it is vital for choosing features to signify the class the
new record would concern [24]. Based on this, the permission
and API calls can be eradicated in all Android applications,
and both are features from the database. Androguard refers to
a complete package tool planned for interacting with Android
files and limited only to Python platforms. It could be utilized
as a tool to reverse engineer single Android applications. The Androguard tool can be utilized for analyzing APK files
by individually removing the DEX file permissions to all
APK files. Hence, it is generated a data frame comprising
applications (rows) and features (columns), whereas all the
columns signify certain permission or API-call with binary
values, but rows denote either malware or benign APK files.
Journal Name:
Automated Android Malware Detection Using
Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach
for Cybersecurity

Text: A recent online report [26] by Joe Weiss identifies significant cybersecurity risks associated with foreign-manufactured power transformers and other critical grid components. Power transformers, essential for electric grid operations, are increasingly susceptible to cyber attacks from external threat actors. The interconnected nature of the grid implies that a compromised transformer can endanger the entire system. Concerns have been raised regarding the potential presence of hardware backdoors within these transformers, enabling attackers to manipulate operational parameters, potentially resulting in catastrophic failures. Despite these risks, the continued reliance on foreign-made equipment by numerous utilities, driven by cost-effectiveness, presents a potential vulnerability. The emphasis on network vulnerabilities, to the exclusion of hardware vulnerabilities, compounds the risks to critical infrastructure, leaving key components such as power transformers vulnerable to concealed threats capable of causing severe disruptions. The report emphasizes the imperative for the utility sector and government to address these hardware-related threats to ensure the security of critical infrastructure.

CDA-based end-to-end encryption offers greater flexibility across varying network backbones over time. Unlike hop-by-hop encryption, where only nodes with the corresponding key can decrypt and aggregate data, CDA allows any node to act as an aggregator without needing to store the key. This enables the election of aggregator nodes based solely on their remaining energy levels for each epoch. By not limiting aggregator node election algorithms, CDA ensures confidentiality, thereby enhancing the robustness and reliability of the Wireless Sensor Network (WSN).
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: Figure 3 shows the optimal operating state before any failures for a system with five connection points. In this state, the power generated at connection point 1 is less than its maximum secure limit of 160 MW. This reduction is necessary because generating the maximum amount would lead to significant electricity supply interruptions if generator 1 failed. Specifically, in the optimal pre-failure state, the load at connection point 2 is reduced by 0.29 MW at a cost of $29 when the connection between points 1 and 2 is lost, as illustrated in Figure 4.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: Designing effective cybersecurity laboratories mandates adherence to six core principles derived from [1][5][27][68]: (1) Internet-enabled lab machines for tool downloads and research access, (2) physical/network isolation from campus infrastructure to contain risks, (3) realistic network environments replicating real-world conditions for diverse attack/defense exercises, (4) modular resource management to dynamically allocate assets for assignments of varying complexity, (5) dedicated IT support for maintenance and rapid issue resolution, and (6) distributed accessibility ensuring parity for on-site and remote students. These guidelines ensure labs balance operational flexibility, pedagogical rigor, and security containment?ritical for training next-generation cybersecurity professionals.

To ensure broad compatibility with computer systems, our encryption utilizes the 256-character ASCII code, encompassing both the standard 128 ASCII characters and the extended 128 characters. This means the resulting ciphertext may contain standard characters as well as localized symbols and markings. Successful decryption with the correct key precisely recovers the original message, as demonstrated in Table I. Conversely, if an incorrect key is used, the recovered message will be garbled and consist of random characters within the extended ASCII range.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: While any device control parameter (bias current, feedback strength, or feedback phase) could theoretically serve as the hardware key, significant changes to bias current or feedback strength would noticeably alter chaotic attractor characteristics, potentially allowing detection by eavesdroppers through power or attractor changes. Conversely, variations in feedback phase remain undetectable when examining time series or RF spectra of the chaotic signal, as noted in reference [8]. Therefore, only feedback phase meets the requirements for a hardware key that produces untraceable changes in the transmitted signal.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: Meidan et al. [26] proposed an ML-based unauthorized IoT device detection method using TCP/IP network traffic data, training a random forest (RF) classifier on labeled data from nine IoT categories (17 devices) with 60 initially extracted features?ater refined by removing zero-variance, irrelevant, or overfitting-prone attributes. By excluding one device type as "unauthorized," they achieved 96% accuracy in identifying rogue devices, validated through cross-lab testing where a model trained on SimpleHomeXCS71001 security cameras (Lab A) successfully detected a different model (Withings WBP02WT9510) in Lab B, demonstrating transportability despite device variations.

The railway industry has rapidly adopted networked and computerized systems to enhance its operations, moving away from traditional electromechanical systems. This transition allows for greater flexibility and performance, enabling operators to provide additional services such as infotainment for passengers. The integration of computer-based systems facilitates the use of off-the-shelf components, significantly reducing costs and accelerating deployment timelines. As the industry approaches 2025, there is a strong emphasis on digital transformation aimed at improving customer service and operational efficiency. Rail operators are increasingly leveraging advanced technologies like artificial intelligence for predictive maintenance and big data analytics to optimize train schedules and enhance the overall passenger experience. This shift towards a fully digitized rail system not only aims to improve safety and reliability but also positions the railway sector as a competitive alternative to other modes of transportation, catering to the growing demand for efficient and sustainable travel solutions.

During a significant disturbance, such as a loss of generation, system frequency begins to drop. Generator governor responses attempt to counteract this decay. If the available spinning reserve is insufficient or the governor response is poor, the frequency continues to decline. When it reaches a certain threshold, up to 1150 MW of Load Resource as Ancillary Service (LaaR) can be tripped by high-set underfrequency relays to restore frequency. However, excessive load shedding may cause frequency overshoot, potentially triggering generator protection schemes and leading to cascading failures.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: This section shows that a market with bilateral contracts is possible. The main point is one of considering a type of “local supplementary control” on each generator involved in the bilat eral market. If the required technical conditions, which we will emphasize later, are satisfied, each of the generators will have a closed loop load following controller.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: Evaluating the reliability of an EIS requires assessing both the system's adequacy and its security response to various disturbances [3]. Current reliability methods use probabilistic models to represent disturbances but do not account for the stochastic behavior of the power system [4], instead analyzing the system only in steady-state conditions after disturbances have occurred [5]. Some of these methods include zone branch [6], cut set [7], go [8], and reliability block diagram [9]. However, these approaches fail to provide indicators that capture the EIS's temporal response to sudden disruptions.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Authentication is the process of confirming the identity of a user, device, or entity within a computer system. It is often a prerequisite for accessing system resources. Positive verification is achieved by matching an identity indicator, such as a shared secret established when the person was authorized to use the system. The most common user authenticator today is the password. An example of machine-to-machine authentication is the secure sockets layer (SSL).
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: In summary, unlike materials that focus solely on cybersecurity management or technical aspects within an ecosystem, training at this level presents challenges due to the diverse range of environments instructors must consider, from small businesses to large corporations and government infrastructure. While it may seem convenient to provide a checklist of technical topics, such an approach is ineffective in driving meaningful behavioral change. Although topics like secure remote access, patch management, change management, and the convergence of physical and cybersecurity are well-suited for checklists, they do not foster the necessary responsiveness in cybersecurity. Instead, research suggests that immersive experiences, such as simulations and live activities, are crucial for enhancing applied learning and improving real-world cybersecurity readiness.

The accelerated proliferation of electric vehicles (EVs) has precipitated a concomitant escalation in concerns regarding user privacy. A critical bottleneck in information dissemination manifests during vehicular charging processes and instances of user-software interaction. Specifically, vehicular actuators, responsible for the aggregation of sensitive data, present a vulnerability wherein compromise of said data directly infringes upon user privacy. Information exfiltration, encompassing location data, identification metrics, payment records, and driving patterns, poses a significant threat to individual privacy. For instance, in scholarly work [23], a comprehensive survey of existing methodologies addressing diverse privacy concerns within EVs and smart grid infrastructures is presented. Furthermore, in research [24], an innovative study was undertaken to elucidate the privacy challenges inherent in the interaction between EVs and Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment (EVSEs). Certain investigations have sought to ameliorate privacy concerns related to user payment transactions. For example, in study [25], a privacy-preserving authentication and payment protocol was developed, demonstrating a secure payment mechanism designed to safeguard user identification and privacy while maintaining the capacity for vehicular tracking in instances of theft. Moreover, user location privacy constitutes a critical concern, as examined in research [26]. Additionally, studies such as [27] and [28] have addressed authentication protocols for EVs connecting to power grid infrastructure. Consequently, a comprehensive assessment of EV information privacy is deemed requisite.

Cybersecurity intrusions in power systems are not just theoretical but have occurred in reality. According to a study by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) on cyber vulnerabilities in control systems, there have been numerous incidents causing damage to electric power control systems for transmission, distribution, and generation. While the research needs and requirements for the cybersecurity of power utilities and protection systems have been extensively discussed, the literature reporting concrete research results in this area is limited. Threats and countermeasures to the cybersecurity of power systems, including system configuration, security protocols, and cryptography, are introduced in [8] and [9]. Although a dedicated network is ideal for maintaining data confidentiality and integrity, it cannot prevent internal attacks.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: In MPSoC architectures based on NoC, these direct attacks to the communication subsystem will be unfeasible since there is no physical network access. The presence of an NoC also avoids the possibility of sniffing (or snooping) the information that is passing through the communication channel if the messages are not explicitly broadcast by the initiator of the communication. The only way to replicate the previous attacks in such systems is to use direct read/ write operations to the memory subsystem since it stores the system status.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text:
User authentication is part of the larger security system, which
can be described as strong or weak—relative terms that measure
the cost of attack versus the potential gain to the attacker. Different
authenticators offer strong or weak defenses against different types
of attack. Authenticators can be attacked at the client, in the transmission channel, and at the host. This discussion focuses on client
and host. To enhance security, different authenticator types may be
combined, a process called multifactor authentication. The paper
also describes how user authentication fits into full authentication
systems such as RADIUS, Kerberos, and SSO.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: The cost of producing electricity varies between power plants due to factors like size, fuel type, location, and age. As electricity demand increases, the price of electricity also increases until it matches the cost of the most expensive power plant supplying energy. If there's a shortage of electricity, whether real or intentionally created, prices can skyrocket because consumers will pay whatever price is demanded. During the California energy crisis in 2000, price limits were put in place to prevent price manipulation. However, this caused electricity prices to align with those limits, showing a simple form of price following. The blackouts imposed by California's grid operator indirectly made consumers more sensitive to retail prices. It's possible to manipulate the market to increase prices even in normal situations. For instance, a company with multiple power plants could set a very high price for one plant's output to try and raise the overall auction price.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text:
The idea of a preventive and reactive cyber defense
dynamics model was first introduced in [20] and partially
analyzed in [48], while noting that its special cases were
studied earlier in [33]?[35]. However, all these studies only
contribute a partial understanding of the dynamics corresponding to a special parameter regime rather than the entire
parameter universe. Very recently, it is proven that these
dynamics are globally convergent in the entire parameter
universe, meaning that there is always a unique equilibrium
[4], whose exact value (or position) depends on the parameter
values rather than the initial state of the dynamics.
Journal Name:
Using Event-Based Method to Estimate
Cybersecurity Equilibrium

Text: This letter presents a novel asymmetric watermarking system capable of embedding multiple watermarks while requiring only a single reference watermark for detection. This approach is beneficial in thwarting attacks aimed at estimating the embedded watermark. The system involves randomly shifting the phase of the reference watermark in the discrete Fourier transform domain to create the embedding watermarks. These embedding watermarks are correlated with each other and share the same correlation with the reference watermark. Additionally, the letter discusses the selection of design parameters for the system.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Security in communication systems is often mistakenly linked directly to receiver architecture, but it is actually related to the difficulty of extracting the message from a chaotic carrier without authorized access. There are two types of attacks: software attacks, which require precise signal sampling (often in picoseconds) to perform time series analysis and potentially extract the message, and hardware attacks, where an unauthorized receiver mimics the authorized one. However, replicating the exact specifications of the authorized receiver is challenging due to the need for precise laser parameters and operating conditions. An open-loop receiver might be the easiest choice for such an attack, but it is less effective if the encoded message amplitude is sufficiently small.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text:
Various studies that aimed at exchanging cybersecurityrelated information among parties have been reported. These
include industry specifications defining information schemata
and cybersecurity-related ontologies. There are also many
guidelines that define common vocabulary and frameworks
to be shared among parties. Cybersecurity information
repositories are also available online, and they can share
a variety of information with many parties. Although the
proposed ontology is not particularly based on any of these
works, they were useful in defining the ontology and provided
a basis for its consideration.
Journal Name:
Reference Ontology for Cybersecurity
Operational Information

Text: The security vulnerabilities of IoT devices, due to inadequate cybersecurity measures, make their timely identification and detection essential. Machine learning (ML) models have significantly advanced in monitoring network devices, but many profiling and identification approaches suffer from poor performance when faced with slight data variations. To address this, a transferability approach based on transductive transfer learning is proposed for IoT device profiling and identification. This approach assigns labels to test data in the target domain by leveraging training data from a source domain. The system consists of three components: device type identification, vulnerability assessment, and visualization. The first component applies transductive transfer learning by transferring trained models to a remote lab for testing. Various ML models are evaluated based on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score to determine their suitability. The second component assesses device vulnerabilities using databases like Vulners, the National Vulnerability Database (NVD), and IBM X-Force. The final component visualizes and displays the vulnerability assessment results on a dashboard.

The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into modern transportation ecosystems necessitates their participation in sophisticated interconnected frameworks, most notably Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs) [36]. These intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) establish multimodal connectivity paradigms, engaging in bidirectional communication with neighboring vehicles, roadside infrastructure, and pedestrian devices through diverse transmission protocols, encompassing the comprehensive V2X spectrum (incorporating Vehicle-to-Network [V2N], Vehicle-to-Vehicle [V2V], Vehicle-to-Infrastructure [V2I], and Vehicle-to-Pedestrian [V2P] modalities) alongside Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC) standards. Nevertheless, this expanded connectivity surface introduces substantial technical complexity and elevates cybersecurity risks [37], as exemplified by scholarly investigations including [38], which provides a comparative analysis of DSRC and Cellular-V2X (C-V2X) technological implementations and their respective architectural frameworks for V2X data exchange. Complementary research in [39] systematically traces the developmental trajectory of V2X communication protocols for ICVs while introducing emergent Internet of Vehicles (IoV) paradigms. The vulnerability landscape of ICVs manifests through multiple attack vectors, including but not limited to: adversarial exploitation of traffic signal control systems [40], communication channel interception and manipulation [41], and sensor spoofing incidents, compounded by persistent security and privacy challenges inherent to both C-V2X and DSRC transmission methodologies [42]. The imperative nature of V2X communication security has prompted extensive academic scrutiny of systemic vulnerabilities within intelligent transportation architectures. However, the cyber-physical duality intrinsic to ICVs substantially amplifies their exposure to multifaceted security breaches [43], where threat actors may potentially compromise vehicular power distribution networks or electronic control units (ECUs), thereby endangering pedestrian safety through deployment of malicious payloads, malware infiltration, arbitrary code execution exploits, or deliberate sabotage of battery management systems and controller modules [44]. Consequently, the development of robust security frameworks must holistically address both the physical operational parameters and digital communication dimensions of ICVs to ensure the integrity and safety of next-generation electric mobility infrastructures.

The use of ML for detecting malicious URLs has proved
to be effective through detecting newly formed URLs and
the automatic update of the model. Recent studies have
explored DL models that use an approach to automatically
detect newly formed URLs and extract the features. In this
way, researchers can extract many features from URLs that
help ML algorithms categorize the URL as malicious or
benign. The most common features extracted from the URLs
are lexical, content-based, and network-based, as described
next.
Journal Name:
Detecting Malicious URLs Using Machine Learning
Techniques: Review and Research Directions

Text: Cybersecurity training is essential for the military's transition to a fully cyberized force, with efforts to develop specialized systems like the SIMTEX (Simulator Training Exercise Network). Initially designed for the U.S. Air Force, SIMTEX has become a key platform for military cybersecurity exercises such as Black Daemon and Cyber Flag, providing virtualized environments to simulate information assets targeted by cyberattacks. Through its capabilities, SIMTEX facilitates isolated attack simulations via VPN tunnels, enhancing the realism of training scenarios. As the military increasingly recognizes the importance of cybersecurity, it relies on comprehensive training programs that equip personnel with necessary skills to defend against evolving threats. This includes building awareness of phishing tactics, secure communication practices, and incident response strategies, which are critical in safeguarding sensitive information and maintaining operational security. By investing in such training systems, the military aims to bolster its defenses against cyber threats that are becoming more sophisticated and pervasive.

The trading process described earlier occurs over multiple iterations, offering an alternative to spot markets for arranging short-term contracts. For instance, the TSP can set a time frame for agents to submit bids for the day-ahead power market. During this period, multiple iterations of the trading process allow agents to buy or sell power by finding suitable trading partners. This iterative approach enables flexible and dynamic market interactions.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: In this paper, based on Schnorr’s digital signature protocol and one-way hash function, we proposed a key exchange protocol for the secure communication between smart card and STB in DTV broadcasting, which has the following merits: security, dynamic session key, mutual authentication, lower computation and communication and freely password for user. Moreover, the proposed scheme can prevent two serious problems in DTV broadcasting, that is, smart cloning and MacCormac Hack problems.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: Referring to the Italian blackout on September 28, 2003, Carson? question provides an opportunity to reaffirm that AVR line-drop compensation was in operation in the Northwest region of Italy instead of SVR. This was due to the activation of the new SCADA/EMS system at the Regional Dispatcher control room. Recent studies indicate that, aside from the issue of line overloading, the voltage collapse could have been prevented?hus avoiding generator tripping due to low voltage and the widespread blackout?f the SVR had been functioning in that extensive area near the French border.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: This paper presents the novel AAMD-OELAC framework, the first intelligent Android malware detection system combining tri-model ensemble learning (LS-SVM, KELM, and RRVFLN) with Hunter-Prey Optimization (HPO) for automated hyperparameter tuning, operating through three key phases: (1) data preprocessing for feature refinement, (2) collaborative ensemble analysis, and (3) bio-inspired parameter optimization. Our comprehensive literature review confirms this specific integration of machine learning models with metaheuristic optimization represents an unprecedented approach in cybersecurity research, addressing critical gaps in detecting evolving malware variants through its adaptive multi-stage architecture. The framework demonstrates superior detection capabilities by synergistically combining the complementary strengths of multiple classifiers while dynamically optimizing their parameters to counter sophisticated evasion techniques prevalent in modern Android threats.

The transformative capabilities of AI have successfully supplanted conventional rule-based systems with adaptive intelligence, yet this technological progress has simultaneously empowered cyber adversaries to develop increasingly sophisticated attack methodologies?hereas historical cyber threats primarily involved high-volume but relatively simplistic intrusion attempts, the integration of AI/ML tools has fundamentally altered the threat landscape by enabling automated, evolving attack vectors that enhance malicious capabilities, as demonstrated by recent cases where generative AI systems have been weaponized for both defensive and offensive cybersecurity purposes, drawing significant attention from security researchers who must now contend with AI-powered threats that dynamically adapt to bypass traditional protection mechanisms while also leveraging these same technologies to develop advanced detection systems and countermeasures.

Undoubtedly, the evolution of Generative AI (GenAI) models has been the highlight of digital
transformation in the year 2022. As the different GenAI models like ChatGPT and Google Bard continue
to foster their complexity and capability, it?s critical to understand its consequences from a cybersecurity
perspective. Several instances recently have demonstrated the use of GenAI tools in both the defensive and
offensive side of cybersecurity, and focusing on the social, ethical and privacy implications this technology
possesses. This research paper highlights the limitations, challenges, potential risks, and opportunities of
GenAI in the domain of cybersecurity and privacy. The work presents the vulnerabilities of ChatGPT, which
can be exploited by malicious users to exfiltrate malicious information bypassing the ethical constraints
on the model. This paper demonstrates successful example attacks like Jailbreaks, reverse psychology, and
prompt injection attacks on the ChatGPT. The paper also investigates how cyber offenders can use the GenAI
tools in developing cyber attacks, and explore the scenarios where ChatGPT can be used by adversaries to
create social engineering attacks, phishing attacks, automated hacking, attack payload generation, malware
creation, and polymorphic malware. This paper then examines defense techniques and uses GenAI tools to
improve security measures, including cyber defense automation, reporting, threat intelligence, secure code
generation and detection, attack identification, developing ethical guidelines, incidence response plans, and
malware detection. We will also discuss the social, legal, and ethical implications of ChatGPT. In conclusion,
the paper highlights open challenges and future directions to make this GenAI secure, safe, trustworthy, and
ethical as the community understands its cybersecurity impacts
Journal Name:
From ChatGPT to ThreatGPT: Impact of
Generative AI in Cybersecurity and Privacy

Text: A primary objective of this research was to propose methods for modifying participant behavior, directing them towards actions that bolster cybersecurity. Within the cybersecurity domain, enhancing awareness of information assurance principles and modulating behaviors is frequently more efficacious than disseminating an excessive volume of unapplied information. Furthermore, the inculcation of affirmative behaviors through best practice methodologies is demonstrably advantageous. Given the rapid evolution of preventative measures, it is imperative that learning materials are designed to be actionable, while maintaining a reasonable lifespan prior to obsolescence.

A cyber-net is a composite model that is formulated by the combination of the firewall and password models. These sub models are used for the analysis of a compromised SCADA system. A cyber-net based on the computer network connec tivity is illustrated in Fig. 7. The cyber-net contains modules representing several networks located at the power plant (bold faced in Fig. 7), substation, distribution operating center, and a control center. Within each module, the firewall and password models for that network are shown.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text:
Cybersecurity lies at the confluence of several disciplines,
including computer science, engineering, information systems,
networks, cryptology, human factors, and policy [1]. To identify its core concepts, the large number and variety of potential
topics motivates a selection process that incorporates multiple
expert perspectives and systematically distills the results. This
paper presents and analyzes results from a pair of Delphi
processes that were carried out in fall 2014 to identify core
concepts for cybersecurity.
Journal Name:
Identifying Core Concepts of Cybersecurity:
Results of Two Delphi Processes

Text: Concurrently, within the private sector, a surge of research initiatives has focused on developing increasingly sophisticated training systems, aimed at fulfilling the more foundational and enduring requisites of cybersecurity education, these contemporary systems incorporate features such as graphical user interfaces for training environment configuration, autonomous red/blue team agents, and automated scoring mechanisms, however, limitations persist in privately developed cybersecurity trainers, characterized by the incomplete integration of these features, thereby impeding the provision of comprehensive and practically applicable cybersecurity training, to address these deficiencies, this study introduces ICSTASY, an innovative cybersecurity training platform designed to furnish holistic support for a diverse array of training functionalities.

Current security systems that automatically identify individuals typically rely on tokens of private knowledge, like passwords, or private possessions, such as smart cards. These tokens are insecure because they can be lost, shared, stolen, or duplicated. In contrast, biometric authentication methods, which use physiological and behavioral characteristics like the iris, retina, fingerprint, palmprint, signature, or gait [2], offer greater security. However, they are not completely invulnerable, as they can still be susceptible to database, replay, and brute force attacks.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: This article aims to delineate the factors influencing the cyber-preparedness of Social Enterprises (SEs) within the U.K. To achieve this objective, the article systematically identifies and analyzes factors that facilitate and impede SEs' preparedness to address cybercrime. The subsequent structure of this article is as follows: initially, a review of existing cybercrime literature is presented, followed by the formulation of key issues and SE characteristics into a conceptual framework and corresponding research questions. Subsequently, the study's methodologies are detailed, and the analytical findings are presented. Finally, the article concludes with statements of contributions and recommendations for future research.

Mouheb et al.'s 2019 study [27] exposed significant fragmentation in cybersecurity education, revealing that universities design curricula along three isolated tracks?cademic (theory-focused), industrial (practice-oriented), and defense (national security-aligned)?ased on institutional priorities rather than standardized workforce needs, resulting in misaligned graduate competencies; this siloed approach, where 78% of programs lack alignment with frameworks like NICE and 63% omit industry practicums, underscores the urgent need for hybrid curricula integrating NICE Framework benchmarks, real-world attack simulations, sector-specific modules, and rotational industry residencies to bridge the global skills gap.

The main objective of the NICE framework is to deliver
a unified lexicon for defining different cybersecurity work
roles. To this end, the framework classifies the work
duties into seven main categories. Furthermore, the NICE
framework divides these 7 categories into specialty areas
