When a button is pressed, the corresponding function screen appears, as shown in Fig. 12.The application program can control appliances individually or manage multiple devices simultaneously through a scenario mode. For instance, activating the "movie" scenario mode can automatically close the electric curtains, turn off the lights, and switch on the DVD player with a single button press.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: In the restructured ERCOT market, load participation is seen as a way to boost competition, reduce unjustified price spikes, improve demand-side responsiveness to wholesale price signals, and maintain system reliability.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text:
We hope that the proposed system will effectively prevent 
any confidential file loss via USB removable storage devices. 
Thus, in our protocol design, file transfer via the USB 
interface is blocked unless the user first passes the remote 
server authentication procedure, and all files transmitted to the 
storage device are encrypted with the key K. Consequently, if 
users want to obtain the original file on another computer, 
they must pass the same verification procedure and acquire the 
same key K for decrypting the file. The key K is generated in 
accordance with the user id and the filename Fn, so different 
files or users produce different keys.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: Further improvements can be accomplished by defining other metrics for the selection of the most reliable signature traits, less affecting the entropy of the employed binary representation and providing higher resilience to privacy attacks, as well as by using different functions to represent the acquired on-line signatures.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: Historically, power system engineers relied on manual inspections and fault analysis software to locate transmission line faults after protective relays triggered. While sometimes adequate, these methods were often time-consuming and complex. Delays in fault identification and repair can jeopardize power system security, stability, and reliability, impacting a utility's ability to provide consistent power. The advent of microprocessor-based monitoring and protection systems [1], [2] has revolutionized fault location. These technologies capture and store detailed system data, enabling engineers to develop rapid and efficient methods for pinpointing transmission line shunt faults, moving away from older, less efficient practices.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: The comparative test data from our experiment are presented in Figure 4. The results show that the new position sensor detected background vibrations in our research laboratory, where the 'hybrid SM-3' was securely fastened to the tile floor on the second floor. These vibrations had a frequency of about 400 Hz, corresponding to mechanical floor vibrations with an amplitude of 40 nm. Figure 4(a) reveals that the background vibrations in the research building are nearly four times greater on weekdays compared to weekends and nights. However, even nighttime vibrations are 50?100 times larger than the noise level of the test oscillator, which is approximately 1?2 Hz, as shown in Figure 4(b).
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: While previous research has significantly contributed to the understanding of security standards adoption and implementation, gaps remain in optimizing compliance efforts. Identifying similarities between standards allows organizations to eliminate redundant tasks, streamline compliance processes, and reduce both implementation time and associated costs. This research aims to provide a comprehensive evaluation of widely adopted security standards across key industry sectors, highlighting the advantages of recognizing their commonalities.

This study employed two Delphi processes to establish consensus among cybersecurity experts on the discipline? core educational concepts, addressing the lack of standardized foundational knowledge despite growing demand for professionals. The first process identified entry-level concepts for introductory courses (Cybersecurity Concept Inventory, CCI), emphasizing adversarial thinking?easoning about attacker motives and defenses?s a critical skill alongside authentication, encryption, and risk management. The second process defined advanced concepts for graduating professionals (Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment, CCA), prioritizing topics like secure coding, network defense, and threat modeling. Experts rated topics by importance, difficulty, and timelessness, revealing key barriers (e.g., complex cryptography) and guiding curriculum prioritization. Results highlighted a consensus to exclude ethics/communication skills from core technical assessments, focusing instead on adversarial scenarios. These findings enable evidence-based educational tools, such as standardized assessments and curricula, to accelerate rigorous training aligned with frameworks like NICE and IEEE/ACM guidelines. By leveraging the Delphi method? iterative expert feedback, the study provides a structured foundation to unify cybersecurity education across disciplines, bridging gaps between academic instruction and real-world professional demands.

Regarding the BPA's use of advanced high-side voltage control with cross-current compensation, my comment is as follows: If the controlled voltage is between the EHV bus and the stator edge of the generator, the result is interesting but not optimal in terms of system support and voltage stability. Furthermore, when these regulators are extensively applied, they will require coordination of their set-points through a wide-area voltage regulator to prevent incorrect reactive power flow and enhance stability. Therefore, the need for Secondary Voltage Regulation (SVR) increases when aiming to achieve high-side voltage control effectively.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: We have identified the requirements for protecting content rights in DBHS and developed a DRM system that fulfills these needs. Additionally, we have proposed a method for multiplexing scramble keys in sync with the video packet of MPEG-2 TS, confirming that trick-play functions can be maintained at the same level as with non-encrypted content. Our innovative DRM system allows for conventional viewing during broadcast reception and provides usage control for viewing after storage. This system is also well-suited for broadcasting, enabling one-to-many content transmission.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Generative AI tools like ChatGPT represent a dual-use paradigm in cybersecurity, offering defenders powerful capabilities?ncluding enhanced threat intelligence through analysis of massive vulnerability datasets, automated processing of security logs and network traffic for accelerated incident response, improved security awareness training against sophisticated attacks, and AI-assisted secure code generation with vulnerability testing?hile simultaneously providing attackers with sophisticated new vectors for exploitation, as these same LLM technologies trained on cybersecurity data can be repurposed to identify system weaknesses, craft advanced social engineering campaigns, and automate malicious code development, creating an ongoing arms race that demands continuous advancement of defensive AI systems alongside robust ethical frameworks to govern their responsible deployment in cyber operations.

The Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed global connectivity by integrating people, smart devices, intelligent objects, and vast amounts of data. Although still in its early stages, IoT presents significant opportunities to enhance accessibility, integrity, availability, scalability, confidentiality, and interoperability. However, ensuring its security remains a major challenge, as system security serves as the foundation for IoT? continued development. This article provides a systematic review of IoT cybersecurity, focusing on the protection and integration of diverse smart devices and information communication technologies (ICT). It offers valuable insights for researchers and practitioners by examining current IoT security research, architecture and taxonomy, key countermeasures, industrial applications, and emerging trends and challenges in the field.

The recently published report on "Definition and Classification of Power System Stability" is highly appreciated for its well-established and thorough definitions of existing stability concepts. The report accurately identifies key instability phenomena, including rotor angle, voltage, and frequency instability. However, emerging trends suggest that an additional instability category might be necessary to fully account for all real-world power system instability scenarios.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: A noteworthy scenario from the December 22 event illustrates that frequency is not uniform throughout the system during disturbances. As shown in Figure 5, only certain LaaRs—those with faster breakers and proximity to the fault location—tripped when the system reached a frequency of 59.7 Hz, successfully arresting the frequency decline. Other LaaRs with slower breaker operation times located farther from the fault did not activate through the high-set underfrequency relay. To restore the system frequency to its nominal value (60 Hz), operators manually commanded these remaining LaaRs to trip within 10 minutes. Figure 5 effectively demonstrates that system frequency varies across different locations during disturbances rather than being uniform throughout the entire system.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Indeed, definition of protection zones fordistance relays is the most important theory in order to specify the operating se quences of protections (main and back-up) in power transmis sion systems using PNs [13], [21]–[23].

Text: Security, in this context, refers to a power system's capacity to withstand sudden disruptions without losing power supply. Security analysis must therefore identify scenarios where the system's response is inadequate, where unnecessary activation of protective devices occurs, or where subsystems malfunction during disruptions. Any of these issues can degrade power quality and reliability, creating risks for both the electrical infrastructure and associated industrial operations.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text:
An electronic dialing circuit attached to home telephone
can be triggered by exerting actuating signal obtained from
any type of detector circuit[9]. The actuating signal given to it
does two things; i. it operates a relay circuit to close the
cradle for a pre-determined time so as to receive dial tone and
to commence dialing, ii. it provides enable signal to a
sequential logic circuit that injects the series of pulses
corresponding to chosen digits into the telephone lines. We
now use this facility to dial the digits of resident’s mobile
number whenever fire detector is activated. Upon detecting
fire it actuates the circuit to give a call and the call reaches the
resident’s mobile giving ring. Instantly, the resident knows
that call arrives from home and understands that there is fire
in his home. He immediately dials back to home telephone
with additional digit as described in section II.B where the
telephone has a relay board extension to control selected
appliances. Receiving the additional digit in home telephone
is arranged to switch ON a relay circuit as to operate a
solenoid valve triggering a fire extinguisher
electromechanically. The fire extinguisher is kept at chosen
location inside the flat and it can be set to operate manually
also. If in case the resident is inside home and receives the call
from his home telephone in his mobile he can opt to
extinguish fire manually or by giving a ring.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

These findings are then used in Section III to design impulsive control laws for nonlinear systems. The note concludes with a summary in Section IV.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

In these simulations, the current measurements of a non-fault feeder are set to zero. A total of 168 real faults with a non-fault feeder out of service and 108 fake faults with amplified single- or three-phase current are generated to test the performance of the proposed PNN.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: Model Reference Adaptive Control (MRAC) is a prominent approach in adaptive control systems. It involves defining the desired performance through a reference model, which specifies the ideal response to an input signal. The adjustment mechanism in MRAC modifies the regulator's parameters to minimize the error between the actual system output and the reference model's output. When this error is reduced to zero, the system achieves perfect model following.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: Since the necessary historical data for the proposed algorithms is unavailable, conducting a meaningful simulation is not feasible. However, the outlined steps suggest that the MMB can oversee the market, balancing the interests of participants with system reliability and security requirements. Given that reliability data significantly impacts spinning reserve prices, market players might view such information as proprietary. Nevertheless, the MMB could collect and utilize reliability data to enhance system security and regulate energy services, as described in the proposed framework.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text:
The MRAC is one of the major approaches in adaptive control. The desired performance is expressed as a reference model,
which gives the wished response to an input signal. The adjustment mechanism changes the parameters of the regulator by
minimizing the error between the system output and the reference model. If the error is equal to zero, then the perfect model
following is achieved.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: The ethical framework, which establishes standards for morally acceptable conduct, plays a pivotal role in cybersecurity due to its direct impact on individual well-being; within the cybersecurity domain, ethical principles are foundational to responsible technological implementation, safeguarding individuals and promoting their welfare [1, 2, 3, 4]; despite the seemingly simplistic ethical mandate of data protection and unauthorized access prevention, the intricacies of cybersecurity ethics are substantial [5]; this study presents the findings of a comprehensive Horizon Scanning initiative, designed to identify prospective and evolving ethical considerations within the realm of cybersecurity.

User authentication is a component of a broader security system, which can be classified as strong or weak based on the cost of an attack relative to the potential gain for the attacker. Various authenticators provide different levels of defense against specific attack types, which can target the client, transmission channel, or host. This discussion primarily examines client and host vulnerabilities. To strengthen security, multiple authenticator types can be combined through multifactor authentication. Additionally, the paper explores how user authentication integrates into comprehensive authentication systems such as RADIUS, Kerberos, and SSO.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: Similar to the approach taken in [7], this note examines the impulsive control of nonlinear systems. We first establish a novel comparison theorem. Using this framework for impulsive differential systems, we derive stability conditions that are less restrictive for impulsive systems with impulses occurring at fixed times. These conditions are then employed to design impulsive control laws for a specific class of nonlinear systems. Our methodology extends to a broader range of nonlinear systems and contributes to advancements in chaotic secure communication and chaotic spread spectrum communication technologies [8]–[13].
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: In the face of complex cybersecurity threats, organizations must adhere to robust security frameworks to protect their systems effectively. This research introduces an innovative approach that integrates the National Cybersecurity Authority's Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC) with the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. The objective is to align regulated cybersecurity controls with practical workforce deployment, ensuring that organizations can comply with necessary regulations while optimizing their cybersecurity personnel. A systematic process is employed to match specific tasks within the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework to the controls mandated by the National Cybersecurity Authority. Central to this research is an optimization model designed to identify the most critical job roles needed to meet these Essential Cybersecurity Controls efficiently and cost-effectively. The findings indicate that certain roles within the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework are pivotal for addressing multiple Essential Cybersecurity Controls, underscoring their strategic significance in enhancing cybersecurity operations. This study lays a foundation for future research in optimizing cybersecurity workforce deployment and provides a framework for organizations to adapt their cybersecurity strategies in alignment with regulatory requirements, thereby strengthening their overall security posture.

In the private sector, there has been a surge in research aimed at developing comprehensive cybersecurity training systems to meet long-term training needs. These modern systems often feature user-friendly graphical interfaces for environment configuration, autonomous red and blue team agents, and automated scoring mechanisms. However, many privately developed cybersecurity training platforms face limitations due to the lack of full integration among these features, which hampers their ability to deliver thorough and practical training experiences. To address these challenges, we introduce ICSTASY, a novel cybersecurity training platform designed to provide holistic support across various training capabilities. ICSTASY aims to create a more cohesive and effective training environment that not only enhances the skills of cybersecurity professionals but also prepares them for real-world challenges in an increasingly complex threat landscape. By integrating diverse training features into a unified system, ICSTASY seeks to elevate the standard of cybersecurity education and readiness in both private and public sectors.

The proposed circuit consists of approximately 20 CMOS gates along with several passive components. It operates with a 5V supply voltage for the astable multivibrator, a 16 MHz clock frequency for the 1-bit counter, and generates random numbers at a bit rate of 50 kb/s. Measurements were conducted at room temperature. Since this RNG uses discrete components, its supply voltage is higher than what is ideal for mobile applications. However, by optimizing the fabrication process, the voltage can be reduced to 1.5V or even lower. Additionally, this random number generation method is versatile and can be adapted to use other randomly fluctuating signals besides MOS-SBD signals, provided they have a sufficiently large amplitude.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

systems as in [6]. We first derive some less conservative conditions

Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: A significant concern is that the problem's dimension becomes extremely large after adding loadflow equation and operating limit constraints for each post-contingency state. In previous research [4], researchers employed a decomposition solution method where post-contingency states were solved separately from the pre-contingency state through an iterative process. This approach would enable simultaneous computation of each post-contingency problem on different machines. Additional research is needed to explore how this technique could be applied to the PDIP algorithm.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: The global demand for cybersecurity experts has prompted standard bodies and governments to continuously monitor workforce requirements and initiate framework developments. Notably, the World Economic Forum highlights a pressing need for 4 million additional cybersecurity professionals to address the talent gap, which could escalate to 85 million by 2030, potentially resulting in $8.5 trillion in unrealized annual revenue. In response to this urgent need, various initiatives have emerged, including the NICE Framework, which categorizes cybersecurity work roles and outlines the necessary skills and knowledge for each position. Despite these efforts, many universities have not yet established active collaborations with the industrial sector, leading to concerns that graduates may lack the skills required by employers. Reports indicate that while the cybersecurity workforce grew by 12.6% between 2022 and 2023, significant gaps remain, emphasizing the necessity for cohesive partnerships between academia and industry to ensure that educational programs align with current workforce demands and effectively prepare students for careers in this critical field.

Next, we will examine the synchronization of two Chua's circuits, referred to as the driving system and the driven system in references7 and14. In this impulsive synchronization setup, the driving system is described by equation (1), while the driven system is described by equation (9).
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text:
In the proposed protocol, a user must use a password to achieve mutual authentication with an authentication server. Without this legal authentication process, the system will not allow access to a USB port. Once authentication is successful, the user and server negotiate a key to encrypt/decrypt files transmitted via the USB port. This ensures that the data transmitted in communication channels and stored on USB devices is protected by the negotiated key.
For remote authentication, the protocol adopts the digital signature scheme proposed by Schnorr in 1989. The key feature of this scheme is that the parameters \( e \) and \( s \) are calculated and saved, requiring only one modular multiplication and one modular addition during signing. This method is cost-effective compared to other digital signature schemes. The signature length in Schnorr's scheme is \( |e| + |s| \). If the order of the cyclic group is approximately \( 2^{160} \) and the hash function output length is 160 bits, the signature length is 320 bits (160 bits + 160 bits).
In comparison, the RSA cryptosystem has a signature length of \( |n| = 1024 \) bits, and the ElGamal system has a signature length of \( 2 \times |p| = 2048 \) bits. Schnorr's digital signature scheme is relatively short and suitable for environments requiring high efficiency and convenience.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: Malware invasive methods have evolved to evade detection, with many malware applications employing over 50 parameters, complicating the identification process. This necessitates the development of techniques capable of addressing the continuous growth of Android malware to effectively find, deactivate, or remove it. Consequently, researchers have established three primary mechanisms for detecting Android malware: dynamic, static, and hybrid analysis methods. Static analysis allows for feature extraction to identify harmful behaviors without deploying the application, but it is vulnerable to code obfuscation techniques that aid malware authors in avoiding detection. In contrast, dynamic analysis assesses malware during runtime, providing insights into its behavior in a live environment. Both approaches expose Android developers and users to unnecessary risks from malware. To enhance detection capabilities, machine learning (ML) models are employed to analyze Android Application Packages (APKs) and derive relevant features for recognizing malicious applications. Deep learning (DL) and ML techniques are increasingly utilized for this purpose, with the detection process involving training on derived attributes to identify vulnerable code segments through code analysis. The integration of these methodologies aims to improve the accuracy and reliability of malware detection in the ever-evolving landscape of Android threats.

Since the inception of blockchain technology [9], its application has expanded across diverse domains, including cybersecurity [9], artificial intelligence [10], decentralized storage [11], and cryptocurrency and payment systems [12]. A blockchain-based methodology for data storage and sharing offers significant advantages for cybersecurity. Through integrated cryptography and consensus mechanisms, blockchain technology ensures transparency, confidentiality, and data integrity, eliminating the need for third-party involvement. The immutability of blockchain renders the modification of ledgers in a manner not immediately visible to all users computationally complex. This solution facilitates the creation of a transparent, distributed, traceable, and absolute audit trail. Consequently, blockchain technology possesses multiple attributes that may contribute to the resolution of cybersecurity challenges. The integration of AI and blockchain within cybersecurity frameworks can yield innovative solutions that strengthen the overall security posture of organizations. One such approach involves the development of decentralized AI models operating on a blockchain network, enabling secure and transparent processing of sensitive data and providing a tamper-proof model.

IoT devices face significant security challenges due to their limited power consumption, memory, and processing capabilities, which restrict their ability to implement robust security measures compared to traditional computers. This makes them particularly vulnerable to various attacks, as they often lack adequate encryption, authentication, and access control mechanisms. Machine learning (ML) models have advanced in monitoring these devices and differentiating between normal and illegitimate ones; however, most research relies on the same data for both training and testing, which can lead to poor performance with minor data changes. To address these issues, it is crucial to develop effective cybersecurity strategies that consider the unique constraints of IoT devices while leveraging ML techniques for better profiling and identification of threats.

This article compares the impacts of various information systems (IS) sourcing strategies on organizational cybersecurity breaches. Through a longitudinal empirical analysis, we
found that when the organization has a narrower spread of IT
applications, a best of breed (BoB) strategy is less likely to cause
cybersecurity breaches than a single-sourcing approach; and the
difference is decreasing as its IT application spread increases. The
insourcing strategy has shown a lower likelihood of organizational
cybersecurity breaches than any outsourcing strategy [i.e., singlesourcing, best of suite (BoS), and BoB], which is weakened by
the organization?s IT application spread and is significant only
when the IT application spread is relatively low. A BoS strategy
has an insignificant difference in cybersecurity breaches compared
to the BoB approach. However, for organizations with a broader
spread of IT applications, there is no significant difference among
all sourcing strategies on the likelihood of cybersecurity breaches.
This research provides theoretical and practical implications for
organizational cybersecurity management in IS development and
interorganizational relationships.
Journal Name:
Information Systems Sourcing Strategies and
Organizational Cybersecurity Breaches

Text: The single-sourcing approach centralizes all IT system integration, maintenance, and troubleshooting responsibilities with a single vendor, significantly reducing the need for extensive in-house IT expertise within client organizations [4]. This model simplifies contract management by consolidating agreements into a single, high-stakes vendor relationship, as opposed to managing multiple vendor contracts [20][21]. However, this convenience comes at the cost of heightened operational dependency, as the organization? IT functionality, system effectiveness, and overall performance become critically tied to the vendor? capabilities and reliability [16]. While this reduces internal staffing burdens, it also introduces systemic risk, as any vendor shortcomings or failures could disproportionately disrupt the client? operations due to the lack of alternative support structures.

Organizations that adopt a single-sourcing strategy often find that their system usage does not align well with existing business processes, necessitating significant efforts to reengineer these processes, adapt policies, and implement new standards for system use. In contrast, a Best of Breed (BoB) approach allows organizations to select information systems vendors that better fit their established routines and policies. The changes required by single sourcing can introduce security vulnerabilities, as malicious actors may exploit weaknesses during the process redesign, while employees may inadvertently make security mistakes due to the challenges associated with adapting to new systems. This highlights the importance of carefully considering sourcing strategies to mitigate risks and maintain alignment with organizational objectives.

This paper will proceed in the following manner: First, a novel comparison theorem and a set of conditions for the stability of impulsive differential systems will be introduced. These findings will then be used to create an impulsive control strategy for nonlinear systems. The paper will conclude with a summary of the main points.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: We also investigated the number of different passwords respondents use for online activities such as banking, social media, and online shopping. Among respondents from the UAE region, the majority (49.7%) reported using three to four passwords for these purposes. This finding suggests a common pattern in password usage habits within the region.

Load resources that can provide regulation services by adjusting their consumption under dispatch control—similar to AGC—and responding instantly to frequency changes, like generator governor action, are classified as Controllable Load Resources (CLD) within LaaR service. In ERCOT’s current market framework, ERCOT sends generation control signals to QSEs based on real-time system area control errors to maintain the target system frequency. Each QSE then independently dispatches its units to meet these control requirements, as ERCOT does not directly regulate individual unit output. This control approach applies to both generators and loads, provided that the load can adjust its consumption in response to the generation control signal. Figure 2 presents a real-world example of CLD responding to a QSE dispatch signal, demonstrating its ability to precisely modify load consumption based on the QSE’s control instructions. As a result, CLD offers a valuable mechanism for load entities to support system security by adhering to AGC and governor control.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: The security of certain DDF systems is vulnerable to exploitation. Attackers can deduce system parameters by analyzing time-series data if assumptions about the nonlinear feedback element’s functional form are made. Many optoelectronic and all-electronic DDF implementations use fixed nonlinearities with predefined mathematical structures, making them susceptible to curve-fitting attacks when the functional form is known. Research demonstrates that DDF chaotic systems can be breached using such algorithms. Additionally, cracking methods rely on identifying the system’s time delay, but modulating this delay has been shown to enhance security.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: We have introduced an innovative digital chaotic secure communication system that utilizes a "magnifying glass" concept to amplify observed errors caused by parameter mismatches, along with an impulsive control strategy employing piecewise-constant intervals to synchronize chaotic circuits. This system combines elements of traditional cryptographic methods with chaotic secure communication techniques. The proposed system demonstrates high sensitivity to parameter mismatches, enhancing its security.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: Before exploring the solution to the ESCOPF (Economic Security-Constrained Optimal Power Flow) problem for this case, let us first consider the solution to the simpler OPF problem, which does not account for system security. The objective of the OPF problem is to minimize system operating costs without considering the costs associated with potential contingencies. In other words, the OPF assumes that the probability of a contingency occurring is effectively zero.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: We propose a new password authentication scheme based on Hopfield Neural Networks (HNN). While maintaining generality, this scheme can be used to verify user IDs and passwords. It is applicable to various access control scenarios for computing resources, such as granting permissions for multiple server access [9] or implementing role-based security controls [12]. The authentication scheme consists of three main procedures: registration, log-in authorization, and password change.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Spear phishing attacks represent a sophisticated form of social engineering wherein threat actors meticulously research potential victims to craft highly personalized and seemingly legitimate emails, often spoofing trusted senders in the "from" field to enhance credibility. These targeted campaigns differ from conventional phishing attempts through their tailored approach, exploiting human psychology rather than technical vulnerabilities to deceive recipients into compromising sensitive information. The attackers' preparatory work typically involves gathering intelligence about the victim's organizational role, communication patterns, and professional relationships to construct convincing narratives that bypass traditional email security filters. This method's effectiveness stems from its ability to manipulate fundamental human tendencies toward trust and authority, particularly when the malicious communication appears to originate from known contacts or reputable institutions. The growing prevalence of such attacks underscores the critical need for comprehensive user awareness training alongside technical safeguards to mitigate this persistent threat vector.

Recent reports from various global associations and European organizations emphasize the pressing challenges in cybersecurity education, highlighting the need for redesigning educational pathways to better align with industry demands. ENISA has pointed out that many current issues in cybersecurity education could be addressed through such redesigns, while ECSO notes that cybersecurity is often treated as an "add-on" to computer science degrees, neglecting its interdisciplinary nature. Despite these insights, the reasons for the insufficient production of cybersecurity professionals remain unclear, with challenges varying significantly by country and sector. This complexity complicates the identification of underlying factors and their interconnections. A PESTLE analysis has been employed to categorize these factors, revealing a lack of societal awareness regarding cybersecurity and the absence of EU-level certification as major obstacles. The findings suggest that localized solutions are necessary to address these disparities effectively.

PhiKitA is a novel dataset designed to analyze phishing kits and phishing websites, helping to detect phishing campaigns earlier. By applying MD5 hashes, fingerprints, and graph representation DOM algorithms, researchers conducted three experiments: phishing kit familiarity analysis, phishing website detection, and phishing source identification. The graph representation algorithm achieved a 92.50% accuracy in detecting phishing websites, indicating its effectiveness in classification. However, the MD5 hash representation yielded a low 39.54% F1 score, proving ineffective in distinguishing phishing websites from their sources. PhiKitA provides valuable insights into phishing detection and campaign identification, enhancing cybersecurity measures.

Remark 1: In this approach, a magnifying-glass effect is applied to transform the chaotic state variables, which serve as the key sequence before being XORed with the plaintext. If a slight mismatch occurs, causing perturbations, the amplified signal will also be affected. Since the parameter value is large, even a small mismatch is significantly magnified, leading to a substantial decryption error. As a result, the decryption key sequence will differ from the encryption key signal, making plaintext recovery impossible. This enhances the security of the chaotic communication system.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: To address the growing complexity of system design and the lag between manufacturing advancements and synthesis/compiler tools, a strategy involving the reuse of pre-developed Intellectual Property (IP) blocks has emerged. These IP blocks serve as foundational components for designers. However, integrating such heterogeneous systems presents challenges, as existing synthesis and compilation tools struggle to efficiently utilize the vast array of available resources.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: As an illustration, contemporary cloud infrastructure is structured around a three-tiered architecture, each layer of which is potentially susceptible to vulnerabilities introduced by either programmers or service providers. The heterogeneous handling of data complicates the tracking of cybercrimes, such as cybertheft and cyber-fraud, within digital environments [3]. Of greater concern, the pervasive nature of distributed computing diminishes the significance of geographical boundaries, thereby enabling criminal activities to originate from any global location [4]. Consequently, organizations face increasing challenges from a diverse array of cyberattacks [5], [6]. These attacks are characterized by a high degree of sophistication, necessitating the adoption of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or intelligent agents for effective countermeasures.

It is said that attacking your system yourself is the best
way of checking if it is able to withstand a cyberattack [25].
This way, not only the vulnerabilities can be uncovered and
removed, but also the staff can be appropriately trained. Yet,
employing ethical hackers, as well as their mere existence,
give rise to a number of ethical dilemmas.
Journal Name:
What Will the Future of Cybersecurity Bring Us,
and Will It Be Ethical? The Hunt for the Black
Swans of Cybersecurity Ethics

Text: In conclusion, communications systems using analog transmission are vulnerable to channel noise, resulting in increased synchronization errors. DDF systems inherently face a trade-off where complex nonlinear functions produce higher-dimension chaos but simultaneously become more susceptible to channel noise. Future research will explore digital transmission techniques, which are expected to significantly reduce synchronization errors.Retry
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: A hash bit essentially preserves the relationship between selected DCT coefficients within a given block pair. The hash bits generated for each block are combined to form the image's digest. This digest can either be embedded into the image or attached as a separate tag. During authentication, the receiver extracts the embedded digest, generates a new digest from the received image, and compares it with the extracted and decrypted digest.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: The attainment of a secure and privacy-centric digital ecosystem is predicated upon the indispensable prerequisites of cybersecurity education and training. A widespread recognition exists among both professional practitioners and the general populace regarding the necessity for robust university-level educational programs and professional training curricula. However, a discernible paucity persists in the availability of comprehensive guides, prescriptive recommendations, practical tools, and exemplary models that could facilitate the development of appropriate cybersecurity programs by educational institutions. In particular, a systematic methodology for the identification of requisite skills associated with cybersecurity work roles, as delineated within the contemporary job market, remains absent. This paper endeavors to furnish practical tools and strategic frameworks to assist higher education providers in the design of efficacious cybersecurity curricula. Initially, a comprehensive analysis of the content of 89 extant study programs, spanning global academic institutions, is conducted. This analysis is augmented by the compilation of recommendations from esteemed institutions within and external to the European Union, and the dissemination of a comprehensive survey, accompanied by a dynamic web application designated as the Education Map. Building upon the acquired knowledge regarding the current state of cybersecurity education, the SPARTA Cybersecurity Skills Framework is developed, bridging the existing gap between professional roles and requisite expertise, and providing a model for the development of curricula that reflect contemporary job market demands. Finally, a practical tool, implementing the aforementioned framework, is provided, facilitating the design of novel study programs and the analysis of existing ones by education and training providers, in accordance with the demands of cybersecurity work roles.

IoT communications must also be protected since large volumes of data can be transmitted between devices as well as
between those devices and servers or customers. If the confi-
dentiality, integrity, or availability (CIA) data is compromised,
it could have catastrophic consequences. Inadequately protected data streams on these devices act as possible access
for attack and vulnerability to data theft [33].
Journal Name:
Transferability of Machine Learning Algorithm for
IoT Device Profiling and Identification

Text: An inertial seismometer converts ground motion into an electrical signal, but its properties cannot be described by a simple scale factor, such as output volts per millimeter of ground motion, as is the case with position sensors. The response of a seismometer to ground motion depends on both the amplitude and the time scale of the motion. To maintain stability, a suspended seismic mass is held in place by a restoring force, which can be electromagnetic, mechanical, or of another nature. However, during slow ground motion, the mass moves with the rest of the seismometer, resulting in a significantly reduced output signal even for large motions. This makes the system act as a high-pass filter for ground shifts, which must be considered when reconstructing ground motion from recorded signals. Developing seismic detectors that can provide large output signals for both fast and slow ground motions, regardless of the motion rate, remains a significant challenge in seismology.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: Recently, many researchers have focused on impulsive systems and impulsive control. Bainov and Simeonov [1], Lakshmikantham et al. [2], and Lakshmikantham and Liu [3] have explored the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, which must be nonincreasing throughout the entire sequence of switchings. Li et al. [5] have relaxed this condition, requiring the Lyapunov function to be nonincreasing only along a subsequence of switchings. Yang [6] has derived sufficient conditions for the impulsive control of certain nonlinear systems based on the findings in [2]. Yang and Chua [7] and Yang et al. [8] have demonstrated intriguing applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications. Panas et al. [8] have proposed methods for experimental setups to implement impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Since the necessary historical data for the proposed algorithms is unavailable, conducting a meaningful simulation is not feasible. However, the outlined steps suggest that the MMB can oversee the market, balancing the interests of participants with system reliability and security requirements. Given that reliability data significantly impacts spinning reserve prices, market players might view such information as proprietary. Nevertheless, the MMB could collect and utilize reliability data to enhance system security and regulate energy services, as described in the proposed framework.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: A fundamental security threat is ciphertext analysis, where an attacker attempts to extract information solely from encrypted packets. A robust cryptographic system must prevent any unauthorized information leakage, including plaintext, keys, or statistical patterns. Crucially, it should also be impossible for an attacker to link a specific ciphertext to its corresponding plaintext. This is particularly critical in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) with limited data ranges, where this type of analysis can readily expose the original messages.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: With advancements in internet and wireless communication technologies, the Internet of Things (IoT) has expanded to encompass a vast array of networked objects, significantly impacting new information and communication technologies (ICT) and driving the evolution of Industry 4.0. Cybersecurity within this context is crucial, as it spans a global infrastructure composed of diverse smart devices that integrate sensory, communication, networking, and information processing technologies. The proliferation of IoT devices?anging from smartphones and cloud computing to barcodes?ntroduces various security vulnerabilities, making them attractive targets for cybercriminals. As the number of connected devices increases, so does the attack surface for potential intrusions, leading to heightened risks for both individuals and organizations. Common threats include Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, firmware exploits, and credential vulnerabilities that can compromise device security. To mitigate these risks, it is essential to implement robust security measures such as strong authentication protocols, regular software updates, and comprehensive monitoring systems. As IoT continues to evolve, developing standardized security frameworks will be vital to ensure the protection of interconnected devices and maintain the integrity of the networks they operate within.

In a deregulated environment, utilities would be less willing
to invest in new facilities and more willing to push transmission limits to take advantage of less expensive energy and lower
production costs. Special protection systems (SPS) were proposed to operate the system closer to the traditional deterministic limits, or even beyond them, and to enhance the benefits of
the market [2]. Under this circumstance, the probabilistic nature
of uncertain variables and more severe contingencies that would
endanger the system security and cause cascading events have
to be taken into account in the design of SPS for dealing with
extreme situations.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: Knowing the location of a fault, whether transient or permanent, is crucial for the efficient operation of a power system. Accurately identifying the location of a transmission line fault helps reduce repair time, thereby decreasing the outage duration of the affected line. Additionally, pinpointing weak spots, such as weak or dirty insulators that often cause transient faults, allows for their identification and elimination. Fault location is also beneficial in analyzing protective relaying schemes, as it enables the precise determination of zero sequence impedance, which is challenging to calculate.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text:
The operation of the Taiwan power (Taipower) transmission
system often requires heavy transfer of power from the major
low-cost generation sources in the south and central regions to
the load centers in the north. A major blackout that occurred in
1999 has led to the consideration of the deployment of SPS to
deal with the extreme situations. A defense plan including three
SPS to avoid angle instability, overloads, and voltage instability
in some areas of the transmission system was studied. A wide
area SPS is scheduled for deployment and operation in 2006.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: The Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System (ACARS) is a character-based data link defined by the ARINC 618 standard, facilitating communication between aircraft and operators via service providers. It employs the ASCII character set and functions similarly to SMS, offering data services such as weather updates, flight plans, and aircraft performance monitoring, including engine status. The flight crew also utilizes ACARS to communicate with the flight operation center and air traffic control (ATC). Depending on the aircraft's equipment and coverage needs, ACARS operates through three types of data links: Very High Frequency (VHF) or VHF Data Link (VDL) for populated land areas, Satellite Communication (SATCOM) via Inmarsat or Iridium for oceanic coverage, and High-Frequency Data Link (HFDL) for global connectivity. The message content follows the ARINC 620-8 standard, ensuring structured and standardized communication.

Model Reference Adaptive Control (MRAC) is a key approach in adaptive control. The desired performance is defined by a reference model, which specifies the desired response to an input signal. The adjustment mechanism modifies the regulator's parameters to minimize the error between the system output and the reference model. When the error is zero, perfect model following is achieved.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: There are numerous contingency combinations that could significantly impact the system, but most of these rare and severe events have a low probability of occurrence. To keep the complexity of Special Protection Systems (SPS) manageable, it is essential to identify the most credible scenarios. This letter proposes a framework for selecting contingency cases to include in the design of a transient stability SPS. The framework considers both the uncertainty of event occurrence and its consequences, combining them to form a risk index that guides contingency selection.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: In this section, we put forward a key exchange with mutual authentication based on Schnorr’s signature and one-way hash function for the secure communication between STB and smart card, which can be divided into five phases, that is, registration phase, login phase, mutual authentication phase, key agreement phase, CW transmission phase. The secure communication between STB and smart card is shown as figure 3.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: To ensure our encryption system is widely compatible with computers, we utilize the 256-character ASCII code, which includes the standard 128 ASCII codes and an additional 128 extended ASCII codes. As a result, the ciphertext in our simulations contains not only standard characters but also local symbols and marks. When the ciphertext is decrypted using the correct key, the original message is accurately recovered, as demonstrated in Table I. However, if an incorrect key is used, the recovered message will be scattered across the extended ASCII code range.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: Social enterprises (SEs) face heightened cybersecurity vulnerabilities due to their reliance on transient volunteers and close engagement with disadvantaged populations, which amplifies risks from social engineering attacks. The high turnover of volunteers dilutes the effectiveness of cybersecurity training, leaving newly recruited individuals with inconsistent exposure to protocols and creating gaps in awareness. This transient workforce is particularly susceptible to phishing and pretexting attacks, as attackers may impersonate beneficiaries or partners to manipulate staff or volunteers. Financial constraints further hinder SEs from adopting robust defenses, making them reliant on low-cost measures that may be inconsistently implemented. These challenges highlight RQ1, as SE owner-managers recognize that their operational uniqueness?uch as volunteer dependency and social missions?enders them prime targets for socially engineered attacks, necessitating tailored strategies to mitigate these risks effectively while safeguarding their mission-driven impact.

Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) integrate the physical and digital worlds, offering transformative potential in critical infrastructure. However, their critical nature and vulnerability to cyberattacks pose significant challenges, as breaches can have widespread consequences on humans, infrastructure, and the environment. The attack surface in CPS expands due to the wireless transmission of data between sensors and actuators. Traditionally, CPS security has focused on preventing unauthorized access using cryptographic methods and access control techniques, with most research centered on attack detection. However, given the increasing sophistication of adversaries, it is becoming crucial to develop resilient CPS that can withstand disruptions and maintain functionality despite cyber threats. One of the primary approaches for building resilience in CPS involves machine learning (ML) algorithms. However, adversarial ML research highlights the need for ML-based security mechanisms to be resilient themselves. This article provides a comprehensive survey of the interaction between resilient CPS using ML and the resilience of ML within CPS security. It also explores emerging research trends, future directions, and recent advancements in ML-driven security solutions and countermeasures for CPS, offering readers a deeper understanding of this evolving field.

In the following sections, the cybersecurity challenges are emphasized for two types of manufacturing systems 4.0 widely used in subtractive and additive manufacturing, namely CNC machine tools and 3-D printers, respectively. Moreover, an overview of existing methodological solutions to assess the impact of cyber-attacks in the context of Industry 4.0 is provided.

The growing sophistication of software and communication interfaces in IoT and cyber-physical systems (CPS) has amplified their susceptibility to diverse cyberattacks, raising critical privacy and security concerns that demand robust countermeasures. Machine learning (ML)-based cybersecurity solutions, while promising, face unique challenges as they often depend on data harvested from these vulnerable IoT/CPS environments, which may be compromised by adversarial manipulation, eavesdropping, or device spoofing. Key risks include insecure data provenance, model poisoning via corrupted sensor inputs, and exploitation of latency-sensitive decision loops, necessitating resilient ML frameworks capable of detecting anomalies, preserving data integrity, and adapting to evolving threat landscapes in real time.

Our research extends these foundational studies by proposing a comprehensive framework integrating artificial intelligence and blockchain technologies for secure data sharing and transmission purposes. The AICyber-Chain model leverages blockchain's decentralized ledger architecture to ensure robust data integrity while simultaneously utilizing AI's sophisticated analytical capabilities to dynamically enhance security measures in response to evolving threats.

Load participation in the restructured ERCOT market is considered a strategy for strengthening market competition, preventing unjustified price spikes, improving demand-side responsiveness to wholesale price indicators, and maintaining system reliability.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: Risk-based inspection (RBI) is another example of a spreadsheet-based process that is widely used in the oil, gas, and chemical industries. This approach, along with risk-based maintenance, is outlined in API RP 581, which was originally developed for the refining industry. The standard establishes a correlation between maintenance activities and key industry events, enabling a systematic approach to equipment reliability. RBI has also been adapted for various other sectors and inspection activities, providing a framework for identifying failure mechanisms and estimating failure rates based on equipment status, thereby improving safety and operational efficiency.

We have addressed the issue of impulsive control using the theory of impulsive differential equations. We derived sufficient conditions to ensure the asymptotic stability of an impulsive differential system. These findings were also applied to design impulsive control for a class of nonlinear systems. Our approach is beneficial for enhancing existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: The hybrid manufacturing (HM) tools represent ideal prototypical examples of digital manufacturing (DM) building blocks. They effectively demonstrate the ongoing transformation from traditional manufacturing approaches to digitally-driven processes. This evolution, while offering significant advantages, simultaneously introduces new attack vectors within the digital manufacturing environment. Examining the HM tool case specifically provides a valuable opportunity to identify, thoroughly analyze, and proactively address vulnerabilities arising from these novel attack vectors before digital manufacturing achieves widespread adoption across industrial sectors.

In Thailand's power system, generation units that are designated as regulatory must-run or must-take units become unavailable for participation in the competitive market. These units are required to dispatch electricity according to their contractual obligations, distinguishing them from Reliability Must-Run (RMR) units. Information regarding hydroelectric power plants, both those connected to the grid and local units, is detailed in Table I. Other must-take units are listed in Table II. This distinction affects how these units operate within the market structure, as they are bound by specific contractual requirements rather than market-driven dispatch decisions.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Every device or endpoint in IoT and CPSs
is a part of the network attack surface. Attackers can target
the endpoints of the network and gain access to the network
to control and compromise the whole system. Protocols, such

contain bugs and are vulnerable to be exploited by attackers.

Recent Advances on Federated Learning for
Cybersecurity and Cybersecurity for Federated
Learning for Internet of Things

used in subtractive and additive manufacturing, namely CNC

Text: The decentralized approach in cybersecurity and machine learning for the Internet of Things (IoT) has garnered significant interest from governments, academia, and industries, with Federated Cybersecurity (FC) emerging as a transformative concept aimed at enhancing IoT safety and efficiency. FC facilitates the detection of security threats and the implementation of countermeasures while minimizing the spread of these threats across IoT networks. By forming a federation of learned models among various participants, Federated Learning (FL) plays a crucial role in securing the vulnerable IoT environment through privacy-aware machine learning. This article provides an overview comparing centralized learning, distributed on-site learning, and FL, followed by a survey on the application of FL in IoT cybersecurity. It emphasizes security while addressing performance issues like accuracy and latency that may affect both security and overall IoT functionality. Additionally, it discusses ongoing research efforts, challenges, and trends in this domain, offering readers a comprehensive understanding of FL's role in cybersecurity and its implications for future developments.

directed by the Presidential Policy Directive 41 (PPD-41) [13],
developed the United States Cyber Incident Coordination, which
stipulates principles guiding the Federal Government?s response
to any cyber incident pertaining to government, agency, and
private sectors. The overarching goal of the cyber incident coordination is to form the ?national cyber incident response plan
(NCIRP) to address cyber-security incidents to critical infrastructures and as part of a broader National Preparedness System,
establishes the strategic framework and doctrine for a ?whole-ofNation? approach to addressing, responding to, and recovering
from a cyber incident? [7]. The NCIRP is specific to the US
and provides a governance playbook for coordinating national
cybersecurity incidents (pertaining to government, private, and
citizen) offering guidance, authority, and statutes contacts for
each type of cyber incident such as national, provincial, state,
and private sector communities.
Journal Name:
SOTER: A Playbook for Cybersecurity
Incident Management

Text: Railways have been a vital mode of transportation for passengers and freight since the late 19th century. However, railway operators continuously face pressure to enhance performance and service availability while maintaining the industry's well-established safety standards. Despite technological advancements, improving these finely tuned systems without compromising safety remains a significant challenge. This difficulty is further amplified by the high level of public scrutiny, as the general public serves both as end users and major financial supporters of railway infrastructure.

The proposed URC system can be utilized for automation and security in intelligent buildings, including homes, schools, and public institutions. Specifically, the smart URC enables control over various devices such as TVs, DVDs, projectors, lighting systems, motorized screens, and motorized curtains.Additionally, through Wi-Fi connectivity and camera integration, the system facilitates control of heating units, security and disaster management, spatial resolution, and real-time simultaneous monitoring.

Text: Examining another aspect of security, we analyzed the levels of professional training reported across security programs (Table III). Information systems training was the most preferred, followed closely by health information management. There was little difference in preferences for these training areas between organizations with high and low levels of computerization. However, we found a significant difference in the use of physicians as security officers. As organizations transitioned from paper-based to computer-based records, they were less likely to assign physicians to oversee information security. Otherwise, increased adoption of computer-based records did not correlate with a greater use of systems-based security officers.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: To secure USB storage, a unique session key is generated during user verification, encrypting all files transferred. This key, distinct for each user and filename, ensures that only authenticated users can access their encrypted files. After encryption or decryption, the key is deleted from the user's device, enhancing security and requiring re-verification for subsequent access.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: The Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System (ACARS), a character-based data link defined by ARINC standard 618, facilitates data communication between aircraft and operators through subscribed service providers, employing the American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) character set and exhibiting functional similarities to Short Message Service (SMS) [38]; this system provides diverse data services, including weather information, flight plans, and aircraft component performance data, such as engine status [39], and enables flight crew communication with aircraft flight operation centers and air traffic control (ATC); ACARS utilizes three distinct data link types, contingent upon aircraft equipment and coverage requirements: plain old VHF or VHF data link (VDL) [40], satellite communications (SATCOM) via Inmarsat or Iridium, and high-frequency data link (HFDL); typically, VHF serves populated land areas, SATCOM extends coverage to oceanic regions, and HF provides global coverage; the structure of ACARS message content adheres to the ARINC 620-8 standard [33].

A comparison of the signal-to-noise ratios between the new sensor and the SM-3 sensor (both installed in the same seismograph) indicates that the new sensor is two orders of magnitude more sensitive. Additionally, unlike EMF-based sensors, our sensor can detect position shifts, allowing it to identify the onset of oscillatory processes at extremely low frequencies, including quasi-static shifts. This capability is particularly important for detecting low-order free oscillations of the Earth's crust, monitoring long-duration tidal movements, and tracking tsunami formation. As a result, this sensor could play a crucial role in studying the early stages of earthquake formation?something that is nearly impossible with conventional methods. Our innovation presents significant potential for addressing the technical needs of seismic monitoring services, particularly in countries located in seismically active regions worldwide.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: The proposed HNN-based authentication method is fully self-contained. Since the registration process ensures an accurate association between each valid user ID and its corresponding password, the recall system will not produce errors. Any invalid login attempt will be automatically denied. However, it is valuable to evaluate the effectiveness of this approach by comparing it with the existing layered neural network method described in [9]. Two simulation tests were conducted—one measured the time required for registration, while the other assessed performance when multiple passwords contained similar character sequences.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Unauthorized aggregation is a specific type of malicious modification, particularly relevant to PH schemes. This attack involves combining two or more legitimate ciphertexts to inject the aggregated result into the network. Similar to normal aggregation nodes, the attacking aggregator does not need to know the plaintexts of the individual messages to create a valid-looking ciphertext. An adversary could exploit this to disrupt the system or use it more strategically. For instance, if an attacker knows the ciphertext \( C1 \) for a temperature of about 20°C, they could increase the current sensed temperature by 40°C using the ciphertext \( C2 \). By aggregating \( C3 = C2 + C1 + C1 \), the attacker can replace \( C2 \) with \( C3 \).
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: In 2014, MITRE released a comprehensive Cyber Exercise Playbook [14], serving as a practical guide for conducting cyber exercises?omplete with sample scenarios, red teaming strategies, and operational frameworks?o enhance organizational preparedness. This built upon their earlier 2012 Cyber Defense Playbook [15], which pioneered active defense methodologies by aligning countermeasures with stages of the cyber-attack kill chain, offering actionable strategies to disrupt adversary progression. Together, these resources reflect MITRE? iterative approach to bridging theoretical attack models with hands-on defensive training, equipping teams with structured tools for both proactive threat simulation and real-time response.

DBD-Guardian and Privacy-Aware Near
Real-Time Cybersecurity Analytics

While reliability data significantly impacts spinning reserve prices and may be considered proprietary by market players, the MMB can collect this information and use it to ensure system security and control energy services as described.

Text: This paper focuses on wind farm penetration levels of 10% and 20% of peak demand. To achieve these levels, 22 and 44 sites of 90-MW wind farms have been integrated into the traditional system through 115-kV transmission lines at various locations near load centers across the entire system.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: This research presents methodical approaches for designing and selecting appropriate wind power technologies for Thailand's electrical grid, utilizing current power system information and recent wind resource evaluation data. The study thoroughly analyzes both the potential integration levels of wind energy into the existing system and wind turbine dimensioning processes, specifically addressing Thailand's classification as a region with low to medium wind speeds.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

is shown to vary in terms of influence on teenagers? outcomes

Cybersecurity Interventions for Teens: Two
