Text: The bilateral market offers several advantages. It allows customers and suppliers to set prices directly, ensuring fair payment allocation. This setup promotes competition in the ancillary services market, reducing the risk of load-following supply shortfalls. Generators with bilateral contracts are fairly compensated for their services, encouraging them to participate in the load-following market. Additionally, generators can enter into contracts outside their Control Area, fostering increased competition, provided there is a communication network across Control Areas.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: Cybersecurity facilitates technological growth and advancement, fostering competitive marketplaces that ultimately contribute to more efficient and prosperous societies. Contemporary societal objectives include the simplification of daily life through innovation and entrepreneurship, achieved via continuous efficiency, adaptability, and affordability. These objectives are realized through mechanisms provided by advancements in technological infrastructure, encompassing both hardware and software, while simultaneously preserving public trust in cybersecurity. Public trust has emerged as a paramount asset for corporations and governmental entities, as evidenced by the cases of organizations such as Amazon and Facebook. This phenomenon falls within the purview of cybersecurity.

Cloud computing platforms offer significant advantages for conducting course assignments and providing students with essential hands-on experience, particularly in cybersecurity education. These platforms enable on-demand access to virtual machines that are elastic, dedicated, and easily configurable, which enhances the learning experience compared to traditional laboratories that struggle to scale with increasing student numbers. By leveraging cloud-based laboratories, educators can effectively teach cybersecurity courses across multiple campuses through virtual classrooms equipped with live audio and video capabilities. This approach not only facilitates the acquisition of crucial cybersecurity skills but also integrates cloud computing competencies, which are increasingly in demand. The use of platforms like Amazon Web Services (AWS) exemplifies how cloud environments can enhance educational outcomes; however, similar methodologies can be applied using other cloud services such as Rackspace and Google Compute Engine. Overall, the integration of cloud computing into cybersecurity education prepares students for future challenges in a rapidly evolving technological landscape.

Standards differ in content based on their intended purpose, regional regulations, and specific requirements of the countries in which they are developed. However, a single standard can fall into multiple categories. For example, NIST 800-82, originally a U.S. national standard, has gained international recognition due to widespread adoption, while also being classified as a horizontal industrial standard. Similarly, ETSI EN 303 645, initially a European regional standard, has evolved into an international standard due to its extensive use. This categorization often leads security practitioners to overlook critical differences between organizations and their unique security needs. Scalability considerations within these classifications directly impact the implementation of security controls, which may vary based on factors such as an organization? size, complexity, the criticality of its information systems, and the scope of its security controls.

Text: The exponential growth of IoT adoption has introduced transformative benefits across industries, yet the absence of robust cybersecurity infrastructure leaves the global IoT network vulnerable to escalating security threats and malicious attacks? concern reflected in the surge of IoT-related cybersecurity research, as evidenced by our analysis of 433 selected publications from IEEE Xplore, Web of Science, ACM Digital Library, INSPEC, and ScienceDirect since 2013. This systematic review not only maps the current landscape of IoT cybersecurity countermeasures?ncluding encryption, intrusion detection, and blockchain-based solutions deployed across healthcare, manufacturing, and smart cities?ut also reveals critical gaps in standardization, device heterogeneity, and real-time threat response. The rising publication trend (demonstrated in Fig. 1) underscores IoT cybersecurity as an urgent research priority, highlighting opportunities to develop adaptive security frameworks that address evolving attack vectors while balancing scalability with energy efficiency in resource-constrained IoT environments. Our findings equip researchers and practitioners with a consolidated reference to navigate challenges like edge security, AI-driven threats, and lifecycle management in next-generation IoT systems.

Text: Impulsive control systems have numerous practical applications. Three notable examples include: an insect population control system, where state variables are the numbers of insects and their natural enemies; a chemical reactor system, with state variables representing different chemical quantities; and a financial system, with state variables being the amount of money in a market and the central bank's savings rates. Additional examples can be found in and.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: This paper introduces a key exchange protocol for secure communication between smart cards and STBs in DTV broadcasting, utilizing Schnorr's digital signature protocol and a one-way hash function. This protocol offers several advantages, including enhanced security, dynamic session keys, mutual authentication, reduced computational and communication overhead, and user-friendly password management. Additionally, the proposed scheme effectively prevents smart card cloning and the McCormac Hack, which are significant security threats in DTV broadcasting.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: In our system, we must ensure that the low-pass filter, gain, and nonlinear element components are matched for both trans mitter and receiver circuits to ensure that chaos synchroniza tion occurs as detailed in [13]. It should be noted that, although the system contains digital elements, the transmitted signal is analog. Therefore, the physical implementation of the system includes an amplifier and dc offset (not shown) to compensate for gain and offset errors within the receiver’s ADC. These two parameters are adjusted such that the subtracted (error) signal is minimized. The transmitting and receiving systems should thus theoretically generate identical waveforms that subtract to give zero synchronization error. In practice, the two systems will not be perfectly matched, and a measurable synchronization error will result. Noise in the system will also lead to synchroniza tion error.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: Dynamic reconfiguration of Data Processing Units (DPUs) incurs overhead only during memory protection updates, which typically occur once per application execution. While reconfigurable DPUs enhance system flexibility, the variable latency introduced by network messaging during reconfiguration compromises time determinism. For hard real-time systems, where timing predictability is critical, this feature is generally unsuitable.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: Cyber events are generated by information systems and may not always lead to incidents; however, when they match predefined or anomaly-based profiles, they can trigger alerts that potentially escalate into incidents. The European NIS directive defines an incident in relation to network information systems as "any event affecting the availability, integrity, or confidentiality of networks and information systems (used in the provision of the essential service) that has a significant impact on the continuity of the essential service itself." This distinction highlights that while cyber events can indicate potential security issues, incidents represent confirmed breaches or violations that necessitate immediate attention and action to mitigate harm. Understanding this differentiation is crucial for organizations to effectively monitor their cybersecurity posture and respond appropriately to threats.

There are various fire-detection techniques, including temperature sampling, relative humidity sampling, smoke analysis, and ultraviolet and infrared sampling. [12] describes a fire-alarming method based on video processing, which, although capable of providing additional information about the burning process, is too costly for home security systems.

In this system, each fire alarm node uses a temperature sensor and an infrared receiver. The temperature sensor monitors the environmental temperature, while the infrared receiver detects heat and flames. If the temperature or infrared levels exceed predefined thresholds, the node sends out an alarm signal. The implementation of a fire alarm node, as shown in Fig. 12, is simple, low-cost, and suitable for home use.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: Authenticators fall into three primary categories: secrets (something you know), tokens (something you have), and IDs (something you are). A password, for example, is a secret that can take the form of a word, phrase, or personal identification number (PIN). While passwords are widely used, they have inherent security risks. Short, mnemonic passwords can be easily guessed or cracked by determined attackers, whereas longer, randomly generated passwords are more secure but challenging for users to remember.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: The deployment of diverse sensor arrays within Internet of Things (IoT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) for monitoring and operational support introduces a significant vulnerability vector, as these sensors are susceptible to adversarial manipulation, thereby posing substantial security and safety risks; notably, critical sensor components, including global positioning system (GPS) signals, light detection and ranging (LiDAR) signals, and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data, are susceptible to compromise, resulting in potentially severe operational disruptions and safety hazards for the affected devices, thus highlighting the critical need for sensor-level security measures to mitigate these risks.

In theory, any control parameter of the device—such as bias current, feedback strength, or feedback phase—could serve as a hardware key. However, significant changes in bias current or feedback strength can alter the chaotic attractor’s characteristics, making them detectable through power fluctuations or attractor changes. In contrast, modifying the feedback phase does not produce noticeable variations in time series data or RF spectra of the chaotic signal [8]. This makes feedback phase the only suitable hardware key that can introduce undetectable changes to the transmitted signal.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: In today's increasingly perilous digital ecosystem, robust cybersecurity measures and strict regulatory compliance have become existential imperatives for organizations, as escalating cyber threats?rom advanced persistent threats to ransomware attacks?emand multilayered defenses that simultaneously harden technical infrastructure and align with evolving legal-ethical frameworks. The consequences of non-compliance extend far beyond financial penalties, potentially cascading into catastrophic data breaches, operational paralysis, and irreversible reputational damage, while in critical sectors like healthcare or energy, such failures may even endanger human lives. This paper underscores how proactive adherence to standards like Saudi Arabia's Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC) serves dual purposes: systematically mitigating attack surfaces through validated security protocols while maintaining stakeholder trust through demonstrable compliance? strategic imperative given that 74% of breaches involve human or process failures according to Verizon's 2023 DBIR. Our workforce optimization model transforms compliance from a checkbox exercise into a force multiplier by algorithmically aligning specialized personnel (e.g., SOC analysts, compliance auditors) with high-impact control implementations, creating adaptive organizational resilience against both current threats and emerging attack vectors like AI-driven social engineering.

The estimation of a networked system's global state is a critical challenge across numerous application domains; while the conventional periodic observation method suffers from inefficiency due to its high-frequency state monitoring, the event-based approach offers an alternative by leveraging system dynamics and triggering observations only upon the satisfaction of specific conditions; this research explores the application of event-based estimation to cybersecurity equilibrium, a metric lacking closed-form solutions, within the context of preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics, which are known to exhibit global convergence; the study demonstrates that the equilibrium estimates derived from the proposed trigger rule converge to the dynamic equilibrium and are Zeno-free, thereby validating the method's practical utility; numerical experiments illustrate a potential 98% reduction in observation costs compared to the periodic method; to facilitate practical implementation, the paper addresses the discrepancy between the continuous probability-state model, which represents node security probabilities, and the discrete sample-state encountered in real-world scenarios, which is obtained through node sampling; this bridge between continuous and discrete state representations, which holds independent significance, facilitates the use of probability-state models for approximating exponentially complex discrete state systems.

When an online generator fails, system frequency must remain stable without requiring load shedding. A method for determining spinning reserve requirements, based on the system's 1-minute recovery frequency after the loss of its largest generator, was proposed in [4] and [5]. For isolated power systems, a specific amount of FRR must be available within a defined time frame to mitigate sudden generator failures, unexpected load fluctuations, or other disturbances. This time frame, known as the margin of time, represents the duration needed to adjust generator output. Different utilities set varying requirements for FRR levels and response times. In the case of TPS, this response time is set at 60 seconds.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: TheDSScanbeimplementedinthetwosituations.Inthefirst situation, utility still has the overplus power capacity but offers the customers interruptible tariffs for relieving part of the power demandtoreducetheoperationcostduringthepeakloadperiod. The objectives are to minimize the generation cost of the utility and to maximize the customers’ benefits simultaneously [11]. The objectives of the other situation are to maintain the system reliability and to minimize the perturbation of the load inter ruption in the same time when the system or substation is suf fering from the capacity shortage. The problem is suitable to be solved by the load interruption because of the effects of the load management are obvious and efficient. However, owing to the customers’ participation in the load management, the scheme must be implemented through two principles. One is to satisfy the customers’ satisfaction, and the other is to keep the system security. The mathematical model of the problem can be formu lated as follows.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) is a fundamental machine learning algorithm used for classification and regression tasks, widely applied in cyber-physical systems (CPS) for pattern recognition, data mining, and intrusion detection. Its non-parametric nature eliminates the need for prior assumptions about the data, making it suitable for real-world applications. The algorithm determines the class of a test point based on majority voting among its K nearest neighbors. Predictions are made by directly referencing the training dataset, where a new instance is classified by identifying the K most similar instances and summarizing their output values. The similarity between instances is typically measured using distance metrics like Euclidean distance. Although KNN has lost some of its popularity due to the rise of more advanced techniques, it remains in use for certain research applications.

To simulate jamming attacks on the Balise-BTM communication system, we employed a custom wire loop matching the Balise's dimensions, connected to an amplified function generator. This experimental setup enabled two distinct attack simulations: (1) a Continuous Wave (CW) jamming attack using a single-frequency tone (documented in Figures 3-5), and (2) a frequency-sweep attack targeting the up-link band. The CW attack demonstrated the system's vulnerability to basic RF interference, while the swept-tone approach revealed more sophisticated vulnerabilities to dynamic frequency disruption?oth attack modes providing critical insights into the electromagnetic resilience (or lack thereof) of current railway signaling architectures under adversarial RF conditions. These controlled experiments systematically quantify how simple, low-cost equipment can disrupt safety-critical train-to-track communications.

In this note, we will also explore the impulsive control of nonlinear systems as discussed in [6]. Initially, we derive less conservative conditions for the stability of impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses. These results are then utilized to design impulsive control laws for a class of nonlinear systems. Our approach can be applied to a broader range of nonlinear systems and is beneficial for enhancing existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications [7],[8].
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Knowing the location of a fault, whether transient or permanent, is crucial for the efficient operation of a power system. Accurately identifying a transmission line fault helps reduce repair time, thereby minimizing outage duration. Additionally, weak spots, such as deteriorated or dirty insulators that frequently cause transient faults, can be detected and addressed. Fault location also plays a key role in analyzing protective relaying schemes, enabling precise determination of the zero-sequence impedance, which is otherwise challenging to calculate.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: The integration of the Hunter-Prey Optimization (HPO) algorithm with an ensemble learning framework enhances the detection accuracy of Android malware. By leveraging multiple classifiers and optimization techniques, the model efficiently identifies malicious patterns and behaviors within Android applications.

The impact of DR’s on congestion management is discussed in this paper. In order to quickly and accurately measure the im pact, a set of contribution factors, that is, the PLDG, QLDG and VDG,arederived fromACpowerflowanalysiswith closedfor mulas. The introduction of the ITDA space provides a straight forward approach to simplify the detailed information to dis crete partitions. Also, a fuzzy clustering approach can suffi ciently identify the effective boundaries of the ITDA space for single and multiple constraints. The proposed methods can be used for the location and operation strategy analysis of DR’s. It is noted that, for large size systems, computation cost of CF’s need to be considered due to changes of system configuration, generation schedules and loading levels. Numerical analysis is going to be carried out in the future to address these challenges for practical applications.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text:
Because of the power consumption, memory usage, connectivity, and battery or power availability, IoT devices cannot
offer the same level of security as traditional computers. In this
sense, machine learning (ML) models used to monitor devices
in a network and make predictions by differentiating between
normal and illegitimate devices have made tremendous strides.
Journal Name:
Transferability of Machine Learning Algorithm for
IoT Device Profiling and Identification

Text: Cybersecurity threats, such as malware attacks, denial of service, phishing, and unauthorized data access, pose significant risks to medical care applications within the Industrial Internet of Healthcare Things (IIoHT) architecture. These threats can compromise system performance and consumer safety, making cybersecurity a critical concern. While known cyberattacks can often be detected in networks, unknown attacks that penetrate different layers of the IIoHT system present greater challenges. To address these issues, cyber-physical system (CPS)-based automated methods leverage autonomous, self-adaptive, and self-learning techniques within fog and cloud computing environments to dynamically detect and mitigate cybersecurity threats in medical applications.

The rapid evolution of information and communication technologies, particularly the Internet, has brought about significant positive implications for organizations and social interactions, facilitating communication, networking, knowledge sharing, and social interaction. However, this reliance on third-party and cloud-based data storage introduces substantial cybersecurity challenges, making it increasingly difficult for organizations to ensure total security of their information systems. With the growing dependence on external vendors for data management, organizations face heightened risks of data breaches and unauthorized access, as these third-party platforms often become targets for cybercriminals. The complexities of managing security across diverse systems further complicate efforts to protect sensitive information, leaving organizations vulnerable to cyberattacks that can have devastating financial and reputational consequences. As such, while the Internet enhances connectivity and collaboration, it simultaneously necessitates robust cybersecurity measures to safeguard against its inherent risks.

In 2016, the U.S. CERT, under Presidential Policy Directive 41 (PPD-41) [13], established the U.S. Cyber Incident Coordination framework, formalizing a whole-of-nation approach through the National Cyber Incident Response Plan (NCIRP) [7]. This governance playbook standardizes federal, state, and private-sector coordination during cyber incidents?articularly those affecting critical infrastructure?y defining response roles, legal authorities, and escalation protocols across government agencies (DHS, FBI, ODNI) and industry partners. Unlike general frameworks (e.g., NIST CSF), the NCIRP provides tactical incident-specific guidance, including contact protocols for different threat tiers (national/state/private) and recovery procedures, positioning it as a legally anchored operational blueprint rather than a voluntary risk management tool.

Various motion estimation algorithms have been developed over time [3]. Among these, the most common and fundamental motion detection methods rely on successive image comparisons, requiring substantial image data storage and transfer between circuit blocks. This data handling leads to significant power consumption and increased hardware complexity, resulting in higher costs. For portable security applications, low-power motion detection is crucial, and a simplified architecture helps reduce system costs. To address these challenges, an efficient motion detection algorithm is proposed that maintains detection accuracy while using only a fraction?one-thousandth or less?of the image data required by conventional methods. This approach eliminates the need for large-scale data transfer between blocks and can be implemented with conventional CMOS image sensors with minimal modifications.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: Raising security awareness for emerging technologies is crucial to prevent cyberattacks. Ensuring information security in an open system architecture, considering potential threats and goals such as confidentiality, integrity, availability, and accountability, is a challenging task. ISO/IEC 17779 provides a list of important controls for information security management systems. A virtual enterprise can facilitate a collaborative approach to managing existing network enterprises by coordinating, controlling, and communicating remotely with different roles and user types. Governments have responded to the increasing connectivity of control networks by enhancing national readiness.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: In Fig. 1(b), the authentication performances of the proposed protected system are compared with those achieved by the pro tected approaches in [5], [7] and [8], as well as with the per formances of an unprotected system employing Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) as classifier [14]. The proposed scheme per forms better than the cryptosystems presented in [5] and [7], implemented using a signature representation based on the 100 parametric features given in [15]. A performance improvement is also observed with respect to the transformation based protec tion approach presented in [8], which relies on a function based signature representation. It is also worth pointing out that the renewability capacity of the approach here proposed is higher than that of the approaches in [5] and [7], due to the possibility of encoding messages with longer length . The proposed ap proach introduces an acceptable loss in performances with re spect to an unprotected system using DTW, currently consid ered the approach giving the best possible authentication per formances for signature recognition, while providing protection to the employed signature templates. It is worth specifying that signature based recognition systems can hardly reach EERs as low as those obtained using fingerprint or iris, due to the be havioral nature of signature biometrics. Nevertheless, the ob tained recognition rates are comparable with those achieved, with E=5 and the same database, by unprotected signature based recognition systems [15].
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: During major disturbances such as generation loss, system frequency begins to decline. Generator governor responses attempt to counteract this frequency drop. The frequency continues to fall if available spinning reserves are insufficient compared to generation loss, or if generator governor response is inadequate. When frequency drops to the high-set frequency relay threshold, up to 1150 MW of LaaRs are disconnected by underfrequency relays to restore normal system frequency. However, excessive load shedding may cause frequency overshoot and potentially trigger generator protection mechanisms, leading to generator trips and cascading contingencies.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: Our analysis reveals uneven adoption of information security personnel within health-care organizations. While many organizations have developed information systems for collecting and storing patient data, they often lack corresponding security committees, teams, or dedicated security managers/officers. Overall, approximately 50% of hospital-based respondents reported having an information security individual, a significantly higher percentage compared to clinic-based (37%) and other practice setting respondents (42%). Hospitals were twice as likely as outpatient settings to have adopted an information security officer.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: A PESTLE analysis was implemented to gain a comprehensive understanding of the challenges facing cybersecurity education by categorizing underlying causes into Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, and Environmental factors. This analytical framework is widely used in development contexts as it effectively reveals gaps and challenges from multiple perspectives. The PESTLE analysis not only helps conceptualize the multifaceted issues within cybersecurity education but also facilitates the creation of a common taxonomy for future research and initiatives. By identifying and defining 31 relevant factors affecting cybersecurity education, the analysis allows stakeholders to assess their significance at both national and European levels. Additionally, it highlights the interconnectivity of these factors, suggesting that localized solutions may be necessary to address the specific challenges faced in different countries. Overall, the PESTLE approach serves as a valuable tool for guiding future research and policy development in the field of cybersecurity education.

The railway industry's adoption of modern digital systems has introduced unprecedented cybersecurity vulnerabilities, transforming these critical networks into high-value targets for attackers of all skill levels?rom amateur hackers to state-sponsored groups. Unlike legacy dedicated systems, contemporary rail technologies present a vastly expanded attack surface due to their standardized components and protocols, requiring minimal specialized knowledge to exploit. This vulnerability is compounded by the industry's lingering security awareness gaps and the high-impact nature of transportation infrastructure. Recent incidents?uch as the 2008 Lodz tram derailment caused by a teenager's signaling system hack [2,3]?emonstrate how even basic replay attacks can catastrophically disrupt rail operations, underscoring the urgent need for robust cybersecurity measures that match the sector's evolving threat landscape while maintaining operational reliability.

Authenticators can be broadly classified into three categories: secrets (what you know), tokens (what you have), and IDs (who you are). Passwords fall under the category of secrets and typically consist of a secret word, phrase, or personal identification number. Despite their widespread use, passwords have vulnerabilities. A short mnemonic password can be easily guessed or cracked by a determined attacker, while a longer, random password is often difficult for users to remember.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text:
In an asymmetric system, for the embedded watermark to be
detected by the usual correlation test, the reference watermark
of the detector and the embedding watermarks should have some
correlation. There exist numerous ways to generate signals that
are different from but have a fixed correlation with a given reference watermark. A simple method is to form a weighted sum
of the watermark and a random noise. Hartung and Girod [2]
proposed replacing a portion of the watermark with a random
noise. In the following, we describe a new method that employs
the phase-shift-transform (PST).
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Authentication methods fall into three primary categories: secrets (knowledge-based), tokens (possession-based), and IDs (inherence-based). Passwords, which are secret words or numbers, are widely used but have significant security weaknesses. Short, easily remembered passwords are vulnerable to guessing or brute-force attacks, while long, complex passwords, though more secure, are difficult for users to memorize.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: The decision-making process in autonomous vehicles (AVs) introduces substantial security challenges. AVs rely on vast amounts of data from both internal and external sources to function effectively. Communication between intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs), onboard sensors, and external services enables machine learning models to process real-time information and make driving decisions. These AI-driven models are trained on extensive datasets to execute hundreds or even thousands of decisions throughout a journey. Research has explored AV simulations, including electronic control units (ECUs) and AI firmware, to better understand system functionality. However, machine learning models in AVs are susceptible to various security threats, which can compromise the reliability and safety of autonomous systems. This section will delve into the vulnerabilities associated with AI-driven decision-making in AVs.

So, comparison of signal-to-noise ratios for new and
SM-3-sensor (both installed in the same seismograph) permits
to conclude that the new sensor is more sensitive by 2 orders
of a value. Besides, because our new sensor permits to detect
position shifts, it may enable to detect the start of oscillating
processes at very low frequencies (beginning at quasi-static
shifts)—in contrast to EMF-based sensors. This may become
crucial for detection of low-order free oscillations of the Earth
crust, and for observation of few hours duration tidal motions
and tsunami shaping. That is why, one may use it to reveal & study the origin of formation of the earthquakes in advance—practically impossible for similar other methods. Our

of the seismic services supported by the governments of the
countries positioned in main World seismically-active regions.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: The integration of AI, cybersecurity, and blockchain presents a transformative approach to digital security, addressing the limitations of traditional cybersecurity methods in combating evolving threats. AI enhances cybersecurity by analyzing vast datasets, detecting anomalies, and responding to threats in real-time. However, centralized AI systems pose vulnerabilities, making them prime targets for cyberattacks. By leveraging blockchain? decentralized and immutable ledger, AI-driven cybersecurity solutions can achieve greater resilience, transparency, and security, ensuring robust protection against sophisticated cyber threats.

The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs) has enabled advanced connectivity through V2X communication (vehicle-to-everything), including vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V), vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I), and vehicle-to-pedestrian (V2P) interactions. These networks form the backbone of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), enabling real-time data exchange for safety, navigation, and traffic management. However, this connectivity introduces significant security and complexity challenges, particularly due to the cyber-physical nature of modern EVs and their reliance on dynamic, ad-hoc communication protocols like DSRC (Dedicated Short-Range Communications) and C-V2X (Cellular V2X)

In today?s world of complex cybersecurity threats, it is crucial for organizations to follow
strong security frameworks. This research introduces a new way to combine the National Cybersecurity
Authority?s Essential Cybersecurity Controls with the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. Our goal
is to connect regulated cybersecurity controls with practical workforce deployment. We use a systematic
process to match tasks in the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework with the controls required by
the National Cybersecurity Authority. This alignment helps organizations comply with these controls while
making good use of their cybersecurity workforce. A key part of our work is creating an optimization model
that identifies the best job roles needed under the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework to fully meet
the Essential Cybersecurity Controls set by the National Cybersecurity Authority. By using optimization
algorithms, our model offers a cost-effective and efficient way for organizations to comply with regulations.
The findings show that certain job roles in the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework are crucial for
covering many Essential Cybersecurity Controls, highlighting their strategic importance in cybersecurity
operations. This study lays the groundwork for future research in cybersecurity workforce optimization and
offers a framework for other organizations to adapt their cybersecurity strategies to meet specific regulatory
requirements.
Journal Name:
Optimal Job Role Allocation for Compliance
With NCA-ECC Controls Using the Saudi
Cybersecurity Workforce Framework

Text: Ethics establish guidelines for distinguishing right from wrong and defining acceptable moral behavior in various contexts. In cybersecurity, ethical considerations are crucial because cybersecurity practices directly impact people? well-being. Ethical principles in this field revolve around the responsible use of technology to protect individuals and ensure their security. While the fundamental ethical stance?rotecting the data of legitimate users and preventing unauthorized access?ay seem straightforward, the reality is far more complex. This paper presents the results of a comprehensive Horizon Scanning campaign aimed at identifying anticipated and emerging ethical challenges in cybersecurity.

The proposed algorithm was validated using real-world data from the LJ36 feeder at the Dar-Gun substation. An autoregressive moving-average (ARMA) model, specifically ARMA (2,1), was used to predict the feeder's load, as detailed in Table I. The load forecasting exhibited an average error of 3.23%, with the maximum error at 6.22% (13th hour) and the minimum at 0.35% (9th hour). The forecasted load's duration curve is shown in Figure 3. To maintain system security, load shedding is required when the feeder load surpasses 6600 kW. The specific load shedding pattern implemented is presented in column 5 of Table I.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text:
In August 2017, the United States National Institute of
Standards and Technology (NIST) released a workforce
framework in the NIST Special Publication 800-181. The
framework, which is called the National Initiative on
Cybersecurity Education (NICE) framework [24], is an
internationally recognized reference to define and categorize
different professions within the cybersecurity realm. The
NICE framework is constantly being modified to meet the
current requirements of the workforce demands. At the time
of writing, the most recent version of the NICE framework
was released in November 2020 [23]
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: The main objective of the NICE Framework is to provide a unified lexicon for defining various cybersecurity work roles, facilitating better communication among stakeholders in the cybersecurity ecosystem. The framework classifies work duties into seven main categories, which encompass a wide range of cybersecurity functions. Each of these categories is further divided into specialty areas and specific work roles, totaling 52 defined work roles. The NICE Framework details the necessary knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) required for individuals to effectively perform cybersecurity tasks associated with each job position. By establishing a standardized approach to defining cybersecurity roles and responsibilities, the NICE Framework aids organizations in identifying, recruiting, and developing a skilled cybersecurity workforce, ultimately enhancing their capacity to address current and emerging cyber threats.

In a chaotic communication system using lasers with delayed optical feedback, data security is ensured by the requirement that the transmitter and receiver be nearly identical. However, this study assumes that this requirement is no longer valid, meaning an eavesdropper may possess an identical receiver. The proposed security method relies on a predefined variation of the feedback phase and exploits the inherent limitation of synchronization response time. In this approach, the feedback phase acts as a key that both the transmitter and receiver must share to achieve synchronization. While one might argue that encrypting the data before encoding it onto the chaotic carrier would provide similar protection, this is not the case. Algorithmic encryption requires additional computational power and is vulnerable to decryption attacks, whereas the proposed technique operates without extra processing and derives its security from fundamental physical constraints.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text:
Cybersecurity threats are increasingly sophisticated and
pose significant challenges to traditional security mechanisms. The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) with
cybersecurity aims to enhance the detection, analysis, and
mitigation of these threats. However, the centralized nature of
many AI systems introduces vulnerabilities and single points
of failure. Blockchain technology offers a decentralized and
immutable ledger that can enhance the security and integrity
of data, making it a promising solution for addressing these
challenges.
Journal Name:
AICyber-Chain: Combining AI and Blockchain
for Improved Cybersecurity

Text: Hybrid Manufacturing (HM) tools integrate additive and subtractive manufacturing on a single platform, streamlining process chains that would otherwise require multiple machines across different locations. This configuration reduces setup times, material costs, and handling errors, making HM tools ideal for custom component fabrication, remanufacturing, and high-value part repairs. They have demonstrated significant cost savings, such as a 97.2% reduction in material costs for offshore oil extraction pipe casings. HM tools also enable customized medical implants, enhanced injection mold cooling, and efficient repair of molds, dies, and turbine blades, showcasing their versatility and industrial impact.

While prior work [48] estimated cybersecurity equilibrium only in constrained parameter regimes (requiring predefined attack-defense graph structures), this study extends the analysis to the entire parameter universe, enabled by proving global convergence of the dynamics under all conditions [4]. This universality ensures broader applicability, allowing equilibrium estimation in diverse, real-world cyber-defense scenarios without restrictive assumptions.

Cybersecurity vulnerabilities often stem from a combination of physical, human, and social factors. In response, many global policymakers and governments prioritize strengthening physical infrastructures as a defense mechanism. This approach aligns with the outdated "Castle Model," which relies on constructing strong defensive barriers around systems to prevent security breaches. While this model offers protection, it fails to fully address modern cyber risks due to cultural diversity, complex socio-technical systems, and varying levels of cybersecurity awareness across global populations. Consequently, an evidence-based investigation into human factors and cyber risk awareness is necessary to develop a more comprehensive and effective cybersecurity framework.

In the following section, we demonstrate that our closed loop load following controller effectively functions as a local supplementary control mechanism that eliminates frequency deviations caused by load variations in systems without centralized Automatic Generation Control (AGC). This only applies when all system load fluctuations are managed through bilateral contracts. Realistically, power systems would likely still require traditional supplementary control. Even in scenarios where all load variations are contract-based, centralized control remains necessary to address factors like system losses, which cannot be fully incorporated into bilateral contracts.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: Over the past century, cars have undergone significant technological transformations, both internally and in their passenger compartments. These changes are largely due to advancements in electrical, electronic, and software engineering, as illustrated in Figure 2. A simplified timeline of automotive history highlights the expanding influence of these technologies in enabling vehicle features, with examples shown at the top of the figure indicating the approximate introduction dates of these applications.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: The computer and information industry's rapid growth has led to a surge in peripheral devices. The USB port, now standard on most computers, has become the dominant connection interface due to its convenience and ease of use. Its primary benefit is providing a universal connection for a wide range of devices, including hard drives, flash drives, printers, keyboards, and PDAs.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text:
Demand-side cyberattacks on power grids are launched
by manipulating internet-connected, high-power and often
behind-the-meter demand-side appliances such as EVs,
DERs, and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC)
loads. Although power grids have not encountered such
attacks in the past, there is mounting evidence to support
that such attacks could be executed using already existing
vulnerabilities. As a consequence of the attacks, power grid
operators will not be able to cope with them without resorting
to massive load shedding. For instance, previous work in [16]
revealed a cyber threat using publicly available EV charging
and power grid data. This can be exploited by an unsophisticated attacker with minimal capabilities (e.g., foreign and
domestic non-state actors). This work demonstrated that this
dilettante but realistic attack imposes minimal data requirements on the attacker, which can be fulfilled by exploring
EVCS smartphone applications for a real-time operational
status, charging prices, and historical usage profiles of the
EVCSs. Adversarial actors can scrape power grid data from
websites and technical documents of the local power utilities
and the concerned regulatory authorities to design the most
destructive attack strategy via impact-driven simulations. For
example, Fig. 1 shows a electrical transmission network and
EVCSs in Manhattan, NY, which was reconstructed using
exclusively public sources
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity of Smart Electric Vehicle Charging:
A Power Grid Perspective

Text: The implementation of a single-sourcing strategy centralizes IT system integration responsibilities within a singular vendor, thereby facilitating the externalization of IS maintenance and troubleshooting operations, which subsequently mitigates the client organization's necessity for extensive in-house IT expertise; consequently, the operational efficacy of the client organization's IT infrastructure becomes contingent upon the vendor's performance, while simultaneously streamlining contract management processes due to the consolidated nature of vendor engagements, however, the expanded scope and criticality of the single vendor's contractual obligations engender a heightened dependency, potentially rendering the client organization's operational integrity and implementation effectiveness vulnerable to the vendor's reliability and stability.

The research process commenced with Step 1, where interviewers transcribed their interviews verbatim to ensure accuracy and minimize the risk of misinterpretation. In Step 2, each interviewer conducted a thematic analysis, coding the transcripts to identify recurring patterns. These codes were then organized into broader themes during Step 3. Step 4 involved a collaborative effort, with all four researchers cross-comparing the themes to reach a consensus. The final analytical stage, Step 5, required the researchers to collectively identify the dominant and overarching themes that emerged from the data. Before constructing the written narrative of the findings, the thematic interpretation was validated through member checking, involving two owner-managers of social enterprises (SEs) who had participated in the study. This rigorous, multi-step approach ensured the reliability and validity of the analysis.

The load shedding scheme has a cost to customers, which depends on the outage costs and the generator forced outage rate.
Users outage costs can be defined approximately according to
power disconnected or damage function [3], [4]. System failure
rate is important in obtaining this cost since each time a load
shedding is applied in a system an interruption cost is incurred.
Power interruption costs ($/MW) seem to be more representative in this estimation than nonsupplied energy costs ($/MWh).
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: Additional potential real fault scenarios, such as the redirection of load from a non-fault feeder, are also generated using real fault simulation data. These simulations retain real fault data while replacing the current measurements of a non-fault feeder with zero. In total, 168 real faults involving a non-fault feeder being out of service and 108 simulated faults with single- or three-phase current amplification are generated to evaluate the performance of the proposed PNN.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: Generation facilities designated as Reliability Must-Run (RMR) units are bound by agreements that impact their tariff structure, dispatching, and market participation. Incorrectly selecting RMR units or quantities can jeopardize system security or create financial strain for the Independent System Operator (ISO) or generators. The method presented here determines RMR unit selection and capacity, while enabling RMR units to sell excess generation. This approach provides the ISO with flexibility to ensure system security through targeted RMR unit and capacity assignments, while still allowing Independent Power Producers (IPPs) to engage in competitive market activities.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: The preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics offer a holistic framework for quantifying cybersecurity, but other dynamics, such as adaptive, active, and proactive defenses, address different aspects of cyber defense. Adaptive defenses adjust to evolving threats, active defenses involve real-time countermeasures, and proactive defenses anticipate and mitigate threats before they occur. Proactive methods, for example, include threat hunting and preemptive actions to disrupt adversaries before attacks materialize. Adapting the event-based method to these diverse dynamics remains an open challenge for future research. This adaptation could enhance the efficiency and applicability of cybersecurity models across various defense strategies, enabling more comprehensive and anticipatory cyber defense systems.

This paper examines the effects of DRs on congestion management. To accurately and efficiently quantify these effects, a set of contribution factors—PLDG, QLDG, and VDG—are derived using AC power flow analysis with closed-form equations. The ITDA space provides a straightforward way to condense detailed data into distinct categories, while a fuzzy clustering technique helps define the effective boundaries of the ITDA space for both single and multiple constraints. These methods can aid in determining optimal locations and operational strategies for DRs. However, for large-scale systems, the computational cost of CF calculations must be considered due to variations in system configuration, generation scheduling, and load levels. Future numerical analyses will explore these challenges to enhance the practicality of these methods.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: StealthNet [5] is a U.S. Army-funded Live-Virtual-Constructive (LVC) platform designed for cyber testing, evaluation, and training on tactical networks, featuring emulation models for attacks like jamming, DDoS, and worm propagation to assess their impact on mission-critical systems. It specializes in wireless tactical network simulations, enabling LVC co-simulation to integrate real hardware, virtual environments, and AI-driven models for comprehensive cybersecurity training. By replicating adversarial cyber threats in a controlled setting, StealthNet helps the Army evaluate network resilience, train personnel, and develop countermeasures, ensuring secure communications in contested cyber-physical battlefields. Its integration with LVC frameworks allows scalable, realistic training scenarios, making it a vital tool for modern military cyber defense.

The risk-based inspection (RBI) methodology, formalized in API RP 581 [55], provides a well-established spreadsheet-driven framework for optimizing maintenance and inspection schedules in high-risk industries like Oil & Gas and Chemicals by correlating equipment conditions with potential failure mechanisms and probabilities. Originally developed for refining, this approach has been widely adapted across sectors to prioritize resource allocation based on risk severity, using data-driven assessments to balance safety requirements with operational efficiency while minimizing downtime?emonstrating the versatility of structured, risk-informed decision-making tools in industrial asset management.

The power community has acknowledged the importance of physical security for power infrastructure. Measures have been taken to prevent vandalism at unmanned substations. Given the increasing concern about potential sabotage, the focus on physical security has expanded to include critical substations, as disruptions here could lead to cascading effects and widespread blackouts. The use of sensors to monitor the structural health of transmission lines is also crucial in reducing power system vulnerability. Additionally, electronic security is equally vital as physical security due to the significant impact that can be achieved through the manipulation of critical cyberassets.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: In this note, we explore the impulsive control of nonlinear systems, building on the approach in. We derive less conservative conditions for the stability of impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses and then use these results to design impulsive control laws for a broader class of nonlinear systems. Our method can be applied to a wider range of nonlinear systems and has the potential to enhance existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Unlike previous approaches, our ontology is specifically designed for real-world cybersecurity operations, emphasizing the management of cybersecurity operational information. To ensure practicality and reusability, it has been developed through extensive discussions with cybersecurity operators, incorporating their expertise and requirements. This ontology serves as a structured framework for sharing and reusing operational cybersecurity data while also standardizing terminology, facilitating more efficient communication and collaboration across different organizations and systems.

The feasibility study investigates the potential impact of the new generation on system performance during normal and contingency conditions. The contingency analysis considers the impact of the new generation on transmission facility loading and transmission bus voltage during outages of transmission line, autotransformers, and generators. The latest version of the Southwest Power Pool 2005 summer peak base case was used for this study
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: The research process began with Step 1, where interviewers transcribed their interviews verbatim to minimize misinterpretation. In Step 2, each interviewer conducted a thematic analysis and coded every transcript. Following this, Step 3 involved collating the codes into broader themes. In Step 4, all four researchers cross-compared the themes to reach a consensus on the findings. Finally, in Step 5, the researchers collectively identified the overarching, dominant themes that emerged from the analysis. Before constructing the written narrative of the analyses, the thematic interpretation was member-validated with two owner-managers of social enterprises (SEs) who participated in the study, ensuring that the interpretations accurately reflected their experiences and insights. This rigorous analytical approach enhances the credibility and reliability of the findings.

This paper proposes a basic mathematical framework for the hybrid market and illustrates a simulation of its feasibility. In Section II-A, we describe a basic outline of our method and its underlying assumptions. Section II-B describes one iteration of the trading process. Section III-A graphically demonstrates the general properties of the trading process on an example net work topology with five out of the ten lines constrained. In Sec tion III-C, we describe the overall trends that we observed after simulating our method on 102 different network topologies. In Section IV, we conclude and outline considerations for future work.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text:
Certainly! Here's a rephrased version of the text:
There are numerous contingency combinations that could significantly impact the system, although the likelihood of most of these rare but severe events is generally low. To keep the complexity of the SPS manageable, it is essential to identify the most credible situations. This letter presents a framework for selecting contingency cases to be included in the design of a transient stability SPS. The framework accounts for the uncertainty in event occurrence and its consequences, combining them to produce a risk index for contingency selection.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: Given this premise, it should be no surprise that the railway industry has quickly become a massive user of novel networked and computerized systems to handle most aspects of its operations, thus replacing the ancient electromechanical systems onboard the train and off-board. Indeed, computer-based systems offer an almost unparalleled level of flexibility and performance, enabling operators to offer additional services like infotainment to passengers. Moreover, using this kind of technology, practitioners have access to a vast array of off-the-shelf components already for affine industries, thus significantly bringing down costs and speeding up deployments.

Securing IoT communications is critical due to the high-volume exchange of sensitive data between devices, servers, and end-users, where breaches of confidentiality, integrity, or availability (CIA) can trigger severe operational, financial, or safety repercussions. Weakly protected data streams not only expose vulnerabilities to theft [33] but also serve as entry points for systemic attacks, necessitating robust encryption, access controls, and anomaly detection to mitigate risks in interconnected IoT ecosystems.

Existing automated security systems often depend on passwords or smart cards for identification, which are susceptible to compromise through loss, sharing, theft, or copying. Biometric methods, using unique biological traits like iris scans or fingerprints, offer stronger security, but are still vulnerable to attacks such as database breaches, replay attacks, and brute-force attempts.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: Three cases were implemented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approaches. First, a scheduling problem for five interruptible load groups (ILGs) was solved using the Interruptible Load Group Scheduler (IDP), and a simple case was validated against conventional dynamic programming. In the second case, a daily load pattern for a capacity-constrained substation was modified using the DSS. The IDP scheduled 25 ILGs, and the results were adjusted by the HIR for practical application. The third case examined the impact of incentive rates on the scheduling process, which was not considered in the first two cases.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Harmonized standards provide the technical details to meet
the essential requirements of a specific legal act within the
European Union. They apply in all EU countries and replace
any conflicting national standards [50]. When harmonized
standards are used and applied in a correct way, they give
a presumption of conformity that legal requirements are
fulfilled. By implementing a harmonized standard, manufacturers and service providers can therefore demonstrate that
their services or products comply with relevant EU legislation. Only harmonised standards referred to and published in
the Official Journal of the European Union (OJEU) [51] ar
Journal Name:
A Comparative Analysis of Industrial
Cybersecurity Standards
