Journal Name:
Blockchain-Enabled Cybersecurity Efficient IIOHT
Cyber-Physical System for Medical Applications

Text: During a major system disturbance, such as the loss of generation, system frequency begins to drop. Generator governors respond to counteract this decline. However, if the available spinning reserve is insufficient or the governor response is weak, the frequency will continue to fall. If the frequency reaches the high-set underfrequency relay threshold, up to 1150 MW of LaaRs may be tripped to restore normal frequency. However, excessive load shedding can lead to frequency overshoot, potentially triggering generator protection schemes and causing cascading failures.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text:
In 2019, Mouheb et al. performed a survey on the efforts
that have been made on cybersecurity curriculum design [27].
Mouheb et al. showed the different approaches that are taken
by the universities to design and update the curriculum. These
approaches were categorized based on the main focus that
the educational body has taken, i.e., educational, industrial,
and defense. Therefore, the methods to design the curricula
that were adopted by these universities were based on their
internal strategies, and thus, these methods (and consequently
the curriculum) may not be suitable for other universities.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Education in Universities:
A Comprehensive Guide to Curriculum
Development

Text: This system proposes a Universal Remote Control (URC) solution designed to enhance automation and security in various smart buildings, including homes, schools, and public facilities. This smart URC enables control over a wide range of devices, such as televisions, DVD players, projectors, lighting, and motorized screens and curtains. Furthermore, it leverages Wi-Fi and camera integration to provide advanced functionalities like heating system control, security and disaster management, spatial awareness, and real-time control.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text:
In today?s digital landscape, cybersecurity is crucial for
organizational integrity and security. The growing frequency
and sophistication of cyberattacks make robust cybersecurity
measures and compliance essential. Compliance not only
strengthens defenses but also aligns organizations with legal
and ethical standards, maintaining stakeholder trust and
avoiding legal issues [1]. Failing to meet regulatory requirements can result in inadequate cybersecurity, increasing risks
like data breaches and network intrusions, which can lead
to severe consequences such as loss of reputation, financial
penalties, service disruptions, and even threats to human life.
Journal Name:
Optimal Job Role Allocation for Compliance
With NCA-ECC Controls Using the Saudi
Cybersecurity Workforce Framework

Text: To address instruction variability, the same textbook, core instruction, assignments, and exams were used across all four sections of the course, with consistent presentation materials except for specific noted differences. The course content focused on threats and countermeasures for various nonspecific cybersecurity threats to systems and applications, following the CSEC framework. Students were actively engaged during crucial learning points by responding to questions or suggesting remediations for programming code, firewalls, open ports, and more. Group projects and presentations were included to foster collaboration. Laboratory exercises provided hands-on experience with tools such as intrusion detection systems, threat modeling tools, network analyzers, infrastructure monitors, log analyzers, port scanners, penetration testers, vulnerability scanners, cryptographic programming, and static and dynamic code analyzers. This comprehensive approach ensured both theoretical understanding and practical application of cybersecurity concepts.

Security standards exhibit considerable variation in content, reflecting their specific purposes and the regulatory requirements of their originating regions or countries. Despite these differences, individual standards can simultaneously belong to multiple categories. For example, NIST 800-82, while initially developed as a U.S. national standard, has achieved international recognition due to its widespread adoption, while also being classified as a horizontal industrial standard. Similarly, ETSI EN 303 645 began as a European regional standard but has evolved into an internationally recognized framework through extensive global implementation. Figure 2 provides a visual representation of these classification dynamics. This complex categorization system often leads security practitioners to overlook important organizational differences and unique situational security requirements. The classification's scalability considerations significantly impact security control implementation, with controls varying in common or unique forms depending on factors like organizational size, complexity, information system mission criticality, and the organization's overall control scope.

In recent years, numerous researchers have explored impulsive systems and impulsive control. Studies such as [2]–[6] have analyzed the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, which must remain nonincreasing across the entire sequence or certain subsequences of switchings. Yang, in [1], established sufficient conditions for impulsive control in a specific class of nonlinear systems by leveraging findings from [3]. Similarly, Li et al. in [7] proposed less restrictive conditions for asymptotic stability in impulsive systems with impulses occurring at fixed times, applying these results to design impulsive control for certain nonlinear systems using insights from [3]. Additionally, studies [8]–[13] have demonstrated various applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication and chaotic spread spectrum communications. Panas et al. in [14] have also contributed by outlining experimental methods for implementing impulsive control.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: The control center's cyber environment, as shown in Figure 1, illustrates the connections between corporate networks, which are typically protected by firewalls. The control center network connects to other corporate networks, as well as substation and power plant networks managed by IT professionals. Control center networks are generally considered highly secure and less likely to be directly breached. This research focuses on intrusions into control center networks through other networks, such as those at substations or power plants.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: Harmonized standards define the technical specifications required to meet the essential legal requirements within the European Union, ensuring uniform application across all member states while replacing conflicting national standards. When properly implemented, these standards provide a presumption of conformity, indicating compliance with legal obligations. By adopting harmonized standards, manufacturers and service providers can demonstrate that their products or services align with relevant EU legislation. Only those standards officially referenced and published in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJEU) are recognized for this purpose.

This paper presents two intervention models targeted at
impacting middle school students? cybersecurity awareness
and training [34]?[39]. The first approach is a 60-minute
workshop model where participants take a hands-on lesson in
networking and can then apply that knowledge in an interactive
exhibit. The second approach is a week-long experience during which participants build websites and, on the fifth and
final day, defend themselves from an ongoing cyberattack.
Results suggest that the second intervention was effective, with
overall increases in teenagers? cybersecurity engagement and
self-efficacy. Moreover, this intervention successfully closed
the gender gaps in cybersecurity engagement and self-efficacy.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Interventions for Teens: Two
Time-Based Approaches

Text:
These Delphi processes are part of a larger project:
educational Cybersecurity Assessment Tools (CATS -
http://www.cisa.umbc.edu/cats/index.html). This larger project
aims to create a Cybersecurity Concept Inventory (CCI) and
a Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment (CCA). The CCI
is for students completing any first course in cybersecurity;
CCA is for students graduating from college about to enter
the workforce as cybersecurity professionals. Accordingly, the
project completed two separate Delphi processes in parallel,
one for CCI, and one for CCA.
Journal Name: Identifying Core Concepts of Cybersecurity:

Text: As illustrated in Figure 3, the frequency initially drops due to increased load, then returns to normal. The overshoot occurs because generators G1, G4, and G5 collectively increase their power output to correct the frequency deviation. Each contributes to primary control, and since G1 and G4 are under AGC, they also participate in supplementary control. The second plot in Figure 3 shows the power outputs in CA1 (similar to CA2). After the transient, generators G2 and G3's outputs match their bilateral load variations, while G1's output adjusts slightly before stabilizing.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text:
In order to ensure the presented analysis is as exhaustive
as possible, several reports and articles related to this topic
were considered. The proposed PESTLE analysis can be
understood as a summary of the current state of cybersecurity
education-related research. In this section, the focus will be on
reviewing research that utilized a PESTLE analysis approach
to explore cybersecurity education. For a more comprehensive
review of cybersecurity education-related publications see
Sections III and IV.
Journal Name:
Understanding Cybersecurity Education
Gaps in Europe

Text:
The control techniques which are most viable and for easy
implementation to home automation system are presented
here. In designing the equipment accepting the commands
from the remote control devices a standard of 16 appliances
are considered here and the coding scheme is shown in table
I. The appliances are given item code in order to select the
appliance for control and action code might be ‘ON’ of ‘OFF’
as to select the action needed. The final control element for
switching ON or OFF each appliance is a relay stacked in a
relay board shown as a simple scheme in Fig.1. The relay
board has a relay register which is updated by the incoming
command retaining the switched status of other appliances.
Obviously the word-length of the relay register is 16 bits for
controlling 16 appliances.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: A recent online report [26] by Joe Weiss highlights the significant cybersecurity risks associated with foreign-made power transformers and other critical grid components. As essential elements of the electric grid, power transformers are increasingly vulnerable to cyber attacks from external threat actors, with grid interconnectivity amplifying the potential impact of a compromised transformer on the entire system. Concerns have been raised about hardware backdoors embedded in these transformers, which could enable attackers to manipulate operations and cause catastrophic failures. Despite these risks, many utilities continue to depend on foreign-made equipment due to cost considerations, overlooking the potential dangers. The predominant focus on network vulnerabilities, while neglecting hardware threats, further exacerbates risks to critical infrastructure, leaving power transformers exposed to hidden cyber threats. The report emphasizes the urgent need for both the utility sector and government to address hardware-related vulnerabilities to enhance the security and resilience of critical infrastructure.

Internal knowledge flow facilitation presents significant challenges that often prevent organizations from realizing knowledge's full potential, thereby increasing ambidexterity costs. Managers who perceive themselves in competition for limited resources may deliberately withhold function-specific knowledge that could benefit other units, while simultaneously resisting new knowledge implementation out of concern for promoting ideas originating from competing departments. The integration of diverse managerial practices?merging from fundamentally different thought processes and cultural frameworks?reates substantial barriers to effective knowledge sharing and potentially intensifies resource competition dynamics throughout the organization.

In summary, a communications system using analog trans mission is sensitive to channel noise and, hence, increased synchronization errors. It is the nature of DDF systems that complicated nonlinear functions give high-dimension chaos but are also increasingly susceptible to channel noise. Future work will include digital transmission techniques that are expected to greatly reduce synchronization errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: Impulsive systems and control have garnered significant research interest recently. Notable works by Bainov and Simeonov, Lakshmikantham et al., and Lakshmikantham and Liu have explored the stability of these systems using Lyapunov functions. Traditionally, these functions were required to decrease consistently across all switching events. However, Li et al. relaxed this constraint, requiring the Lyapunov function to decrease only along a subset of switchings. Yang, building on prior work, developed sufficient conditions for impulsive control in nonlinear systems. Furthermore, Yang and Chua, along with Yang et al., demonstrated the practical applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication and spread spectrum systems. Panas et al. provided experimental methodologies for implementing these impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Our results are illustrated in Figure 4, which shows eye diagrams of recovered messages using closed-loop and open-loop receivers with authorized access. The closed-loop receiver perfectly recovers the message, while the open-loop receiver produces a poor quality signal. Additionally, after applying a simple linear filtering process to the signal, we found that a message with a 5% amplitude remains undetectable, whereas a 7.5% amplitude message can be detected. This highlights the importance of keeping the message amplitude low to ensure it remains hidden within the chaotic carrier.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: The system identified the fault at a distance of 67.28 miles from the station, with a maximum and minimum estimated locations of 67.36 miles and 66.33 miles, respectively. Past experience indicates that the actual fault location consistently falls within this range. The error in the fault distance estimate was calculated to be 0.27%. The results also include the maximum RMS currents recorded during the fault, along with the corresponding voltages for each monitored phase of the affected transmission line. Additionally, the system reports the impedance of the faulted line up to the fault location, including the line angle. The estimated fault duration was 97.76 milliseconds.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text:
Cybersecurity vulnerability assessment models, frameworks,
and tools are very efficient in identifying gaps and vulnerabilities in a network, system, or facility. However, these tools do
not have the capability to ingest user requirements and produce
a mitigation method supported by mathematical and logical
constructs. This paper presented a framework and methodology
that can be implemented with some of the well-vetted vulnerability analysis frameworks, such as C2M2, CSF, and RMF. This
paper also demonstrated the proposed mitigation framework by
testing with a real-world cyberattack. Through the presented attack-based analysis, it was evident that the mitigation methodology, CyFEr, was able to perform an efficient analysis through
several thousands of possible solutions to reach a maturity.
CyFEr also identified the potential ideal solutions that could
meet all of the user requirements while reaching a desired
cybersecurity maturity. Future work and publications will focus
on enhancing the presented mitigation methodology to add
needed complexity and a stage-based approach to ensure that
the controls are layered based on their relative weights/masses
in addition to their MIL.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Vulnerability Mitigation Framework
Through Empirical Paradigm (CyFEr):
Prioritized Gap Analysis

Text: Prior investigations into equilibrium estimation [48] have been confined to restricted parameter spaces, within which dynamic convergence was established for specific parameter configurations, notably the global attack-defense graph structure; conversely, this study extends the scope of inquiry to encompass the entire parameter universe, thereby enhancing the generalizability of the results to a wider array of scenarios; this expansion is facilitated by the theoretical demonstration of global convergence across the entire parameter universe [4], enabling the development of estimation methodologies applicable to broader and more diverse cybersecurity contexts.

The HNN-based authentication scheme is self-contained. The recall mechanism is error-free, as the registration process ensures an exact match between each valid user ID and its corresponding password. Any invalid pair is automatically rejected. However, to evaluate the scheme's effectiveness, we compared it with the existing layered neural network method described in [9]. Two simulation experiments were conducted: the first measured the computational time for registration, and the second assessed performance when many passwords had similar character sequences.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: We have explored the problem of impulsive control using the framework of impulsive differential equations. Sufficient conditions were established to guarantee the asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems. These findings were further applied to designing impulsive control strategies for a class of nonlinear systems. Our approach contributes to enhancing existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text:
Currently, it is difficult to conclude whether the key length
is satisfactory because the answer depends on the security
concept we consider. An appropriate security concept exists
for control systems, such as indistinguishability against parameter estimation attack (IND-PEA), proposed in [45],
which is in provable security and revealed that IND-PEA is
equal to indistinguishability under the chosen plaintext attack
(IND-CPA). The updatable ElGamal-based encrypted control
system [41], [46], which covers computational security,
protects the controller parameters from being identified by
attackers, even though the key length is shorter than that
required by NIST. Furthermore, key updating ideas help
solve real-time constraint issues. Such a security concept
that is appropriate for control systems has recently been
studied; therefore, appropriate security may exist for the 256-
bits KH-PKE scheme. Exploring the appropriate security
concept is significant for developing the control theory and
cryptography fields, which will be explored in our future
study. Additionally, in the sense of achieving IND-CCA1/2,
the key length is insufficient because it is less than 2048 bits.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity-Enhanced Encrypted Control
System Using Keyed-Homomorphic
Public Key Encryption

Text: Our analysis highlights the nonuniform adoption of infor mation security personnel within health-care organizations. Many organizations have developed information systems for the collection and storage of patient data, but do not adopt corresponding security committees or teams, nor security man ager/officers or coordinators. Overall, about one-half (50%) of the hospital-based respondents have an information security individual, a significantly higher percentage compared to clinic (37%) and other (42%) practice setting respondents. Hospitals here were twice as likely to have adopted an information security officer, compared to outpatient settings.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text:
Big data is now a common slogan used to mean the generation of large volumes of data. Enormous amount of data are
being generated at an alarming rate. This is due to the
growth of the Internet. Laney [1] came up with the term the
three V?s which he associated with big data. These terms
were volume, velocity, and variety. In addition to 3 V?s,
there is fourth V which is veracity. Volume represents the
fact that the data being generated is enormous, velocity represents the fact that data is being generated at an alarming
rate, and variety represents the fact that the data being generated comes in all types of forms. Big Data could be
explained simply as data at rest according to Miloslavskaya
et al. [2]. They also highlighted the difference between big
data, data lake, and fast data. Data lake holds a large amount
of raw data in its original format. Fast data can be time sensitive data which may either be structured or unstructured,
which is usually acted upon right away.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity in Big Data Era: From Securing
Big Data to Data-Driven Security

Text: Researchers are increasingly focusing on phishing kits due to the significant threat posed by large-scale phishing attacks. A critical aspect of this research is the availability of datasets, which can be challenging to create. Currently, data collection often relies on known phishing sources that provide kits but lack connections to actual phishing website attacks. Consequently, researchers utilize these samples to generate phishing websites, which limits the evaluation of detection methods as the data may be influenced by the researchers' choices during sample collection. To address these issues, a new dataset called PhiKitA has been introduced, which accurately links phishing kits with real phishing websites, thereby enhancing the reliability of research in this domain and providing valuable insights into the characteristics and behaviors of phishing attacks.

Equation (3) is used to assess the deviation of the incentive rate for a given ILG. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the weighted function approaches one when the incentive rate of the ILG is near the average incentive rate of all ILGs. If the incentive rate exceeds the average, the weighted function increases the objective function, reducing the likelihood of interruption for that ILG. Conversely, if the incentive rate falls below the average, the weighted function decreases the objective function, making the ILG more susceptible to interruption.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text:
Thus, in order to realize DBHS, there is a need for new CA
systems that can prevent illegal copying and regulate the use
of stored digital content by receivers. Furthermore, because it
is easy to edit and re-construct programs using metadata, there
is a requirement for access control systems that will allow the
broadcaster to regulate the ways in which content can be used.
In this paper, security systems capable of protecting the rights
of content and controlling access to content are referred to as
digital rights management (DRM) systems [4]. DRM has been
studied previously as a platform for rights protection and access
control for content on the Internet. The technical gap between
CA for broadcasting and DRM for communication is gradually
closing.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: In the private sector, recent research efforts have focused on developing more comprehensive cybersecurity training systems to meet long-term security challenges. Modern training platforms often include graphical user interfaces for environment configuration, autonomous red/blue team agents, and automated scoring mechanisms. However, these privately developed systems face limitations due to the lack of full integration, reducing their effectiveness in delivering comprehensive, hands-on training. To address these gaps, this work introduces ICSTASY, a novel cybersecurity training platform designed to provide holistic support for a wide range of training capabilities, ensuring a more immersive and practical learning experience.

The domain of critical infrastructure has emerged as a prominent target for cyberattacks, attributable to the increasing interconnectivity between previously isolated operational technology (OT) networks and information technology (IT) networks, thereby rendering formerly air-gapped systems susceptible to internet exposure. Contemporary adversarial trends have precipitated a surge in targeted cyberattacks directed at both industrial control systems (ICS) and building automation systems. Furthermore, the prevailing deficit in cybersecurity workforce availability compounds the challenges faced by organizations in securing their systems. Game-based learning methodologies are gaining increasing recognition, with research demonstrating their efficacy as educational components. The training of facility operators responsible for critical service provision can be effectively achieved through the gamification of security policies and controls. The Network Defense Training Game (NDTG) represents a cybersecurity training platform that incorporates a series of cybersecurity events, necessitating player assessment and responsive action to defend the network against adversarial attacks throughout the scenario. NDTG employs scenario narratives grounded in historical cyber incidents affecting ICS environments. It is designed to equip facility owners and operators with the skills to evaluate their cybersecurity posture and to implement cybersecurity frameworks both proactively and reactively in the context of cyber events and incidents. This study provides a comprehensive technical overview and architectural design of NDTG, and demonstrates its potential to enhance the capabilities of the ICS cybersecurity workforce.

Artificial intelligence algorithms play a pivotal role in enhancing cybersecurity and attack detection, often outperforming traditional intrusion detection systems such as Snort and Suricata in various scenarios. This research focuses on evaluating the characteristics of well-established machine learning algorithms commonly applied in intrusion detection system (IDS) contexts. Initially, a categorization of cybersecurity datasets is proposed, grouping records into several categories to facilitate analysis. This study aims to determine which neural network models?pecifically multilayer or recurrent networks?long with their respective activation functions and learning algorithms, yield the highest accuracy based on the categorized data groups. The findings will ultimately identify the most relevant and representative data groups within cybersecurity datasets for effective intrusion detection, as well as the optimal configuration of machine learning algorithms that can minimize the computational load of these systems. By leveraging advanced machine learning techniques, organizations can not only improve their threat detection capabilities but also enhance their overall cybersecurity strategies, making them more adaptive to evolving cyber threats.

We have successfully demonstrated a novel RNG that leverages the large fluctuating current of the MOS structure following soft breakdown. This RNG features a compact design comprising approximately 20 logic gates and several passive components. The random numbers produced by this RNG have successfully passed various high-level tests, confirming they are high-quality random numbers closely resembling true random numbers. This makes our RNG a promising solution for cryptographic security applications in mobile network services.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed system, we study its
sensitivity when there is parameter mismatch in Chua’s circuit. We investigate the cases when , , and m0 have 1% mismatch in the receiver, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the key sequences errors between the
encrypter and the decrypter. We can see that the error signals are not
stable, that is, the key sequences in the encrypter and the decrypter are
completely different. The original speech signal cannot be recovered
from the incorrect reflection coefficients and the residual signal in the
receiver.
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: In August 2017, the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) introduced a groundbreaking workforce development tool through NIST Special Publication 800-181?he National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Framework [24]. This internationally adopted taxonomy systematically classifies cybersecurity roles, skills, and competencies across seven core categories, serving as both a workforce planning tool and curriculum development benchmark. Continuously refined to reflect evolving industry needs, the framework underwent its latest significant update in November 2020 [23], incorporating emerging domains like cloud security orchestration and AI threat detection.

Building on these foundational studies, our work introduces the AICyber-Chain model, which integrates AI and blockchain for secure data sharing and transmission. This model leverages blockchain? decentralized ledger to ensure data integrity while utilizing AI? analytical capabilities to dynamically enhance security measures, creating a robust framework for protecting sensitive information.

The Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC), mandated by Saudi Arabia's National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA), create a unified cybersecurity baseline for government entities, critical infrastructure, and digital service providers, offering sector-specific safeguards against evolving threats through 114 controls that cover risk management, access control, encryption, and incident response. By enforcing standardized protections tailored to organizational risk profiles, the ECC ensures resilient defenses against attacks like ransomware, data breaches, and supply chain compromises, while mandatory compliance audits drive continuous improvement?aking it a model for national cybersecurity frameworks worldwide.

Cyberattacks are becoming more frequent, with significant financial impacts, yet their severity appears to have plateaued. A single cyberattack can cost an organization an average of $229,000, contributing to global losses in the hundreds of billions of dollars. While many organizations consider cyber insurance as a protective measure, this may not be viable for social enterprises (SEs) due to financial constraints. Additionally, since SEs prioritize societal impact over profit, financial compensation alone may not adequately address the broader consequences of cybercrime. Just as SEs struggle to quantify their social value, measuring the full impact of cybercrime?nd insuring against it?emains a challenge.

This paper focuses on low-power motion detection with partial modifications to conventional image sensor chips. Through computer simulations, we demonstrate that only a few thousand image data points are sufficient to achieve motion detection accuracy comparable to standard CMOS image sensors. The system achieves low power consumption by utilizing only a small percentage of total pixels and a single bit per selected pixel. Additionally, unused blocks of the CMOS image sensor (CIS) are placed in standby mode to conserve power. This architecture is being developed using 0.35?m standard CMOS technology (1-P, 4-M) with a pixel array of 128?96.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text:
Although the initial definitions of big data relied on the
3V?s [21], more recent ones add more characteristics to big
data and identify 7V?s [22], i.e., volume, velocity, variety,
variability, veracity, value, and validity. Indeed, BDA
involves extracting insights from large and complex datasets
and aims to improve the understanding of a system or dataset
and predict anomalies or future behavior [11]. However,
when used for cybersecurity, the amount of data supporting
analytics operations can impact its effectiveness
Journal Name:
DBD-Guardian and Privacy-Aware Near
Real-Time Cybersecurity Analytics

Text: The rapid proliferation of electric vehicles (EVs) has elevated user privacy to a critical concern, particularly during information exchange scenarios such as vehicle charging or software-based interactions, where vehicle actuators collect sensitive data?ncluding location, identification, payment details, and driving habits?osing significant risks if compromised. Prior research, such as [23], has surveyed privacy solutions for EVs and smart grids, while [24] investigated challenges specific to EVs and EVSEs, with studies like [25] proposing privacy-preserving payment schemes that balance anonymity and traceability, and others like [26] addressing location privacy, alongside authentication frameworks for EV-power station interactions [27][28], collectively underscoring the urgent need for comprehensive EV privacy assessments.

The strategic behavior of power suppliers in the market at any given time step k is influenced by factors such as demand elasticity, system residual demand, transmission reliability index, generation reliability index, fuel costs, and market clearing price—all of which are inherently random variables. If market participants act rationally, they will adhere to energy market operator rules to mitigate price volatility and profit loss risks. For example, they may bid or offer within a 10% tolerance of the previous trading period’s clearing price to remain competitive [11]. Mathematical modeling of these strategic bidding practices is a growing area of research [9], [10].
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: Facilitating internal knowledge flows within a firm is essential for realizing the full potential of certain knowledge, yet it often increases the cost of achieving organizational ambidexterity. Managers may hesitate to share function-specific knowledge that could benefit other units due to perceived competition for resources, leading to a reluctance to implement new ideas that might promote the initiatives of other teams. This dynamic creates barriers to effective knowledge sharing, as differing managerial practices and cultural perspectives can complicate collaboration and raise the likelihood of resource competition. Addressing these challenges requires fostering a culture of openness and trust, where knowledge sharing is encouraged and recognized, thus enabling organizations to leverage collective insights and enhance innovation while balancing exploration and exploitation effectively.

CDA-based end-to-end encryption offers greater flexibility for varying connected backbones across different epochs. In hop-by-hop encryption, only nodes with the corresponding key can decrypt and aggregate data. However, with CDA, any node can be elected as an aggregator since they do not need to store the key to process incoming ciphertext messages. This allows the election process for each epoch to be based solely on the nodes' remaining energy levels. CDA ensures confidentiality without limiting the aggregator-node-election algorithms, thereby enhancing the robustness and reliability of the WSN.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text:
Criteria-based decision-making calculations that encompass
a variety of available criteria that are assigned different priorities and weights are often very subjective. Validated datasets are
required to make accurate quantitative decision-making calculations [25]; however, the necessary data are not always available,
which can become a major roadblock for cybersecurity research.
Researchers have looked at using various rank methods for similar data-constrained scenarios [11]?[16]. The use of these similar
techniques for a cybersecurity vulnerability assessment has not
been recorded in the literature.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Vulnerability Mitigation Framework
Through Empirical Paradigm (CyFEr):
Prioritized Gap Analysis

Text:
Innovation oriented and cost oriented approaches balance
exploitative and exploratory behaviors respectively and
have a positive effect on innovative ambidexterity. Adaptability is a firm?s ability to react to changes in their environment which is inspired by management conveying an
urgency to do so to employees which leads to innovative
new ideas. Alignment is a firm?s ability to effectively allocate resources, maximize efficiency, and encourage interdepartmental collaboration toward these objectives which
leads to cost-effective solutions (see also [16]). Innovation orientation refers to a firm?s openness to new ideas.
Cost orientation refers to a firm?s cost-efficient mindset
that balances their desires to innovate. Innovative firms,
although geared toward exploratory projects, are poised
to take on both discontinuous and incremental innovations
which means innovation ambidexterity increases. Cost orientation improves innovation ambidexterity by balancing
explorative behavior induced by innovation orientation
with exploratory behavior.
Journal Name:
Ambidextrous Cybersecurity: The Seven Pillars (7Ps)
of Cyber Resilience

Text:
In the proposed system, there are three types of receivers, all utilizing RF signals based on the IEEE802.15.4 standard, particularly the ZigBee protocol. The RF to IR-RS232 receiver, shown in Fig. 2, is used for a lighting control system that employs IR and UART communication protocols. This receiver receives control signals from the URC via RF protocol and converts them to RS232 signals. The RS485 converter then transmits these RS232 signals to various locations for efficient home lighting control.
Additionally, the RF to IR-Relay receiver, depicted in Figs. 3 and 4, can be connected to electronic appliances such as electric motorized screens, curtains, and windows. This receiver, connected to the URC, uses RF signals to control appliances with both AC and DC motors.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: Critical infrastructure has become a prime target for cyberattacks as operational technology (OT) networks, once considered secure due to air-gapping, are increasingly exposed to the internet through integration with informational technology (IT) networks. This growing connectivity has led to a surge in targeted attacks on industrial control systems (ICS) and building automation systems. The shortage of skilled cybersecurity professionals further complicates defense efforts. Game-based learning has emerged as an effective training method, with studies showing its potential to enhance cybersecurity education. The Network Defense Training Game (NDTG) is a cybersecurity training platform designed to equip facility operators with the skills needed to defend against cyber threats. By simulating real-world cyber incidents affecting ICS, NDTG challenges players to assess and respond to attacks, reinforcing their ability to apply cybersecurity frameworks both proactively and reactively. This study explores the technical architecture of NDTG and highlights its role in strengthening the ICS cybersecurity workforce.

An isolated power system such as the TPS is sensitive in responding to frequency deviations, therefore; SOs need to schedule a sufficient reserve capacity, which utilizes the AGCfunctions of online generating units to regulate the active power and balance system load demand. In the daily operation of an isolated power system, an adequate provision of FRR within a few seconds following the loss of an online unit is essential to maintain system frequency within acceptable levels. The FRR is required to continuously balance the isolated power system’s supply resource instantaneous demand varia tion in order to meet the reliability and control performance standards.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: This paper will proceed in the following manner: First, a novel comparison theorem and a set of conditions for the stability of impulsive differential systems will be introduced. These findings will then be used to create an impulsive control strategy for nonlinear systems. The paper will conclude with a summary of the main points.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: Risk-Based Inspection (RBI) is a well-established methodology utilized in the oil and gas and chemical industries, focusing on optimizing inspection strategies based on risk assessments. Initially developed by the American Petroleum Institute (API) in API RP 581 for the refining sector, RBI correlates maintenance activities with significant events in these industries. It allows for the identification of failure mechanisms and rates by adapting inspection activities to the specific status of equipment. The approach emphasizes the importance of targeting high-risk components, thereby enhancing safety and operational efficiency. By systematically assessing the probability of failure (PoF) and the consequence of failure (CoF), RBI helps prioritize inspection resources effectively. This methodology has been adapted across various sectors, demonstrating its versatility in improving asset integrity management and ensuring compliance with safety regulations. Despite being rooted in established practices, ongoing developments in RBI techniques continue to emerge, indicating a promising direction for future research and application.

By providing a unified approach for designing the curricula, showing the good-practice curricula and developing a
practical software tool usable for curricula design, we hope
to boost new cybersecurity study programs at universities and
training institutions while emphasizing the interdisciplinary
nature of cybersecurity. Furthermore, we hope that the new
programs will be designed according to specific rules and
standardized approaches reflecting the actual requirements of
particular cybersecurity positions.
Journal Name:
Framework, Tools and Good Practices for
Cybersecurity Curricula

Text:
A key responsibility of cybersecurity is to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data and systems [23].
This can be achieved, in part, by implementing a suitable
set of controls, policies, processes as well as organizational
structures that support a systematic mitigation of cyber risks.
Cybersecurity will continue to pose a significant challenge in
the years ahead. The implementation of best practices in organizations is greatly supported by the use of standards [24].
These documents serve as a set of regulations that specify
how organizations should carry out their operations and processes. Security standards are often embraced because they
are proved to be effective in providing well-structured security requirements and controls. They provide a multitude of
benefits that justify the time and financial resources required
to produce and apply them. A raising number of manufacturers and vendors are using these standards in order to
produce and sell standards-compliant products and services.
Governments and businesses increasingly mandate the implementation of security standards as well. According to a recent
survey conducted by Gartner, Inc. [25], 75% of organizations
are actively seeking security vendor consolidation in 2022,
which marks a significant increase from 29% in 2020. The
requirement for secure integration and compatibility of ICT
systems using technical standards is increasingly necessary.
This is especially relevant in open markets where individuals
have the ability to combine equipment and services from
various providers, resulting in cost-saving benefits for organizations. The rapid growth of IoT devices, cyber-physical
systems, and algorithm-controlled embedded systems like
autonomous vehicles and digital twins is also contributing to
this need [10]. Cloud computing relies heavily on standardization of hardware, software, and the services they run to
ensure interoperability [26]. However, as cloud computing
expands, connected systems will be exposed to new and
evolving cybersecurity threats. In response, a growing number of organizations are participating and contributing to the
development of cybersecurity standards. This has resulted in
a significant increase in the number of standards. This trend
is expected to continue, necessitating the development of new
standards in the future.
Journal Name:
A Comparative Analysis of Industrial
Cybersecurity Standards

Text: This correspondence provides a systematic analysis of brute-force attacks against our palmprint system, which uses Competitive Code as features and angular distance for matching. We employ a projected multinomial distribution to model the relationship between the probability of false acceptance and the number of attacks. Our analysis shows that if the system threshold is set below 0.39, it becomes computationally infeasible to breach our palmprint system using brute-force methods.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: To comprehensively evaluate the proposed Probabilistic Neural Network (PNN), a variety of realistic fault scenarios were created. These included simulations of situations where the load from a non-faulty feeder was redirected, based on actual fault simulation data. These real fault scenarios also included instances where the current measurements of a non-faulty feeder were set to zero. In total, 168 real fault cases, with a non-faulty feeder out of service, and 108 simulated (fake) fault cases, where single- or three-phase currents were amplified, were generated to test the PNN's effectiveness.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

There were no main effects for gender or workshop in terms
of Cyber and Digital Awareness, nor was the the Male x
Treatment interaction significant in the Cyber and Digital
Awareness scale. In other words, there was no significant
growth for males or females overall or as a result of the
workshop; controlling for baseline scores, males and females
indicated similar scores on the CDA.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Interventions for Teens: Two
Time-Based Approaches

Text: As substation automation systems transition to network-based communication, the risk of cyber threats to protection systems increases. A successful cyber intrusion could disrupt measurement transmission from an electronic instrument transformer and inject false data into the protection system, potentially causing misoperation. To complement existing security measures, this paper proposes a context information-based cyber security protection approach. When a fault is detected using measurements from one or more instrument transformers, data from the entire substation is gathered for pattern classification to validate the fault. A probabilistic neural network (PNN) is employed as a pattern classifier. Testing with real and simulated fault scenarios, generated using predefined rules, demonstrates that the proposed PNN effectively distinguishes fake faults from real ones using optimized smoothing parameters.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: Under the proposed approach, the Market Monitoring Board (MMB) would function as an independent body with both technical and political authority. Its role would be to proactively assess market competitiveness and calculate Market Control Factors (MCFs), which would then be shared with market participants. The MCFs would establish limits on market behavior, ensuring that no entity exploits market power while also addressing concerns related to system reliability and security.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: The rapid expansion of internet accessibility, from 20% of the global population in 2005 to 63% in 2021, has led to a significant rise in internet users, reaching 4.9 billion people. This exponential growth has increased concerns about user protection and data security, making cybersecurity a priority for law enforcement agencies (LEAs), research centers, and the general public. As cyber threats evolve, safeguarding digital assets and personal information becomes crucial, driving the need for advanced security measures and continuous research in cybersecurity.

"Our proposed system minimizes computational overhead during group key refreshes, requiring only a few simple multiplication and addition operations. Each subscriber receives a Head Group Key (HRGK) from the transport stream. Using this HRGK and their stored secret keys, they can derive the necessary group and authorization keys. Furthermore, subscriber join/leave events are handled efficiently by broadcasting a single package containing the new secret group key. To enhance security, Authorization Keys (AKs) are typically refreshed daily. In our scheme, changing the HRGK automatically refreshes all AKs. Therefore, the system broadcasts just one package with the new HRGK, significantly reducing the daily computational burden.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: This paper proposes a methodology for assessing the security of EIS and power systems based on Petri Nets (PNs) Theory. The methodology not only models the operating sequences of protection devices but also incorporates uncertainty in their operation using Generalized Stochastic Petri Nets (GSPN). It also measures the impact of this uncertainty on security assessment. The approach establishes a relationship between the operating states of power systems and the places in PN models to identify PN places that represent non-secure operating states.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: We have developed a new class of ultra-broadband, nanoscale, and cost-effective position sensors. This innovation significantly extends the frequency range and enhances the resolution of existing vibrometers and seismographs by a factor of 10?100, depending on the base model. Examples of such base models include the American KS-1/KS-54000 and FBA-23, the European GS-13 and STS-1/STS-2, and the Russian SM-3, which was used for comparison in our tests. The prototype of the new sensor is capable of converting vibrations in buildings and structures with amplitudes greater than 1 nm into detectable electrical signals. This exceptional resolution is achieved due to the higher measurement precision enabled by frequency-based detection. In contrast, position sensors relying on inductance-change detection, such as those using lithographically fabricated single-layer flat coils, demonstrate a resolution that is three orders of magnitude lower [11].
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text:
The lack of appropriate cyber security measures
deployed on Internet of Things (IoT) makes these devices prone
to security issues. Consequently, the timely identification and
detection of these compromised devices become crucial. Machine
learning (ML) models which are used to monitor devices in a
network have made tremendous strides. However, most of the
research in profiling and identification uses the same data for
training and testing. Hence, a slight change in the data renders
most learning algorithms to work poorly. In this article, we study
a transferability approach based on the concept of transductive transfer learning for IoT device profiling and identification.
Notably, this type of transfer learning works by explicitly assigning labels to the test data in the target domain by using the test
feature space in the target domain, with training data from the
source domain. Specifically, we propose a three-component system
comprising: 1) the device type identification; 2) the vulnerability assessment; and 3) the visualization module. The device type
identification component uses the underlying concept of transductive transfer learning where the trained model is transferred
to a remote lab for testing. A variety of ML models are evaluated with respect to accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score in
order to determine which are the most suitable for the proposed
transferability profiling. Furthermore, the vulnerability of the
predicted device type is also assessed by using three vulnerability
databases: 1) Vulners; 2) National Vulnerability Database (NVD);
and 3) IBM X-Force. Finally, the results from the vulnerability
assessment are visualized and displayed on a dashboard.
Journal Name:
Transferability of Machine Learning Algorithm for
IoT Device Profiling and Identification

Text:
The GNSS represents a new era of navigation that uses
space-based navigation, rather than conventional terrestrial
radio navigation aids. Ground-based navigation aids have
many limitations, such as the cost of installation and periodic
requirement for flight inspection [48]. Furthermore, the clearance area required around ground-based radio navigation aids
restricts the heights of nearby buildings.
Journal Name:
Studying Cybersecurity in Civil Aviation,
Including Developing and Applying Aviation
Cybersecurity Risk Assessment

Text: The design of cybersecurity laboratories necessitates adherence to specific features and guidelines, as outlined in prior research [1, 5, 27, 68], which can be summarized as follows: (1) laboratory machines must possess internet connectivity to facilitate the acquisition of essential tools and access to online resources; (2) isolation of laboratory machines from campus networks is imperative to maintain security and prevent unintended network interactions; (3) the laboratory networking environment should emulate real-world scenarios, enabling the execution of prevalent cybersecurity exercises; (4) efficient resource management, allocation, and scalability are crucial to accommodate assignments of varying complexity; (5) adequate staffing with IT personnel is required to ensure maintenance and timely troubleshooting; and (6) the laboratory should be distributed, providing equitable access to both on-campus and off-campus students, thereby ensuring comprehensive educational accessibility.

The escalating global demand for cybersecurity professionals has driven standards organizations and governments to systematically track workforce requirements and develop competency frameworks?esulting in tools like the NICE Framework and ENISA's cybersecurity role blueprints that categorize specialized skills across threat landscapes. These efforts have produced: (1) standardized taxonomies mapping 52+ cybersecurity roles to 1,000+ knowledge/skill requirements, (2) national upskilling initiatives addressing sector-specific gaps (e.g., healthcare IoT security), and (3) credentialing pathways aligning academic programs with industry certifications (ISC2, CompTIA). We analyze these frameworks' efficacy in bridging the 4 million professional shortfall, particularly their adoption by universities still struggling to translate theoretical curricula into job-ready competencies for modern attack surfaces like AI-powered threats or cloud-native infrastructures.

The Delphi processes establish a critical foundation for creating evidence-based cybersecurity education tools, offering educators data-driven insights on effective teaching strategies, curriculum design, and student engagement to cultivate and retain future professionals. By quantifying expert consensus on importance, difficulty, and timelessness, the numerical ratings provide a structured way to prioritize core concepts in curriculum development, training exercises, and policy-making. This rigorous approach ensures that cybersecurity education aligns with real-world demands, equipping students with enduring, high-impact knowledge while optimizing instructional methods to bridge the workforce skills gap. The findings serve as a benchmark for standardizing and improving cybersecurity training programs across academic and professional settings.

The primary goal of regulatory must-run units is to ensure fair competition in a deregulated market. A notable example of such units is hydro power plants, which are often designed for both power generation and irrigation. Allowing these plants to participate in the competitive market could compromise their agricultural function. Additionally, hydropower plants operate with minimal or no fuel costs, making it potentially unfair for them to compete in the scheduling market unless suitable market regulations are established.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

still used as the main approach in many organizations today.
However, with the irruption of cyberspace, the information security approach has become insufficient. Cyberspace,
understood as a set of interconnected information systems
through communication networks in which people and entities interact and accomplish their activities, has unique characteristics: high dynamism; it is a common playing field

Journal Name:

Manage Asset-Focused Cybersecurity From

These results are then applied in Section III to design impulsive control laws for nonlinear systems. The note concludes with Section IV.

Text: The Kc is assigned to each content unit and is multiplexed with the content as a Kc distribution ECM section. This Kc is stored within the variable unit of the Kc distribution ECM, allowing flexibility in choosing the encryption algorithm and key length. By transmitting the Digital Rights Management Information (DRMI) alongside the Kc, advanced access control for stored content can be achieved on a per-content unit basis. The Kc distribution ECM includes a tampering-detection code within the encrypted area, utilizing a Hash function (SHA-1) to prevent unauthorized alterations to key information and data. The Kc distribution ECM can be transmitted either with the encrypted content or separately for specific viewing times. This DRM system is well-suited for digital satellite and terrestrial broadcasting, as it enables the Kc to be sent to multiple receivers using the Kc distribution ECM.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: In Conditional Access Systems (CAS), program data is scrambled using control words to prevent unauthorized access. Authorized users can unscramble the programs with a smart card and a set-top box (STB). Service providers charge subscription fees by distributing smart cards to paying customers. Because most digital television (DTV) broadcasts are one-way, there's no direct online verification between the broadcaster and the subscriber. Therefore, providers rely on authentication between the STB and the smart card to protect their revenue. Secure communication between these devices is critical and directly impacts the provider's income. Without mutual authentication, a single smart card could be used in multiple STBs of the same type, leading to the "McCormac Hack" and smart card cloning. The McCormac Hack involves intercepting the data line between the smart card and STB and redirecting it to another STB, making it appear as if the card is present. Smart card cloning involves duplicating legitimate cards for unauthorized access. If the key exchange process is compromised, pirates can extract key information for duplicating cards or redirecting signals to other STBs. This allows unauthorized viewers to access scrambled programs. It's estimated that media providers lose $100 million annually due to smart card cracking. Secure key exchange with mutual authentication is essential for enhancing system security and minimizing losses.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: Our numerical analysis has demonstrated that the most effective way to transmit and recover low-amplitude messages—while ensuring a certain level of security in all-optical chaos-based communication systems—is to use a closed-loop receiver configuration. Conversely, an open-loop configuration requires messages with higher amplitudes, which weakens security. In practical applications, the success of chaos-based communication systems with closed-loop receivers depends on the availability of stable external or integrated cavities. These types of cavities are already being developed successfully in modern optical systems [21].
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text:
To navigate unpredictable real-world situations, EVs
became part of a complex network of connected entities,
Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANET) [36]. These new ICVs
can connect to other vehicles, infrastructure, and pedestrians
via various communication modes, including V2x (includes
V2N, V2V, V2I, V2P) and DSRC. However, ICVs face several
complexity and security issues [37]. For instance, in [38],
the authors describe DSRC and C-V2X technologies and
their architectures for V2X communication. Meanwhile, [39]
discusses the evolution of communication technologies for
V2X and ICVs and demonstrates an emerging IoV technology.
Other attacks on ICVs include those targeting traffic light
infrastructure [40], attacks on the communication channel and
sensor tampering [41], and the security and privacy concerns
of C-V2X and DSRC communication technologies [42]. V2X
communication security is crucial, and many studies have
examined the flaws in this type of transportation. However, the
cyber-physical nature of ICVs introduces more vulnerabilities
to their communications [43]. Adversaries can compromise the
vehicle?s power system or controllers and endanger pedestrians
by injecting malicious code, malware, arbitrary code execution, and vandalizing the battery or controllers [44]. Hence,
considering both the physical and communication aspects of
ICVs to maintain a secure transportation system is critical in
EVs
Journal Name:
Evaluation Framework for Electric Vehicle
Security Risk Assessment

Text: Blockchain technology has been widely adopted across various fields, including cybersecurity, AI, decentralized storage, and finance, due to its transparency, confidentiality, and data integrity features. By eliminating third-party involvement through cryptography and consensus mechanisms, blockchain ensures an immutable and tamper-proof ledger, creating a reliable audit trail. In cybersecurity, integrating blockchain with AI can lead to decentralized AI models that securely process sensitive data while maintaining transparency and preventing tampering. This synergy enhances organizational security, offering innovative solutions to combat evolving cyber threats.

Cybersecurity vulnerabilities and threats typically stem from a combination of physical, human, and social factors. Many governmental bodies and institutional policymakers worldwide continue to favor strengthening physical infrastructure as their primary defense strategy. This approach mirrors what experts refer to as the outdated "Castle Model," which relies on constructing robust defensive boundaries (metaphorical walls) around systems to prevent security breaches. While the Castle Model offers some protection, it proves increasingly inadequate given today's realities of cultural diversity, complex socio-technical systems, and varying cybersecurity awareness levels across global populations. These factors create persistent challenges for governments attempting to eliminate cyber risks comprehensively. Consequently, developing truly effective cybersecurity frameworks requires evidence-based investigation into human factors and assessment of cyber risk awareness levels to create more holistic protection strategies.

Text: The test bed created to simulate an attack on real systems involves the placement of the Balise Transmission Module (BTM) on a wooden stand inside a semi-anechoic chamber, ensuring the correct distance of approximately 50 cm from a Balise positioned underneath. This setup allows for the verification of successful telegram exchanges between the BTM and the Balise using a magnetic sniffer connected to a spectrum analyzer. The BTM system operates by transmitting a downlink excitation signal at 27.095 MHz, which activates the ground Balise when the train passes over it. The Balise then sends an upstream link message at a frequency of 4.234 MHz, which is received by the BTM antenna and processed to extract train control information. This configuration highlights the importance of understanding both the operational mechanics of the BTM system and its vulnerabilities, as demonstrated by the attack simulations conducted in this controlled environment.

An effective approach [1] combined automated mapping with facilities management and geographic information systems to prevent distribution transformers from being damaged due to overloading. A pulse-width-modulation-based control scheme [2] for the ILM was proposed to effectively reduce system peak load. However, utilities must establish contracts with customers by offering price discounts or incentive rates to form interruptible load groups (ILGs). The appropriate incentive rates for customers were discussed in [3] and [4]. Additionally, a dynamic tariff [5] was proposed for demand-side management (DSM), presenting a real-time pricing strategy for industrial end-users to maximize profits.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: Contemporary reports from international associations [2, 3], European organizations [4, 5], and European projects [6, 7, 8, 9] have consistently emphasized the criticality of addressing current challenges within cybersecurity education, highlighting potential causative factors and proposing remedial strategies; the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) [4] posits that the restructuring of educational and training trajectories could mitigate many prevailing cybersecurity educational deficiencies; the European Cyber Security Organisation (ECSO) [5] suggests that the prevailing perception of cybersecurity education as a mere specialization or adjunct to computer science curricula obscures its inherent interdisciplinary nature; however, despite these reports, the precise mechanisms contributing to the shortfall in cybersecurity professionals remain incompletely elucidated, as the contextual challenges exhibit variability across countries and sectors [2], thereby complicating the identification of underlying factors and their interconnected relationships.

Although the ethics of cybersecurity might seem to be simple, the matter can be surprisingly
complicated. This paper discusses the results of an extensive study aimed at uncovering the anticipated,
emerging ethical issues related to cybersecurity. First, it discusses the ??strong signals??, i.e., the ??mainstream?? worries and concerns. Then, it uncovers the ??weak signals?? - the hidden, less-discussed concerns,
which may still define the upcoming future of the ethics of cybersecurity. The results of the study are also
compared to the outcomes of a similar experiment conducted two years ago, in order to see if the upcoming
ethical dilemmas anticipated back then have in fact become a reality
Journal Name:
What Will the Future of Cybersecurity Bring Us,
and Will It Be Ethical? The Hunt for the Black
Swans of Cybersecurity Ethics

Text: Over the past few years, various fault location techniques have been developed, as discussed in references?. Each of these methods relies on specific operating conditions and power system configurations. However, when these conditions change, the expected results may not be achieved, leading to ongoing research to address these limitations. At MTI, a new fault locating system has been developed to overcome these existing constraints. This system utilizes a reactance-based approach, leveraging data from one end of a transmission line captured by a digital fault recorder.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text:
In the evolving landscape of critical infrastructure security, the increasing sophistication of
cyber threats poses challenges, particularly to the power grid?s new technology infrastructure. Despite
traditionally being considered passive elements, power transformers, as critical components of the grid,
are now equipped with smart technologies and intelligent monitoring systems. These enhancements, while
beneficial for asset management, inadvertently increase their vulnerability to cyber threats. Existing literature
predominantly focuses on the cybersecurity of smart grids, mainly utilising model-based detection methods.
Yet, there?s a noticeable gap in research on the cybersecurity of critical power components, notably power
transformers, within the network. Our paper addresses this oversight by pioneering the examination of
cybersecurity challenges presented by smart transformers. We introduce a comprehensive architecture
and a well-formed taxonomy of cyber-physical attacks relevant to smart transformers. We present a
detailed analysis of smart transformers? topology, identifying vulnerable components and illustrating the
ramifications of cybersecurity breaches. Finally, we discuss potential future cybersecurity challenges facing
smart transformers. Our findings underscore the need for integrating advanced cybersecurity measures into
the development of online condition monitoring systems, safeguarding power transformers against evolving
cyber threats while paving the way for more resilient power grids.
Journal Name:
A Review of Cybersecurity Challenges in Smart
Power Transformers

Text: Following the loss of an online generator, it is essential to maintain system frequency within acceptable levels without load shedding. A method to determine the spinning reserve requirements by considering the 1-min recovery frequency following the loss of the largest generating unit was proposed in [4] and [5]. For isolated power systems, an assigned amount of FRR must be available within a given margin of time to provide protection in the event of a sudden loss of generating unit, an unanticipated load change, or any other power system disturbance. The margin of time is defined as the time required to make necessary changes in generating unit output. Different utilities have different policies regarding the minimum amount of FRR and the margin of time. In the case of the TPS, the margin of time is 60 s.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: Balancing innovation-oriented and cost-oriented approaches enhances innovation ambidexterity by fostering both exploratory and exploitative behaviors. Adaptability drives innovation by encouraging responsiveness to environmental changes, while alignment ensures efficient resource allocation and interdepartmental collaboration for cost-effective solutions. Innovation orientation promotes openness to new ideas, whereas cost orientation maintains a focus on efficiency. By balancing these approaches, firms can effectively pursue both incremental and disruptive innovations, strengthening their ability to innovate while maintaining financial sustainability.

Several tasks remain for future investigation. It is necessary to identify the network conditions under which the max-revenue objective function fails and to analyze the behavior of the min-absolute-value objective function. Another issue involves grid expansion. While the method supports grid expansion through capacity increases, as the TSP profits from such expansions, it does not address the potential for detrimental grid expansion that could increase congestion rents [6]. The topic of transmission expansion is left for future research. A particularly important question is the degree of market power exerted by large end users in this method compared to a bundled centralized market, assuming all other conditions remain the same. This critical issue will likely determine the extent to which transmission service can be separated from energy service and is also left for future exploration.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: In August 2017, the United States National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) released the National Initiative on Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Framework in Special Publication 800-181, which serves as an internationally recognized reference for defining and categorizing various professions within the cybersecurity field. The NICE Framework aims to establish a common lexicon for cybersecurity work and workers, applicable across public, private, and academic sectors. It has been continuously updated to align with current workforce demands, with the most recent version released in November 2020. This framework categorizes cybersecurity roles into seven high-level categories and includes over 2,200 Task, Knowledge, and Skills (TKS) statements that detail the requirements for each role. The NICE Framework not only facilitates better communication among educators, employers, and job seekers but also aids organizations in assessing their cybersecurity workforce needs and planning targeted training programs to address skills gaps. As of March 2024, further updates have been made to enhance its applicability, including new work role categories and competency areas to support the evolving landscape of cybersecurity challenges.

Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Modern cyberwarfare represents an omnipresent and persistent threat that can emerge instantaneously across global networks, with far-reaching consequences that extend beyond traditional military operations to critical civilian infrastructure and daily life. While cybersecurity has become a military priority, current dependence on private-sector solutions for cyber mission assurance creates potential vulnerabilities due to the inherent conflict between military secrecy requirements and commercial partnerships. Recognizing this gap, military organizations have sought to develop internal cybersecurity training capabilities, though existing systems often fail to provide sufficiently comprehensive, realistic training environments. Our research addresses these limitations through ICSTASY ?an innovative, scenario-based training platform that combines interactive and immersive technologies to deliver holistic cybersecurity preparedness. By analyzing previous training system shortcomings, we established fundamental design principles that enable authentic threat simulation and skill development. Our prototype demonstration validates that this approach can achieve unprecedented training efficacy for both military and civilian applications, bridging the critical gap between theoretical knowledge and practical cyber defense readiness in an era of escalating digital threats.

This mapping study examines safety and cybersecurity assessment techniques in critical industries?ncluding nuclear power, oil and gas, autonomous vehicles, and railways?ocusing on the challenges posed by modern instrumentation and control (I&C) systems, whose complexity and growing connectivity through Industry 4.0 technologies introduce escalating reliability and security risks. Analyzing 49 selected studies (from an initial pool of 320 publications, 2018?022), the paper systematizes current practices and identifies emerging trends, revealing that while many techniques remain long-established, the integration of unified safety-cybersecurity assessment frameworks represents a novel and promising direction for addressing the intertwined risks of interconnected critical systems. The findings highlight the need for adaptive methodologies to balance legacy reliability requirements with evolving cyber-physical threats in increasingly open I&C architectures.

Text: Landline telephony has long been the primary medium for telecommunication. While the advent of cellular phones and internet-based voice communication has diminished its usage, landline networks remain in service due to their simplicity and cost-effectiveness for subscribers. Home automation controls have been implemented using landline telephones by dialing additional digits to switch electrical appliances ON or OFF [7]. An extension card connected to the home telephone detects and decodes these digits, then executes the corresponding appliance control. The underlying principle of this system is illustrated in Fig. 5.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems
