Text: This article seeks to explore the factors that influence the cyber-preparedness of social enterprises (SEs) in the U.K., systematically examining both the enablers and barriers that shape their ability to address cybercrime. To achieve this, the article begins with a review of existing cybercrime literature, followed by the development of a conceptual framework that highlights the key issues and unique characteristics of SEs, alongside the formulation of relevant research questions. The methodology of the study is then outlined, providing a detailed account of the research approach, after which the findings of the analysis are presented. The article concludes by summarizing its contributions to the field and offering recommendations for future research directions, aiming to enhance the understanding and resilience of SEs in the face of cyber threats.

Top security companies joined forces to share information
with each other in an attempt to gather intelligence from the
shared data (SecIntel Exchange). Their goal was to provide
reliable security tools for their clients, and to achieve that,
they had to learn as much as possible from evolving threats
that were developed each day. They understood the power
of collaboration for the greater good. This was needed
because with the rise of polymorphic malware and other
evolving threats, they needed a lot information on these
threats in order to fully understand what they were dealing
with and how to counteract against it. The traditional
approaches of classifying malware were proving to be futile.
SecIntel Exchange data provided them with the opportunity
to derive actionable insights from voluminous data. Human
analysis and traditional methods such as database storage
could however not keep up with the pace of the data that
was being generated [17]. There was the need to adopt modern approaches. As seen in a case study conducted by Zions
Bancorporation [18], it would take their traditional Security
Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems between
20 minutes to an hour to query a month?s worth of security
data. However, when using tools with Hadoop technology, it
would only take about one minute to achieve the same
results. As such BDA has become an important tool in cybersecurity. Several studies have shown that the traditional
approaches and human analysts can not keep up with the big
data. BDA is one of the best solutions to combat these issues
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity in Big Data Era: From Securing
Big Data to Data-Driven Security

Text: The historical trajectory of generative models extends to the 1950s, a period marked by the development of Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs). A substantial enhancement in the performance of these generative models was realized subsequent to the emergence of deep learning methodologies [10]. An early method for sequence generation involved N-gram language modeling, wherein the optimal sequence is generated based on learned word distribution patterns [11]. The introduction of the Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) [1] significantly augmented the generative capabilities of these models. The transformer architecture [12], a foundational technology for numerous generative applications, has been applied to Large Language Models (LLMs) such as BERT and GPT. Generative AI (GenAI) has undergone significant evolution across diverse domains, including image, speech, and text. However, the scope of this discussion is limited to text-based AI chatbots, with a particular focus on ChatGPT, due to its relevance to this research. Given that ChatGPT is powered by the GPT-3 language model, a concise overview of the evolutionary progression of OpenAI's [13] GPT models is provided. Figure 2 illustrates the developmental trajectory of GPT models, culminating in their current state of sophistication.

We also have the ability to modulate the digital time-delay el ement. Published cracking algorithms use measures of average mutual information (AMI) to determine the time delay from a chaotic waveform[16]. Modulating the time delay compromises the ability to determine a fixed value forthe time delay and other system parameters [20]. We have implemented a system where the time delay is alternately switched between 60 and 45 s every 10 s within the FPGA. The rationale for this scheme is discussed in Section V.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: In 2019, Mouheb et al. conducted a survey on cybersecurity curriculum design efforts, categorizing university approaches based on their primary focus: educational, industrial, or defense. The study highlighted that universities design curricula based on their internal strategies, meaning these methods may not be universally applicable to other institutions.

The smart grid infrastructure is susceptible to four primary attack vectors: physical-based (e.g., physical component damage), cyber-based (e.g., software or firmware alterations), communication-based (e.g., physical link failures), and network-based (e.g., Denial of Service). Table 2 provides a comprehensive categorization of these attack types, delineating their impact on security aspects such as integrity, confidentiality, and availability. False Data Injection Attacks (FDIA) are identified as a pervasive threat across all attack groups. At the physical layer, FDIA can manifest through the manipulation of device input. At the cyber layer, data manipulation occurs via application-level falsifications without code modification. GPS data injection represents a potential communication layer attack vector, and network packet manipulation is also classified as FDIA.

While numerous potential contingencies could significantly impact the power system, most severe events occur with low probability. To keep Special Protection Systems (SPS) manageable, it's crucial to identify the most likely critical scenarios. This letter proposes a framework for selecting contingency cases for transient stability SPS design. This framework addresses the inherent uncertainty in event occurrence and its potential consequences, combining them into a risk index to prioritize contingencies.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: The Delphi processes in this study are part of the Cybersecurity Assessment Tools (CATS) project (http://www.cisa.umbc.edu/cats/index.html), which aims to develop two key instruments: the Cybersecurity Concept Inventory (CCI) for students finishing an introductory cybersecurity course, and the Cybersecurity Curriculum Assessment (CCA) for graduates entering the workforce. To ensure these tools reflect essential knowledge, the project conducted two parallel Delphi studies, gathering expert consensus on core concepts for each level?rioritizing importance, difficulty, and timelessness. The CCI establishes baseline competencies for beginners, while the CCA assesses professional readiness, helping standardize cybersecurity education and align curricula with industry needs. By providing data-driven benchmarks, CATS supports educators in refining instruction, evaluating student proficiency, and closing workforce skill gaps, ultimately strengthening cybersecurity training programs.

Security awareness is crucial for emerging technologies to prevent cyberattacks. Ensuring information security in open system architectures poses significant challenges, particularly regarding confidentiality, integrity, availability, and accountability. ISO/IEC 17799 provides guidelines for implementing controls within an information security management system. Virtual enterprises offer a collaborative framework for managing networked organizations by coordinating, controlling, and communicating across different roles and user types remotely. As control networks become more interconnected, governments have responded by enhancing national readiness to address these evolving threats.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Landline telephony has traditionally been a primary medium for teleconversations. Despite the rise of cellular telephony and internet-based voice communication, which have reduced its usage, landline networks remain popular due to their simplicity and cost-effectiveness for subscribers. Landline telephones have been used to control home appliances by dialing additional digits to switch them on or off. An extension card connected to the home telephone identifies and decodes these digits, controlling the switching of appliances. The principle behind this system is illustrated in Fig. 5.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: The Privacy Act of 1974 requires federal information systems to maintain the confidentiality of personally identifiable data [7]. However, these regulations offer minimal guidance on the specific structure and organization of technology-related functions needed to comply with such requirements. In most service industries, failing to implement security measures may not have severe consequences, but in healthcare, noncompliance results in increasingly strict penalties [8]–[10]. The stakes for security in the healthcare sector are particularly high. While information models are often used to analyze security concerns within individual organizations, there has been little research on broader industry-wide trends. The introduction of comprehensive industry regulations, along with penalties for failing to comply, may provide a more holistic perspective, especially when regulatory or market-wide influences challenge established practices within specific organizations. Additionally, there is limited research on the impact of information technology in clinical settings. Historically, physicians have viewed information management as an administrative task and have not developed significant expertise in this field, despite the universal requirements enforced by HIPAA and the Privacy Act [11], [12].
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

four trams using a replay attack
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Considerations for Communication
Based Train Control

Text: Currently, there are three primary wind turbine technologies utilized in the industry. The first is the squirrel-cage induction generator, known for its simplicity. This type of turbine adjusts the pitch of its blades based on wind speed to maintain a near-constant rotational speed. The second technology is the double-fed induction generator, which has its stator winding connected to the grid while the rotor winding links to a back-to-back voltage-source converter. This converter allows for variable-speed operation by adjusting the frequency of the rotor's feeding current. The third technology is the direct-drive synchronous generator, where the rotor is directly coupled to the generator without a gearbox.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: Different system characteristics, whether involving long or short lines, do not alter the previous conclusions. Regarding the BPA system, their ability to maintain voltage near the maximum during heavy loads with minimal generator support indicates a surplus of capacitors. The primary risk they face is controlling over-voltage. In Italy, the policy is to reduce the cost of capacitor banks and their maintenance (since frequent switching reduces their lifespan) in favor of fully controlling all available reactive power resources, primarily those already available from generators. This approach economically recognizes their support as a contribution to the Voltage Ancillary Service.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: The quantification of risk, serving as a primary output metric for assessment techniques, is prevalent across numerous studies, typically representing the confluence of hazardous event probability and consequence severity; specifically, traditional risk priority numbers (RPNs), calculated from effect severity, occurrence probability, and detection difficulty, are employed in [1], [4], [7], and [9], while [3] extends this concept to incorporate risk interaction; [5] enhances risk assessment objectivity through fuzzy confidence interval numbers (FCINs), generalized trapezoidal fuzzy numbers (GTrFNs), and sensitivity analysis; [6] calculates risk based on hazard severity, exposure, and system controllability; [8] distinguishes fairness risk from safety risk; [10] emphasizes assurance risks; [12] computes risk from vulnerability impact and likelihood; and [13] incorporates attack cost, difficulty, and detection probability, thus illustrating the diverse methodologies employed in risk quantification within cybersecurity and safety assessments.

Furthermore, the issue of inadequate skills is compounded by the transient nature of volunteer personnel, thereby diminishing the efficacy of any training initiatives. The close engagement of Social Enterprises (SEs) with often disadvantaged and vulnerable populations renders them particularly susceptible to social engineering attacks, which are inherently challenging to defend against [67], [93]. Collectively, this provides evidence supporting Research Question 1 (RQ1), demonstrating that owner-managers acknowledge the unique characteristics of SEs that may render them vulnerable to cyberattacks, especially those employing social engineering tactics.

Some research suggests that cyberattacks are becoming more
frequent, and there is a growing body of literature that proffers
instruments for assessing cyber risks [3], [8], [52]. The severity
of cyberattacks seems to have plateaued [99], yet a single cyberattack is estimated to cost an average of $229,000. The global
cost of cyberattacks is thought to be several hundreds of billions
of dollars [70]. As a result of this, one-third of organizations
are planning to take out cyber insurance [65]. However, this
may not be a viable option for SEs that are frequently beset by
considerable financial constraints. Furthermore, it is questionable whether financial compensation for being the subject of
cybercrime is a meaningful support for SEs, whose purpose is
usually socially motivated rather than driven by purely profit.
SEs are measured not only on their financial performance but
also on their societal value or benefit. Consequently, just as they
find their social value difficult to measure [33], [47], [101] so
is the totality of the impact of cybercrime difficult for SEs to
measure and therefore insure against.
Journal Name:
Antecedents of Cybersecurity Implementation:
A Study of the Cyber-Preparedness
of U.K. Social Enterprises

or unsupervised learning. In a supervised learning model,
the network receives a set of behavioral examples already
tagged; in contrast, in the case of unsupervised learning,
the inputs are the only source of information for learning, and
the network learns to categorize the inputs.

Evaluation of Cybersecurity Data Set Characteristics
for Their Applicability to Neural

Text: Practical experience highlights the significant role of pumped storage units in providing FRR for isolated power systems, especially during emergencies when reserves are critically low. Pumped storage units are highly effective in this role, as they can either generate power with AGC to provide frequency regulation reserves or operate in pumping mode to offer emergency reserves. Comparative energy benefit analyses indicate that mode C is ideal for light load conditions (such as in spring and winter) to minimize pumping energy costs while maintaining emergency reserves. In contrast, mode D is more suitable for heavy load conditions (such as in summer and autumn), as it provides frequency regulation reserves. The real-world operation of pumped storage units discussed in this paper can help assess their impact on system security and define their role in ancillary service markets. After extensive evaluation, the Taiwan Power Company’s system operations department confirmed the advantages of flexible scheduling for pumped storage units, noting improvements in power quality, enhanced system security, and the overall value of pumped storage units in daily FRR operations.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: Organizations using a single-sourcing strategy often face misalignment between the provided system and their existing business processes, requiring significant efforts in reengineering workflows, adapting policies, and enforcing new standards. In contrast, a best-of-breed (BoB) approach allows organizations to select IS vendors that better align with their current processes, routines, and policies, reducing the need for major adjustments. The extensive changes required in a single-sourcing strategy can introduce security vulnerabilities, as malicious attackers may exploit weaknesses in process redesign, while nonmalicious employees may struggle with the transition, leading to unintended security errors.

The rapid advancement of the computer and information industry in recent years has led to the creation of numerous new peripheral devices that can connect to business computer terminals, particularly through USB ports. USB ports have become a standard feature in modern computer hardware due to their convenience and ease of connectivity. The primary advantage of USB ports is that they provide a single interface for connecting a variety of devices, including hard disks, flash drives, printers, keyboards, and PDAs.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: An HNN with high capacity can store authentication information efficiently, requiring minimal training time. The HNN-based authentication scheme can instantly and accurately recall information for valid user IDs and passwords. Our experiments have demonstrated the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed authentication scheme.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: This study aimed to influence participant behavior toward proactive cybersecurity practices, emphasizing the importance of awareness and behavioral moderation over simply presenting vast amounts of theoretical information. In cybersecurity, fostering an understanding of information assurance principles and encouraging practitioners to adopt best practices is crucial. The goal is not only to inform but to instill habitual, affirmative behaviors that enhance security. Additionally, since preventive measures evolve rapidly, cybersecurity training materials must be both actionable and designed for long-term applicability before becoming obsolete.

has become a crucial feature of home security system. This can 
be done via internet or GSM/GPRS. GSM/GPRS is more 
convenient than internet. The main reason is that the 
GSM/GPRS network has wide spread coverage making the

Text: The rest of this note is organized as follows. In Section II, a new comparison theorem and sufficient condition for asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems are given. These results are used to design impulsive control law for nonlinear systems in Section III. Finally, this note is concluded in Section IV.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: The production cost of each power plant varies depending on factors such as its size, fuel type, location, and age. As energy demand rises throughout the day, the market clearing price increases until it aligns with the cost of the most expensive available supply. If a supply shortage occurs—whether genuine or artificially created—prices can skyrocket since consumers with inelastic demand must accept whatever price suppliers bid. During the 2000 California power crisis, the independent system operator (ISO) introduced price caps to curb market manipulation. However, energy prices quickly adjusted to these caps, creating a simple leader-follower dynamic without proper incentives. Additionally, the blackouts imposed by the California ISO unintentionally led to a form of retail price elasticity. Even under normal conditions, market manipulation can occur. For instance, an energy provider with multiple plants in a state could bid excessively high prices for one plant’s output to influence the overall market price at auction.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: This circuit can be built using approximately 20 CMOS gates plus several passive components. The astable multivibrator operated with a 5 V supply voltage, the 1-bit counter used a 16 MHz clock frequency, and the random number output achieved a 50 kb/s bit rate. All testing was conducted at room temperature. Since this RNG uses discrete components, its supply voltage exceeds what would be used in mobile applications. With an appropriate fabrication process technology, the supply voltage for our circuit could be reduced to 1.5 V or lower. It's worth noting that our random number generation method could work with other randomly fluctuating signals besides MOS-SBD signals, provided those signals have sufficient amplitude.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: The conceptual framework of a preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics model was initially proposed in [20] and subsequently analyzed in [48], with earlier investigations of specific cases documented in [33?5]; however, these studies provided only a partial characterization of the dynamics, limited to specific parameter configurations rather than the complete parameter space; recent research has established the global convergence of these dynamics across the entire parameter universe, indicating the existence of a unique equilibrium state [4], the precise location of which is determined by parameter values rather than the system's initial state, thereby enabling a more comprehensive understanding of the model's behavior.

Before analyzing the ESCOPF problem solution for this case, let's first examine the solution to the basic OPF problem, which doesn't address system security. This problem aims to minimize system operating cost without considering costs associated with contingency occurrences. In essence, the OPF assumes zero probability of contingency occurrence.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: In reality, wind’s operation requires a proper control setting for each wind plant to accomplish system security operation. Whether current interconnection regulations of PF control mode are sufficient enough is still under debate. Therefore, Section IV of this paper investigates the impact of the pene tration level of wind farm to the system. Major interests include steady-state voltage profile, voltage ride-through capabilities, and system stability following disturbances in various scenario changes due to different control strategies of the IG-based wind farms.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: User authentication plays a vital role in overall security, which can be categorized as strong or weak based on the balance between attack cost and potential attacker gain. Authentication methods vary in their effectiveness against different attack types, and vulnerabilities can exist at the client, during transmission, and at the host. This discussion primarily focuses on client and host vulnerabilities. To strengthen security, multifactor authentication combines different authenticator types. 1  This paper also contextualizes user authentication within broader authentication systems like RADIUS, Kerberos, and Single Sign-On (SSO).
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text:
The proposed solution introduces a five-phase protocol combining Schnorr's digital signatures with one-way hash functions to enhance CAS security:

Registration: Initial credential setup for STBs and smart cards

Login: User authentication initiation

Mutual Authentication: Bidirectional verification between devices

Key Agreement: Dynamic session key generation

CW Transmission: Secure delivery of descrambling keys

This framework addresses critical vulnerabilities by ensuring:

Session keys change dynamically to prevent replay attacks

Cryptographic signatures validate device authenticity

Lightweight computations maintain system performance

User-friendly password management without compromising security

By integrating these mechanisms, the protocol effectively mitigates smart card cloning and McCormac Hack scenarios while maintaining compatibility with existing DVB standards.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: The decision-making process in autonomous vehicles (AVs) introduces substantial security challenges. AVs rely on vast amounts of data from both internal and external sources to function effectively. Communication between intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs), onboard sensors, and external services enables machine learning models to process real-time information and make driving decisions. These AI-driven models are trained on extensive datasets to execute hundreds or even thousands of decisions throughout a journey. Research has explored AV simulations, including electronic control units (ECUs) and AI firmware, to better understand system functionality. However, machine learning models in AVs are susceptible to various security threats, which can compromise the reliability and safety of autonomous systems. This section will delve into the vulnerabilities associated with AI-driven decision-making in AVs.

The Decision Support System (DSS) can be implemented in two different scenarios. In the first scenario, the utility still maintains excess power capacity but offers interruptible tariffs to customers to alleviate some power demand and reduce operational costs during peak periods. The dual objectives here are minimizing the utility's generation costs while maximizing customer benefits. The second scenario aims to maintain system reliability while minimizing disruption from load interruption when the system or substation experiences capacity shortages. This problem is appropriately addressed through load interruption due to the obvious and efficient effects of load management. However, since load management requires customer participation, implementation must follow two principles: satisfying customer expectations and maintaining system security. The mathematical formulation of this problem follows.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

The overshoot is due to the fact that G1, G4 and G5 are all contributing to bring the de viation in frequency back to zero by increasing their power output. Each of them joins the primary con trol and, since G1 and G4 are under AGC, they also contribute to supplementary control. Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) herald a paradigm shift in navigation, transitioning from traditional terrestrial radio navigation aids to space-based positioning systems; ground-based navigation systems are encumbered by several limitations, including substantial installation expenses and the necessity for recurring flight inspections [48]; additionally, the clearance area mandated around ground-based radio navigation aids imposes height restrictions on adjacent structures, thus hindering urban development and infrastructure planning.

meter and device which provides the data. Digital-meter works
in power systems usually communicate by the protocol that was

meters which use their own protocols, and other controllable

Text: In our analysis of training program adoption as a security measure, we found little difference between highly computerized and less computerized organizations in terms of actual implementation. However, there were differences in planned implementations, with primarily paper-based organizations more likely to plan for training programs. Many organizations were transitioning from paper to computerized patient data systems. This transition phase may influence their approach to security training.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: Cloud computing platforms offer a highly effective solution for conducting course assignments and equipping students with essential hands-on experience. The cloud provides teaching staff and students, whether local or remote, with on-demand, elastic, dedicated, isolated, and virtually unlimited virtual machines that are easily configurable. Compared to traditional laboratories, cloud-based labs have significant advantages, particularly in scalability when accommodating a growing number of students and distant university campuses. This study demonstrates how the cloud paradigm can be leveraged for teaching a cybersecurity course by sharing experiences from using cloud computing in a senior-level cybersecurity class across two campuses via a virtual classroom with live audio and video. Additionally, it proposes guidelines applicable to similar computer science and engineering courses. Cloud-based laboratory exercises prove instrumental in helping students acquire crucial cybersecurity and cloud computing skills, both of which are in high demand. While this study utilized Amazon Web Services (AWS), the presented use cases and methodologies are equally applicable to other cloud platforms such as Rackspace and Google Compute Engine.

The GCC was established in 1981 as an institutional alliance
to progress a common agenda in economic, defence, and foreign policy, in the context of high regional instability (e.g.,
the emergence of a police state in Iraq, the unfolding of the
Islamic revolution in Iran). It comprises Saudi Arabia, Kuwait,
the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Bahrain, Oman, and Qatar.
Together these Gulf States have a population of over 47 million
inhabitants and in geostrategic terms, the GCC is the world?s
largest producer of oil and also a major producer of natural gas.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity: Perceived Threats and Policy
Responses in the Gulf Cooperation Council

Text: Our numerical simulations have shown that the most effective and secure method for transmitting and recovering small-amplitude messages in all-optical chaos-based communication systems is to use a closed-loop scheme in the receiver. In contrast, an open-loop scheme requires larger amplitude messages, which compromises security. In practice, successful chaos-based communication with a closed-loop receiver relies on stable external or integrated cavities, similar to those currently being developed [21].
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

reviews related work on cybersecurity education. Section III
summarizes the cybersecurity skills framework used to define

application for designing cybersecurity curricula. The final

Journal Name:
Framework, Tools and Good Practices for

Text: PSR (Passive Radar) determines the azimuth and slant range of targets without relying on data from the transmitted signal, which means that standard Software Defined Radio (SDR) transmitters cannot be used to inject or modify message content. The high power of the transmitted PSR signal complicates jamming attempts, although it remains vulnerable to sophisticated jamming attacks that typically require military-grade equipment. Consequently, while PSR can be jammed with high-power signals, the complexity and resource requirements for such attacks limit their feasibility, leading to a lack of detailed cybersecurity coverage in studies related to PSR.

While it is challenging to assess the periodicity and regularity of random numbers through statistical tests, the spectral test [8] provides a visual representation of how random numbers correlate with themselves. Two sequential 8-bit random numbers (ranging from 0 to 255) were plotted on a two-dimensional (2-D) graph, as shown in Fig. 3. If the autocorrelation of the 8-bit random numbers is low, the 2-D graph appears uniform and well-distributed. Fig. 3(a) displays the results for random numbers generated by our RNG, while Fig. 3(b) shows the results for random numbers generated by a pseudo-RNG (a linear feedback shift register (LFSR) with 10 shift registers) [9]. The results clearly indicate that our RNG exhibits no periodicity or regularity, especially when compared to the LFSR. Although an LFSR with 10 shift registers is relatively simple, its circuit size is already larger than that of our RNG. These results highlight the potential of our circuit as a compact, high-quality RNG for security system applications.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: The overhead required by the dynamic reconfiguration of the DPU occurs only when the memory protection must be updated. However, this situation usually happens only once per application run. The possibility of dynamically reconfiguring the DPUs increases the flexibility of the system, but its variable overhead, involving several net work messages, affects the time determinism of an application/context switching. For hard real-time systems, the use of this feature should be avoided.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: We addressed the problem of impulsive control by leveraging the theory of impulsive differential equations. We derived sufficient conditions to guarantee the asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems. These findings were then applied to design an impulsive control strategy for a class of nonlinear systems. Our approach has the potential to enhance existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text:
Cyber attacks on smart grids can be categorized into 
passive and active types. Passive attacks, such as spying, 
eavesdropping, and traffic analysis, target system information 
without directly affecting system resources. Conversely, 
active attacks aim to alter data and information through means 
such as malware and Denial of Service (DoS), often leading 
to severe consequences. Attack vectors in the literature 
often point to vulnerabilities at the monitoring device level,substation level, or via remote access, with FDIA identified 
as the most prevalent and challenging threat due to its wide
ranging impacts
Journal Name:
A Review of Cybersecurity Challenges in Smart
Power Transformers

Text: In their 2019 study, Mouheb et al. [27] analyzed global approaches to cybersecurity curriculum development, revealing that universities typically adopt one of three distinct design paradigms?ducation-focused (prioritizing theoretical foundations), industry-aligned (emphasizing practical skills), or defense-oriented (concentrating on national security needs)?ased on institutional priorities. This siloed approach creates fragmented competency outcomes, as curricula are tailored to internal strategic goals rather than standardized workforce requirements, resulting in graduates whose skills may not align with broader sectoral needs or interoperable professional frameworks like NICE. The findings underscore the critical need for cross-sector collaboration in curriculum design to bridge the growing divide between academic outputs and the dynamic demands of cybersecurity practice.

Modern cloud computing infrastructure follows a three-tier architectural model, with each layer susceptible to distinct vulnerabilities - whether introduced through programming errors or provider-side configurations [3]. This segmented data management approach significantly complicates the detection and tracing of cybercrimes like data theft and financial fraud across digital ecosystems. Perhaps more concerning is how distributed computing architectures have effectively erased geographical constraints, enabling malicious actors to launch attacks from virtually any global location [4]. Consequently, organizations now face an escalating barrage of highly sophisticated cyber threats [5,6] that increasingly require AI-powered security solutions and intelligent defense mechanisms to effectively counteract.

The widespread adoption of remote controllers, driven by their ease of use and convenience, marks them as a pivotal 21st-century innovation. Beyond traditional applications in home entertainment like TVs and DVD players, their digital integration has expanded to car keys, air conditioners, game controllers, and increasingly, home automation systems for lighting, temperature, security, and door management. Modern life, with its reliance on these devices for accessing appliance functionalities, is now practically unimaginable without remote controllers.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: Variations in system characteristics, whether involving long or short lines, do not alter the previous conclusions. Regarding the BPA system, its ability to maintain voltage near the maximum under heavy loads with minimal generator support suggests an excess of capacitors. The primary risk in this case is managing over-voltage. In Italy, the strategy focuses on reducing the cost and maintenance of capacitor banks?ince frequent switching shortens their lifespan?hile prioritizing full control over all available reactive power resources, primarily those already provided by generators. Additionally, economic recognition is given to their contribution as part of the Voltage Ancillary Service.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: The Internet of Things (IoT) encompasses a vast array of heterogeneous devices, with rapid growth in connectivity presenting significant security challenges. In 2015, IoT linked 4.9 billion devices, a number projected to reach 25 billion by 2020. While IoT offers exceptional flexibility and scalability, increased connectivity amplifies cybersecurity risks for individuals, networks, and global infrastructure. The number of connected devices per person has risen dramatically, from fewer than 0.08 in 2003 to 1.84 in 2010, and an estimated 6.58 by 2020. Despite their widespread adoption, IoT devices remain vulnerable entry points for cyber threats. A robust cybersecurity infrastructure is essential to securing these devices and ensuring their safe use. IoT smart devices range from computers and smartphones to communication interfaces, operating systems, lightweight services, and preloaded applications. Equipped with RFID sensors and actuators, these intelligent devices can autonomously make decisions, execute tasks, and relay information to users, further emphasizing the need for strong security measures.

Impulsive control systems have many practical applications. Three notable examples include an insect population control system, where state variables represent the number of insects and their natural enemies; a chemical reactor system, where state variables denote the quantities of different chemicals; and a financial system, where state variables include the amount of money in a market and the saving rates of a central bank [1]. Further practical examples are discussed in [2] and [3].
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: Learning methods are generally classified into supervised and unsupervised learning. In supervised learning, the model is trained using a dataset where each example is labeled with the correct output, allowing the network to learn from predefined patterns. On the other hand, unsupervised learning relies solely on input data without labeled examples, requiring the network to identify patterns and categorize the data independently.

In 2014, MITRE developed a Cyber Exercise Playbook, which serves as a comprehensive guide for conducting cyber exercises in cyberspace, offering guidance on exercise planning, execution, and reporting. This playbook introduces essential terminology and outlines the lifecycle of a cyber exercise, detailing objectives, scenarios, and assessment procedures to enhance the effectiveness of training programs. Prior to this, in 2012, MITRE published a Cyber Defence Playbook that focused on active defense strategies leveraging the cyber-attack kill chain. The Cyber Exercise Playbook emphasizes the importance of realistic scenarios and structured planning to ensure that participants can effectively detect and respond to cyber threats during exercises.

In this note, we focus on the impulsive control of nonlinear systems, building on the work in [7]. We first establish a new comparison theorem. Using this theoretical foundation for impulsive differential systems, we derive less conservative stability conditions for systems with fixed-time impulses. These results are then used to design impulsive control laws for a class of nonlinear systems. Our approach is applicable to a broader range of nonlinear systems and has the potential to enhance existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications [8]–[13].
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: Many researchers tend to associate security aspects directly with the receiver’s architecture, even though security is only indirectly linked to the receiver’s characteristics. The primary security concern is the challenge of extracting the transmitted message from the chaotic carrier without the authorized receiver. There are two types of potential attacks. The first is a software attack, which relies on extracting information directly from the transmitted signal. If the signal is sampled with extremely high precision—usually at the level of picoseconds, which is difficult to achieve experimentally—time series analysis could be performed, and in some cases, parts of the message might be retrieved [18]. The second type of attack is hardware-based, where an attacker attempts to construct a receiver similar to the authorized one without knowing its exact specifications. This is highly challenging since the system's design depends on critical factors such as laser parameters and the operating conditions of the emitter, which are meant to remain confidential. In this scenario, an open-loop receiver would be the simplest option for an attacker. However, as demonstrated later, retrieving the encrypted message is impossible if the encoded signal’s amplitude remains sufficiently low.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: The study utilized a 14-item questionnaire with 7-point Likert-scale questions, demonstrating strong internal consistency (Cronbach? a = 0.794). To enhance future reliability, improvements such as translating the tool into local languages directly (rather than relying on interpreters), refining item clarity, minimizing redundancy, and expanding construct-aligned questions were proposed. Analysis of responses via t-tests revealed that items 1, 3, and 4 lacked statistical significance, while items 2, 5 through 14 showed significant results (detailed in Table 3). These findings suggest targeted revisions could strengthen the instrument? validity for cross-cultural cybersecurity awareness assessments.

In recent years, many researchers have focused on impulsive systems and impulsive control. Studies in [2]–[6] have explored the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, which must be nonincreasing across the entire sequence or subsequence of switchings. In [1], Yang derived sufficient conditions for the impulsive control of a class of nonlinear systems by building on the results from [3]. Similarly, Li et al. in [7] provided less conservative conditions for the asymptotic stability of impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses, using these results to design impulsive control for nonlinear systems. Works in [8]–[13] have demonstrated various applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications. Additionally, Panas et al. in [14] proposed experimental methods for implementing impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Cyber events are generated or produced by information systems that may not necessarily result to an incident; events that
match certain predefined or anomaly based symptomatic profile
will trigger an alert, and one or more alerts may lead to an
incident. The recently formed European NIS directive defines

and information systems (used in the provision of the essential

essential service itself [12].?
Journal Name:
SOTER: A Playbook for Cybersecurity
Incident Management

Text: Innovation-oriented and cost-oriented approaches play a crucial role in balancing exploitative and exploratory behaviors, positively affecting innovative ambidexterity. Adaptability, defined as a firm's ability to respond to environmental changes, is fostered by management conveying urgency to employees, leading to innovative ideas. Alignment refers to a firm's capacity to effectively allocate resources, maximize efficiency, and encourage inter-departmental collaboration toward these objectives, resulting in cost-effective solutions. Innovation orientation reflects a firm's openness to new ideas, while cost orientation emphasizes a cost-efficient mindset that balances the desire to innovate. Innovative firms, although primarily focused on exploratory projects, are positioned to pursue both discontinuous and incremental innovations, thereby enhancing their innovation ambidexterity. Cost orientation aids this process by balancing the explorative behaviors driven by innovation orientation with the necessary exploratory behaviors, ensuring that firms can adapt and thrive in dynamic markets.

The study proposes a lightweight Matching-Scheme Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MS-DDPG) approach to optimize node search for scheduling tasks in distributed computing networks. This method efficiently utilizes resources and time during task processing and resource matching. Unlike existing Q-learning, Deep-Q-Learning, and SARSA approaches, which are resource-intensive, MS-DDPG is designed to be adaptive and lightweight, making it more efficient for dynamic node selection in reinforcement learning-based systems.

Numerous studies employ risk as a core metric for evaluating assessment techniques, typically combining event likelihood and consequence severity, though methodologies vary significantly across applications. Traditional approaches like the Risk Priority Number (RPN)?ncorporating severity, occurrence probability, and detection difficulty?ominate in [1][4][7][9], while [3] extends RPN to address risk interactions. Advanced refinements appear in [5], which introduces fuzzy logic (FCIN, GTrFN) and sensitivity analysis to improve objectivity, whereas [6] focuses on hazard severity, situational exposure, and system controllability. Specialized adaptations include [8]'s separation of fairness risk from safety risk, [10]'s emphasis on assurance risks, and [12]'s dual focus on attack likelihood/vulnerability impact. Meanwhile, [13] adopts a cost-focused lens, evaluating risk through attack difficulty, cost, and detection probability?emonstrating how domain-specific needs shape risk quantification frameworks.

In a deregulated energy market, utilities are incentivized to maximize profits by minimizing investments in new infrastructure and pushing existing transmission lines to their limits, leveraging cheaper energy sources. To address the resulting security risks, Special Protection Systems (SPS) have been proposed [2]. These systems enable operation closer to, or even beyond, traditional limits, while still maximizing market benefits. However, the design of SPS for handling extreme events in this environment must account for the probabilistic nature of uncertainties and the increased likelihood of severe contingencies that could trigger cascading failures and compromise system security.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: In practice, the operation of wind power plants requires appropriate control settings to ensure the security of the power system. The adequacy of existing interconnection regulations for power factor (PF) control mode remains a topic of discussion. Therefore, Section IV of this paper examines the effects of wind farm penetration on the power system. Key areas of interest include the steady-state voltage profile, voltage ride-through capability, and system stability under various disturbance scenarios influenced by different control strategies of IG-based wind farms.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: To enable decryption of broadcast content, a decryption key, denoted as Ks, is continuously sent to the receiver alongside the encrypted data. This Ks information is embedded within an Entitlement Control Message (ECM), specifically the ECM-Kw [5]. To ensure security, the ECM-Kw, including the Ks, is encrypted before transmission using a Key Working (Kw). This Kw is typically updated monthly. Furthermore, the Kw itself is encrypted using a unique Key Management (Km) for each individual receiver [6]. This encrypted Kw is also transmitted. Figure 2 illustrates the structure of an ECM, which consists of a fixed-length unit and a variable-length unit. The fixed unit carries information with a consistent size. For security, a portion of the fixed unit, as well as the entire variable unit, are encrypted. Crucially, the Ks decryption key is located within the fixed unit of the ECM-Kw.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Security is defined as the power system's ability to handle sudden disturbances without interrupting the power supply. Therefore, security analysis must evaluate inappropriate system responses, unnecessary operation of devices (e.g., protection systems), or malfunctioning subsystems during sudden disturbances. Any of these events can negatively impact power quality and system reliability, potentially endangering the electrical infrastructure and associated industrial processes, creating a high-risk scenario.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: The Internet of Things (IoT), characterized by its expansive integration of diverse and heterogeneous devices, has witnessed a rapid proliferation, escalating from 4.9 billion connected entities in 2015 to a projected 25 billion by 2020, this exponential growth, while indicative of IoT's flexibility and scalability, introduces substantial security vulnerabilities, the increased connectivity of devices amplifies individual and network risks, thereby heightening the overall cybersecurity threat to global infrastructure, a comparative analysis reveals a significant increase in per-capita device ownership, from less than 0.08 devices in 2003 to 1.84 in 2010, with projections indicating 6.58 devices per person by 2020, the widespread and rapid deployment of diverse devices across the IoT network, despite their functional utility, renders them susceptible to attacks, positioning them as potential weak points within the IoT ecosystem, consequently, the establishment of a robust IoT cybersecurity infrastructure is imperative to ensure the secure maintenance of devices and facilitate appropriate user interaction, the scope of IoT smart devices encompasses a broad spectrum, including computers, smartphones, communication interfaces, operating systems, lightweight services, and preloaded applications, these intelligent devices, equipped with RFID sensors or actuators, are capable of autonomous execution, decision-making, and information dissemination to users.

While statistical tests struggle to characterize the periodicity and regularity of random numbers, the spectral test [8] provides a visual representation of how random numbers correlate with themselves. Two sequential 8-bit random numbers (decimal values 0 to 255) were plotted on a two-dimensional (2-D) graph as shown in Fig. 3. When 8-bit random numbers have low autocorrelation, the resulting 2-D plot appears uniform and well-balanced. Fig. 3(a) displays results from our RNG, while Fig. 3(b) shows results from a pseudo RNG [a linear feedback shift register (LFSR) with 10 shift registers] [9]. Our results clearly demonstrate no periodicity or regularity, especially when compared to the LFSR results. While a 10-shift register LFSR is admittedly simplistic, even with that configuration, its circuit size exceeds that of our RNG. These results indicate that our circuit represents a promising compact, high-quality RNG for security system applications.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: In the proposed system, refreshing a group key requires only a few encryption and decryption operations, involving primarily multiplication and addition, which have minimal computational load. Each subscriber receives a head group key (HRGK) from the transport stream. Using the HRGK and their secret keys, subscribers can derive the corresponding group keys and authorization keys (AKs). When a member joins or leaves a group, the system broadcasts a single package containing the new secret group key. To enhance system security, the AK is typically refreshed daily. In this scheme, updating the HRGK automatically refreshes all AKs. The system achieves this by broadcasting a single package with the new HRGK to all users, significantly reducing the daily computational overhead.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: The power industry has long recognized the importance of physical security in safeguarding infrastructure. One preventive measure has been protecting unmanned substations from vandalism [9]. However, with rising concerns over potential sabotage, the scope of physical security has expanded to include critical substations whose compromise could trigger cascading failures and widespread blackouts [10]. Additionally, deploying sensors to monitor the structural health of transmission lines plays a crucial role in mitigating system vulnerabilities [11]. Alongside physical security, electronic security is equally vital, given the potential disruptions that could arise from cyber threats targeting critical assets.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: To prepare for the emerging electric-power market, this paper proposes an AMI system with bidirectional communication. This system allows utilities to operate cost-effectively and offer the flexible pricing options demanded by the market. By adopting advanced communication media such as GSM and GPRS, the AMI system can quickly and accurately collect meter data automatically. It can integrate with any existing billing and management system, reducing labor costs and increasing meter-reading accuracy. Additionally, the statistical load usage and profiles help customers manage their energy consumption and patterns. When available, the system will also provide real-time pricing for customers, making it a crucial installation for the future deregulated utility industry.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: The concept of preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics was introduced in earlier studies and partially analyzed within specific parameter regimes, focusing on special cases like the structure of attack-defense graphs. However, these studies offered only a limited understanding of the dynamics. Recent advancements have proven that these dynamics are globally convergent across the entire parameter universe, ensuring a unique equilibrium whose position depends solely on parameter values rather than initial conditions. This breakthrough expands the applicability of the model to broader cybersecurity scenarios, providing a more comprehensive framework for analyzing and predicting cyber attack-defense interactions.

The study focuses primarily on wind-farm penetration levels of 10% and 20% of peak electricity demand. To analyze these scenarios, the researchers integrated either 22 or 44 sites (each with 90-MW installed capacity) into the conventional power system. These wind farms were connected through 115-kV transmission lines and strategically positioned in various locations surrounding load centers throughout the entire power grid.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

The most common configurations of HM tools combine
additive and subtractive manufacturing processes on the
same platform [4] so that process chains spread across
multiple machines (possibly located at different enterprises) can be carried out within a single machine. This
is especially beneficial for the fabrication of custom components, as it results in reduced setup times, material
costs, and error in handling. HMs have been increasingly
considered in the industry for remanufacturing and repair
of high-value components and in manufacturing parts that
require complex process chains. Pipe casings for offshore
oil extraction have several features (e.g., fins and spiral
coatings) on the surface critical. The use of an HM for
such a part was proved to reduce the material cost by
~97.2% in addition to the tooling cost [5]. An HM can customize implants by milling the implant?abutment interface
followed by printing the abutment custom-designed for a
patient [6], create novel injection molds with improved
cooling performance over traditional fabrication methods [7], and enable surface patching in the mold and die
repair [8] and turbine blade repair [9].
Journal Name:
A Survey of Cybersecurity of
Digital Manufacturing

Text: The subsequent sections analyze the distinct cybersecurity challenges confronting two pivotal Industry 4.0 manufacturing technologies: CNC machine tools (subtractive manufacturing) and 3D printers (additive manufacturing). For CNC systems, we examine threats to precision toolpath integrity and unauthorized access to proprietary material specifications, while for 3D printers, we focus on vulnerabilities in digital design files and layer-by-layer production sabotage. Alongside this technology-specific risk mapping, we present a methodological review of existing frameworks for quantifying cyberattack impacts in smart manufacturing environments?valuating their efficacy in addressing emergent threats like production line ransomware or intellectual property theft in digitally networked factories. This dual focus reveals critical gaps in current defenses while establishing a foundation for tailored security solutions aligned with each technology's operational parameters and business-critical data flows.

In this section, we utilize the stability results from Section II to develop an impulsive control strategy for a class of nonlinear systems. We begin by providing a formal definition of impulsive control, slightly adapted from. This definition involves a plant P with a state variable X in R^n, a set of control instants T, and control laws U(k;X) in R^n. At each control instant k, the state X undergoes an impulsive change, described by X(k+) = X(k-) + U(k;X), ensuring system stability and meeting specific performance criteria.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: The proposed motion detection scheme utilizes one-bit image data from selected pixels and includes frame latch blocks and a signal difference detector (equivalent to an MSB) as shown in Figure 12. Each frame latch block contains the image data of the selected column line in digital form. The current and previous image data are compared in the difference detector. If the difference between the two frames exceeds the preset motion detection threshold, the circuit will determine that motion has occurred.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: The remainder of this paper is structured systematically to present a comprehensive exploration of gamified cybersecurity training. Section II conducts a literature review examining existing applications of gamification in educational contexts and investigates its potential adaptation for cybersecurity training programs. Section III analyzes the role of gamification in workforce development, specifically addressing its capacity to enhance cybersecurity proficiency within facility control systems. Section IV elaborates on the methodological framework employed in designing the game mechanics for the Network Defense Training Game (NDTG). Section V presents a practical use case demonstrating the implementation of this methodology. Section VI evaluates the previously described scenario to illustrate NDTG's efficacy in cyber-workforce development initiatives. The paper concludes with Section VII, which synthesizes key findings and outlines potential directions for future research in this domain.

This study employs the C-I-A triad (Confidentiality-Integrity-Availability) as a foundational security framework to evaluate breach consequences in Industry 4.0 manufacturing systems, where violations of these core principles directly impact operational and business outcomes. While derived security properties (e.g., non-repudiation, authenticity) will be examined in future research, we focus here on establishing actionable cyber risk management strategies tailored to smart manufacturing environments. The proposed methodology begins with comprehensive risk assessment?dentifying and prioritizing critical assets?s the essential first step toward developing robust, implementation-ready cybersecurity protocols for Industry 4.0 infrastructures.

The Privacy Act of 1974, likewise, mandates that federal infor mation systems ensure the confidentiality of individually iden tifiable data [7]. These mandates provide little guidance on the specific structure and formation of localized technology-related organizational functions required to meet such requirements. Unlike most service industries, however, failure to adopt secu rity measures in health-care organizations carries increasingly severe penalties [8]–[10]. Undeniably, in health care, the stakes are high regarding security noncompliance. For the most part, information models have been used as a means for examining organization-specific security issues. Little has been done to ex amine industry-wide, or institutional, trends. The emergence of industry-wide information regulations, and related penalties for noncompliance,mayprovideamorecompleteperspectivewhen regulatory or cross-market influences serve to counteract ac cepted behavior withinspecificorganizations. There isalso little research into how information technology affects the clinical health-care environment. As a whole, physicians have histori cally viewed the information management process as adminis trative in nature, and thus, have developed little expertise in this area, despite universal requirements now mandated by HIPAA and the Privacy Act [11], [12].
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: The discussed HNN authentication scheme is self-contained. The recall devise will never make a mistake since the registration procedure ensuresthematchingofeachlegalpairofuserIDandthecorresponding password accurately. Any illegal pair will be rejected. Nevertheless, it is desirable to know the effectiveness of this scheme by comparing it with the existing layered neural network method documented in [9]. Two simulation experiments were conducted. The first test examined the computational time for registration, and the other test examined the performance of cases when many passwords had similar character sequences
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: To fully realize the economic and efficiency benefits of Digital Manufacturing (DM), it is essential to identify and secure vulnerable nodes within the supporting infrastructures. Key components of Hybrid Manufacturing (HM) tools, which integrate additive and subtractive processes, present specific vulnerabilities that must be addressed to prevent exploitation. The interconnected nature of DM increases the risk of cyberattacks, particularly through legacy systems that often remain unpatched and susceptible to threats such as unauthorized access, malware injection, and insider threats. For instance, a recent report highlighted that 80% of manufacturing firms have critical vulnerabilities, with many organizations experiencing internal exploit attempts due to the convergence of IT and operational technology (OT) networks. This article will discuss the identified vulnerabilities associated with HM tools, serving as a foundation for developing a taxonomy of these vulnerabilities and proposing targeted solutions to enhance cybersecurity in DM environments. By proactively addressing these risks, manufacturers can better protect their operations and ensure the integrity of their production processes as they transition to more digitally integrated systems.

In this paper, we focus on the low power motion detection 
with partial modifications from the conventional image sensor 
chips. We prove with computer simulations that only a few 
thousands of image data is sufficient for comparable motion 
detection accuracy using normal CMOS image sensors. Low 
power consumption is possible since this system uses a few 
percent of total pixels and just one bit of the selected pixels. 
And the unused blocks of the CIS are put in the standby mode 
for power savings. this architecture is being designed using 
0.35? standard CMOS technology (1-P, 4-M) with pixel 
arrays of 128?96.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: Over the past decade, chaos-based secure communications have evolved to their fourth generation, as documented in references?,,, and. The first three generations employed continuous synchronization, while the fourth generation utilizes impulsive synchronization. Notably, the fourth generation requires less than 94 Hz of bandwidth to transmit the synchronization signal for a third-order chaotic transmitter, compared to the 30 kHz needed in the previous generations. This represents a significant improvement in bandwidth efficiency. However, attacks described in and have revealed that many of these methods lack robust security or have low security levels. Consequently, enhancing the security of chaotic secure communication systems is highly desirable.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text:
Estimating the global state of a networked system is
an important problem in many application domains. The classical
approach to tackling this problem is the periodic (observation)
method, which is inefficient because it often observes states at a
very high frequency. This inefficiency has motivated the idea of
event-based method, which leverages the evolution dynamics in
question and makes observations only when some rules are
triggered (i.e., only when certain conditions hold). This paper
initiates the investigation of using the event-based method to
estimate the equilibrium in the new application domain of
cybersecurity, where equilibrium is an important metric that has
no closed-form solutions. More specifically, the paper presents an
event-based method for estimating cybersecurity equilibrium in
the preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics, which has
been proven globally convergent. The presented study proves that
the estimated equilibrium from our trigger rule i) indeed
converges to the equilibrium of the dynamics and ii) is Zeno-free,
which assures the usefulness of the event-based method.
Numerical examples show that the event-based method can
reduce 98% of the observation cost incurred by the periodic
method. In order to use the event-based method in practice, this
paper investigates how to bridge the gap between i) the
continuous state in the dynamics model, which is dubbed
probability-state because it measures the probability that a node
is in the secure or compromised state, and ii) the discrete state
that is often encountered in practice, dubbed sample-state because
it is sampled from some nodes. This bridge may be of
independent value because probability-state models have been
widely used to approximate exponentially-many discrete state
systems.
Journal Name:
Using Event-Based Method to Estimate
Cybersecurity Equilibrium

Text: This research explores a low-power motion detection method that requires minimal changes to standard CMOS image sensors. We demonstrate, through computer simulations, that using only a few thousand image data points achieves motion detection accuracy comparable to traditional methods. This is accomplished by processing just a small percentage of total pixels, with each pixel contributing only a single bit. To further reduce power consumption, unused portions of the image sensor are placed in standby mode. The proposed architecture is being developed using 0.35?m standard CMOS technology (1-Poly, 4-Metal) and a 128x96 pixel array.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: Meidan et al. [26] employed machine learning (ML) techniques to categorize unauthorized Internet of Things (IoT) devices connected to a network, utilizing Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) traffic network data, predicated on the assumption that the dataset adequately represents each whitelisted device type; specifically, supervised ML, particularly random forest (RF), was used to extract features from network traffic data, enabling the effective identification of IoT device types within the whitelist; a dataset comprising nine distinct IoT device categories, encompassing 17 unique devices, was manually labeled for multiclass classifier training and testing; from an initial set of 60 features, a subset was selected based on criteria that excluded zero variance, irrelevance, and overfitting tendencies, thereby optimizing device profiling and identification; to simulate unauthorized device detection, one IoT device type was omitted from the whitelist; classifier transportability was validated by training the model on two identical security cameras (SimpleHomeXCS71001) in Laboratory A and testing it on a dissimilar security camera (Withings WBP02WT9510) in Laboratory B; the trained classifiers achieved an average accuracy of 96% in detecting illegitimate IoT device types, demonstrating the efficacy of this transfer learning approach.

While a broadly inductive approach was applied to data
analysis, this was informed by relevant theory on institutional
isomorphism [20] in the construction of thematic headings.
Institutional isomorphic forces can assume various forms (force,
persuasion, signaling, restructuring, use of government mandate,
policy transfer, etc.), so this framework enabled the interpretation of participants? perceptions concerning: GCC-wide shared
cybersecurity understandings, approaches, and responses; and
GCC-wide cybersecurity institutional coordination and integration
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity: Perceived Threats and Policy
Responses in the Gulf Cooperation Council

In accordance with RMR study results for the South
Bangkok power plant, this unit must reserve at least
565.88 MW and 273.89 Mvar to maintain system security. Absence of this amount of generation at this
particular bus might result in a thermal limit violation in
