inside their units and sell surplus generation capacity
(compare to the RMR quantity) to the deregulated
market
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: To adapt to the evolving electric-power market, this paper proposes an Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) system featuring bidirectional communication. This system aims to enhance utility efficiency and facilitate flexible pricing models. Utilizing advanced communication technologies like GSM and GPRS, the AMI system enables rapid and accurate automated meter data collection. Seamless integration with existing billing and management systems minimizes labor costs and improves meter-reading precision. Furthermore, the system provides customers with detailed load usage statistics and profiles, empowering them to optimize energy consumption. When implemented, it will also support real-time pricing, a crucial feature for the future deregulated utility sector.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: Regarding the Italian blackout of September 28, 2003, I want to reiterate that in the northwestern region of Italy, Automatic Voltage Regulator (AVR) line-drop compensation was active instead of Static Var Regulation (SVR). This was due to the recent activation of a new SCADA/EMS system at the regional dispatcher control room. Recent analyses have indicated that, aside from line overloads, the cascading tripping phenomenon, which led to generator shutdowns due to low voltage and the subsequent blackout, could have been prevented if SVR had been operational in that extensive border area with France.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: The pervasive expansion of internet connectivity has facilitated the emergence of a cyber society characterized by diverse communication exchanges, encompassing private information dissemination and commercial transactions; however, this digital proliferation has concurrently amplified the prevalence and diversification of cyber threats, extending to targets ranging from individual users to corporate entities and critical infrastructure installations, with objectives spanning financial gain to politically motivated actions; consequently, the imperative for robust cybersecurity operations has intensified, necessitating the development and implementation of effective mitigation strategies to counteract these evolving threats.

According to the RMR study results for the South Bangkok power plant, it is necessary to reserve at least 565.88 MW and 273.89 Mvar to ensure system security. Without this level of generation at the specific bus, there is a risk of thermal limit violations in the transmission system, which could lead to significant security issues. To remain competitive in the market, the power plant should optimize its dispatch and unit commitment strategies. This allows the plant to sell any surplus generation capacity beyond the required RMR quantity in the deregulated market, thereby maximizing its operational efficiency and market participation.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: The structure of this note is as follows: Section II presents a novel comparison theorem along with a sufficient condition for the asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems. These findings are then utilized in Section III to formulate an impulsive control law for nonlinear systems. Finally, Section IV provides concluding remarks.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: This study examines the impact of different information systems (IS) sourcing strategies on organizational cybersecurity breaches through a longitudinal empirical analysis. The findings indicate that when an organization has a limited range of IT applications, a best-of-breed (BoB) strategy poses a lower cybersecurity risk than a single-sourcing approach, though this difference diminishes as IT application diversity increases. Insourcing appears to reduce cybersecurity breaches more effectively than outsourcing strategies, including single-sourcing, best-of-suite (BoS), and BoB, but this advantage weakens as IT application diversity grows and is only significant when IT application spread is relatively low. Additionally, the BoS strategy shows no significant difference in cybersecurity risk compared to the BoB approach. For organizations with a wide range of IT applications, all sourcing strategies exhibit a similar likelihood of cybersecurity breaches. These insights contribute to both theoretical understanding and practical strategies for improving cybersecurity management in IS development and interorganizational relationships.

Authenticators can be categorized into three main types: secrets
(what you know), tokens (what you have), and IDs (who you are).
A password is a secret word, phrase, or personal identification
number. Although passwords are ubiquitously used, they pose vulnerabilities, the biggest being that a short mnemonic password can
be guessed or searched by an ambitious attacker, while a longer,
random password is difficult for a person to remember.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: An independent sample t-test methodology was implemented in this research. Data integrity was confirmed through multiple validation steps: boxplot inspection revealed no outliers, the Shapiro-Wilk test (p >.05) confirmed normal distribution, and Levene's test verified homogeneity of variances (p =.164). Table 2 presents comprehensive descriptive statistics including means and standard deviations. The study findings reveal statistically significant differences in cybersecurity awareness between UAE and USA respondents across several domains. The research design involved initially conducting the study in the UAE, then establishing comparable demographic controls on Mechanical Turk to ensure equivalent participant characteristics in the USA sample. Further validation was achieved by comparing male participants from the UAE (n = 42) with their USA counterparts (n = 40), yielding similar outcome patterns. These methodological precautions effectively mitigated potential gender bias concerns in the research findings.

Cyber security breaches in power systems are a real and growing concern. A U.S. Department of Energy study revealed numerous incidents of unauthorized access causing damage to power control systems across transmission, distribution, and generation. While there's extensive discussion about the cyber security needs of power utilities and protection systems, there's a lack of published research detailing concrete solutions. Existing literature outlines threats and countermeasures, covering aspects like system configuration, security protocols, and cryptography. Although dedicated networks enhance data confidentiality and integrity, they do not fully protect against internal threats.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: StealthNet is a U.S. Army-funded Live-Virtual-Constructive (LVC) platform designed for cyber-related testing, evaluation, and training specifically focused on the Army's tactical networks. This platform incorporates emulation models of various cyber attacks, including jamming, Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS), and worm propagation, to assess the impact of these threats on tactical network operations. Notably, StealthNet offers simulation models tailored for wireless tactical networks, facilitating LVC co-simulation that enhances cybersecurity training within these environments. By utilizing StealthNet, military personnel can engage in realistic training scenarios that accurately reflect the complexities of cyber warfare, thereby improving their preparedness against potential cyber threats and ensuring the resilience of operational networks in the field.

The practice of internal system penetration testing, as a means of evaluating cyberattack resilience, is widely regarded as an effective strategy for identifying and mitigating vulnerabilities, while simultaneously providing valuable training for staff [25]; however, the engagement of ethical hackers, and their very existence within an organization, introduces a spectrum of ethical dilemmas that necessitate careful consideration and management.

The proposed vulnerability assessment framework is structured into three levels: system, scenarios, and access points. The process flow, as shown in Fig. 3, outlines the simulation steps. This methodology has been developed using Visual Basic.NET, with integration between SPNP [24] and MATLAB. An XML file is employed to store simulation models, which are then used to generate an intermediate file in C-Based SPNP Language (CSPL). This file is created through an algorithm that constructs a cyber-network topology based on network definitions, which include firewall and password models.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: To deter potential eavesdroppers, authorized users continuously adjust the phase within the external cavity to maintain synchronization, making it extremely difficult for an attacker to achieve the same. One might suggest that an eavesdropper could detect these phase variations by observing their receiver switching between synchronized and desynchronized states depending on the phase shifts. However, as the subsequent analysis will demonstrate, this is not feasible when phase variations occur rapidly.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: One of the most widely referenced image digest functions and authentication schemes is SARI, introduced by Lin and Chang [1]. The SARI authentication scheme includes an image digest function that produces hash bits resistant to JPEG compression. These hash bits remain unchanged if the image undergoes JPEG compression but alter significantly under any other substantial or malicious modification. In this paper, we demonstrate that the image digest component of the SARI authentication system lacks sufficient security. Specifically, if an attacker possesses image digests for multiple images generated using the same secret key, they can manipulate arbitrary images to be authenticated. The paper is structured as follows: Section II provides a brief overview of the image digest computation in SARI, Section III details our attack, and Section IV proposes potential solutions to mitigate the attack.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: The proposed motion detection scheme relies on one-bit image data from selected pixels and includes frame latch blocks and a signal difference detector, akin to a Most Significant Bit (MSB) comparator (as shown in Figure 12). Each frame latch block stores the digital image data from the selected column line. The difference detector compares the current and previous image data. If the difference between two frames exceeds the predefined motion detection threshold, the circuit determines that motion is present.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: Authentication is the process of confirming the identity of a user, device, or entity within a computer system, often a prerequisite for accessing system resources. This verification is achieved by matching an identity indicator, such as a prearranged shared secret, typically established when a person was authorized to use the system. The most common user authenticator in use today is the password. Machine-to-machine authentication is exemplified by the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL).
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: The ongoing development of Generative AI (GenAI) tools has presented a dual-faceted paradigm within the realm of cybersecurity, yielding both advantageous and detrimental implications for defenders and attackers, respectively. Specifically, GenAI tools, such as ChatGPT, may be leveraged by cyber defenders to fortify systems against malicious intrusions. These tools capitalize on information derived from Large Language Models (LLMs), which are trained on extensive datasets encompassing cyber threat intelligence, including vulnerability data, attack pattern analysis, and indicators of compromise. Cyber defenders can utilize this substantial information repository to enhance their threat intelligence capabilities by extracting actionable insights and identifying emergent threats [18]. Furthermore, GenAI tools can facilitate the analysis of voluminous log files, system output, and network traffic data in the context of cyber incident response. This capability enables defenders to expedite and automate incident response procedures. GenAI-driven models also contribute to the cultivation of security-conscious human behavior by providing training on increasingly sophisticated attack vectors. GenAI tools can further support secure coding practices, both through the generation of secure code segments and the production of test cases to validate the security of written code. Additionally, LLM models can aid in the development of robust ethical guidelines, thereby strengthening cyber defense mechanisms within a given system.

The Room Transfer Function (RTF) is typically measured by correlating the acoustic source signal with the received signal at a specified position. The choice of source signal is crucial; while impulse signals, such as a gunshot, are commonly used, this paper utilizes white noise. The method of using white noise for sound measurement offers advantages, including improved repeatability and a higher signal-to-noise ratio through repeated measurements compared to using sound radiated from a speaker in a room. In an ideal environment like an anechoic chamber, no signals are received after the initial peak, but in real-world settings, reflected signals lead to prolonged reverberation, as illustrated in Figure 1.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: During the more than one hun dred year history, much has changed "beneath the hood" and within the vehicle cabin area. These changes have been enabled by advances in electrical, electronics and software technologies as shown in Fig. 2. A coarse history of the automobile reveals the broad and growing role played by these technologies in en abling vehicle-level features, exam ples of which are shown in the top part of the figure with arrows pointing to approximate dates when first applications appeared in the market place.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: In this work, we introduce a biometric cryptosystem based on Juels’ fuzzy commitment [6], designed to protect function-based online signature templates. The recognition performance achieved with this system significantly surpasses that of parametric feature-based representations, which are commonly used in existing signature template protection methods, such as those in [5] and [7].
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: The system's accuracy and the effectiveness of remedial actions taken after a contingency depend on how closely actual operating conditions align with the base cases used for simulations. In each system loading and power transfer scenario, Taipower's generator dispatch rules are followed, adjusting power generation to remain within the MW limits of the target transfers for each study. The dispatch priority is determined by fuel type while adhering to additional operational rules. For determining remedial actions, prioritized load and generator shedding tables were developed and utilized. Generators capable of rapid restart are given higher priority for shedding, while the load shedding sequence is determined based on interruption costs.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: Real-time notification of alarm incidents has become a vital feature of home security systems. This can be achieved through the internet or GSM/GPRS, with GSM/GPRS offering greater convenience. The primary advantage of GSM/GPRS is its widespread network coverage, ensuring system availability almost all the time. Additionally, GSM/GPRS provides a high-security infrastructure that safeguards transmitted and received information from being monitored [8]. Several networks discussed in [3], [5], [6], and [7] use the internet to relay information to remote users, while [8] and [9] present home systems that utilize GSM/GPRS for remote control. However, [8] only identifies GSM as a communication method between remote users and the home network server without applying it specifically to home security. Meanwhile, the system in [9] incorporates GSM/GPRS technology solely for intrusion detection, with its communication being non-wireless.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: In the coming decades, electronic controllers, micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS), and nano-scale electrochemical sensors and actuators will play a crucial role in emissions treatment. These technologies will enable the electrochemical systems necessary to significantly reduce the levels of hydrocarbons, carbon oxides, and nitrogen oxides in tailpipe emissions. Currently, electronic controllers, sensors, and actuators are used in multi-stage exhaust gas treatment processes, ensuring that hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are captured and converted into cleaner emissions before exiting the tailpipe.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: This paper systematically outlines the design process and selection approach for integrating current wind power technologies into Thailand’s power system. The analysis is based on existing power system data and the latest wind resource assessment. It thoroughly examines the appropriate penetration level of wind power generation and the sizing of wind turbines, considering Thailand’s classification as a low-to-medium wind speed region.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: Through the proposed hard partitioning process, complex Contribution Factor (CF) spaces are simplified into the ITDA space with just three discrete values: 1, 0, and -1. These values respectively represent "desirable," "less determinative," and "undesirable" impacts on various constraints, as summarized in Table III. This approach enables straightforward classification of individual DR characteristics for congestion management purposes.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: The study of brute-force break-ins necessitates a probabilistic model to describe the relationship between the number of attacks and the probability of false acceptance. Therefore, it is essential to establish a probabilistic model for the angular distance as given in equation (4). To simplify the model, we assume that all preprocessed palmprint images are clear and free of non-palmprint pixels, allowing us to disregard masks and normalization terms. The same results can be obtained using either the integer or bitwise representation of Competitive Code, but for clarity, we will use the integer representation. Thus, we will consider the angular distance given in equation (2) for the following analysis.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: One of the critical functionalities of a phishing kit is its ability to save stolen data, employing various methods based on complexity. These methods include saving stolen credentials in plain text files, sending the data to a specified email address each time a victim is deceived, and utilizing more sophisticated phishing kits that feature control panels and databases for displaying stolen credentials to the attackers. Common exfiltration techniques involve writing stolen data to files hosted on the phishing site or using email to send compromised information directly to the attackers. Advanced phishing kits may also incorporate databases that allow for easier access and management of stolen data through an admin panel, although these databases are often poorly secured. Overall, the design and functionality of phishing kits are evolving, enabling cybercriminals to execute attacks more efficiently while increasing the challenges for detection and prevention.

The proposed system aims to prevent the loss of confidential files through USB removable storage devices. In our protocol, file transfers via the USB interface are restricted until the user successfully completes remote server authentication. All transmitted files are encrypted using the key 
To access the original file on another computer, the user must undergo the same authentication process and obtain the same key K for decryption. The key 
K is uniquely generated based on the user ID and filename (), ensuring that different users or files produce distinct keys.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: A cyber-net is a composite model that integrates firewall and password models to analyze security breaches in SCADA systems. The structure of a cyber-net, based on computer network connectivity, is depicted in Fig. 7. This cyber-net consists of modules that represent different networks within a power plant (highlighted in bold in Fig. 7), substation, distribution operations center, and control center. Each module contains firewall and password models that correspond to the specific network, aiding in security analysis.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text:
In this paper, we deal with privacy-maintaining near realtime BDCA. We propose DBD-Guardian, a solution for
BDCA that relies on modules running over a distributed
query engine. Our solution uses a novel approach in which
dashboard and iterative user queries are executed directly on
distributed data sources. A single query can combine multiple
sources from a specific host or even combine data sources of
different types distributed across the entire environment. One
can, for instance, use a single query to access data on the
system log files of all servers on the network and combine
them with captured network traffic. Data sources (e.g., log
files) are queried while still stored in their original locations
without requiring their transfer to a centralized repository,
reducing data storage and processing costs and providing near
real-time access to relevant data. We implemented parsers
capable of dealing with the heterogeneity of data sources
that allow querying on virtual fields identified in such data
sources. Moreover, DBD-Guardian applies anonymization
to fulfill privacy-related requirements. We prototyped and
evaluated our proposals? performance and threat detection
capabilities in a scenario with several threats to hosts of
distinct types
Journal Name:
DBD-Guardian and Privacy-Aware Near
Real-Time Cybersecurity Analytics

Text: We propose a novel password authentication method based on Hopfield Neural Networks (HNN). Without compromising its general applicability, we demonstrate how this authentication system can validate user IDs and passwords. This method can be applied to various access control mechanisms, including multi-server login permissions [9] and role-based security models [12]. The authentication process consists of three main steps: user registration, login authorization, and password modification.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Cybersecurity encompasses a combination of processes, human behaviors, and systems designed to protect electronic resources. Just as Moore? Law predicts the doubling of components on an integrated circuit every two years while reducing costs, cybercriminals are rapidly enhancing the effectiveness of their attack tools at lower costs within shorter timeframes. Global cybersecurity expenditures are projected to surpass $1 trillion between 2017 and 2021, with spending already witnessing a nearly 40% increase from 2013, reaching $66 billion. This trend highlights the growing importance of robust security measures to counter evolving cyber threats.

This paper provides a detailed examination of brute-force attacks targeting our palmprint recognition system. Employing Competitive Code features and angular distance matching, we developed a projected multinomial distribution model to quantify the correlation between the likelihood of false acceptance and the number of attack attempts. Our analytical findings demonstrate that, with a system threshold set below 0.39, brute-force attacks against our palmprint system become computationally impractical.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: By integrating these mechanisms, the protocol effectively mitigates smart card cloning and McCormac Hack scenarios while maintaining compatibility with existing DVB standards.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text:
As the Internet develops and grows, many of our activities
are now conducted online, including e-commerce, business,
social networking, and banking, raising the likelihood of
online crime. So, securing the world wide web is becoming
increasingly important. According to Internet World Stats [1],
around 237,418,349 users used the Arabic language on the
Internet in 2020. Attempts to bait users to click through
to malicious uniform resource locators (URLs) lead to the
system being hacked or access being gained to sensitive data.
Consequently, it is becoming increasingly necessary to secure this side. Protocols and regulations secure the connection
between the client and server, yet it is still vulnerable to those
with malicious intent to attack it. The term ??Malicious?? is a
general term for attack types that include phishing, spam and
malware, and more.
Journal Name:
Detecting Malicious URLs Using Machine Learning
Techniques: Review and Research Directions

Text: Isolated power systems, such as the Taiwan Power System (TPS), are highly sensitive to frequency deviations. Therefore, system operators (SOs) must schedule sufficient reserve capacity, utilizing the Automatic Generation Control (AGC) functions of online generating units to regulate active power and balance load demand. In daily operations, providing an adequate amount of Frequency Regulation Reserve (FRR) within seconds of losing an online unit is critical to maintaining system frequency within acceptable limits. FRR is necessary to continuously balance supply and demand variations in isolated power systems, ensuring reliability and control performance standards are met.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: The Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System (ACARS), standardized under ARINC 618, operates as an ASCII-based digital datalink analogous to SMS, facilitating exchanges between aircraft, operators, and air traffic control (ATC) for critical data like weather updates, flight plans, and engine performance metrics [38][39]. It supports three transmission modes: VHF (for terrestrial coverage), SATCOM (oceanic/remote regions via Inmarsat/Iridium), and HFDL (global backup), with message formatting governed by ARINC 620-8 [33][40]. While versatile, ACARS? character-based protocol and legacy design introduce cybersecurity vulnerabilities, particularly in plaintext transmissions and dependency on aging infrastructure? focal point for modern aviation risk assessments given its role in safety-critical communications.

As demand grows, Distributed Resources (DRs), including distributed generation and energy storage devices, are becoming increasingly prevalent in the industry. They are being integrated into distribution and sub-transmission systems to provide load services. It is anticipated that DRs will cover about 25% of the load increase in North America over the next decade. However, DRs are typically not controlled by Independent System Operators (ISOs) or Distribution Companies (DISCOs), making it challenging for ISOs to gather detailed information about each DR device.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: The increasing reliance on modern technology in the railway industry has introduced a new set of cybersecurity challenges, making railway systems more vulnerable to attacks. These networked and computerized systems not only expand the attack surface compared to traditional dedicated systems but also require less specialized knowledge to exploit due to their commonality across different components. This situation, coupled with a general lack of cybersecurity awareness among industry players and the high-profile nature of railway systems, positions them as prime targets for a range of attackers, from amateur "script kiddies" to sophisticated state-sponsored actors. Numerous cyber incidents have occurred in recent years, including a notable event in Lodz, Poland, where a teenager managed to derail trams using a replay attack on signaling systems. As cyber threats against rail infrastructure continue to rise, with reports indicating that such attacks have doubled annually over the past five years, it is imperative for railway operators to adopt robust cybersecurity measures. These measures should include enhanced authentication protocols, secure networking practices, and continuous monitoring to safeguard against potential breaches and ensure the safety and reliability of rail operations.

Research indicates that cyberattacks are increasing in frequency, accompanied by a growing body of literature offering tools and frameworks for assessing cyber risks. While the severity of these attacks appears to have stabilized, the financial impact remains significant, with a single cyberattack costing an average of $229,000. Globally, the cumulative cost of cyberattacks is estimated to reach hundreds of billions of dollars annually. In response, approximately one-third of organizations are considering cyber insurance as a mitigation strategy. However, this option may not be feasible for social enterprises (SEs), which often face substantial financial limitations. Additionally, the value of financial compensation for SEs?rganizations typically driven by social missions rather than profit?s debatable. SEs are evaluated not only on financial performance but also on their societal impact, which is inherently challenging to quantify. This difficulty in measuring social value extends to assessing the full impact of cybercrime, making it equally challenging for SEs to secure adequate insurance coverage against such risks.

An effective reserve policy must consider the impact of various factors on system frequency to ensure a secure dispatch. Typically, the load-frequency sensitivity factor (LFSF) is used to assess network behavior after a contingency [3]. Some advanced reserve scheduling methods for isolated power systems have incorporated the system’s LFSF and frequency-based reserve constraints (FBRCs) [4], [5].
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text:
Inertial seismometer converts ground motion into electrical
signal, but its properties can not be described by a single-scale
factor, such as the output volts per millimeter of the ground motion (as occur in case of position sensor). Its response to ground
motion depends not only on the amplitude of motion (how large
it is), but also, on its time scale (how sudden it is). That is why
the suspended seismic mass has to be kept in place by certain
restoring force (electromagnetic, mechanical, or any other nature). But, when ground motion is slow, the mass will move
with the rest of a seismometer, and the output signal even for
a large motion will thus be negligibly smaller. Such a system
is so a high-pass filter for the ground shift. This must be taken
into account if ground motion is reconstructed from the recorded
signal. This is why creation of seismic detectors, which may give
large output signals both for the fast and slow ground motion
(regardless of the rate of motion—as behave themselves position sensors),still remains among the prime important problems
in seismology (and not only).
Thus, we discuss below a n
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: This paper presents a key exchange protocol for secure communication in DTV broadcasting, based on Schnorr’s digital signature protocol and a one-way hash function. The proposed method offers several advantages, including enhanced security, dynamic session keys, mutual authentication, reduced computational and communication overhead, and a password-free experience for users. Furthermore, the proposed scheme effectively prevents two major security threats in DTV broadcasting: smart card cloning and the McCormac Hack.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: Simulations indicate that if the wind generator operates at 0.95 leading power factor (worst-case scenario), the terminal at bus G will experience undervoltage problems when line B is taken out of service after a disturbance. To address this issue, three improvement strategies are proposed. Figures 14–16 present the simulation results after implementing the proposed solutions.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text:
Malware invasive methods emerge for avoiding identification, as few malware applications have more than
50 parameters that make detection a difficult one [4]. Hence,
it is essential to devise techniques that deal with the continuous growth of Android malware to find it, deactivate or
remove it efficiently. All these difficulties engage scholars
in the area and urge them to continue more research to
find malware and manage it properly [5]. Thus, researchers
have developed three mechanisms to find Android malware such as dynamic, static, and hybrid analysis methods.
Static analysis extracts the features that assist in identifying harmful performance for apps without a demanding
actual application deployment [6]. But this kind of analysis
suffered from code obfuscation methods which assist help
malware author to avoid static methods. Dynamic analysis can be used for determining the malware of apps in
their runtime [7]. Commonly, the static analysis feature
offers the capability of locating the malware element using
source code, while the dynamic analysis feature offers the
capability of finding the location of malware in a runtime
environment. Android developers and users can be exposed
to unnecessary risks and dangers with malware [8]. This
study covers malware detection methods. The detection of
malware using the ML model includes Android Application
Packages (APKs) for deriving an appropriate set of features.
Deep learning (DL) and machine learning (ML) approaches
can be used for recognizing malicious APKs [9]. Like malware detection, vulnerability detection in software code has
two stages: training ML on derived attributes to find vulnerable code segments and feature generation utilizing code
analysis [10].
Journal Name:
Automated Android Malware Detection Using
Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach
for Cybersecurity

Text: We have developed an asymmetric watermarking scheme that utilizes a reference watermark along with multiple embedding watermarks. These embedding watermarks are derived from the reference watermark and specific keys through phase shifts in the DFT domain. While they are correlated with each other, the correlation is not strong enough to cause confusion with other keys. This allows for both asymmetric detection using the reference key and symmetric detection to extract key information. Since the energy spectra of the reference and embedding watermarks are identical, our method achieves a consistent asymmetric-to-symmetric detection statistic ratio in correlation tests using prewhitening filtering.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: The development of specialized cybersecurity training systems, particularly cyber ranges, represents a fundamental requirement for achieving full military cyber readiness. Among early military-developed solutions, SIMTEX (Simulator Training Exercise Network) [2] emerged as a pioneering platform initially created for U.S. Air Force training before being adopted for large-scale cybersecurity exercises including Black Daemon and Cyber Flag. This system established critical training capabilities through virtualized host environments that accurately simulated vulnerable information assets, combined with VPN tunnel technology that effectively isolated attack traffic across distributed training locations. While representing significant progress in military cyber training, such early systems primarily focused on technical simulation capabilities, highlighting the ongoing need for more comprehensive approaches that integrate tactical, strategic, and decision-making dimensions to fully prepare military personnel for modern cyber warfare challenges.

Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: Currently, three main wind turbine technologies are prevalent in the industry. First, the squirrel-cage induction generator, the simplest type, adjusts turbine blade pitch based on wind speed to maintain near-constant speed. Second, the double-fed induction generator connects its stator winding to the grid and its rotor winding to a back-to-back voltage-source converter, which enables variable-speed operation by adjusting the rotor's feeding current frequency. Third, the direct-drive synchronous generator connects the rotor directly to the generator, eliminating the need for a gearbox.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: In a meshed power system, protection devices must account for current flows that can move in either a clockwise or counterclockwise direction [13]. Therefore, coordinating protections within such a system is crucial for accurately modeling Petri Nets (PNs). Specifically, defining protection zones for distance relays is a key principle for establishing the correct sequence of operations for primary and backup protections in power transmission networks [13], [21]–[23].
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Real-time notification of alarm incidents has become a critical feature of home security systems. This can be achieved through either the internet or GSM/GPRS networks, with GSM/GPRS offering greater convenience. The primary advantage of GSM/GPRS is its widespread coverage, ensuring the system remains accessible almost all the time. Additionally, the high-security infrastructure of the GSM/GPRS network ensures that transmitted information remains secure and cannot be intercepted. While some systems, such as those in,,, and, rely on the internet to send information to remote users, examples like and utilize GSM/GPRS for remote control. However, only demonstrates GSM as a communication method between the remote user and the home network server without applying it specifically to home security systems. Meanwhile, the system in uses GSM/GPRS technology for intrusion detection but operates through non-wireless communication.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: Attacking your own system through ethical hacking is an effective way to uncover vulnerabilities, strengthen defenses, and train staff to respond to cyber threats. Ethical hackers simulate real-world attacks to identify weaknesses before malicious actors can exploit them, helping organizations improve their security posture and comply with regulations. However, ethical hacking raises dilemmas, such as ensuring strict adherence to codes of ethics, maintaining trust, and preventing misuse of sensitive findings. Ethical hackers must operate within legal boundaries, have explicit permission, and avoid harm to systems or data. While their work is invaluable for proactive cybersecurity, it requires careful oversight to address the ethical complexities involved

The mapping process encompasses all the security controls
outlined in ISO/IEC 27001:2022. Each control is thoroughly
examined and evaluated, then the teleological interpretation
method is applied to determine if a corresponding control
exists in the standards being compared. If the security control encompasses multiple sub-controls (Figure 3), they are
also included in the mapping. To accommodate the extensive
number of security controls in each of the analyzed standards,
the mapping tables in Appendix IX (Tables 5 and 6) solely
display the controls that demonstrate alignment between
the standards. Controls that lack a corresponding entry are
excluded from these tables.
Journal Name:
A Comparative Analysis of Industrial
Cybersecurity Standards

Text:
Physical security of the power infrastructure has been recognized by the power community as an important issue. One
example precaution was to prevent vandalism on unmanned
substations [9]. Due to the growing concern over the potential
sabotage, the focus of physical security has been broadened
to incorporate critical substations that may result in cascading
effects, leading to a wide-area blackout [10]. The application of
sensors to monitor the structural health of transmission lines is
also an important way to reduce the power system vulnerability
[11]. Electronic security is as important as physical security due
to the potential impact that can be made through operations
of critical cyberassets.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text:
This research undertakes the presentation and analysis of outcomes derived from two distinct Delphi processes, employing expert consensus to evaluate cybersecurity topics according to their perceived importance, difficulty, and enduring relevance, these assessments serve to pinpoint core concepts, defined as interdisciplinary ideas that bind knowledge within the cybersecurity domain, the initial Delphi process focused on delineating core concepts pertinent to introductory cybersecurity education, while the subsequent process aimed to identify essential knowledge for cybersecurity professionals upon graduation, notwithstanding the escalating demand for cybersecurity expertise, a definitive framework for foundational cybersecurity knowledge remains elusive, the preliminary data obtained from these Delphi processes establishes a basis for the articulation of core disciplinary concepts, thereby facilitating a unified starting point for the advancement of standardized and rigorous cybersecurity educational practices, furthermore, these results contribute to the development of evidence-based educational assessment tools, designed to identify and quantify effective cybersecurity pedagogy, and inform the creation of curricula, learning modules, and related educational resources and policies.

This article aims to examine the factors influencing the cyber-preparedness of social enterprises (SEs) in the U.K. by systematically identifying the elements that support or hinder their ability to address cybercrime. It begins with a review of relevant cybercrime literature, followed by the development of a conceptual framework and research questions based on the unique characteristics of SEs. The methodology and findings are then presented, concluding with key contributions and recommendations for future research.

A unique feature of the RL that distinguishes it from other
types of learning algorithms is the trade-off between exploration and exploitation. This, in simple terms means that
since the goal of the agent is to maximize the reward while
interacting with the environment, it must seek to exploit the
knowledge it already has based on past interactions and the
rewards obtained. However, in order to select better actions
in the future, the agent needs to explore other actions to
maximize rewards. This occurrence is usually known as the
exploration-exploitation dilemma.
Journal Name:
Resilient Machine Learning for Networked Cyber
Physical System

Text: The rapid expansion of the Internet has accelerated the emergence of a digital society, facilitating widespread communication, private data exchange, and commercial transactions, yet simultaneously escalating both the frequency and complexity of cyber threats, which now target individuals, corporations, and critical infrastructure?rom financial theft to politically motivated attacks [1-3]. This evolving landscape demands heightened cybersecurity measures to counteract increasingly sophisticated threats, necessitating robust defensive strategies to protect sensitive data, maintain operational integrity, and safeguard national security interests in an interconnected world.

The security of some DDF systems can be compromised. Es sentially, the parameters of the system can be determined from the time series after making some assumptions regarding the functional formofthenonlinearityofthefeedbackelement[16], [17]. Many optoelectronic [13] and all-electronic [18], [19] im plementations of DDF systems have used a fixed nonlinearity with awell-definedfunctionalform. Ithas beenshownthatDDF chaotic systems can be cracked using curve fitting algorithms if the functional form is known [16]. Further, the cracking algo rithm that compromises the security of the DDF system relies on the ability to determine the time delay in the system. It has recently been shown numerically that security can be improved by modulating the time delay [20].
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text:
As the substation automation system migrates to network
communication, the protection system is faced with an increasing risk of cyber security under network context. A
successful intruder can block the measurement transmitting an
electronic instrument transformer and send fake measurements
to a corresponding protection system, which will usually lead
to its maloperation. In order to provide a complementary
mechanism against other measures, context information-based
cyber security protection is proposed in this paper. When the
protection system detects a fault based on the measurements of
a single or couple instrument transformers, the measurements
of the whole substation will be collected to carry out pattern
classification to validate the fault. A PNN used as pattern
classifier has been constructed. The test of real and fake fault
exemplars generated with specific rules show that the proposed
PNN can identify the fake fault from the real fault with selected
smoothing parameters.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: This section demonstrates the application of the stability criteria developed earlier to design impulsive control for nonlinear systems. We begin by defining impulsive control, adapting a definition from existing literature.Definition 4: Given a system (plant P) with state variable X in n-dimensional space (Rn), a sequence of control times T (denoted as k, where k is a positive real number and k < k+1 for all k), and control laws U(k, X) in Rn, impulsive control involves modifying the system state at each control time k. Specifically, the state X is impulsively changed at k according to the equation: X(k+) = X(k-) + U(k, X). The goal of this control is to stabilize the system and achieve specified performance objectives.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: In Multi-Processor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) architectures that rely on Network-on-Chip (NoC), direct attacks on the communication subsystem are not feasible due to the absence of direct physical network access. The use of NoC also prevents unauthorized interception of data passing through communication channels, provided that messages are not explicitly broadcast by the sender. The only way to replicate traditional attacks in such architectures is through direct read/write operations on the memory subsystem, as it retains the system's operational state.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: Recent research has increasingly focused on phishing kits due to the significant threat posed by large-scale phishing attacks, yet the absence of standardized datasets presents a major obstacle, as compiling such data is inherently complex and resource-intensive. Currently, researchers rely on known phishing sources to gather kits, but these lack contextual information linking them to actual phishing campaigns, necessitating manual reconstruction of phishing websites for analysis [25]. This approach introduces potential biases, as the methodology and decisions during data collection and sample creation may inadvertently influence the evaluation outcomes, thereby limiting the reliability and generalizability of the findings.

This paper presents an Automated Android Malware Detection using Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach for Cybersecurity (AAMD-OELAC) technique, which employs a multi-stage methodology beginning with data preprocessing to enhance input quality. The core detection process utilizes an ensemble of three machine learning models?east Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), Kernel Extreme Learning Machine (KELM), and Regularized Random Vector Functional Link Neural Network (RRVFLN)?hile the Hunter-Prey Optimization (HPO) algorithm dynamically optimizes their parameters to maximize detection accuracy. Through comprehensive experimental validation, the proposed AAMD-OELAC framework demonstrates superior malware identification performance compared to existing solutions, establishing its effectiveness as an advanced cybersecurity tool for Android environments.

In the proposed system, there are three types of receivers, all based on RF signals using the IEEE802.15.4 standard, particularly the ZigBee protocol. The RF to IR-RS232 receiver, shown in Fig. 2, is used for a lighting control system that employs IR and UART communication protocols. This receiver receives control signals from the URC via RF protocol and converts them to RS232 signals. The RS485 converter then transmits these RS232 signals to various locations for efficient home lighting control. 
Additionally, the RF to IR-Relay receiver, depicted in Figs. 3 and 4, can be connected to electronic appliances such as electric motorized screens, curtains, and windows. This receiver, connected to the URC, uses RF signals to control appliances with both AC and DC motors.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Organizations with a single-sourcing strategy entail system use that often is not aligned with their existing
business processes. This requires the organization to make more
extensive efforts on reengineering existing business processes,
adapting policies and other routine activities, and enforcing new
standards for system use [7]. Comparing to the single-sourcing

Journal Name:
Information Systems Sourcing Strategies and
Organizational Cybersecurity Breaches

Text: The combination of the hunter-prey optimization (HPO) algorithm and an ensemble learning process significantly enhances the detection accuracy of Android malware. By utilizing multiple classifiers, specifically the Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), kernel extreme learning machine (KELM), and Regularized random vector functional link neural network (RRVFLN), the model effectively identifies malicious patterns and behaviors in Android applications. The ensemble approach leverages the strengths of these diverse models to improve overall detection capabilities, making it more adept at recognizing complex malware variants that may evade traditional detection methods. Comprehensive experimental analyses demonstrate the superiority of this combined methodology, underscoring its effectiveness in addressing the challenges posed by evolving malware threats in the Android ecosystem.

We also investigated password diversity among respondents, specifically examining how many different passwords they employ across their online activities (banking, social media, e-commerce, etc.). The results revealed that nearly half of participants from the UAE region?9.7% to be precise?ndicated using only 3 to 4 distinct passwords for all their online accounts. This finding suggests limited password diversity among UAE internet users, potentially increasing their vulnerability to credential-based attacks, as a single compromised password could grant attackers access to multiple accounts. This practice contradicts cybersecurity best practices that recommend unique passwords for different services to contain potential security breaches.

In this protocol, a user must authenticate with an authentication server using a password to gain access to a USB port. Without successful authentication, the system denies access. Upon authentication, the user and server establish a shared key, which encrypts and decrypts files transmitted via the USB port. This ensures that both communication channels and stored files are secured with the negotiated key.For remote authentication, we implement Schnorr?s digital signature scheme (1989) [1], known for its efficiency. In this scheme, the parameters and are precomputed and stored, reducing computational costs by requiring only one modular multiplication and one modular addition during signing. Compared to other digital signature schemes, this method is cost-effective. The signature length in Schnorr?s scheme is and the hash function output is 160 bits, the total signature length is 320 bits (160 bits  160 bits).In contrast, the RSA cryptosystem [2] requires a 1024-bit signature (
|n|=1024 bits), and the ElGamal system [3] produces a 2048-bit signature (
2?|p|=2048 bits). Schnorr?s signature scheme offers a more compact signature, making it ideal for environments demanding high efficiency and convenience.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: As illustrated in Figure 7, during low-power detection mode, the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) functions as a comparator. It converts pixel image data into one-bit data by comparing the output voltages of the Active Pixel Sensors (APS) to a brightness control voltage. In contrast, the conventional detection mode employs a single-slope ADC in each column line for simplicity and low power consumption. This ADC includes a ramp signal generator, a latched comparator, and a counter. It uses the APS output voltage in conjunction with a ramp signal to produce 8-10 bit image data for each pixel.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

In this paper, the study devises a cybersecurity-efficient blockchain-enabled CPS Aware IIoHT system for medical applications.
The study considers the execution cost and blockchain cybersecurity as the constraints of the applications and objectives of the
study. The study only focused on a few cybersecurity issues, such
as known and unknown malware threats, where blockchain technology ensures safe data transactions between different hospitals
for patients. The study devised the cyber-physical-systems aware
cybersecurity scheme where both kinds of malware, such as
known and unknown, are detected in IIoHT for medical applications. The known attacks could be labeled based on supervised
learning and predicated before the application starts in the network. However, runtime cybernetics, such as passive and active
attacks, could occur at the runtime of applications that could not
be handled by supervised learning. The reinforcement learning [15] is widely exploited and handles the runtime attacks in the
system for the healthcare applications in the network.
Journal Name:
Blockchain-Enabled Cybersecurity Efficient IIOHT
Cyber-Physical System for Medical Applications

One of the most important functionalities of a phishing
kit is to save the stolen data [21], [22]. There are different approaches according to their complexity: (i) saving the
stolen credential into plain text, (ii) sending the stolen data to
a specific email each time a victim is deceived, (iii) phishing
kits that contain control panels and use databases to show the
stolen credentials to the phishers [20].

PhiKitA: Phishing Kit Attacks Dataset
for Phishing Websites Identification

Text: Another key consideration is that the problem size increases significantly when adding load flow equations and operating constraints for each post-contingency state. In prior research [4], a decomposition method was employed, where post-contingency states were solved separately from the pre-contingency state through an iterative process. This approach allows post-contingency problems to be computed simultaneously on different machines. Further research is necessary to explore how this method can be integrated with the PDIP algorithm.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: In Multi-Processor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) architectures based on Network-on-Chip (NoC), direct attacks on the communication subsystem are impractical due to the lack of physical network access. The presence of an NoC also prevents the possibility of sniffing (or snooping) information transmitted through the communication channel, provided the messages are not explicitly broadcast by the communication initiator. The only way to replicate such attacks in these systems is through direct read/write operations to the memory subsystem, as it stores the system's status.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text:
In this section, we will apply the stability results from Section II to design impulsive control for a class of nonlinear systems. We begin with a formal definition of impulsive control, slightly modified from [6], as follows:
**Definition 4:** Consider a plant \( P \) with state variable \( X \in \mathbb{R}^n \), a set of control instants \( T = \{\tau_k\} \), where \( \tau_k \in \mathbb{R}^+ \) and \( \tau_k < \tau_{k+1} \) for \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \), and control laws \( U(k, X) \in \mathbb{R}^n \) for \( k = 1, 2, \ldots \). At each \( \tau_k \), the state \( X \) is changed impulsively, i.e., \( X(\tau_k^+) = X(\tau_k) + U(k, X) \), ensuring the system remains stable and meets certain specifications.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: To decrypt broadcast content, the Ks information is continuously transmitted to the receiver in the form of an Entitlement Control Message (ECM-Kw) [5] along with the encrypted content. Before transmission, the ECM-Kw, which includes the Ks, is encrypted using a Kw that is typically updated on a monthly basis. The Kw itself is encrypted with the Km for each individual receiver and is also transmitted [6]. Figure 2 illustrates an ECM section comprising a fixed unit and a variable unit. The fixed unit carries fixed-length information, while part of the fixed unit and the entire variable unit are encrypted to protect the transmitted data. The Ks is stored within the fixed unit of the ECM-Kw.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: With the growing use and popularity of remote controllers, they are considered one of the greatest inventions of the 21st century due to their convenience and ease of use. Their application has rapidly expanded with digital technology, reaching consumer devices like car keys, air conditioners, and game controllers, alongside home appliances such as TVs, DVD players, and audio/video systems. Additionally, remote controllers now play a vital role in home automation, enabling control over lighting, temperature, door management, and security. In today's world, remote controllers are indispensable, as they provide seamless access to the various functions of modern appliances, making life more convenient and advanced.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: Another issue of importance is that the dimension of the problem becomes very large after adding loadflow equation and operating limit constraints for each post-contingency state. In previous work [4], a decomposition solution method was used in which post-contingency states were solved separately from the pre-contingency state in an iterative process. This would allow for computing the results of each post-contingency problem simultaneously on different machines. Further inves tigation is needed into studying how this technique could be applied to the PDIP algorithm.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text:
Abstract—In this letter, we propose a new asymmetric watermarking system which can accommodate many embedding watermarks but needs only one reference watermark for detection. Such
a system is useful in averting attacks that seek to estimate the embedding watermark. In the proposed system, the phase of the reference watermark is shifted randomly (clockwise or counterclockwise) in the discrete Fourier transform domain to make embedding
watermarks. They are correlated with one another and have the
same correlation with the reference one. We also address how to
select the design parameters.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Synchronization in our system requires precise matching of components—low-pass filters, gain, and nonlinear elements—between transmitter and receiver circuits. Despite digital elements, the transmitted signal remains analog, necessitating analog adjustments (e.g., amplifiers and DC offsets) to compensate for receiver ADC errors. These adjustments minimize the synchronization error signal. While theoretical synchronization produces identical waveforms, real-world mismatches and noise result in measurable synchronization errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: Research has explored collaboration between cybersecurity educational institutions and industry, yet most universities have not actively implemented such partnerships. Despite a global cybersecurity workforce shortage of 4 million in 2023, there is no concrete plan to bridge this gap. Additionally, surveys indicate that cybersecurity graduates may lack the specific skills required by the industry.

This study meticulously outlines the design processes and selection criteria for current wind power technologies tailored to Thailand's power system, utilizing existing power system data and recent wind resource assessments. It thoroughly evaluates the integration level of wind power generation into the system, along with the sizing procedures for wind turbines, specifically for Thailand, which is characterized as a low-to-medium wind speed region.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: The growing sophistication of cybersecurity threats?ncluding malware attacks, denial of service, phishing campaigns, data breaches, and SQL injections?oses particularly severe risks to Industrial Internet of Healthcare Things (IIoHT) systems, where compromised medical applications can directly impact patient safety and care quality. Unlike conventional IT systems, IIoHT architectures demand multi-layered protection where software must remain malware-free, wireless communications require virus-proofing, and servers need continuous monitoring against suspicious activity. While known network attacks can be mitigated through standard protocols, the greater danger lies in undetected threats operating across different layers of IIoHT infrastructure [8-11]. To address these challenges, cyber-physical systems (CPS) have emerged as critical defense mechanisms, employing autonomous, self-adaptive machine learning algorithms in fog-cloud environments that continuously evolve to detect and respond to dynamic threat landscapes in medical IoT ecosystems.

In the emerging DM, timeliness of information is
important for lean production, as well as quality and
productivity assurance. Digitization creates communication channels across vendors and OEMs, on the one
hand, and between the various machines and processes
inside an MSE, on the other hand. DM requires the
integration of cyber (computing and communications)
resources with the physical resources in the manufacturing process and supply chain. Continuous streaming of
data from sensors at various locations in the manufacturing plant (e.g., individual machines and the network
of machines) informs the data-driven decision-making
that guides design modifications, calibrates manufacturing
methods, and programs the robot tasks and paths that
they navigate the manufacturing floor. Securing such a
distributed and connected cyber?physical system against
cyberattacks requires developing novel approaches that
are tailored to the threats faced by such systems. The
cyberattacks can range from sabotage of product quality and intellectual property theft to ransomware. The
attack surface, threat vectors, and solutions need to
be analyzed to enable a secure, resilient, and scalable
next-generation DM.
Journal Name:
A Survey of Cybersecurity of
Digital Manufacturing

Text: The proposed method involves creating a Market Monitoring Body (MMB) as an independent entity that proactively assesses market competitiveness and calculates Market Clearing Factors (MCFs) for market players. The MCFs set boundaries to prevent market power abuses while addressing system reliability and security concerns. This approach ensures that market operations are fair and secure.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text:
This article therefore aims to understand the factors that influence the cyber-preparedness of SEs in the U.K. In achieving this
goal, the article systematically unpacks the factors that support
and hinder the preparedness of SEs to deal with cybercrime. The
rest of this article is structured as follows. First, a review of the
cybercrime literature is presented before the key issues and the
characteristics of SEs are formulated as a conceptual framework
and research questions. Following this the methods of the study
are detailed and the findings of the analyses are presented. This
article closes with statements of contributions and suggestions
for future research.
Journal Name:
Antecedents of Cybersecurity Implementation:
A Study of the Cyber-Preparedness
of U.K. Social Enterprises

Text: Impulsive control systems have numerous real-world applications. Three prominent examples include an insect population control system where state variables represent the number of insects and their natural predators, a chemical reactor system in which state variables denote the concentrations of different chemicals, and a financial model that considers market money supply and central bank savings rates as state variables [1]. Additional practical applications can be found in [2] and [3].
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: If the control word (CW) is transmitted back to the STB without encryption, an attacker could intercept the communication between the smart card and STB and redirect the CW to another compatible descrambler, allowing them to view the program without authorization. This is a security vulnerability. Even if the CW is encrypted, the security of the session key (SK) is crucial. However, many existing systems use a fixed SK, which makes them vulnerable to known plain-text attacks. Furthermore, the absence of mutual authentication allows pirates to clone smart cards or redirect communication from legitimate cards and STBs to unauthorized devices, resulting in significant financial losses for service providers. Therefore, dynamic SKs and mutual authentication between STBs and smart cards are necessary.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: This article investigates the effects of different information systems sourcing strategies on cybersecurity breaches within organizations. Through a longitudinal analysis, it reveals that a best of breed (BoB) strategy tends to result in fewer cybersecurity incidents compared to single sourcing, especially when the organization has a limited range of IT applications; however, this difference diminishes as the variety of IT applications increases. Insourcing is associated with a lower risk of breaches than any outsourcing strategy, including single sourcing and BoB, but this advantage is most pronounced when the IT application spread is minimal. The study finds that a best of suite (BoS) strategy does not significantly differ from BoB in terms of breach likelihood. For organizations with a broader array of IT applications, no significant differences emerge among the various sourcing strategies regarding cybersecurity breaches. The findings offer valuable theoretical and practical insights for managing cybersecurity in information systems development and interorganizational relationships.

Mouheb et al. (2019) conducted a survey examining cybersecurity curriculum design efforts. Their study categorized university approaches based on three main focuses: educational, industrial, and defense. Each institution tailored its curriculum development strategies according to internal priorities, making some methods potentially unsuitable for adoption by other universities.

The microprocessor used in this system is 8-bit PSoC 
(Programmable System on Chip) device. There are three 
reasons to use this device. Firstly, it makes the design easier

capacitive sensor keyboard in the system
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: As illustrated in Figure 3, the frequency initially drops due to increasing load, but subsequently returns to zero. The observed overshoot occurs because generators G1, G4, and G5 collectively work to eliminate the frequency deviation by increasing their power output. Each participates in primary control, while G1 and G4, being under AGC, also contribute to supplementary control. The second plot in Figure 3 displays power outputs in Control Area 1 (with Control Area 2 showing similar patterns). After the transient period, generators G2 and G3 produce power exactly matching their bilateral load variations, while G1 shows only slight initial variation before quickly returning to zero.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: We have successfully developed a novel RNG that leverages the large fluctuating current of a MOS structure after soft breakdown. This RNG is a compact circuit composed of approximately 20 logic gates and several passive elements. The generated random numbers have undergone rigorous testing, confirming their high quality and strong resemblance to true randomness. Therefore, this RNG presents a promising solution for cryptographic security in mobile network applications.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: In time-frequency analysis, like the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT), a signal is divided into short, overlapping time windows. For each window, the frequency composition is determined, often visualized as a magnitude spectrum showing the energy distribution across different frequencies. STFT-derived features are widely used due to their computational efficiency, leveraging the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm. Specifically, the following features are calculated from the magnitude component of the STFT.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: Cybersecurity intrusions in power systems are not just theoretical concerns but real-world threats. A study by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) [7] on cyber vulnerabilities in control systems highlights numerous incidents that have caused damage to electric power control systems across transmission, distribution, and generation sectors. While research on cybersecurity needs and requirements for power utilities and protection systems has been extensively discussed [5]?18], there is limited literature presenting concrete findings in this area. Threats and countermeasures, including system configuration, security protocols, and cryptographic techniques, are explored in [8] and [9]. Although a dedicated network is ideal for ensuring data confidentiality and integrity, it remains vulnerable to internal attacks.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: Organizational ambidexterity relies on the simultaneous completion of exploration and exploitation activities, enabling organizations to leverage their existing competencies while seeking new opportunities. In the context of ambidextrous cybersecurity, this dual focus translates into two primary goals: protecting data, systems, and networks while fostering the rapid introduction of new technologies. Achieving this balance requires a strategic approach that integrates robust security measures with innovative practices. Organizations must create structures that support both exploratory initiatives?uch as adopting cutting-edge cybersecurity technologies?nd exploitative efforts that refine and enhance existing security protocols. By cultivating a culture that embraces both risk-taking and efficiency, organizations can effectively navigate the complexities of the cybersecurity landscape, ensuring they remain resilient against evolving threats while capitalizing on new technological advancements.

Text: Over the past decade, chaos-based secure communication systems have evolved into their fourth generation [2]?[6], [8], [9], [18]. The first three generations utilize continuous synchronization, while the fourth generation employs impulsive synchronization. In the fourth generation, a third-order chaotic transmitter requires less than 94 Hz of bandwidth to transmit the synchronization signal, compared to the 30 kHz bandwidth needed in the previous generations [18]. This significantly enhances bandwidth efficiency. However, attacks demonstrated in [10], [11] have revealed that many of these methods either lack security or offer low protection. Therefore, enhancing the security of chaotic secure communication remains a critical objective.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: The cybernet environment of a control center, illustrated in Fig. 1, shows the connectivity of corporate networks typically protected by firewalls. The control center network is linked to other corporate networks, as well as substation and power plant networks managed by IT personnel. While control center networks are highly secure and difficult to penetrate directly, this research focuses on intrusions that occur through other networks, such as those at substations or power plants.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: The Internet of Things (IoT), a nascent technological paradigm, has fundamentally transformed the interconnected global ecosystem, encompassing individuals, intelligent devices, smart objects, and data repositories, despite its transformative potential, the IoT domain remains in its developmental stages, necessitating the resolution of numerous inherent challenges, the foundational concept of IoT, which entails the pervasive integration of diverse entities, presents a significant opportunity to elevate global standards of accessibility, integrity, availability, scalability, confidentiality, and interoperability, however, ensuring the security of IoT systems constitutes a formidable undertaking, as system security serves as the bedrock for IoT's progressive advancement, this discourse presents a systematic overview of IoT cybersecurity, with a particular emphasis on the protection and seamless integration of heterogeneous smart devices and information communication technologies (ICT), this review aims to furnish researchers and practitioners with pertinent information and insights into IoT cybersecurity, encompassing current research trends, architectural frameworks, taxonomic classifications, key countermeasures and strategic approaches, major industrial applications, and prevailing research challenges.

During the next few decades, electronic controllers, micro-electromechanical systems or MEMS, and nano scale electro-chemical sensors and actuators will play an important role in emissions treatmentVenabling the electro-chemical systems needed to drive down the percentage of hydrocarbons, oxides of carbon & nitrogen from tailpipe emissions. Today these electronic control lers, sensors, and actuators are used in the multistage treatment of exhaust gases as they travel from the internal combustion engine to the tailpipe to ensure that hydro carbons and oxides of nitrogen are trapped and reduced to clean tailpipe emissions.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: The study employed an independent sample t-test to analyze cybersecurity awareness differences between UAE and USA respondents. Data met all parametric assumptions: no outliers (confirmed via boxplot inspection), normal distribution (Shapiro-Wilk test, p > .05), and homogeneity of variances (Levene? test, p = .164). Demographic controls were replicated across both regions using Mechanical Turk to ensure comparable sample compositions. Results revealed statistically significant differences in cybersecurity awareness between the populations. For instance, comparisons between male subgroups (UAE: n = 42; USA: n = 40) demonstrated consistent regional disparities, controlling for gender bias. Descriptive statistics, including means and standard deviations, are detailed in Table 2, reinforcing the observed variations in awareness levels.

Text: We conducted numerical simulations using the standard rate equations model for two lasers—one serving as an emitter and the other as a receiver—coupled unidirectionally. The equations describe the slowly varying amplitude of the electric field, denoted as E(t), and the carrier number, N(t). These simulations assume that the system operates in a single-mode state with low to moderate feedback strengths.
