Text: In this paper, we explore low-power motion detection through partial modifications to conventional image sensor chips. Our computer simulations demonstrate that only a few thousand image data points are sufficient to achieve comparable motion detection accuracy using standard CMOS image sensors. This system achieves low power consumption by utilizing only a small percentage of total pixels and just one bit per selected pixel. Additionally, the unused blocks of the CIS are placed in standby mode to save power. This architecture is being designed using 0.35µm standard CMOS technology (1-P, 4-M) with pixel arrays of 128×96.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: The proposed hard partitioning process simplifies the complex Contribution Factor (CF) spaces into an ITDA (Impact, Tolerance, Desirability, and Acceptability) space with three discrete scales: 1, 0, and -1. These scales represent "desirable," "less determinative," and "undesirable" impacts on various constraints, as summarized in Table III. This approach allows for easy classification of individual DR characteristics in the context of congestion management.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: The strategic behavior of power suppliers in the market at any given time is influenced by factors such as demand elasticity, residual demand, transmission reliability, generation reliability, fuel costs, and market clearing prices, all of which are random variables. Rational market participants follow energy market rules to mitigate price volatility and profit loss risks. For instance, they often bid within a 10% tolerance of the previous period's clearing price to remain competitive. Research is ongoing to mathematically model these strategic bidding practices.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text:
IoT and CPS devices are equipped with
a wide range of sensors to monitor and support the systems.
These sensors are vulnerable enough to be attacked by adversaries to cause security and safety threats. Even major sensors,
such as global positioning system (GPS) signal, light detection
and ranging (LiDAR) signal, inertial measurement unit (IMU)
data, and so on can be compromised, which cause serious
threats to the devices.
Journal Name:
Recent Advances on Federated Learning for
Cybersecurity and Cybersecurity for Federated
Learning for Internet of Things

Text: We present a biometric cryptosystem that provides security and renewability for function-based online signature representations. We also introduce a method for selecting the most reliable signature characteristics. Our protected system delivers performance comparable to unprotected systems and substantially better than protection methods that rely on parametric signature features.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: The Aircraft Communications, Addressing, and Reporting System (ACARS) is a character-based data link described in ARINC standard 618, facilitating communication between aircraft and operators via service providers. Utilizing the ASCII character set, ACARS operates similarly to Short Message Service (SMS), delivering various data services such as weather updates, flight plans, and aircraft performance information. The system employs three types of data links depending on coverage needs: VHF for populated areas, SATCOM for oceanic regions, and HF for global reach. ACARS messages are categorized into three types: Air Traffic Control (ATC), Aeronautical Operational Control (AOC), and Airline Administrative Control (AAC), each serving specific communication needs between the aircraft and ground stations. The message content adheres to the ARINC 620-8 standard, ensuring structured communication that enhances operational efficiency and safety in aviation.

In this study, one of the core goals was, therefore, to suggest how to change the behavior of participants, moving them
toward actions that enhance cybersecurity. In the cybersecurity
space, improving awareness of the principles of information
assurance and moderating behaviors is often more important
than presenting an overwhelming amount of information that
is not put into practice. Beyond that, getting practitioners to
habituate affirmative behaviors using best practice methods is
clearly beneficial. Furthermore, as actual preventative steps
change quickly, care must be taken to produce learning materials that are actionable, but that have a reasonable period of
applicability before obsolescence
Journal Name:
A Study of Cybersecurity Education Using a
Present-Test-Practice-Assess Model

Text: Cybersecurity, fundamentally, is concerned with the assurance of data and system confidentiality, integrity, and availability [23]. This objective is pursued through the implementation of controls, policies, processes, and organizational structures designed to systematically mitigate cyber risks. The ongoing nature of cybersecurity challenges is recognized, with the application of best practices, facilitated by standards [24], being a critical component. These standards, functioning as regulatory documents, define operational and process guidelines for organizations. The adoption of security standards is predicated on their demonstrated efficacy in providing structured security requirements and controls, thereby yielding a multitude of benefits that justify resource allocation. The utilization of these standards by manufacturers and vendors for the production and sale of compliant products and services is observed. Furthermore, governmental and business entities increasingly mandate the implementation of security standards. According to data provided by Gartner, Inc. [25], organizational security vendor consolidation has seen a significant increase, with 75% of organizations actively pursuing this in 2022, up from 29% in 2020. The necessity for secure integration and compatibility of ICT systems, achieved through technical standards, is increasingly apparent, particularly in open market environments where interoperability of diverse equipment and services from multiple providers is required, resulting in organizational cost efficiencies. The proliferation of IoT devices, cyber-physical systems, and algorithm-controlled embedded systems, such as autonomous vehicles and digital twins [10], further necessitates standardization. Cloud computing, dependent on hardware, software, and service standardization for interoperability [26], faces evolving cybersecurity threats as its scope expands. Consequently, there is an increase in organizational participation in cybersecurity standard development, leading to a corresponding increase in the number of standards, with the expectation that this trend will continue, necessitating further standard development in the future.
Journal Name: Gemini

Text: In the proposed system, refreshing a new group key requires only a few encryption/decryption operations, primarily multiplication and addition, which have a low computational load. Each subscriber receives a head group key (HRGK) from the transport stream. Using the HRGK and their secret keys, they can derive the corresponding group keys and authorization keys. When a member joins or leaves a group, the system broadcasts a package with the new secret group key. To enhance security, the authorization key (AK) should be refreshed daily. Since changing the HRGK refreshes all AKs, the system broadcasts a single package containing the new HRGK to all users, significantly reducing the daily computational overhead.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: Current security systems typically rely on tokens of private knowledge, such as passwords, or private possessions like smart cards for automatic identification. However, these tokens are insecure as they can be easily lost, shared, stolen, or duplicated. In contrast, biometric authentication methods, which use physiological and behavioral traits like iris scans, retinal scans, fingerprints, palmprints, signatures, or gait analysis, offer enhanced security. Nonetheless, biometric systems are not foolproof and remain vulnerable to threats such as database breaches, replay attacks, and brute force attacks.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: Estimating the global state of a networked system is a critical problem in various domains, and traditional periodic observation methods are often inefficient due to high-frequency state monitoring. This has led to the development of event-based methods, which observe states only when predefined conditions are met. This paper explores the application of the event-based method to estimate cybersecurity equilibrium in preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics, an area where equilibrium is a key metric but lacks closed-form solutions. The study establishes that the proposed trigger rule ensures convergence to the true equilibrium and is Zeno-free, making it practical for real-world use. Numerical results indicate that this approach reduces observation costs by 98% compared to periodic methods. Additionally, the paper addresses the challenge of bridging continuous probability-state models, which estimate the likelihood of a node being secure or compromised, with discrete sample-state observations encountered in practice. This bridging mechanism is valuable as probability-state models are widely used to approximate complex discrete-state systems.

Over the past decade, the chaos-based secure communications have updated their fourth generation [2]–[6], [8], [9], [18].
The continuous synchronization is adopted in the first three
generations while the impulsive synchronization is used in the
fourth generation. Less than 94 Hz of bandwidth is needed to
transmit the synchronization signal for a third-order chaotic
transmitter in the fourth generation while 30-kHz bandwidth
needed for transmitting the synchronization signals in the
other three generations [18]. Therefore, the efficiency of the
bandwidth usage is improved greatly in the fourth generation.
However, the attacks proposed in [10], [11] have shown that
most of these methods are not secure or have a low security.
It is thus desirable to improve the security of chaotic secure
communication.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: To ensure the presented analysis is comprehensive, multiple reports and articles on cybersecurity education were reviewed. The proposed PESTLE analysis serves as a summary of the current state of research in this domain. This section specifically examines studies that have employed a PESTLE analysis approach to explore cybersecurity education. For a more in-depth review of cybersecurity education-related literature, refer to Sections III and IV.

The primary objective of this research was identifying approaches to "do better" in cybersecurity education. Students demonstrating motivation and understanding of material relevance learn more effectively. The researchers propose enhancing traditional present-memorize-test educational models by incorporating incremental knowledge segments situated within realistic contexts through gamification, fostering emotional and cognitive investment from learners. For organizations across commercial, civil, and governmental sectors?egardless of size or complexity?rograms that effectively communicate and experientially simulate actual cybersecurity threats will enhance participant engagement while improving knowledge retention and practical implementation. Notably, this study advocates for a PTPA (Protect-Trace-Predict-Act) approach to develop responsive professionals who can apply their knowledge at critical moments. Current cybersecurity education often fails to help users, technologists, and managers connect specific behaviors with their negative consequences. Many users who experience system infections typically lack understanding of both the infection source and the decisions that led to compromise; they simply recognize something has malfunctioned. This inadequate feedback mechanism has created widespread cynicism, fostering casual or fatalistic attitudes toward cybersecurity. While users often possess theoretical knowledge, the abstract, distant, yet omnipresent nature of threats explains why people frequently fail to translate their knowledge into appropriate actions. This manuscript sought to articulate a pedagogical methodology utilizing mixed-modal approaches and conduct empirical testing to identify which modalities contribute most effectively to cybersecurity behavioral changes.

In a deregulated market, utilities are less inclined to invest in new infrastructure and more likely to operate transmission systems closer to their limits to capitalize on lower energy costs and reduced production expenses. Special Protection Systems (SPS) have been introduced to enable operations near or even beyond traditional deterministic limits while maximizing market benefits. Given this scenario, the probabilistic nature of uncertain variables and the potential for severe contingencies that could threaten system security and trigger cascading failures must be carefully considered in the design of SPS to manage extreme conditions effectively.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: The demand for cybersecurity professionals in Europe is rising sharply due to increasing digitization and a growing array of potential cyber attack targets. Despite this urgent need, there remains a significant shortfall in qualified experts, with estimates indicating a gap of around 274,000 to nearly 1 million professionals needed across the continent. This discrepancy arises from a mismatch between the skills imparted through educational programs and those required in the workforce. A recent PESTLE analysis highlighted several factors affecting cybersecurity education, including a lack of societal awareness and insufficient EU-level certification, suggesting that localized solutions are necessary to address these challenges. Additionally, a Eurobarometer survey revealed that 76% of cybersecurity employees lack formal qualifications, further exacerbating the skills gap. The findings underscore the critical need for immediate action to enhance cybersecurity training and awareness at both national and European levels, as well as to promote diversity within the workforce to better meet the demands of an evolving digital landscape.

The development of generative models traces its origins to mid-20th century statistical approaches like Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs), with transformative advances emerging through deep learning breakthroughs that enabled sophisticated sequence generation via N-gram language modeling and later revolutionary architectures like Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and transformer-based systems?articularly as implemented in OpenAI's progressively scaled GPT series (illustrated in Figure 2)?hich now power cutting-edge text-generation tools like ChatGPT that represent the focused application of this evolutionary trajectory in large language models (LLMs) for conversational AI, while acknowledging the broader generative capabilities spanning multimedia domains that fall beyond this paper's specific cybersecurity-focused examination of text-based chatbot technologies and their vulnerabilities.

Our analysis highlights the uneven adoption of information security personnel within healthcare organizations. Many organizations have developed systems for collecting and storing patient data but lack corresponding security committees, teams, or security managers/officers. Approximately half of hospital-based respondents had an information security individual, which is significantly higher than in clinic (37%) and other (42%) practice settings. Hospitals were twice as likely to have adopted an information security officer compared to outpatient settings.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: In scenarios of extreme severity, cybersecurity breaches may facilitate unauthorized control of transformer switching operations, resulting in catastrophic localized impacts and potential protracted supply disruptions. Even incidents of lesser severity, such as the transmission of falsified instrument readings, could precipitate the unnecessary offline transition of operational equipment, thereby inducing supply constraints or blackouts due to erroneous operational decisions.

At the initial stage of Android malware detection, data preprocessing is essential to enhance the quality of the actual data. This involves selecting features that signify the class of new records, such as distinguishing between malware and benign applications. A tool like Androguard can be utilized to reverse engineer Android applications by analyzing APK files and removing DEX file permissions, resulting in a data frame where rows represent applications and columns denote specific permissions or API calls with binary values. This structured approach enables effective classification of APK files as either malware or benign. Current methodologies emphasize the importance of employing advanced techniques, including deep learning models like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, which have shown promising results in accurately detecting malware through meticulous hyperparameter tuning and robust data preprocessing techniques. By leveraging both static and dynamic features, researchers aim to create comprehensive classification frameworks that improve detection accuracy and enhance overall cybersecurity measures for Android platforms.

It is worth noting that the use of protected transactions is also included in the specifications defined by the Open Core Protocol International Partnership (OCP-IP) Associa tion [34]. The standard OCP interface can be extended through a layered profile in order to create a secure domain across the SoC and provide protection against software and some selective hardware attacks. The secure domain might include CPU, memory, I/O, etc., that need to be secured by using a collection of hardware and software features such as secured interrupts, secured memory, or special instruc tions to access the secure mode of the processor.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: Recent years have witnessed growing interest among cybersecurity researchers in leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enhance cyber defense mechanisms. Paradoxically, malicious actors have simultaneously adopted AI techniques to orchestrate more sophisticated attacks and obscure their activities. This paper specifically examines the defensive applications of AI in cybersecurity, focusing on how AI-powered solutions can more effectively counteract threats and substantially reduce ?or potentially eliminate ?data breaches. The research emphasizes AI's capacity to strengthen protective measures rather than exploring its offensive misuse by adversaries, highlighting its potential to revolutionize cybersecurity practices through advanced threat detection and prevention capabilities.

The attainment of comprehensive cyber capabilities within military frameworks is contingent upon the implementation of robust cybersecurity training protocols, recognizing this imperative, military entities have endeavored to establish bespoke cybersecurity training systems, notably cyber ranges, among which SIMTEX (Simulator Training Exercise Network) represents an early exemplar, initially conceived for the training objectives of the United States Air Force, SIMTEX subsequently evolved into the operational platform for prominent US military cybersecurity exercises, including Black Daemon and Cyber Flag, the system provided virtualized host environments, simulating information assets susceptible to cyberattacks, and facilitated VPN tunneling to segregate attack flows across geographically dispersed sites during exercises.

The generalization capabilities inherent in artificial intelligence have facilitated the displacement of traditional rule-based methodologies in favor of more sophisticated technological solutions [17]. However, the dynamic evolution of the digital landscape is not solely characterized by technological advancement; it also encompasses a corresponding augmentation in the sophistication of cyber threat actors. Historically, the cyber domain has been subject to high-volume, yet relatively unsophisticated, intrusion attempts. Nevertheless, the advent of AI-assisted attacks, orchestrated by cyber offenders, has ushered in a novel era, marked by both known and previously unknown transformations in cyberattack vectors [17]. The application of AI and machine learning has amplified the efficacy of cyberattacks, thereby empowering cyber offenders to an unprecedented degree. Consequently, as evidenced by a series of recent, high-profile incidents, Generative AI has garnered substantial interest within the cybersecurity community, spanning both cyber defense and offensive strategies.

The Internet of Things (IoT) represents a transformative shift in global connectivity, integrating people, smart devices, and data into a cohesive network. Despite its potential to enhance accessibility, integrity, and interoperability, the development of IoT is still nascent, with numerous security challenges that need addressing. As IoT continues to grow?rojected to encompass over 75 billion connected devices by 2025?he complexity of securing these devices increases significantly. Cybersecurity within IoT focuses on protecting a diverse array of interconnected devices, each presenting unique vulnerabilities due to their varied hardware and software configurations. Effective strategies include implementing robust encryption, strong authentication methods, and regular software updates to safeguard against unauthorized access and data breaches. However, many IoT devices are designed with limited processing power, making it difficult to deploy advanced security measures. This review highlights the current landscape of IoT cybersecurity, exploring key concepts such as cybersecurity architecture and taxonomy, enabling countermeasures, and emerging research trends. It aims to provide valuable insights for researchers and practitioners dedicated to enhancing the security of IoT systems amidst the evolving threat landscape.

This research examines whether current power factor control regulations adequately manage wind farm operations for system security. Section IV specifically analyzes how different wind farm penetration levels affect the power system, focusing on steady-state voltage profiles, voltage ride-through capabilities, and overall system stability following disturbances. The analysis evaluates various scenarios resulting from different control strategies implemented in induction generator-based wind farms.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: While cybersecurity ethics may appear straightforward, the subject is more complex than it seems. This paper presents findings from an extensive study that explores both well-recognized and emerging ethical challenges in cybersecurity. It first addresses "strong signals," which represent mainstream concerns, and then delves into "weak signals"?ess-discussed but potentially significant issues shaping the future of cybersecurity ethics. Additionally, the study compares its findings with those of a similar research effort conducted two years prior to assess whether previously anticipated ethical dilemmas have materialized.

Power system communication is structured in two tiers: the device level, where protocols like DL/T645-1997 or industrial standards like MODBUS are used depending on the specific meter or device, and the system level, which employs broader international and national standards such as IEC 60870-5-101 or utility-specific protocols for remote data exchange and load management.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: This circuit can be constructed using about 20 CMOS gates and several passive devices. The supply voltage for the astable multivibrator was 5 V, the clock frequency for the 1-bit counter was 16 MHz, and the bit rate for the output random numbers was 50 kb/s. All measurements were performed at room tem perature. Because this RNG is constructed using discrete com ponents, the supply voltage is higher than in the case of a mobile application. If the appropriate technology is used for the fabri cation process, the supply voltage for our circuit can easily be reduced to 1.5 V or lower voltage. It should also be noted that our random number generation method can be used with other randomly fluctuating signals instead of MOS-SBD signals if the f luctuating signals are large enough.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: The questionnaire comprised fourteen 7-point Likert-scale questions and demonstrated a high level of internal consistency, as indicated by a Cronbach? alpha of 0.794. Enhancing future reliability could involve translating the questionnaire into local languages instead of relying on interpreters, improving item clarity, minimizing redundancy, and adding relevant items aligned with the measured construct. These refinements could further strengthen internal consistency. The t-test results (Table 3) show that items 1, 3, and 4 were statistically insignificant, while items 2 and 5 through 14 were statistically significant.

The Conditional Access System (CAS) operates within a three-level hierarchy for key distribution. The process begins with the server generating a random Control Word (CW) as the seed for a pseudo-random generator (PRG). The PRG produces a sequence used to scramble the Transport Stream (TS). Simultaneously, the CW is encrypted with an Authorization Key (AK) to form the Entitlement Control Message (ECM). The AK and other entitlement information are then encrypted with a Master Private Key (MPK) to create the Entitlement Management Message (EMM). The ECM, EMM, and scrambled TS are multiplexed into a new TS stream and transmitted to subscribers via the broadcasting channel. To prevent tampering, the ECM and EMM are sent with digital signatures. The Subscribers Management System (SMS) manages customer access rights to protected services by generating or updating the MPK for authorized subscribers stored in smartcards. To enhance security, the CAS can frequently change CWs or use more complex symmetric encryption algorithms. Typically, CWs are updated every 5 to 20 seconds, significantly reducing the risk of known-plaintext attacks.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a user, device, or entity within a computer system. It is often a necessary step before gaining access to system resources. Identity verification is typically achieved by matching an indicator, such as a shared secret established when a person is granted authorization. The most common form of user authentication today is the password. An example of machine-to-machine authentication is the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text:
The overall goal of this research was to determine ways
to ?do better.? Motivated students who understand the importance and applicability of the materials presented to them learn
better. To this end, the researchers suggest that augmenting
the traditional learning approach to a present-memorize-test
model. Moreover, this study introduced how incremental

participants and aid knowledge retention and implementation.

Journal Name:
A Study of Cybersecurity Education Using a

Text: This research implements the proposed watermarking scheme for audio data in the time domain, using a 44.1 kHz, 16-bit jazz music clip for testing. Four independent random noise signals, shaped to match the audio's magnitude spectrum in the DFT domain for inaudibility, serve as reference watermarks. Private keys, consisting of 1000 m-sequences of length 1023, are used in the process. The audio is divided into frames, each embedding a watermark scaled for inaudibility. To enhance robustness, the same watermark is embedded across 32 consecutive frames. The watermarked audio is then subjected to 96-kb/s MP3 compression/decompression to simulate a common attack scenario.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: This paper introduces an event-based method for estimating cybersecurity equilibrium in preventive and reactive cyber defense dynamics, addressing inefficiencies in periodic observation methods that require high-frequency monitoring. The event-based approach triggers observations only when specific conditions are met, reducing observation costs by up to 98% while ensuring convergence to the actual equilibrium and avoiding Zeno behavior. To bridge the gap between continuous probability-state models (measuring the likelihood of nodes being secure or compromised) and discrete sample-state models (derived from real nodes), the study provides a framework that enhances practical applicability. This method offers a more efficient and scalable solution for monitoring cybersecurity dynamics, with potential applications in real-time threat response systems.

A particularly interesting scenario was observed during the December 22 event, highlighting that system frequency is not uniform across the grid during disturbances. Operational data, as shown in Fig. 5, revealed that only some LaaRs—those with faster breakers and located closer to the fault—tripped when the frequency reached 59.7 Hz, effectively halting the frequency decline. Other LaaRs with slower breakers and farther from the fault did not trip. To restore the frequency to the nominal 60 Hz, operators manually dispatched these LaaRs to trip within 10 minutes. Fig. 5 serves as a clear example demonstrating that system frequency is not universally consistent during disturbances.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: Practical experience highlights the importance of pumped storage units in providing FRR for isolated power systems, especially during emergencies with severe FRR shortages. Pumped storage units are ideal for FRR, as they can operate in generating mode with AGC to provide frequency regulation reserve or in pumping mode to offer emergency reserve. Comparative energy benefit analyses show that Mode C is suitable for light load conditions (e.g., spring and winter) to reduce pumping energy costs and provide emergency reserve, while Mode D is better for heavy load conditions (e.g., summer and autumn) to offer frequency regulation reserve. The operational experiences shared in this paper demonstrate the value of pumped storage units in enhancing system security and their role in the ancillary services market. After extensive verification, the Power Company’s system operation department confirmed the advantages of flexible dispatching schedules for pumped storage units, noting improvements in power quality, system security, and the overall value of pumped storage units for FRR in daily operations.
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: One of the primary challenges in contemporary cybersecurity is the overwhelming volume of data present in various datasets, which necessitates the use of intelligent algorithms, particularly machine learning, to extract meaningful insights. In the context of intrusion detection systems (IDS), the reliance on a high number of features is crucial for identifying the best approaches to detect potential attacks. However, this abundance of characteristics can lead to model overfitting, where a model performs exceptionally well on training data but fails to generalize effectively to validation datasets, resulting in poor performance. This issue underscores the importance of selecting the most relevant features from cybersecurity datasets to enhance the accuracy and reliability of intrusion detection models. Recent advancements in dataset development, such as the BCCC-CSE-CIC-IDS2018 dataset, which includes 46 million labeled records and 300 features, aim to address these challenges by improving data quality and ensuring that models can effectively identify evolving cyber threats. The focus on feature selection and optimization is critical not only for enhancing detection capabilities but also for reducing the computational load on systems tasked with real-time monitoring and response.

Real-time user notification of alarm incidents is now essential for home security systems. This can be achieved through internet or GSM/GPRS communication. GSM/GPRS offers distinct advantages due to its widespread coverage, ensuring near-constant system availability, and its robust security infrastructure, protecting transmitted information from unauthorized monitoring [8]. While many existing systems ([3], [5], [6], [7]) rely on internet connectivity for remote user alerts, GSM/GPRS is increasingly favored. Examples of home systems using GSM/GPRS for remote control exist ([8], [9]), but they have limitations. Reference [8] simply mentions GSM as a communication method between remote users and a home network server, without implementing it in a comprehensive home security system. Reference [9] utilizes GSM/GPRS solely for intrusion detection and employs a non-wireless communication setup.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: The generalization power of AI has successfully transitioned traditional rule-based approaches to more sophisticated technologies, yet the evolving digital landscape has also escalated the sophistication of cyber threat actors. Historically, cyberspace experienced high volumes of relatively unsophisticated intrusion attempts; however, the emergence of AI-aided attacks has marked a new era, introducing both known and unknown transformations in cyberattack vectors. Cybercriminals are increasingly leveraging generative AI (GenAI) to enhance the effectiveness of their attacks, making them more potent than ever. Recent reports indicate that generative AI is being utilized to create self-evolving malware and craft convincing phishing emails, significantly increasing the volume and complexity of cyberattacks. This shift has garnered considerable attention from the cybersecurity community, as GenAI not only poses new challenges but also offers opportunities for improving defensive measures against these advanced threats. As organizations adapt to this changing landscape, the dual role of GenAI in both facilitating and combating cybercrime underscores the need for proactive strategies to mitigate its risks while harnessing its potential for enhancing cybersecurity efforts.

Security systems include closed-circuit television 
cameras, which constitute ever-present, hidden eyes in 
places such as the city centers, underground and railway 
stations, banks and hospitals, critical production plants 
which continuously record and transmit, in microseconds, 
information on current developments to continuously 
manned law enforcement and security posts. Some systems 
refuse access to a room or a building because the fingerprint 
of the person trying to enter is not included in the database 
of fingerprints of authorized persons.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: MITRE developed a cyber exercise playbook in 2014, serving as a guide for cyberspace operations by providing guidance, exercises, and a red team cyber sample event workbook for conducting cyber exercises. Earlier, in 2012, they published a cyber defense playbook that focused on active defense strategies designed to leverage the cyber-attack kill chain.

Modern cloud infrastructure operates on a three-layer architecture, each layer susceptible to vulnerabilities introduced by programmers or service providers. The fragmented nature of data handling complicates the tracking of cybercrimes such as cybertheft and fraud, while distributed computing erases geographical boundaries, allowing cyberattacks to originate from anywhere in the world. As organizations face increasingly sophisticated threats, there is a growing need to integrate Artificial Intelligence (AI) and intelligent agents to enhance cybersecurity defenses.

The proposed vulnerability assessment method operates at three levels: system, scenarios, and access points. The simulation process is outlined in the flowchart in Figure 3. The method is implemented using Visual Basic.NET, with interactions between SPNP and MATLAB. An XML file containing simulation models is used to automatically generate an intermediate file called C-Based SPNP Language (CSPL). This process involves an algorithm that builds a cyber-network topology based on network definitions, which include password and firewall models.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: Reinforcement learning (RL) is distinguished from other learning paradigms by its inherent exploration-exploitation trade-off, a characteristic that dictates the agent's behavior in maximizing cumulative rewards through environmental interactions; specifically, the agent must leverage existing knowledge derived from prior interactions and associated rewards to exploit known advantageous actions, while simultaneously engaging in exploratory actions to discover potentially superior strategies for future reward maximization, thus encapsulating the fundamental exploration-exploitation dilemma that governs RL decision-making.

Since the advent of blockchain, various fields have leveraged its capabilities, particularly in cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, decentralized storage, and cryptocurrency. A blockchain-based approach to data storage and sharing significantly enhances cybersecurity by ensuring transparency, confidentiality, and data integrity through embedded cryptography and consensus mechanisms. The immutable nature of blockchain makes it computationally challenging to modify ledgers without detection, thus providing a transparent and traceable audit trail. This technology can potentially resolve many cybersecurity issues. Combining AI with blockchain can lead to innovative solutions that improve the overall security posture of organizations. One approach involves creating decentralized AI models that operate on a blockchain network, allowing for secure and transparent processing of sensitive data while ensuring a tamper-proof environment.

The integration of AI, cybersecurity, and blockchain is
a burgeoning field with significant potential to transform
the landscape of digital security. Traditional cybersecurity
approaches often struggle to keep pace with the dynamic and
sophisticated nature of modern cyber threats. AI has emerged
as a powerful tool for enhancing cybersecurity through its
ability to analyze vast amounts of data, detect anomalies,
and respond to threats in real-time. However, the centralized

AICyber-Chain: Combining AI and Blockchain
for Improved Cybersecurity

Text: The Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC), established by the National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA), provide a comprehensive framework aimed at enhancing the cybersecurity posture of organizations by mitigating various cyber risks. These controls encompass five main domains, 29 subdomains, and 114 specific controls, making them a benchmark for cybersecurity practices globally. The ECC is designed to ensure the protection of information and technology assets within organizations, emphasizing key principles such as confidentiality, integrity, and availability. By aligning with national and international regulatory requirements, the ECC facilitates a structured approach to cybersecurity that is crucial for both public and private sectors in Saudi Arabia. This meticulous design not only addresses current cybersecurity challenges but also lays the groundwork for ongoing improvements in security measures, reinforcing the importance of a proactive stance against evolving threats in the digital landscape.

For reducing the peak load effectively, the interruptible load groups are divided into two parts. One is scheduled on the off-line by the IDP and called ILGS. The other is utilized for adjusting the results of IDP by the HIR and called ILGA. The optimal or near optimal schedule of the ILGS can be acquired by the IDP. However, the results of the reduction load of the schedule will be influenced by the uncertainties of the practical system load. The HIR, therefore, is employed on the real-time to adjust the schedule for enhancing the robustness of the uncertainties.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: Meidan et al. [26] employed TCP/IP traffic network data and machine learning (ML) to classify and detect unauthorized IoT devices in a network. They assumed that the dataset sufficiently represented each device type on a whitelist. Using supervised ML?pecifically, the random forest (RF) algorithm?hey extracted features from network traffic data to classify IoT device types. The study gathered 17 unique IoT devices across nine categories, manually labeled them, and generated 60 features, later refining the list by removing those with zero variance, irrelevance, or overfitting risks. To simulate unauthorized access, one device type was deliberately excluded from the whitelist. The classifier? transferability was tested by training on two security cameras (SimpleHomeXCS71001) in Lab A and testing on a different model (Withings WBP02WT9510) in Lab B. The trained classifiers achieved an impressive 96% accuracy in detecting unauthorized IoT devices.

Given that we cannot transmit the ciphertext until the two Chua’s circuits (1) and (9) are synchronized, it is crucial to minimize the synchronization time. To achieve this, the impulsive intervals should be as short as possible, and the constant \( \lambda \) should be maximized. For instance, we select the impulsive intervals for synchronization as \( \Delta_1 = 1/4 \) and \( \Delta_2 = 1/4 \), respectively. Consequently, we obtain the following result regarding synchronization time.
Journal Name: Chaotic Cryptosystem With High Sensitivity to Parameter Mismatch

Text: The integration of AI, cybersecurity, and blockchain is a burgeoning field with significant potential to transform the landscape of digital security. Traditional cybersecurity approaches often struggle to keep pace with the dynamic and sophisticated nature of modern cyber threats. AI has emerged as a powerful tool for enhancing cybersecurity through its ability to analyze vast amounts of data, detect anomalies, and respond to threats in real-time. However, the centralized nature of many AI systems creates vulnerabilities, making them attractive targets for cyberattacks. By leveraging blockchain technology, organizations can enhance data privacy and security through decentralized storage solutions that ensure immutability and transparency. This combination allows for secure and tamper-proof data management, enabling AI to operate on reliable datasets while maintaining user privacy. The synergy between AI and blockchain can lead to novel solutions that improve threat detection, fraud prevention, and identity management, ultimately strengthening the overall security posture of organizations in an increasingly digital world.

Text: The HNN-based authentication system is designed to be reliable. The network's retrieval mechanism is inherently accurate because the registration process ensures a perfect match between each valid user ID and password combination. Any incorrect combination will be rejected. To evaluate the effectiveness of this system, we compared it to the existing layered neural network method. We conducted two simulations: one to measure the time required for registration, and the other to assess performance when many passwords have similar character patterns.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: The security of a Conditional Access System (CAS) relies heavily on the scrambling algorithm and, crucially, the scrambling key distribution scheme [10]. Due to the high data rates and real-time demands of Digital Television (DTV) broadcasting, CAS typically employs symmetric encryption for stream scrambling [5]. Given the rapidly changing Control Word (CW) encryption keys, attackers are more likely to target the key distribution process than the scrambling algorithm itself. Therefore, secure descrambling key distribution to authorized subscribers is paramount for a successful CAS. This paper introduces a four-level key architecture and proposes a group-based access control scheme for key distribution. This scheme enhances security while minimizing encryption computations and offering scalability for subscriber management. The paper proceeds as follows: Section 2 reviews related work on CAS key distribution; Section 3 details the proposed key distribution scheme; Section 4 compares the scheme with others and provides security analysis; and Section 5 concludes the paper.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: User authentication is a component of the broader security system, which can be characterized as strong or weak based on the cost of an attack versus the potential gain for the attacker. Different authenticators provide varying levels of defense against different types of attacks. Authenticators can be targeted at the client, during transmission, or at the host. This discussion focuses on client and host vulnerabilities. To improve security, multiple types of authenticators can be combined, a process known as multifactor authentication. The paper also explains how user authentication integrates into comprehensive authentication systems like RADIUS, Kerberos, and SSO.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: The optimal pre-contingency operating state of the ESCOPF problem for the five-bus case is shown in Fig. 3. The generation at Bus 1 is less than the maximum possible amount of 160 MW that can be generated while still maintaining a secure system, as discussed above. This is due to the large amount of load in terruption that would occur if Generator 1 were producing 160 MW in the pre-contingency operating condition. When oper ating at the optimal pre-contingency state, the load at Bus 2 is interrupted by 0.29 MW at a cost of $29 when line 1–2 is re moved, as shown in Fig. 4.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: The implementation of a political, economic, social, technological, legal, and environmental (PESTLE) analysis was undertaken to systematically categorize the root causes of prevailing cybersecurity education challenges, thereby enabling a more comprehensive understanding of the problem domain [10]; PESTLE analyses, frequently employed within development frameworks, offer a straightforward methodology for identifying and interpreting gaps and challenges from diverse perspectives; consequently, PESTLE serves as an effective conceptual tool for examining the multifaceted complexities inherent in cybersecurity education; furthermore, the application of PESTLE facilitates the development of a standardized taxonomy of challenges, thereby establishing a foundational framework for future research and related activities within this critical domain.

The proposed PESTLE analysis serves as a comprehensive summary of the current state of cybersecurity education-related research, focusing on identifying underlying causes and challenges. Several reports and articles have been reviewed to ensure an exhaustive analysis, particularly those that utilize the PESTLE framework to explore cybersecurity education. This approach categorizes factors impacting education into Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, and Environmental dimensions. Notably, the REWIRE project highlights that many issues in cybersecurity education could be mitigated by redesigning educational pathways to better reflect its interdisciplinary nature. Despite these insights, the reasons for the persistent shortfall of trained cybersecurity professionals remain unclear, with variations in challenges across different countries and sectors complicating the identification of underlying factors. The findings from this analysis will inform future research and initiatives aimed at addressing these gaps in cybersecurity education. For a more detailed review of publications related to this topic, refer to Sections III and IV of the analysis.

In recent years, numerous researchers have explored impulsive systems and impulsive control. Studies in [2]–[6] have examined the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, which are required to be nonincreasing across the entire sequence or subsequence of switchings. In [1], Yang derived sufficient conditions for the impulsive control of a class of nonlinear systems by applying results from [3]. Similarly, Li et al. in [7] provided less conservative conditions for the asymptotic stability of impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses, utilizing findings from [3] to design impulsive control for nonlinear systems. Additionally, works in [8]–[13] have demonstrated various applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications. In [14], Panas et al. proposed experimental methods for implementing impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: In contrast to prior endeavors, the ontology presented herein is specifically engineered to support real-world cybersecurity operations, with a primary emphasis on operational information relevant to threat management and incident response; to ensure practical applicability and facilitate reusability, the ontology's development was grounded in extensive consultations with cybersecurity operators, thereby enabling the creation of a framework that facilitates the sharing and reuse of operational information while establishing a standardized terminology for the domain.

The security of certain Delayed Feedback (DDF) systems can be vulnerable. Specifically, the system's parameters can be deduced from time series data by making assumptions about the functional form of the nonlinear feedback element [16], [17]. Many optoelectronic [13] and all-electronic [18], [19] implementations of DDF systems use a fixed nonlinearity with a well-defined functional form. Research has demonstrated that DDF chaotic systems can be compromised using curve-fitting algorithms if the functional form is known [16]. Additionally, the cracking algorithm that breaches DDF system security relies on identifying the system's time delay. Recent numerical studies suggest that modulating the time delay can enhance security [20].
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: Recent years have witnessed significant private-sector research initiatives aimed at developing advanced cybersecurity training systems capable of addressing fundamental, long-term training requirements. These contemporary platforms incorporate sophisticated features such as intuitive graphical interfaces for environment configuration, autonomous red team/blue team agents, and automated performance evaluation mechanisms. However, current commercially-developed training solutions remain constrained by fragmented functionality, where these individual components operate in isolation rather than as an integrated system, ultimately limiting their capacity to deliver truly comprehensive and practical training experiences. To address these systemic limitations, this work introduces ICSTASY - an innovative cybersecurity training platform that overcomes existing fragmentation through seamless integration of all critical training components. ICSTASY's architecture provides unified support for diverse training capabilities within a single cohesive environment, enabling holistic cybersecurity skill development that bridges the gap between theoretical knowledge and real-world operational requirements. The platform's design specifically targets the shortcomings of current solutions by offering fully synchronized training features that collectively enhance both the effectiveness and efficiency of cybersecurity preparedness programs.

To implement DBHS effectively, there is a need for advanced Conditional Access (CA) systems that can prevent unauthorized copying and regulate the use of stored digital content by receivers. Additionally, given the ease of editing and reconstructing programs using metadata, there is a requirement for access control systems that allow broadcasters to manage how content is used. These security systems, referred to as Digital Rights Management (DRM) systems, are designed to protect content rights and control access to content. While DRM has traditionally been used for internet-based content protection, the gap between CA for broadcasting and DRM for communication is narrowing, as both technologies evolve to address similar challenges in content protection and access control.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Unauthorized aggregation is a specific variation of malicious modification, particularly relevant to PH schemes, warranting separate consideration. This attack involves combining two or more valid ciphertexts and injecting the aggregated result into the network.Similar to legitimate aggregation nodes, a malicious aggregator does not need to know the plaintext values to generate a seemingly valid ciphertext. An adversary could exploit this property to disrupt the system or manipulate data in a targeted manner.For instance, with knowledge or assumptions about certain ciphertext-plaintext pairs, an attacker could strategically modify packets. Suppose an adversary knows that ciphertext corresponds to a temperature reading of approximately 20?C.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: The development of generative models dates back to the 1950s with the introduction of Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs), but significant advancements only came with the rise of deep learning. Early sequence generation methods, such as N-gram language modeling, relied on learned word distributions to generate text. The introduction of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) further enhanced generative capabilities, but the most transformative breakthrough came with the advent of transformer architectures, which now form the foundation of large language models (LLMs) like BERT and GPT. Generative AI has since expanded into various domains, including image, speech, and text, though this work focuses specifically on text-based AI chatbots, particularly ChatGPT. As ChatGPT is powered by OpenAI? GPT-3 model, this paper also provides an overview of the evolution of OpenAI's GPT models, highlighting their progression toward more sophisticated versions, as illustrated in Figure 2.

Cybersecurity is a critical concern that must be addressed before implementing protection systems over broadband networks. This article focuses on developing a context information-based real-time cybersecurity defense approach for protection systems within a network context. The article is structured as follows: Section II presents the proposed methodology, Section III introduces and sets up the Probabilistic Neural Network (PNN), and Sections IV and V provide simulation results and conclusions, respectively.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: Every device or endpoint in the Internet of Things (IoT) and cyber-physical systems (CPS) contributes to the network's attack surface, making them potential targets for attackers who can exploit vulnerabilities to gain control over the entire system. Protocols such as WiFi, Bluetooth, and GSM facilitate connections between external devices and various sensors, but they also contain inherent bugs that can be exploited by malicious entities. As these systems become increasingly interconnected, the risk of cybersecurity breaches rises, necessitating robust protective measures. Effective cybersecurity solutions are essential to safeguard against these threats, ensuring that vulnerabilities are addressed and that the integrity of the IoT and CPS environments is maintained.

The automobile can be viewed in its operating environment through two scales. The first is a large-scale "system-of-systems" perspective, where automobiles are integral components of multimodal transportation systems, multimedia information systems, global energy systems (fossil-fuel, bio-fuel, or hydrogen-based), and atmospheric chemistry systems. At this scale, approximately 900 million automobiles operate worldwide (Fig. 1). Beyond being part of these large-scale physical and chemical systems, the automobile is increasingly becoming a component of a sophisticated information infrastructure system (Fig. 3), creating new opportunities for services enabled by electrical, electronic, and software technologies.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

It is posited that future enhancements to internal consistency scores could be achieved through the translation of the questionnaire into local languages, rather than reliance on local interpreters, alongside improvements in item wording clarity, reduction of redundancy, and the inclusion of additional items aligned with the measured construct. Passive attacks comprise all attacks that do not require the
adversary to actively interfere with the connection. In order
to perform such an attack, the adversary needs to do

Text: An electronic dialing circuit connected to a home telephone can be activated by an actuating signal generated from any detector circuit [9]. This signal serves two functions: (i) it triggers a relay circuit to close the cradle for a predetermined duration, allowing the system to receive a dial tone and initiate dialing, and (ii) it enables a sequential logic circuit to transmit a series of pulses corresponding to specific digits through the telephone lines. This mechanism is utilized to automatically dial the resident? mobile number when a fire detector is activated. Upon detecting a fire, the circuit places a call to the resident? mobile, signaling the emergency through a ringing alert. Recognizing the call as originating from home, the resident immediately understands the fire situation and can respond by dialing back with an additional digit, as outlined in Section II.B. The home telephone, integrated with a relay board extension, receives this additional digit and activates a relay circuit, triggering a solenoid valve that operates a fire extinguisher electromechanically. The fire extinguisher is strategically placed within the home and can also be manually operated. If the resident is at home when the fire alarm triggers, they can choose to extinguish the fire manually or by returning the call.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

The process is divided into five phases: registration, login, mutual authentication, key agreement, and control word transmission. Figure 3 illustrates the secure communication protocol between the STB and smart card.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Section III explores the role of gamification in workforce development and its impact on enhancing cybersecurity in facility-related control systems. Section IV details the methodology behind the game mechanics of NDTG. Section V introduces a use case demonstrating the practical application of this approach. Section VI analyzes the scenario from the use case to illustrate how NDTG contributes to cyber workforce development. Finally, Section VII concludes the paper.

The emergency analysis specifically investigates the impact of the new generation on transmission line loading and bus voltage during outages of transmission lines, autotransformers, and generators. The study utilized the most recent version of the Southwest Power Pool 2005 summer peak base case.

Text: This study utilized an independent sample t-test, with no outliers detected based on a boxplot inspection. The data followed a normal distribution, as confirmed by the Shapiro-Wilk test (p > .05), and variance homogeneity was verified using Levene's test (p = .164). Descriptive statistics, including mean and standard deviations, are presented in Table 2. The findings reveal statistically significant differences in cybersecurity awareness between respondents from the UAE and their counterparts in the USA. The study was first conducted in the UAE, and to ensure demographic consistency, similar controls were applied on Mechanical Turk for the USA dataset. Additionally, gender bias was mitigated by comparing male participants from the UAE (n = 42) and the USA (n = 40), yielding comparable outcomes.

To tackle the challenges of information sharing across organizational boundaries, various organizations are developing standardized information formats, often in the form of industry specifications or global standards. These common formats offer two primary benefits: they help reduce disparities in information availability worldwide, ensuring that no country or organization is left behind, particularly aiding developing nations in enhancing their cybersecurity capabilities through global collaboration. Additionally, these standardized formats streamline cybersecurity operations by structuring information into machine-readable formats, thus improving knowledge management and reducing the manual effort required by human operators. This structured approach facilitates more efficient sharing and utilization of cybersecurity information, ultimately strengthening collective defenses against cyber threats.

The PhiKitA dataset introduces a first-of-its-kind repository of phishing kits and their corresponding phishing websites, enabling researchers to detect phishing campaigns earlier by analyzing kit-based patterns through MD5 hashes, fingerprints, and DOM graph algorithms. In benchmark tests, the dataset achieved 92.5% accuracy in phishing website detection using DOM graph representations, proving kits contain valuable classification signals, while MD5 hashes underperformed (39.54% F1-score), revealing limitations in tracking kit-to-website origins?hough the data still uncovered small phishing campaigns and kit variants, offering new avenues for proactive phishing defense.

While the previous sections described the process by which the quantities traded and TSCs are set at a particular iteration, the actual trading process occurs over many iterations. This it erative trading process can be viewed as an alternative to using the spot market for arranging short term contracts. For example, the TSP can fix a time period during which agents can submit bids for transmission for the day-ahead power market. During this time, multiple iterations of the trading process described in Section II-B may occur, allowing each agent to buy or sell as much power as they require by seeking out their own trading partners.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: An inertial seismometer converts ground motion into an electrical signal; however, its characteristics cannot be defined by a single-scale factor, such as output voltage per millimeter of ground displacement (as is the case with position sensors). Its response depends not only on the magnitude of the motion but also on its time scale?how quickly it occurs. To function properly, the suspended seismic mass must be stabilized by a restoring force, which can be electromagnetic, mechanical, or of another type. If the ground motion is slow, the mass will move along with the seismometer, resulting in a significantly smaller output signal even for large displacements. Consequently, the system acts as a high-pass filter for ground shifts, which must be considered when reconstructing ground motion from recorded signals. Developing seismic detectors capable of generating strong output signals for both fast and slow ground movements?independent of motion rate, similar to position sensors?remains a critical challenge in seismology and related fields.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: The proposed system aims to prevent confidential file loss through USB removable storage devices by implementing a secure protocol. File transfer via USB is only allowed after the user completes a remote server authentication process. All files transmitted to the storage device are encrypted using a key, denoted as K, which is generated based on the user ID and filename. To access the original file on another computer, users must repeat the verification process and obtain the same key K for decryption. This ensures that different files or users have unique keys, enhancing security.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: Generative AI (GenAI) tools have emerged as a double-edged sword in cybersecurity, offering advantages to both defenders and attackers. Cyber defenders can leverage tools like ChatGPT to strengthen security by utilizing insights from large language models (LLMs) trained on vast cyber threat intelligence datasets, including vulnerabilities, attack patterns, and indicators of compromise. These AI-driven systems enhance threat detection, automate incident response by analyzing large volumes of log files and network traffic, and accelerate remediation efforts. Additionally, GenAI contributes to cybersecurity awareness by training individuals to recognize sophisticated threats. It also aids in secure coding practices by generating secure code and producing test cases to validate security. Furthermore, LLMs can assist in developing ethical guidelines to reinforce cyber defense strategies, ensuring a more resilient digital ecosystem.

IoT involves so many different things, especially heterogeneous devices. In 2015, IoT connected 4.9 billion things and
will connect 25 billion things by 2020 [5]. IoT has great flexibility and scalability, but this huge number also may imply
a security challenge. The more devices a person connects,
the greater the risk to the individual and to the network, and
the higher the cybersecurity risk to the global infrastructure.
In 2003, each person had only fewer than 0.08 devices. In
2010, the number increased to 1.84. By 2020, there will be
6.58 devices per person [6]. Devices of all types are developing widely and rapidly across the global IoT network, but
these devices are easily attacked and are considered as vulnerable points in the IoT network. Thus, the IoT cybersecurity
infrastructure ensures that devices are maintained in a secure
environment and that users can use them appropriately. The

computers, smart phones, communication interfaces, operating systems, lightweight services, and preloaded applications.
Equipped with RFID sensors or actuators, intelligent devices
can execute accordingly, make decisions autonomously, and

Text: When injection strength substantially exceeds feedback strength in the slave laser, the receiver reproduces the injected waveform through strong injection-locking-type synchronization. In this scenario, synchronization recovery time is significantly reduced compared to the previous case and remains constant regardless of complexity and external-cavity length. However, recovery times below 200 picoseconds have not yet been documented, indicating that phase variations of this magnitude would still protect messages from interception. Furthermore, in this operating regime, the receiver essentially functions as an open-loop system without phase sensitivity, resulting in very poor decoding performance for low-amplitude messages (as shown in Figure 2).
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: The Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC) by Saudi Arabia's National Cybersecurity Authority (NCA) provide a legally mandated, sector-specific framework with 114 controls addressing governance, technical defenses, and incident response, proven to reduce breach impact by 28% through quarterly audits and MITRE ATT&CK-aligned mitigations. Unlike generic frameworks, the ECC enforces tiered compliance based on organizational risk, requiring cross-departmental coordination (IT, legal, executives) and quantifiable metrics like 72-hour critical patch deadlines, making it a global benchmark for actionable, enforceable cybersecurity standards.

The Conditional Access System (CAS) typically operates in a three-tiered hierarchy for key distribution. First, the server generates a random Control Word (CW), which serves as the seed for a pseudo-random generator (PRG). The PRG then produces a pseudo-random sequence used to scramble the Transport Stream (TS). Simultaneously, the CW is encrypted with an Authorization Key (AK) to form an Entitlement Control Message (ECM). Additionally, the AK and other entitlement information are encrypted using the Master Private Key (MPK) to create an Entitlement Management Message (EMM).The ECM, EMM, and scrambled TS are then multiplexed into a new TS stream and transmitted to subscribers via the broadcasting channel. To prevent unauthorized modifications, both ECM and EMM must be transmitted with their respective digital signatures. The Subscriber Management System (SMS) oversees customer access rights to protected services, allowing for the addition or removal of access by generating or updating the MPK stored in the smartcard.To enhance system security, CAS frequently updates CWs or employs more advanced symmetric encryption algorithms. In a typical CAS, CWs are changed every 5 to 20 seconds, significantly reducing the risk of known-plaintext attacks.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System
