The increasing demand for cybersecurity experts has prompted standard bodies and governments to continuously monitor workforce requirements and develop relevant frameworks. These initiatives have led to the creation of work role frameworks and detailed reports on workforce needs. The following section reviews the most relevant initiatives in this domain.

The security of Internet of Things (IoT) communications is critical due to the large volumes of data transmitted between devices, servers, and customers. If the confidentiality, integrity, or availability (CIA) of this data is compromised, it can lead to severe consequences, including data theft and unauthorized access. To mitigate these risks, implementing robust cybersecurity measures is essential. Best practices include employing strong encryption methods for data both in transit and at rest, using authentication protocols like multi-factor authentication to ensure only authorized access, and leveraging firewalls and intrusion detection systems to monitor and protect networks. Additionally, regular vulnerability assessments and network segmentation can help identify potential threats and contain breaches. By prioritizing these security strategies, organizations can better protect their IoT ecosystems from cyber threats and maintain the integrity of sensitive data.

Hybrid Manufacturing (HM) tools serve as prime examples of Digital Manufacturing (DM) building blocks, showcasing the shift from traditional to digital processes. However, this transformation introduces new attack vectors, increasing cybersecurity risks. Studying HM tools allows for the identification, analysis, and mitigation of these vulnerabilities before DM is widely adopted, ensuring a more secure transition to interconnected manufacturing systems.

In 2016, the US Homeland Security (US CERT) developed the United States Cyber Incident Coordination under the Presidential Policy Directive 41 (PPD-41). This initiative aims to establish the National Cyber Incident Response Plan (NCIRP) to address cybersecurity incidents affecting critical infrastructure as part of a broader National Preparedness System. The NCIRP provides a strategic framework for a "whole-of-Nation" approach to cyber incident response and recovery. It serves as a governance playbook for coordinating cybersecurity incidents across government, private sectors, and citizens, detailing guidance, authority, and statutory contacts for different types of cyber incidents at national, state, and private sector levels.

Various fire detection techniques exist, including temperature sampling, relative humidity sampling, smoke analysis, and ultraviolet and infrared sampling. The method presented in [12] utilizes video processing for fire alarms, providing additional insights into the burning process. However, it is too costly for home security applications.In this system, each fire alarm node incorporates a temperature sensor and an infrared receiver. The temperature sensor monitors ambient temperature, while the infrared receiver detects heat and flames. If either the temperature or infrared levels exceed predefined thresholds, the node triggers an alarm signal. The implementation of a fire alarm node, as shown in Fig. 12, features a simple design, low cost, and is well-suited for home use.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: The rapid evolution of internet technologies, wireless communication protocols, and sensor networks has dramatically expanded the IoT ecosystem, incorporating countless network-enabled objects?rom industrial sensors to consumer smart devices?nto a complex cybersecurity landscape that now underpins critical infrastructure and Industry 4.0 initiatives. This global network of heterogeneous devices, which merges sensory, communication, and data-processing capabilities, inherently disperses cybersecurity risks across every layer, exacerbated by the integration of ancillary technologies like barcodes, smartphones, social platforms, and cloud computing. While these advancements enable unprecedented connectivity and automation, they also introduce multifaceted vulnerabilities, as each component?hether an IP-based industrial controller or a consumer-grade wearable?ecomes a potential entry point for threats, demanding cohesive security frameworks that address interoperability challenges and the dynamic attack surfaces of modern ICT environments.

This questionnaire consisted of fourteen Likert-scale (7-
point) questions. The scale had a high internal consistency level, as determined by a Cronbach? alpha of 0.794.
We believe that translating the questionnaire in the local
languages (instead of relying on local interpreters to conduct questionnaires), brining clarity in item wording, limiting
redundancy, and adding more items when aligned with the
measured construct might further enhance the internal consistency scores. These steps could increase the internal consistency and reliability of future questionnaires. The results
of the t-test (in Table 3) indicate that items 1, 3, and 4 were
statistically insignificant, whereby the remaining items 2, 5,
to 14 were statistically significant.
Journal Name:
A Comparative Assessment of Human Factors in
Cybersecurity: Implications for Cyber Governance

Text: Traditional motion estimation algorithms, while numerous, often rely on comparing successive, full-resolution images. This approach necessitates significant data storage and transfer, leading to substantial power consumption and complex, costly hardware. For portable security applications, low power consumption and a simple, cost-effective architecture are crucial. To address these challenges, we propose a novel motion detection algorithm that achieves comparable accuracy while utilizing only a fraction (one-thousandth or less) of the image data required by conventional methods. This streamlined approach minimizes data movement between circuit blocks and can be implemented with minor modifications to standard CMOS image sensors, resulting in reduced power consumption and lower system cost.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: This study examines the relationship between information systems (IS) sourcing strategies and organizational cybersecurity breaches, revealing that a best-of-breed (BoB) approach results in fewer breaches than single-sourcing when an organization's IT application spread is limited, though this advantage diminishes as the spread expands. Additionally, insourcing demonstrates a lower breach likelihood compared to outsourcing strategies?ncluding single-sourcing, best-of-suite (BoS), and BoB?ut this benefit weakens with increased IT application spread and is only significant at lower levels. Notably, BoS and BoB strategies show no statistically significant difference in breach risk, and for organizations with a wide IT application spread, no sourcing strategy proves superior in mitigating cybersecurity breaches. These findings offer valuable insights for cybersecurity management, guiding IS development and interorganizational decision-making to optimize risk mitigation based on IT infrastructure complexity.

Room Transfer Functions (RTFs) are determined by correlating a known sound source with the signal received at a specific location; while traditional methods use impulse signals like gunshots, this approach employs white noise, offering superior repeatability and enhanced signal-to-noise ratio through repeated measurements. In ideal anechoic environments, the received signal would cease after the initial peak, but in real rooms, reflections cause reverberation, resulting in a prolonged sound decay visible in the RTF. This demonstrates the advantages of white noise in accurately capturing a room's acoustic characteristics.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: In the proposed method, the MMB would be an independent, technically and politically enabled entity that, on a proactive and predictive fashion, determines market competitiveness, and calculates and disseminates the MCFs to market players. The MCF’s set boundaries for the behavior of market players such that market power abuses do not take place and system reliability and security concerns are addressed.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: Focusing on task integration during an acquisition can impede human integration, potentially disrupting organizational identity. Conversely, prioritizing human integration may delay the realization of operational synergies. Achieving a successful acquisition requires a careful balance between separation and coordination among different sectors. Separation allows units to maintain autonomy, fostering innovation and the development of new ideas, while integration is necessary to avoid duplicating processes and ensure a cost-effective structure. This dynamic underscores the importance of addressing both operational and cultural aspects during the integration process to enhance overall effectiveness and maintain a cohesive organizational identity.

Over the past decade, chaos-based secure communications have evolved to their fourth generation [2]–[6], [8], [9], [18]. The first three generations utilized continuous synchronization, while the fourth generation employs impulsive synchronization. The fourth generation requires less than 94 Hz of bandwidth to transmit the synchronization signal for a third-order chaotic transmitter, compared to the 30 kHz bandwidth needed for the previous three generations [18]. This significantly improves bandwidth efficiency in the fourth generation. However, attacks described in [10], [11] have demonstrated that many of these methods are either insecure or have low security. Therefore, enhancing the security of chaotic secure communication is necessary.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: The remainder of this note is structured as follows. Section II introduces a new comparison theorem and sufficient conditions for the asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems. These findings are applied in Section III to design impulsive control laws for nonlinear systems. The note concludes with Section IV.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Cybersecurity is an interdisciplinary field that intersects with various domains, including computer science, engineering, information systems, networks, cryptology, human factors, and policy. To effectively identify its core concepts amidst the vast array of potential topics, a systematic selection process that incorporates diverse expert perspectives is essential. This paper discusses the results of two Delphi processes conducted in fall 2014 aimed at pinpointing these core concepts for cybersecurity education. The findings from these processes not only highlight critical knowledge areas for introductory courses but also establish foundational topics that cybersecurity professionals should master upon graduation. As the demand for skilled cybersecurity practitioners continues to rise, defining these essential concepts becomes crucial for developing effective educational frameworks and assessment tools that can enhance training and prepare individuals for successful careers in this rapidly evolving field.

The Transmission Service Provider (TSP) requires a different objective function for networks with fewer constrained lines. An alternative function, which minimizes the absolute value of transmission service charges, has proven effective in practice. This function works well because, as the number of constrained lines decreases, optimal nodal prices become more uniform, reducing the need for significant locational price variations to achieve Optimal Power Flow (OPF). The two objective functions have distinct characteristics. Maximizing TSP revenue ensures an increase in total social welfare and guarantees positive TSP revenue. In contrast, minimizing the absolute value of transmission service charges does not always yield these outcomes; it may result in lower social welfare or even negative TSP revenue. However, on average, the min-absolute-value function successfully achieves OPF in many relatively unconstrained simulated networks.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: Cyber events encompass any observable activity within information systems, whether benign or malicious, with only a subset meeting predefined anomaly-based thresholds to trigger alerts?scalating to full incidents when correlated alerts indicate actual compromises. The European NIS Directive formally defines incidents as events that disrupt the availability, integrity, or confidentiality of critical network information systems, specifically those impairing essential service continuity [12], establishing a legal threshold for reporting and response in regulated sectors. This distinction between events, alerts, and incidents provides a layered framework for operationalizing threat detection and prioritizing responses based on impact severity.

With increasing energy demands, Distributed Resources (DRs), such as distributed generation and energy storage devices, are becoming more prevalent in the industry. These resources are being integrated into distribution and sub-transmission systems to provide localized load services. It is projected that DRs will meet 25% of the load growth in North America over the next decade [5]. In electricity markets, DRs are typically not controlled by Independent System Operators (ISOs) or Distribution Companies (DISCOs). As a result, ISOs often lack detailed information about individual DR devices.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: The aim of this article is to identify critical data that must be protected against cyber-attacks targeting networked manufacturing machines, distinguishing between subtractive and additive production technologies commonly used in high-tech industries such as aeronautics, automotive, and medical sectors. Additive manufacturing, which builds products layer-by-layer, offers significant design versatility for complex models but may compromise durability compared to subtractive manufacturing, which preserves material integrity by removing excess material. The article emphasizes the importance of safeguarding sensitive data within these manufacturing processes to mitigate risks associated with cyber threats. Current cybersecurity measures must address vulnerabilities inherent in both manufacturing technologies, as well as the unique challenges posed by networked environments. Effective strategies include implementing physical access controls, network segmentation, and robust authentication measures, alongside regular software updates and employee training on data protection best practices. By prioritizing these security measures, manufacturers can enhance their resilience against cyber-attacks and maintain operational integrity while ensuring compliance with industry regulations.

Cyberwarfare can strike anytime, anywhere, and its impact extends beyond the military, affecting various aspects of daily life. As cybersecurity has only recently become a critical military concern, the armed forces often depend on the private sector for cyber mission assurance, a reliance that could increase the risk of mission failure due to security gaps. To mitigate this, the military has sought to develop dedicated cybersecurity training systems; however, existing solutions often lack comprehensive support for effective training. This study introduces ICSTASY, an interactive, scenario-based cybersecurity training platform designed to provide immersive and holistic training. By reviewing prior research, key design principles and requirements for building an advanced cyber training system were identified. The prototype demonstration validates ICSTASY? potential to deliver realistic and efficient cybersecurity training, benefiting both military and private-sector applications.

Social Enterprises (SEs) collectively constitute a significant commercial sector, characterized by attributes that render them vulnerable to cyberattacks, with potential adverse effects on both the organization and its stakeholders. Their growing social and commercial viability, as evidenced by the 52% turnover growth among U.K. SEs in the past year [81], may inadvertently increase their visibility to malicious actors. Consequently, their escalating popularity may correlate with heightened susceptibility to cybercrime, a trend observed in the increasing cybercrime targeting larger charitable organizations.

The microprocessor used in this system is an 8-bit PSoC (Programmable System on Chip) device, chosen for three main reasons. Firstly, it simplifies the design process and reduces system costs, thanks to its configurable analog and digital blocks and programmable interconnects logic. This architecture enables the creation of customized peripherals such as filters, amplifiers, analog-to-digital converters, and communication interfaces. Secondly, the device includes a sleep timer and an SMP (Switch Mode Pump) circuit, which help reduce power consumption. Lastly, a specialized PSoC device is available that simplifies the design of the capacitive sensor keyboard within the system.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text:
This paper presents and analyzes results of two
Delphi processes that polled cybersecurity experts to rate cybersecurity topics based on importance, difficulty, and timelessness.
These ratings can be used to identify core concepts?cross-cutting
ideas that connect knowledge in the discipline. The first Delphi
process identified core concepts that should be learned in any
first course on cybersecurity. The second identified core concepts
that any cybersecurity professional should know upon graduating
from college. Despite the rapidly growing demand for cybersecurity professionals, it is not clear what defines foundational
cybersecurity knowledge. Initial data from the Delphi processes
lay a foundation for defining the core concepts of the field and,
consequently, provide a common starting point to accelerate the
development of rigorous cybersecurity education practices. These
results provide a foundation for developing evidence-based educational cybersecurity assessment tools that will identify and
measure effective methods for teaching cybersecurity. The Delphi
results can also be used to inform the development of curricula,
learning exercises, and other educational materials and policies.
Journal Name:
Identifying Core Concepts of Cybersecurity:
Results of Two Delphi Processes

Text: A recent study revealed that 49.7% of respondents in the UAE use 3 to 4 passwords for online activities such as banking, social media, and shopping. This aligns with broader findings that UAE residents rank third globally for password forgetfulness, a phenomenon attributed to "password fatigue." On average, UAE users manage 55 accounts, often requiring complex passwords due to stricter security requirements. This mental exhaustion leads to frequent resets, with UAE residents averaging just 24 months between resets?he shortest globally. To address this issue, tools like password managers and single sign-on (SSO) systems are recommended to simplify password management while maintaining security.

We are proposing a new password authentication scheme based on HNN. Without losing its generalities, we are able to demonstrate this authentication scheme to verify user IDs and passwords. This authentication scheme can be used for any access control of computing resources, such as multiple server access permission [9] or role-based security control [12]. The authentication scheme includes three major procedures: registration, log-in authorization, and password change.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Our system also incorporates the ability to modulate the digital time-delay element. Existing cracking algorithms use average mutual information (AMI) to estimate the time delay from a chaotic waveform [16]. By modulating the time delay, we disrupt the ability to determine a fixed time delay and other system parameters [20]. In our implementation, the time delay is alternately switched between 60 and 45 seconds every 10 seconds within the FPGA. The reasoning behind this approach is discussed in Section V.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: The preventive-reactive cyber defense dynamics model, initially proposed in [20] and later examined in [48] with partial analyses (building on earlier special cases [33]?35]), was historically limited to narrow parameter regimes. Recent breakthroughs [4] prove its global convergence across the entire parameter universe, guaranteeing a unique equilibrium determined solely by system parameters?ot initial conditions?hus enabling universal applicability for cybersecurity quantification.

In 2014, the MITRE Corporation introduced a cyber exercise playbook [14], a comprehensive resource designed to guide the execution of cybersecurity exercises, encompassing guidance, practical exercises, and a red team cyber sample event workbook; preceding this, in 2012, MITRE released a cyber defense playbook [15], which emphasized active defense strategies predicated on the cyber-attack kill chain, thereby establishing a framework for proactive threat mitigation.

A particularly notable scenario from the December 22 event highlights that system frequency is not uniform across the network during disturbances. Analysis of recorded operational data, as illustrated in Figure 5, indicates that only some LaaRs—those equipped with faster breakers and located closer to the fault—tripped when the system frequency reached 59.7 Hz, successfully mitigating the decline. Meanwhile, LaaRs with slower breaker response times and located farther from the fault remained unaffected by the high-set underfrequency relay. To restore the frequency to the nominal 60 Hz, operators manually dispatched these remaining LaaRs within 10 minutes. Figure 5 effectively demonstrates that frequency variations occur across different parts of the system during disturbances.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text:
Remark 1: Here, we have used the magnifying-glass to
transform the chaotic state variables which act as key sequence
before XOR with the plaintext. Assuming that there is a small
mismatch that results in perturbations
, then the signal getting through the amplifier has
. Since
the parameter is a large number, we can see that the signal
is enlarged many times, which implied that the parameters

The security of the chaotic communication system is thus

Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: Two scales may be used to view the automobile in the context of its operating environment. One is a large-scale "system-of-systems" view in which automobiles are components of a multimodal transportation system, a multimedia information system, an even larger planetary (fossil-fuel, bio-fuel or hydrogen) energy system, and an atmospheric chemistry system. At this scale, 900 million or so automobiles Broam[ this planet (Fig. 1). In addition to being a component in a large-scale physical and chemi cal system, the automobile is becoming a component in a rich information infrastructure system (Fig. 3), opening a new frontier for electrical, electronic & software tech nology enabled services.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: The burgeoning interest in decentralized paradigms within cybersecurity and machine learning (ML) for the expanding Internet of Things (IoT) landscape has catalyzed significant attention across governmental, academic, and industrial sectors, with federated cybersecurity (FC) emerging as a transformative concept aimed at enhancing IoT security and operational efficiency; this innovative framework facilitates the detection, mitigation, and containment of security threats through the collaborative development and dissemination of learned models among distributed participants, leveraging federated learning (FL), a privacy-preserving ML technique, to fortify the inherently vulnerable IoT ecosystem; this discourse commences with a foundational overview and comparative analysis of centralized learning, distributed on-site learning, and FL, subsequently transitioning to a comprehensive survey of FL applications in IoT cybersecurity, emphasizing security considerations while addressing performance-related factors such as accuracy, latency, and resource constraints that may impact security and overall system functionality; furthermore, the exploration extends to encompass ongoing research initiatives, challenges, and emerging trends, thereby providing readers with a comprehensive understanding of FL's role in cybersecurity, the reciprocal security implications for FL, and the landscape of relevant security threats and countermeasures.

Abstract·This letter presents a novel asymmetric watermarking system capable of embedding multiple watermarks while requiring only a single reference watermark for detection. This approach enhances security by preventing attacks aimed at estimating the embedded watermark. In the proposed method, the phase of the reference watermark is randomly shifted (either clockwise or counterclockwise) in the discrete Fourier transform domain to generate embedded watermarks. These watermarks remain correlated with each other and maintain the same correlation with the reference watermark. Additionally, we discuss the selection of design parameters for optimal performance.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Cybersecurity and cyber vulnerabilities are often attributed to a range of physical, human, and social factors. Many policymakers and governments tend to focus on building robust physical infrastructures to combat these threats, a strategy known as the Castle Model, which emphasizes creating thick defensive boundaries around systems to prevent security breaches. While this model offers some protection, it falls short in addressing the complexities of cultural diversity, socio-technical systems, and varying levels of cybersecurity awareness among global populations. As a result, governments struggle to fully eradicate cyber risks. To develop a more effective cybersecurity framework, there is a pressing need for evidence-based investigations into human factors and levels of cyber risk awareness, enabling a holistic approach that incorporates both technical defenses and human-centric strategies.

The pervasive and omnipresent nature of cyberwarfare, manifesting globally and with greater frequency than commonly perceived, disrupts not only military operations but also the fabric of daily life, the military's nascent reliance on cybersecurity as a critical operational component necessitates a substantial dependence on the private sector for cyber mission assurance, a dependency that, given the military's inherent confidentiality, may precipitate heightened risks of mission degradation or failure, to mitigate this, efforts have been directed towards the development of dedicated, internal cybersecurity training systems, however, extant systems often lack the comprehensive capabilities required for efficacious and efficient training, this research introduces ICSTASY, a scenario-driven, interactive, and immersive cybersecurity training platform designed to provide holistic support for diverse training functionalities, the study delineates the fundamental requirements and design principles essential for addressing the challenges associated with cyber training system development, derived from an analysis of prior work, and demonstrates, through a prototype, the viability of implementing efficient and authentically realistic cyber training solutions applicable to both military and private sector contexts.

Delivering equitable cybersecurity training across multiple campuses?hether for local or remote students?ntroduces significant logistical and financial hurdles, as traditional lab setups require duplicated, isolated hardware networks at each location, escalating maintenance costs and coordination complexity. While single-campus labs can segregate machines via firewalls or physical isolation, scaling this model geographically demands prohibitive investments in infrastructure and IT support, making cloud-based virtual labs a cost-effective alternative that preserves uniformity, accessibility, and security for distributed learners.

The collaboration between cybersecurity educational institutions and industry has been researched before. However, to the best of our knowledge, most universities have not yet implemented an active collaboration with the industrial sector. Although the global cybersecurity workforce shortage was estimated to be 4 million in 2023, there is no concrete plan to fill this gap. Moreover, some surveys suggest that the cybersecurity graduates from universities may not hold the skills that industry requires.

Fast spinning reserve includes power that can be delivered
within a few seconds after a large frequency fall is detected. The
remaining spinning reserve is slow and though it can be useful
for reducing power deficit is not quick enough to have influence
on the value of reached minimum frequency. It is assumed that
an amount of fast spinning reserve affected by reserve factor
“ ” is equivalent to an amount of load-shedding in its effect
on system response. Equation (1) represents a simplified form of
imposing a dynamic condition in which Em is a growing function of fmin, the minimum frequency reached by a generating
unit in area m when a sudden large loss of generation occurs in
the system. The requirement of a minimum value of Em avoids
that low frequency transients may trip other units by low frequency protection and thus produce a cascading effect that leads
to system collapse.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: The updated NIST Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF, 2018) provides a quantitative and measurable guide for organizations to integrate cybersecurity activities into their risk management processes. It offers common, consistent, and comparable guidelines applicable to any organization, helping to assess cybersecurity capability progress and hygiene. However, while the CSF is valuable for structuring cybersecurity efforts, it does not serve as a dedicated cybersecurity incident playbook.

A well-designed reserve policy must consider the impact of various factors on system frequency to ensure secure dispatching. Typically, the load-frequency sensitivity factor (LFSF) is used to assess how the network responds to contingencies [3]. Some revised reserve scheduling methods for isolated power systems incorporate both the LFSF and FBRCs to enhance system stability [4], [5].
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text:
We implement our scheme for audio watermarking in the time domain using a jazz music clip sampled at 44.1 kHz with 16-bit resolution. In our experiments, we use four independently generated random noise signals as reference watermarks. These signals are shaped in the DFT domain to match the magnitude spectrum of the cover audio, ensuring they remain inaudible while maximizing detectable energy.
The private keys consist of 1000 m-sequences, each 1023 in length, as detailed in Section II. We segment the audio sequence into frames of a specified length. Within each frame, we embed an embedding watermark using a scaling factor to maintain inaudibility. The same embedding watermark is applied to each set of 32 successive frames. The marked audio signal is then subjected to 96-kb/s MP3 compression and decompression to simulate attacks.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: One of the widely cited image digest function/authentication scheme is SARI, proposed by Lin and Chang [1]. The SARI authentication scheme contains an image digest function which generates hash bits that are invariant to JPEG compression. That is, the hash bits do not change if the image is JPEG compressed but do change for any other significant or malicious operation. In this paper, we show that the image digest component of the SARI authentication system is not secure enough. That is, if an attacker has image digests for a multiple number of images where the same secret key has been used to construct the digest, then he or she can cause arbitrary images to be authenticated. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we briefly review the image digest computation component of SARI. Then, in Section III, we describe our attack and give pos sible solutions that can prevent our attack in Section IV.
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: During the user verification process, the user and the authentication server generate a session key, which is used to encrypt all files transmitted to the storage device via the USB interface. Consequently, all files stored on the USB storage device are encrypted. Once the files are encrypted and transmitted, USB access is restricted until the next successful verification. To decrypt the files later, users must undergo the same verification procedure and obtain the same session key to access the original files. This session key is unique to each filename and user identity, meaning different users or files generate different keys. Additionally, the system deletes the session key temporarily stored on the user end after encryption/decryption, ensuring key independence and system security.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: In summary, developing effective cybersecurity training materials presents significant challenges due to the vast range of environments instructors must address?panning small businesses, large corporations, and government infrastructure. While creating simple technical checklists might seem appealing, this approach fundamentally fails to achieve the desired outcomes. Though topics like secure remote access, patch management, change control processes, and physical-cybersecurity integration lend themselves to checklist formats, such approaches rarely catalyze the behavioral changes necessary for improved cybersecurity responsiveness. Our research indicates that immersive learning experiences through simulations and practical activities play a crucial role in enhancing applied learning performance and developing the adaptive security mindset required in today's threat landscape.

The rapid advancement of the computer and information industry in recent years has led to the development of numerous peripheral devices that can be connected to business computer terminals. Among these, the USB port has become a standard feature in modern computer hardware due to its ease of use and convenience. Its primary advantage lies in providing a single interface for connecting various devices, including hard drives, flash drives, printers, keyboards, and PDAs
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text:
Equation (3) is used to assess the deviation of the incentive rate for the 
i
ith Interruptible Load Group (ILG). As depicted in Figure 1, the weighted function value approaches one when the incentive rate of the 
i
ith ILG is close to the average incentive rate of all ILGs. If the incentive rate of an ILG exceeds the average, the weighted function increases the objective function, reducing the likelihood of that ILG being interrupted. Conversely, if the incentive rate is below the average, the weighted function decreases the objective function, making the ILG more likely to be interrupted.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: The Demand-Side Management System (DSS) can be applied in two scenarios. In the first scenario, the utility has surplus power capacity but offers customers interruptible tariffs to reduce power demand during peak periods, aiming to lower operational costs. The objectives here are to minimize the utility’s generation costs and maximize customer benefits simultaneously [11]. In the second scenario, the focus is on maintaining system reliability and minimizing the disruption caused by load interruptions when the system or substation faces capacity shortages. Load interruption is an effective solution due to the significant and efficient impact of load management. However, customer participation requires adherence to two principles: ensuring customer satisfaction and maintaining system security. The mathematical model for this problem is formulated as follows.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

Text: The mapping procedure incorporates all security controls specified within ISO/IEC 27001:2022. Each control undergoes comprehensive examination and evaluation, followed by the application of the teleological interpretation method to ascertain the presence of corresponding controls in the comparative standards. Where a security control comprises multiple sub-controls (Figure 3), these are also included in the mapping process. Due to the extensive quantity of security controls within each analyzed standard, the mapping tables provided in Appendix IX (Tables 5 and 6) exclusively present controls demonstrating alignment between the standards. Controls lacking corresponding entries are omitted from these tables.

Random number generators (RNGs) that utilize white noise, such as thermal noise or the shot noise in silicon devices, are already available commercially [1]. While these RNGs can produce high-quality random numbers, their large size makes them unsuitable for mobile devices. This is because thermal noise is inherently weak, requiring significant amplification of the noise signal. On the other hand, small-amplification RNGs using the dual-oscillator technique have also been proposed [2], [3]. However, these RNGs produce random numbers with bit-to-bit correlation, necessitating post-processing, which results in an unstable bit rate.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: By establishing a unified framework for curriculum design, showcasing best-practice models, and developing a practical software tool for program development, this initiative aims to enhance the creation of new cybersecurity study programs at universities and training institutions. Emphasizing the interdisciplinary nature of cybersecurity, the approach seeks to ensure that new programs adhere to standardized methodologies and align with the real-world requirements of specific cybersecurity roles, ultimately improving the quality and relevance of cybersecurity education.

This correspondence presents a systematic analysis of the brute force break-ins directed against our palmprint system. Using Competitive Code as the features and angular distance as the matching scheme, we set up a projected multinomial distribution to describe
the relationship between the probability of the false acceptance and
the number of attacks. According to our analysis, when the system
threshold is set to lower than 0.39, it is computationally infeasible to
break into our palmprint system using brute-force attacks.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: The second part of the assessment involved an applied lab where participants were tasked with scanning systems, log files, routers, and firewalls to identify and remediate ten major vulnerabilities in a web application. This hands-on experience allowed students to engage in real-world cybersecurity practices, earning a total of 500 points for the assessment, which included T-shirts and coffee mugs as incentives, though these points did not contribute to their overall grades. The lab accounted for half of the performance scores, with the other half derived from case studies. This structure emphasized practical learning and skill development in vulnerability detection and remediation, encouraging participants to apply their knowledge in a meaningful context while fostering engagement without the pressure of grading.

This paper introduces a fundamental mathematical framework for the hybrid market and presents a feasibility simulation. Section II-A outlines our approach along with its key assumptions, while Section II-B details a single iteration of the trading process. In Section III-A, we visually demonstrate the general characteristics of the trading process using a sample network topology where five out of ten lines are constrained. Section III-C explores the overall trends observed after testing our method on 102 different network topologies. Finally, in Section IV, we summarize our findings and discuss potential directions for future research.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: The rapid advancement of information and communication technologies, particularly the Internet, has significantly benefited organizations and society by enabling communication, networking, knowledge sharing, and social interaction?ey factors in human development. However, this progress comes with challenges. The growing reliance on third-party and cloud-based data storage makes it increasingly difficult for organizations to ensure complete security for their information systems, exposing them to potential cyber risks.

The next section provides a brief background on how Artificial Intelligence (AI) is utilized in addressing cybersecurity issues, followed by a discussion of existing related works and the current knowledge gap. The methodology for conducting the study, along with findings, discussions, and conclusions, will also be presented to help researchers identify the most efficient techniques and their impact on cyberspace security. While there is a general perception among information security (InfoSec) and cybersecurity (CyberSec) researchers and practitioners that AI has improved organizational information security, these claims remain largely speculative and lack empirical substantiation. Most existing studies either demonstrate how their innovations outperform selected existing methods or survey a sample of systems to assess performance comparisons, often introducing significant selection biases. Therefore, there is a pressing need for aggregated literature that summarizes issues, challenges, and future research directions within the domain of AI applications in cybersecurity. This systematic review aims to fill that gap by analyzing the current state of AI techniques used to combat cyber-attacks, highlighting both advancements and limitations in this rapidly evolving field.

IoT and cyber-physical systems (CPS) rely on various sensors to monitor and support their functions, but these sensors are highly vulnerable to attacks. Adversaries can exploit these weaknesses to create security and safety threats, potentially disrupting critical operations. Even essential sensors like GPS signals, LiDAR signals, and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data can be compromised, leading to severe consequences for the devices and the overall system. Such attacks can manipulate location data, distort environmental sensing, or interfere with navigation, emphasizing the need for enhanced security mechanisms to safeguard these sensor-driven technologies.

While existing research has explored academia-industry partnerships in cybersecurity education, most universities have yet to establish active collaborations with industry stakeholders?espite a staggering global shortage of 4 million cybersecurity professionals in 2023. This disconnect persists alongside growing concerns that academic programs are failing to equip graduates with the practical, up-to-date skills demanded by employers, exacerbating the workforce crisis. The absence of systemic collaboration frameworks and standardized competency alignment (e.g., with NICE Framework specifications) has created a paradoxical situation where both unfilled jobs and underprepared graduates coexist, highlighting the urgent need for: (1) co-developed curricula integrating real-world threat scenarios, (2) mandated industry residencies/practicums, and (3) continuous feedback loops between employers and educators to dynamically adapt training to evolving attack landscapes. Without such structural reforms, the cybersecurity skills gap will continue widening as threats outpace talent development.

The third approach to detecting these malicious sites is
the use of artificial intelligence (AI) approaches, including machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL).
These approaches have been widely applied in different
fields, including cybersecurity, healthcare, medical imaging
analysis, e-commerce, and social media. Particularly in the

and they are frequently used to detect malicious sites
Journal Name:
Detecting Malicious URLs Using Machine Learning
Techniques: Review and Research Directions

Text: Generation facilities classified as Reliability Must-Run (RMR) units are required to operate under a must-run agreement. This agreement impacts tariff structures, dispatch strategies, and the ability of these units to engage in competitive market processes [1]?3]. Incorrect selection of RMR units or improper determination of RMR capacity can either compromise system security or impose financial strain on the ISO or generators. The proposed approach in this paper establishes a method to determine the appropriate amount of generation capacity designated as RMR while enabling these units to sell surplus capacity back to the system. This framework provides the ISO with flexibility in selecting RMR units and capacity levels to maintain system security while allowing Independent Power Producers (IPPs) to continue market participation.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: In the developing Digital Manufacturing (DM) landscape, the timeliness of information is crucial for lean production, quality assurance, and productivity enhancement. Digitization enables communication channels across vendors and Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs), and between machines and processes within a Manufacturing Small and Medium-sized Enterprise (MSE). DM necessitates the integration of cyber resources, encompassing computing and communications, with physical resources within the manufacturing process and supply chain. Continuous data streaming from sensors located throughout the manufacturing plant, including individual machines and machine networks, facilitates data-driven decision-making, informing design modifications, calibrating manufacturing methodologies, and programming robot tasks and navigation paths. Securing this distributed and interconnected cyber-physical system against cyberattacks mandates the development of novel approaches tailored to the specific threats encountered by these systems. Cyberattacks may encompass sabotage of product quality, intellectual property theft, and ransomware. The attack surface, threat vectors, and corresponding solutions require comprehensive analysis to enable a secure, resilient, and scalable next-generation DM.

The widespread proliferation of the Internet is bolstering
the development of a cyber society, in which diverse
communications, including the sharing of private information
and business transactions, are taking place. Nevertheless, it has
also increased the number of cyber threats and diversified their
targets and objectives [1, 2]. The targets range from individuals
to private companies and even critical infrastructures such
as nuclear power plants, whereas the objectives range from
monetary benefit to political actions [3]. Accordingly, the need
for cybersecurity operations is increasing in order to mitigate
these threats.
Journal Name:
Reference Ontology for Cybersecurity
Operational Information

Text: One approach to minimizing design complexity and bridging the gap between advancements in manufacturing technology and those in synthesis and compiler technology is the reuse of pre-developed Intellectual Property (IP). These IP blocks serve as fundamental components for designers. However, designing such heterogeneous systems presents challenges, particularly in the need for synthesis and compilation tools that can effectively utilize the vast array of available resources.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: Organizational ambidexterity, by its inherent definition, necessitates the concurrent execution of two distinct activities, specifically the maintenance of equilibrium between exploratory and exploitative endeavors. This underscores the capacity of organizations to leverage their established competencies while concurrently pursuing novel opportunities. Within the domain of ambidextrous cybersecurity, the realization of two objectives is imperative: the safeguarding of data, systems, and networks, and the facilitation of the expeditious integration of new technologies within the organizational framework.

These Delphi processes lay a foundation necessary for
developing educational cybersecurity assessment tools that
will provide rigorous evidence-based infrastructure to advise
educators about effective ways to engage, inform, educate, nurture, and retain cybersecurity students, as well as effective
ways to structure cybersecurity curricula to prepare 
professionals for careers in this field [6]. The numerical ratings from
these Delphi processes provide a resource for prioritizing concepts and content in developing curricula, learning exercises,
and other educational materials and policies.
Journal Name:
Identifying Core Concepts of Cybersecurity:
Results of Two Delphi Processes

Text: The aviation sector's growing reliance on digital, space-based systems?eplacing legacy analog infrastructure?as amplified cybersecurity risks, particularly as open-design architectures and rising air traffic density expose vulnerabilities in critical systems like air-ground communications and satellite navigation. This paper introduces a systematic risk assessment framework (qualitative and quantitative) to evaluate threats across aviation subsystems?ncluding voice/data communications, navigation aids (e.g., satellite-based vs. ground-based), surveillance (e.g., ADS-B vs. secondary radar), and SWIM?evealing that highest-risk vulnerabilities reside in VHF voice comms, satellite navigation, and ADS-B, while lower risks align with data-link comms and traditional radar systems. By prioritizing mitigations for legacy and next-gen infrastructure, this methodology addresses a critical gap in aviation cybersecurity literature, which has lacked holistic, actionable risk evaluation tools to balance safety and operational continuity against evolving cyber-physical threats.

A significant number of studies utilize "risk" as a metric to represent the outputs of assessment techniques, typically combining the likelihood of hazardous events and the severity of their consequences. Traditional Risk Priority Number (RPN), used in studies,,, and, is based on effect severity, occurrence probability, and detection difficulty, with study extending it to include risk interactions. Study improves objectivity and accuracy using fuzzy confidence interval numbers (FCIN), generalized trapezoidal fuzzy numbers (GTrFN), and sensitivity analysis. Study computes risk by considering hazard severity, exposure, and controllability, while study separately addresses fairness risk alongside safety risk. Assurance risks are emphasized in study, whereas study calculates risk based on vulnerabilities' impact and likelihood. Study incorporates attack cost, difficulty, and detection possibilities into its risk assessment model. These approaches demonstrate diverse methodologies tailored to specific contexts for comprehensive risk evaluation.

System dispatch with spinning reserves impacts deliverable energy and represents a steady-state cost. In contrast, load-shedding costs are primarily borne by customers and occur only during emergencies when loads are disconnected.
However, efforts to reduce these costs can affect system reliability, leading to greater economic losses for both generator companies and users. The extent of these impacts depends on market regulations, interruption cost dynamics, and commercial agreements.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text:
Critical infrastructure has become a focal point of cyberattacks, as previously isolated
operational technology networks that were once perceived to be air-gapped are becoming Internet-exposed
through increased connectivity with informational technology networks. Recent adversarial tendencies have
led to an increase in targeted cyberattacks against both industrial control systems (ICS) and building
automation systems. Furthermore, the insufficient supply of a cyber workforce exacerbates the challenges
for organizations to defend their systems. Game-based learning is gaining traction and studies have shown
that it is an effective educational element. Training facility operators responsible for critical services can
be achieved through gamification of security policies and controls. The Network Defense Training Game
(NDTG) is a cybersecurity training platform that encompasses a series of cybersecurity events that the player
must assess and react to throughout the scenario to defend the network by thwarting the adversary?s attack.
The NDTG uses scenario narratives based on historical cyber incidents that affect ICS. It is designed to train
facility owners and operators to evaluate their cybersecurity posture and to apply cybersecurity frameworks
before and during the process of addressing cyber events and incidents. This study provides a detailed
technical overview and design architecture of NDTG and demonstrates its capability in advancing the ICS
cybersecurity workforce
Journal Name:
Gamification of Cybersecurity for Workforce
Development in Critical Infrastructure

Text: The escalating global demand for cybersecurity professionals has prompted standards bodies and governments to actively monitor workforce requirements and develop targeted competency frameworks. These efforts have yielded standardized work role taxonomies and detailed workforce gap analyses, which we systematically review here to identify: (1) evolving skill requirements across security domains, (2) credentialing approaches for specialized roles, and (3) policy interventions addressing the talent shortage?roviding a foundation for aligning educational outputs with industry needs through evidence-based curriculum development.

In an era of evolving cybersecurity threats, organizations must adopt robust security frameworks to safeguard their digital assets. This research presents a novel approach to integrating the National Cybersecurity Authority? Essential Cybersecurity Controls with the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework, bridging the gap between regulatory compliance and practical workforce deployment. By systematically mapping workforce tasks to required controls, organizations can enhance their cybersecurity strategies while ensuring regulatory adherence. A key contribution of this study is an optimization model that determines the most effective job roles needed to fully meet cybersecurity controls, leveraging algorithms to enhance cost-efficiency and operational effectiveness. The results highlight the strategic importance of specific job roles in fulfilling multiple cybersecurity requirements, providing a foundation for future research on workforce optimization. This framework serves as a scalable model for organizations looking to align their cybersecurity workforce with regulatory mandates efficiently.

Figure 4 presents eye diagrams illustrating the recovered messages using chaos modulation (CM) with a 5% signal amplitude. The top-left panel displays results obtained with a closed-loop authorized receiver, which successfully recovers the message with high accuracy. In contrast, the bottom-left panel shows results from an open-loop receiver, where the message quality is significantly degraded. The right side of the figure shows eye diagrams obtained after applying a basic linear filtering process to PT(t). When using a 5% message amplitude (top), the filtering is unable to extract the encoded message. However, when the amplitude increases to 7.5% (bottom), the message becomes detectable, revealing that the information is not sufficiently concealed within the chaotic carrier.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: In recent years, cybersecurity researchers have increasingly turned to Artificial Intelligence (AI) to bolster defenses against sophisticated cyber threats, while cybercriminals exploit AI to enhance their attack strategies. AI-based cybersecurity solutions offer several advantages in combating these threats, including improved threat intelligence through real-time data analysis, which allows organizations to anticipate and mitigate potential attacks before they occur. Additionally, AI enhances incident response times by automating threat detection and mitigation processes, thereby reducing the time from identification to action and limiting the impact of breaches. AI's ability to identify vulnerabilities and predict breach risks further strengthens security measures by enabling proactive resource allocation towards the most critical areas. However, the effectiveness of these solutions depends on the quality of data and the algorithms used, highlighting the need for continuous improvement in AI techniques. Future research opportunities in this field include developing more robust AI models that can adapt to emerging threats across various application domains, ultimately enhancing overall cybersecurity resilience.

Cybersecurity threats are becoming more sophisticated, challenging traditional security mechanisms. Integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) with cybersecurity enhances threat detection, analysis, and mitigation, but centralized AI systems introduce vulnerabilities and single points of failure. Blockchain technology, with its decentralized and immutable ledger, offers a promising solution to enhance data security and integrity, reducing risks associated with centralized architectures.

In our system, it is crucial to ensure that the low-pass filter, gain, and nonlinear element components are matched between the transmitter and receiver circuits to achieve chaos synchronization, as described in [13]. Although the system includes digital elements, the transmitted signal remains analog. Therefore, the physical implementation incorporates an amplifier and DC offset (not shown) to compensate for gain and offset errors in the receiver's ADC. These parameters are adjusted to minimize the subtracted (error) signal. Ideally, the transmitting and receiving systems should produce identical waveforms, resulting in zero synchronization error. However, in practice, imperfect matching between the systems and noise will lead to measurable synchronization errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

While previous research have greatly advanced our understanding of security standards adoption and implementation.

compliance efforts. Through the identification of similarities between standards, organizations can eliminate redundant work and simplify the compliance process. This, will
reduce both the implementation time and the cost associated
with meeting the full set of standards. The objective of this
research is to provide a comprehensive evaluation of widely

A Comparative Analysis of Industrial

Although DIS and HLA provide architectures and middlewares suitable for military training and exercises, they
are barely adoptable for cybersecurity simulations. The middlewares of DIS and HLA are designed to support data
exchanges between heterogeneous LVC simulation models
and entities, however, in general simulation for military training and exercises, the levels of fidelity coherently correspond
to the ones of abstraction, which are categorized as four levels: campaign, mission, engagement, and engineering. This
means that most of events occur in each model, and the middleware only mediates the interactions between them. On the
other hand, in the majority of cybersecurity simulation, levels
of fidelity do not correspond to the ones of abstraction, which
makes heavy weather of LVC interoperability - the different
levels of fidelity are evenly used for cybersecurity simulation
models, but the level of abstraction is limited to the engineering level in most cases. To achieve LVC interoperability in
cybersecurity simulation, we will need to address frequent,
atomic data exchange between the most complicated models
while processing all the engineering-level events occurring in
each model.
Journal Name:
Cy-Through: Toward a Cybersecurity Simulation
for Supporting Live, Virtual, and Constructive
Interoperability

Text: Impulsive control systems have various real-world applications. Three common examples include an insect population control system, where state variables represent insect numbers and their natural predators, a chemical reactor system in which state variables track the quantities of different chemicals, and a financial system with state variables representing market money supply and central bank savings rates [1]. Additional practical applications can be found in [2] and [3].
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: Primary Surveillance Radar (PSR) employs a methodology that determines target azimuth and slant range without relying on data embedded within the transmitted signal, thereby precluding the use of conventional software-defined radio (SDR) transmitters for message injection or modification [19], [20]; furthermore, the substantial power of the transmitted signal renders PSR highly resistant to jamming attempts [58]; while PSR remains susceptible to jamming attacks utilizing exceptionally high transmission power, the requisite sophisticated equipment is predominantly accessible to military entities, thus resulting in a less detailed examination of PSR cybersecurity within this study.

Text: With advancements in internet connectivity, wireless communication, smart devices, and sensor network technologies, an increasing number of network-based objects are becoming integral to IoT cybersecurity. These innovations are also driving significant transformations in new information and communication technologies (ICT) and Industry 4.0. IoT cybersecurity spans a global infrastructure of heterogeneous smart devices that integrate sensory, communication, networking, and information processing technologies. Additionally, various other technologies, including barcodes, smartphones, social networks, and cloud computing, influence IoT security by introducing new vulnerabilities and risks that must be addressed for a secure and resilient IoT ecosystem.

The primary goal of regulatory must-run units is to ensure "fair" competition in a deregulated market. Hydro power plants are a prime example of such units. These plants are typically multipurpose, designed for both power generation and irrigation. Allowing a hydro power plant to compete in the market could undermine its agricultural purpose. Additionally, hydro power plants have very low or no fuel costs, making it potentially unfair for them to compete in a scheduling market unless suitable market rules are established.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: Generation units in the Thailand power system become unavailable for the competitive market if they are previously qualified as regulatory must-run or must-take units. Consequently, these units must dispatch electricity to the system according to their contracts and are excluded from the RMR units study. Information on hydro power plants in the Thailand power system, both those connected to the power grid and local units, is shown in Table I. Other must-take units are listed in Table II.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: Cybersecurity education and training are vital for creating a secure and privacy-friendly digital environment, with both professionals and the general public recognizing the necessity for high-quality university programs and professional training courses. Despite this acknowledgment, there remains a significant gap in practical tools, guidelines, and examples that can assist institutions in designing effective cybersecurity curricula. Specifically, a comprehensive method to identify the skills required for various cybersecurity roles in the job market is lacking. This paper aims to address this gap by providing practical tools and strategies to help higher education providers develop robust cybersecurity programs. Initially, it analyzes the content of 89 existing study programs worldwide and gathers recommendations from esteemed institutions both within and outside the EU. The research culminates in the creation of the SPARTA Cybersecurity Skills Framework, which establishes a crucial link between job roles and the necessary expertise, guiding curriculum development that aligns with market demands. Additionally, a dynamic web application called Education Map is introduced to aid education and training providers in designing new programs and evaluating existing ones based on the requirements of cybersecurity work roles. By leveraging these insights, institutions can enhance their educational offerings, ensuring that graduates are well-equipped to meet the evolving challenges of the cybersecurity landscape.

Different system characteristics, whether involving long or short lines, do not alter the previous conclusions. Regarding the BPA system, its ability to maintain voltage near the maximum during heavy loads with minimal generator support indicates that it has a surplus of capacitors. The primary risk in this setup is controlling over-voltage. In Italy, the policy focuses on reducing the cost of capacitor banks and their maintenance, as frequent switching shortens their lifespan. Instead, there is an emphasis on fully controlling all available reactive power resources, primarily those already provided by generators. This approach economically recognizes the generators' contribution to Voltage Ancillary Services.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: Adopting a single-sourcing strategy often forces organizations to significantly modify their existing business processes, policies, and routines to align with the vendor's system, requiring substantial reengineering efforts and the implementation of new operational standards [7]. This transition period introduces cybersecurity risks, as process redesign can expose vulnerabilities that malicious actors may exploit, while employees adapting to unfamiliar systems may inadvertently commit security errors. In contrast, a best-of-breed (BoB) approach allows organizations to select specialized vendors whose systems better match current workflows, minimizing disruptive changes and reducing associated security risks [6]. The inherent flexibility of BoB strategies thus provides both operational and security advantages over the rigid, transformation-heavy nature of single-sourcing implementations.
