With this approach, the characteristics of individual DRfor congestion management can be easily classified.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: A primary challenge encountered in contemporary cybersecurity datasets is the sheer volume of data, necessitating the implementation of intelligent algorithms, specifically machine learning algorithms, for the extraction of pertinent information. Within the context of Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS), the application of these algorithms involves the processing of a substantial quantity of features, with the aim of identifying the most effective approach for attack detection. This challenge is significant due to the phenomenon wherein an excessive number of characteristics within a dataset can induce model overfitting, thereby resulting in suboptimal performance on validation datasets [3].

The comparative test data from this experiment is presented in Fig. 4. As shown in the figure, the background vibration detected by the new position sensor in our research laboratory ("hybrid SM-3"), which was securely fastened to the tiled floor of the experimental room on the second floor, is approximately 400 Hz. This corresponds to a mechanical vibration amplitude of 40 nm [3]. Additionally, Fig. 4(a) indicates that background vibrations in the research building are nearly four times higher on working days compared to weekends and nights. However, even nighttime vibrations are 50?100 times greater than the noise level of the test oscillator, which, as seen in Fig. 4(b), is around 1?2 Hz.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: Passive attacks involve no active interference with the connection; instead, the adversary simply listens to transmitted packets. The intercepted information can be analyzed and often subjected to cryptanalysis to uncover secret data. While the most severe outcome could be the deduction of the secret key, most passive attacks focus on revealing plaintexts or gathering information for future actions.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: This paper presents a mapping study on safety and cybersecurity assessment techniques used in critical industries such as nuclear power plants, oil and gas, autonomous vehicles, and railways, with a focus on instrumentation and control (I&C) systems. Modern I&C systems, consisting of thousands of components, pose significant challenges in terms of reliability and safety, especially in critical applications. With the rise of Industry 4.0 technologies, these systems are increasingly interconnected with public networks and the Internet, leading to new cybersecurity and safety concerns. The study formulates research questions and analyzes recent literature, initially identifying 320 records from 2018 to 2022, of which 187 were reviewed for eligibility, ultimately including 49 papers based on predefined criteria. The findings help systematize existing assessment techniques and identify emerging trends. While many techniques have been in use for decades, the study highlights new developments, particularly the potential of a unified safety and cybersecurity assessment approach, which presents a promising avenue for future research.

The exponential growth of IoT devices?rom 4.9 billion in 2015 to a projected 25 billion by 2020?emonstrates unprecedented flexibility and scalability, yet simultaneously amplifies cybersecurity risks as each connected device (projected at 6.58 per person by 2020) becomes a potential attack vector in global infrastructure. This heterogeneous ecosystem spans computers, smartphones, RFID-enabled sensors, and autonomous decision-making systems, all of which introduce vulnerabilities through diverse communication interfaces, operating systems, and preloaded applications. While these intelligent devices enable real-time data dissemination and automated actions, their rapid proliferation outpaces security protocols, transforming them into weak points susceptible to exploitation. Consequently, robust IoT cybersecurity infrastructure must prioritize secure device maintenance, user education, and standardized protections across this expansive attack surface to safeguard against escalating threats to both individual users and networked systems. The breadth of IoT components?rom hardware to lightweight services?emands integrated security frameworks that address vulnerabilities inherent in their interconnectivity and autonomous functionalities.

Biometrics can be further divided into two subtypes: physical and behavioral. Physical biometrics are based on body features, while behavioral biometrics are based on learned gestures, such as signatures. This paper suggests a more precise classification for biometric signals: stable and alterable. Stable signals are relatively constant and unchanging, whereas alterable signals are derived from an underlying stable biometric combined with a variable.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: An effective reserve policy should consider how all these factors influence system frequency to ensure secure dispatch. Typically, the load-frequency sensitivity factor (LFSF) is employed to assess network behavior following contingencies [3]. Some modified reserve scheduling approaches for isolated power systems have incorporated both the system's LFSF and the Frequency Bias Regulation Coefficients (FBRCs) [4], [5].
Journal Name: Role and Value of Pumped Storage Units in an Ancillary Services Market for Isolated Power Systems—Simulation in the Taiwan Power System

Text: The development of standardized, globally accepted information-sharing formats?stablished as industry specifications or international standards?ddresses critical cybersecurity challenges by enhancing cross-organizational collaboration and operational efficiency. These formats mitigate global disparities in threat intelligence access, enabling developing nations to bridge resource gaps through structured knowledge exchange and coordinated countermeasures, fostering equitable cybersecurity partnerships. Additionally, by transforming unstructured data into machine-readable formats, they automate and optimize traditionally manual processes, improving the speed and accuracy of threat response while reducing human error, as highlighted in [4]. This dual benefit of inclusivity and operational streamlining underscores the transformative potential of unified cybersecurity frameworks in a digitally interconnected landscape.

One of the most fundamental attacks involves analyzing encrypted packets, where the adversary seeks to extract information solely from ciphertexts. A secure cryptographic system must prevent the disclosure of any unauthorized information, including plaintext, keys, or statistical data. Furthermore, it should ensure that an attacker cannot determine whether an encrypted packet corresponds to a specific plaintext. This is particularly critical in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), where the limited domain of values can make it easier for attackers to deduce plaintexts through such analysis.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: The introduction of the Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC) serves to establish a standardized cybersecurity foundation, applicable across governmental bodies, critical sectors, and digital service providers, these controls are meticulously designed to mitigate a diverse array of cyber risks and vulnerabilities, ensuring organizational resilience and effective response capabilities in the face of cyber incidents.

The Automated Android Malware Detection using Optimal Ensemble Learning Approach for Cybersecurity (AAMD-OELAC) technique is introduced as a novel solution for detecting Android malware. This technique incorporates data preprocessing at the initial stage, followed by an ensemble learning process that utilizes three machine learning models: Least Square Support Vector Machine (LS-SVM), kernel extreme learning machine (KELM), and Regularized random vector functional link neural network (RRVFLN). Additionally, the technique employs the hunter-prey optimization (HPO) algorithm for optimal hyperparameter tuning of these models, significantly enhancing malware detection accuracy. To the best of our knowledge, the AAMD-OELAC technique has not been previously documented in the literature. Comprehensive experimental analyses demonstrate its superiority over existing methods, showcasing its effectiveness in addressing the challenges posed by evolving malware threats in Android applications.

We possess the capability to modulate the digital time-delay element. Published decryption algorithms utilize average mutual information (AMI) measurements to identify time delay from chaotic waveforms [16]. Modulating the time delay undermines the ability to determine a fixed value for time delay and other system parameters [20]. We have implemented a system in which the time delay alternates between 60 and 45 seconds every 10 seconds within the Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA). The rationale for this approach is elaborated in Section V.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text:
Cyberwarfare can occur at any moment, anywhere on the planet, and it happens more often
than we realize. The new form of warfare is wreaking havoc on not only the military but also on every
aspect of our daily lives. Since cybersecurity has only recently established itself as a critical element of the
military, the military community relies heavily on the private sector to ensure cyber mission assurance. Given
the military?s secrecy, such reliance may increase the danger of mission degradation or failure. To address
this issue, the military has attempted to build a dedicated cybersecurity training system for the purpose
of internalizing cybersecurity training. However, existing cybersecurity training systems frequently lack
comprehensive support for effective and efficient cybersecurity training. In this study, we propose ICSTASY,
a scenario-based, interactive, and immersive cybersecurity training platform that supports a variety of
training features holistically. The primary requirements and design principles required to overcome the
challenges inherent in developing a cyber training system were offered based on a review of prior work.
Through the demonstration of our prototype, we have proven the feasibility of efficient and truly realistic
cyber training, not only for the military environment but also for the private sector.
Journal Name:
ICSTASY: An Integrated Cybersecurity Training
System for Military Personnel

Text:
The ACARS is a character-based data link described in
ARINC standard 618. It is used to provide data link
communication between aircraft and aircraft operators
via service providers subscribing to the aircraft operator.
It uses the American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) character set and functions in a manner
similar to that of the Short Message Service (SMS) [38].
Examples of data services provided by the ACARS include
weather information, flight plans, and information on the
performance of aircraft components such as engines [39].
Furthermore, the flight crew can use the ACARS for communication with the aircraft flight operation center and the ATC.
The ACARS uses three different types of data links, depending on the aircraft equipment and required coverage: plain
old VHF or VHF data link (VDL) [40], SATCOM (Inmarsat,
Iridium), and a high-frequency data link (HFDL). Typically,
VHF is used for populated land areas, SATCOM extends coverage to oceanic areas, and HF provides coverage worldwide.
The ACARS message content is structured according to the
ARINC 620-8 standard [33].
Journal Name:
Studying Cybersecurity in Civil Aviation,
Including Developing and Applying Aviation
Cybersecurity Risk Assessment

Text: The way power suppliers strategically operate in the market at a given time step (k) is influenced by various factors, including demand elasticity, remaining system demand, transmission and generation reliability indexes, fuel costs, and the market clearing price—all of which are inherently unpredictable. If market participants act rationally, they will follow the energy market operator’s guidelines to protect themselves from price fluctuations and financial losses. For example, they may aim to place bids or offers within 10% of the previous trading period’s clearing price to maximize their chances of securing a deal [11]. Research is ongoing to mathematically model the strategic bidding behaviors of market participants [9], [10].
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text: We introduce our system, which utilizes a palmprint-identification algorithm known as Competitive Code [19]. We chose to analyze Competitive Code in the context of brute-force attacks, rather than other palmprint-verification algorithms [13], [14], [21], because it is the most accurate and computationally fastest algorithm developed by Zhang and his team. The version of Competitive Code used in this correspondence has been modified to reissue new templates when the original templates are compromised. In other words, the new Competitive Code offers a cancelable palmprint representation [4], [5], [7].
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: We present a system that utilizes the Competitive Code palmprint-identification algorithm. We focus on analyzing Competitive Code in the context of brute-force attacks, rather than other palmprint verification algorithms, because it is the most accurate and computationally efficient algorithm developed by Zhang and his team. The version of Competitive Code used here has been modified to allow for the issuance of new templates if the original ones are compromised, providing a cancelable palmprint representation.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

the identical embedding watermark for each set of successive
32 frames. The marked audio signal goes through the 96-kb/s
MP3 compression/decompression as an example of attacks.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: As energy demand continues to rise, Distributed Resources (DRs), which include distributed generation and energy storage systems, are becoming more prevalent in the industry. These resources are being integrated into distribution and sub-transmission networks to help meet load requirements. Projections indicate that DRs will contribute to 25% of the anticipated load growth over the next decade in North America [5]. However, in electricity markets, DRs are typically not managed by Independent System Operators (ISOs) or Distribution Companies (DISCOs), meaning ISOs may lack detailed information about individual DR units.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: Recent congestion management approaches commonly assume that energy flows in a specific direction—from generation to load via transmission systems. They also presume that loads should be served whenever possible without compromising system security. DR's will transform this traditional generation-load pattern by enabling localized load service, thereby helping to alleviate transmission congestion.
Journal Name: Identify the Impact of Distributed Resources on Congestion Management

Text: Impact analysis involves examining intrusion behaviors and evaluating the consequences of cyberattacks on SCADA systems. This process assesses the vulnerability of computer networks and power systems, potentially leading to power loss or equipment damage due to compromised SCADA cybersecurity. If an attack successfully penetrates the control center network connected to substations, it can cause significant disruptions by initiating switching actions that result in load loss. An integrated risk modeling approach has been proposed to capture both power control system vulnerabilities and their impacts on real-time power system operations. This methodology involves identifying vulnerabilities, modeling cyber threats, evaluating power system impacts, and developing mitigation strategies to prevent or minimize the effects of cyberattacks on power systems.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Cybersecurity is a critical issue that must be addressed before implementing protection systems over broadband networks. This article focuses on developing a context information-based real-time cybersecurity defense approach for a protection system within a network context. The article is organized as follows: Section II introduces the proposed methodology, Section III discusses the setup of the Probabilistic Neural Network (PNN), and Sections IV and V present the simulation results and conclusions, respectively.
Journal Name: Context Information-Based Cyber Security Defense of Protection System

Text: According to the RMR study results for the South Bangkok power plant, this unit must reserve at least 565.88 MW and 273.89 Mvar to maintain system security. The absence of this generation capacity at the specified bus could result in a thermal limit violation in the transmission system, potentially triggering a major security issue. To compete in the market, this unit should perform optimal dispatch and unit commitment within their units and sell any surplus generation capacity (beyond the RMR quantity) to the deregulated market.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text:
In the proposed protocol, users must first authenticate with an authentication server using a password to gain access to a USB port. Once authenticated, the user and server negotiate a key for encrypting and decrypting files transmitted via the USB port, ensuring both the communication channels and stored files are secure. For remote authentication, the Schnorr digital signature scheme is employed, which is efficient due to its requirement of only one modular multiplication and one modular addition. This scheme offers a shorter signature length compared to RSA and ElGamal, making it suitable for environments requiring efficiency. Specifically, Schnorr's signature length is 320 bits when using a cyclic group order of about 
  and a 160-bit hash function output, whereas RSA signatures are typically 1024 bits and ElGamal signatures are 2048 bits.
Journal Name: A Secure Control Protocol for USB Mass Storage Devices

Text: The rising digitization of society and the expanding landscape of cyber threats have led to a growing demand for cybersecurity professionals across industries and institutions. However, a significant gap persists between the skills imparted through education and those required in professional settings. To explore the factors influencing cybersecurity education in Europe, a political, economic, social, technological, legal, and environmental (PESTLE) analysis was conducted. This framework enabled the classification of key factors affecting cybersecurity education and skills development, while also allowing professionals to assess their impact at both national and European levels. Additionally, social network analysis was employed to evaluate the interconnectivity of these factors, utilizing the concept of modularity. A European-level stakeholder survey was then conducted to validate the findings. The study identified a major challenge in the lack of societal awareness of cybersecurity, alongside the absence of an EU-wide certification framework. Notably, differences in perceived challenges across countries highlighted the need for localized solutions to address the cybersecurity education gap.

Fast spinning reserve provides power within seconds of detecting a significant frequency drop, whereas slow spinning reserve, while useful for addressing power deficits, is too slow to impact the minimum frequency reached. The fast spinning reserve, influenced by a reserve factor, has an effect on system response similar to load shedding. Equation (1) simplifies a dynamic condition where increases with , the minimum frequency in area m
m following a sudden large generation loss. Ensuring a minimum prevents low-frequency transients from triggering other units' low-frequency protection, thereby avoiding a cascading effect that could lead to system collapse.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text:
It is worth mentioning that the preventive and reactive cyber
defense dynamics are particular kinds of cybersecurity
dynamics for quantifying cybersecurity from a holistic
perspective [51]?[55]. There are other kinds of cybersecurity
dynamics, which aim to accommodate adaptive defenses [45],
active defenses [56]?[58], and proactive defenses [43].
Adapting the event-based method to these kinds of dynamics
is an important open problem for future research.
Journal Name:
Using Event-Based Method to Estimate
Cybersecurity Equilibrium

Text: In this letter, we introduce a novel asymmetric watermarking system capable of accommodating multiple embedding watermarks while requiring only a single reference watermark for detection. This system is effective in preventing attacks aimed at estimating the embedding watermark. The proposed method involves randomly shifting the phase of the reference watermark (either clockwise or counterclockwise) in the discrete Fourier transform domain to create embedding watermarks. These watermarks are interrelated and maintain the same correlation with the reference watermark. Additionally, we discuss the selection of design parameters.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Learning methodologies in machine learning are broadly categorized into supervised learning and unsupervised learning. In supervised learning, the model is trained using a dataset that includes labeled examples, where each input is paired with the correct output or tag. This allows the network to learn a mapping from inputs to outputs by analyzing these pre-labeled instances. Conversely, unsupervised learning relies solely on the input data, without any pre-existing labels or tags. In this approach, the network learns to categorize the inputs based on their inherent statistical properties, identifying patterns, clusters, or anomalies within the data. Supervised learning is commonly used for tasks such as classification and regression, where the goal is to predict a specific outcome, while unsupervised learning is often employed for exploratory data analysis, clustering, and dimensionality reduction to uncover hidden structures within the data.

Fast spinning reserve refers to power that can be delivered within seconds after a significant frequency drop is detected. In contrast, the remaining spinning reserve is slower and, while useful for reducing power deficits, is not quick enough to influence the minimum frequency reached. It is assumed that an amount of fast spinning reserve, adjusted by a reserve factor, is equivalent to load shedding in its effect on system response. Equation (1) provides a simplified representation of a dynamic condition where \( E_m \) is a function of \( f_{min} \), the minimum frequency reached by a generating unit in area \( m \) during a sudden large generation loss. Ensuring a minimum value of \( E_m \) prevents low-frequency transients from tripping other units via low-frequency protection, thereby avoiding a cascading effect that could lead to system collapse.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: Designing cybersecurity laboratories requires adherence to specific features and guidelines to ensure effective learning and security. Key requirements include: (1) lab machines must have Internet connectivity for downloading necessary tools and accessing online resources, (2) they should be isolated from campus networks to prevent unauthorized access, (3) the networking environment must realistically simulate popular cybersecurity exercises, (4) the setup should facilitate easy management, allocation, and scaling of resources for varying assignment complexities, (5) adequate IT staff and technicians must be available for maintenance and troubleshooting, and (6) the lab should be distributed to ensure accessibility for both on-campus and remote students. These guidelines are essential for creating a robust educational environment that effectively prepares students for real-world cybersecurity challenges.

The aviation sector's critical reliance on safety is increasingly intertwined with the indispensable need for robust cybersecurity, a necessity underscored by the escalating frequency of cyberattacks that inflict reputational damage and instigate political and economic instability; the transition from analog ground-based air navigation systems to digital space-based architectures, driven by exponential air traffic growth, has amplified cybersecurity vulnerabilities, particularly given the prevalence of open system designs that often neglect security considerations; therefore, the establishment of a systematic methodology for aviation cybersecurity risk assessment is paramount, enabling the identification of potential threats, the quantification of their likelihood and impact, and the implementation of effective mitigation strategies to reduce risks to acceptable levels; this study presents a comprehensive qualitative and quantitative cybersecurity risk assessment methodology, specifically tailored for legacy and next-generation critical aviation infrastructure, including air-ground communication, radio navigation aids, aeronautical surveillance, and system-wide information management (SWIM), revealing that very-high frequency voice communication, satellite-based navigation, and automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast exhibit the highest risk levels, while controller-pilot data link communication, ground-based radio navigation aids, and secondary surveillance radar demonstrate the lowest, with SWIM presenting a medium risk profile.

This study presents a novel framework for optimizing cybersecurity workforce deployment by systematically aligning Saudi Arabia? Essential Cybersecurity Controls (ECC) with the Saudi Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (SCWF). By mapping SCWF job roles to ECC requirements, we developed an optimization model that identifies the most critical positions for full regulatory compliance while maximizing cost efficiency. Our analysis reveals that certain SCWF roles?uch as threat analysts and security architects?re strategically vital, as they cover the broadest range of mandated controls. The model leverages algorithmic optimization to help organizations minimize redundancies and allocate personnel effectively, ensuring both adherence to national standards and operational resilience. These findings not only enhance cybersecurity workforce planning in Saudi Arabia but also provide a scalable blueprint for other nations and enterprises to harmonize regulatory mandates with workforce capabilities. Future research can expand this approach to dynamic threat environments and evolving compliance frameworks.

Ethical hackers, or white hat hackers, are cybersecurity specialists whose primary function involves intentionally penetrating systems to identify security vulnerabilities; the distinguishing characteristic between white hat hackers and traditional cybersecurity experts lies in their respective focus: white hats prioritize vulnerability discovery, whereas traditional experts emphasize attack prevention and unauthorized access mitigation [24].

Since the 1970s, control center systems have shifted from self-contained, isolated designs to more interconnected, open architectures. With the rise of standardized communication protocols, particularly Internet Protocol (IP), power utilities are increasingly adopting internet-based communication for wide-area operations. This standardization has reduced system deployment costs and improved upgradeability. However, increased integration also creates new security weaknesses. It's well-known that connecting SCADA systems to the internet introduces vulnerabilities. The growing potential for cyber threats makes securing information exchange between power entities even more difficult. The increasing reliance on internet communications has amplified the significance and scale of the problem. Security awareness and training for personnel working with supervisory control systems are essential. Recent work has compared various security guidelines and standards to highlight crucial cybersecurity elements for SCADA systems. Research is also focusing on security interdependency modeling, including defenses against deliberate sabotage, and improving power system information architecture and communication interactions. SCADA testbeds are valuable tools for identifying cybersecurity vulnerabilities in power infrastructure. Novel approaches, such as using wireless sensor technology to assess transmission system health, are being explored. Quantitative techniques for analyzing system interdependencies and model-based attack-detection methods are also being developed.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: For our system to maintain chaos synchronization, it is necessary to match the low-pass filter, gain, and nonlinear components between the transmitter and receiver circuits, as outlined in [13]. Although digital elements are included, the transmitted signal remains analog. As a result, the system requires an amplifier and a DC offset (not shown) to correct for gain and offset discrepancies within the receiver’s ADC. These two factors are adjusted to minimize the error signal obtained from subtraction. In theory, both transmitting and receiving units should produce identical waveforms that cancel out when subtracted, resulting in zero synchronization error. However, in real-world conditions, minor mismatches between the two systems lead to measurable synchronization errors. Additionally, noise within the system further contributes to these errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: The proposed motion detection system operates on single-bit image data from selected pixels. It comprises frame latch blocks and a difference detector that analyzes the most significant bit (MSB) equivalent signal (as shown in Figure 12). Each frame latch block stores the digital image data of a chosen column line. The difference detector compares the current and previous frame data. If the difference between these frames exceeds a predefined motion detection threshold, the system registers motion.
Journal Name: A CMOS Image Sensor (CIS) Architecture with Low Power Motion Detection for Portable Security Camera Applications

Text: The landscape of cybersecurity information exchange is characterized by a diverse array of initiatives, encompassing industry specifications that delineate information schemata, cybersecurity-focused ontologies that establish semantic relationships, and guidelines that standardize vocabulary and frameworks for inter-party communication; furthermore, online cybersecurity information repositories facilitate broad information dissemination; while the presented ontology's design is independent of these specific works, they collectively provided valuable contextual insights and foundational considerations for its development, thereby informing the conceptualization and refinement of the ontological framework.

In the ERCOT market, a load resource capable of adjusting consumption in response to dispatch control, similar to Automatic Generation Control (AGC), or reacting to frequency changes like a generator governor, is referred to as Controllable Load Device (CLD) in Load Resource as Ancillary Service (LaaR). ERCOT sends generation control signals to Qualified Scheduling Entities (QSEs) based on real-time system area control errors to maintain target frequency. Each QSE self-dispatches unit outputs to meet these requirements. The same logic applies to loads that can adjust consumption based on control signals. Figure 2 illustrates a real example of CLD responding to QSE dispatch signals, showing how CLD can adjust consumption accordingly, thus helping maintain system security by following AGC and governor control.
Journal Name: Grid Security Through Load Reduction in the ERCOT Market

Text: The strategic decisions of power suppliers in the market at any given time are influenced by factors such as how sensitive demand is to price changes, the remaining electricity demand, transmission and generation reliability, fuel costs, and the market clearing price, all of which are variable. If market participants act rationally, they will follow the market operator's rules to protect themselves from price fluctuations and potential losses. For example, they might try to bid within a certain percentage of the previous trading period's price to increase their chances of success. Analyzing these strategic bidding practices through mathematical models is an ongoing area of research.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text: In theory, any of the device’s control parameters—such as bias current, feedback strength, or feedback phase—could serve as the hardware key. However, significant changes to bias current or feedback strength can drastically alter the chaotic attractor characteristics, potentially revealing these changes to eavesdroppers through power or attractor shifts. In contrast, variations in feedback phase are undetectable when observing time series or RF spectra of the chaotic signal [8]. Therefore, only the feedback phase meets the criteria for a hardware key, as it induces untraceable changes to the transmitted signal.
Journal Name: Feedback Phase in Optically Generated Chaos: A Secret Key for Cryptographic Applications

Text: In Thailand's power system, generation units classified as regulatory must-run or must-take units are excluded from competitive market participation. These units are obligated to supply electricity according to their contractual agreements and are treated separately from Reliability Must-Run (RMR) units. Table I provides details on both grid-connected and local hydropower plants within the Thai power system. Table II lists other must-take units.
Journal Name: Defining the Must-Run and Must-Take Units in a Deregulated Market

Text: Remote controllers have become one of the most celebrated inventions of the 21st century due to their convenience and ease of use. Their application has rapidly expanded beyond traditional home appliances like TVs, DVD players, and audio/video systems to include digital devices such as car keys, air conditioners, and game controllers. Moreover, remote controllers have been integral in home automation, enabling control over lighting, temperature, door management, and security systems. Today, it is unimaginable to enjoy the modern conveniences without these devices, as they are essential for accessing the full range of functions available in various appliances.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: This paper presents the most viable and easily implementable control techniques for home automation systems. When designing equipment to receive commands from remote control devices, a standard set of 16 appliances is considered, with the corresponding coding scheme outlined in Table I. Each appliance is assigned an item code for selection, while an action code, either ?N·or ?FF,·determines the desired operation. The final control element responsible for switching appliances on or off is a relay system, organized on a relay board, as illustrated in Fig. 1. This relay board contains a relay register that updates based on incoming commands while maintaining the switched status of other appliances. The relay register has a 16-bit word length to accommodate the control of 16 appliances.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: It is advised that the DFIG-type wind farm be utilized for future wind power investments in Thailand’s electric power system, as it has the least impact on system stability. Additionally, the capacity of each wind site should be restricted to the security level determined by the system impact study, which varies based on the timing of the project's implementation.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

Text: Modern security systems commonly employ closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras for constant surveillance in various locations, including public spaces, transportation hubs, financial institutions, and critical infrastructure. These cameras rapidly transmit live video feeds to security personnel. Additionally, biometric access control systems, such as fingerprint scanners, restrict entry to authorized individuals by verifying their fingerprints against a database.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: The next section explains how the closed-loop load-following controller functions as a local supplementary control. It helps restore frequency deviations to zero when load variations are managed through bilateral contracts and there is no centralized Automatic Generation Control (AGC). However, even in a scenario where all load variations are covered by contracts, centralized control is still necessary to address issues like power losses, which cannot be fully accounted for in bilateral contracts.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: The recent report on the "Definition and Classification of Power System Stability" is highly appreciated. It provides well-founded and comprehensive definitions of existing stability concepts. The report outlines various phenomena that contribute to instability, categorizing them as: 1) rotor angle instability, 2) voltage instability, and 3) frequency instability. Recent advancements suggest that an additional category may be necessary to encompass all practical instability scenarios in power systems.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: The size and capabilities of systems offered by vendors vary across different sourcing strategies. Research indicates that IS vendors providing single-sourcing solutions are typically larger, well-established firms with substantial resources dedicated to cybersecurity performance. These vendors possess greater capabilities to identify vulnerabilities and implement security measures effectively. In contrast, vendors supporting a best-of-breed (BoB) strategy are often smaller companies operating in niche markets, which increases the risk of business failure and limits their ability to address cybersecurity concerns. Beyond resource availability, larger IS vendors generally exhibit a stronger awareness of cybersecurity issues and are more likely to adopt secure practices compared to their smaller counterparts.

This paper introduces a new password authentication method based on Hopfield Neural Networks (HNNs). This method can be used to verify user IDs and passwords, and it's applicable to various access control scenarios, such as managing access to multiple servers or implementing role-based security. The authentication process consists of three main steps: user registration, login authorization, and password modification.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Several recent survey papers have addressed adversarial attacks and defenses in machine learning (ML) models, albeit with certain limitations; Ozdag [28] provided a limited analysis, focusing solely on deep neural networks (DNNs) and defenses related to the Neural Information Processing System (NIPS) 2017 competition, neglecting the resilience of physical systems; Biggio and Roli [29] offered a more comprehensive decade-long overview of ML evolution, yet restricted their scope to deep learning (DL) and omitted the resilience of cyber-physical systems (CPS); Liang et al. [30] examined the beneficial, detrimental, and ambiguous applications of ML for cybersecurity in CPS/IoT, but presented only a generalized perspective; lastly, Yuan et al. [31] conducted an extensive survey on adversarial attacks and defenses in DL, but similarly bypassed reinforcement learning (RL), a prevalent CPS technique, and confined their analysis to pre-2017 publications, thus demonstrating a need for a more comprehensive and current assessment encompassing diverse ML paradigms and CPS resilience.

Cybersecurity is a fast-evolving discipline that is always in the news over the last decade, as the
number of threats rises and cybercriminals constantly endeavor to stay a step ahead of law enforcement. Over
the years, although the original motives for carrying out cyberattacks largely remain unchanged, cybercriminals have become increasingly sophisticated with their techniques. Traditional cybersecurity solutions are
becoming inadequate at detecting and mitigating emerging cyberattacks. Advances in cryptographic and
Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques (in particular, machine learning and deep learning) show promise in
enabling cybersecurity experts to counter the ever-evolving threat posed by adversaries. Here, we explore
AI?s potential in improving cybersecurity solutions, by identifying both its strengths and weaknesses. We also
discuss future research opportunities associated with the development of AI techniques in the cybersecurity
field across a range of application domains.
Journal Name:
Harnessing Artificial Intelligence Capabilities
to Improve Cybersecurity

Text: The control center cybernet environment, depicted in Fig. 1, describes the connectivity of the corporate networks that are normally protected by firewalls. The control center network is connected to other corporate networks and substation and power plant networks maintained by information technology personnel. It is recognized that control center networks are highly secured and therefore unlikely to be penetrated directly. In this research, the focus is on the intrusion to control center networks through other networks such as those networks at the substations or power plants.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text:
Cybersecurity vulnerability assessments include the analysis
of the network, system, or facility through a set of controls. The
number of controls may vary significantly, ranging from 100 to
over 500 depending on the tool or framework used (e.g., CSF,
C2M2, or RMF). Therefore, unless a prioritized list of criteria
has been provided, it is almost impossible to determine the ideal
cybersecurity stance. Because of this complexity, it may be useful to use a multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) [25]?[28].
When using MCDA, specific weights that are normalized to
a scale of 1?100 are assigned to a set of criteria prior to the
decision-making process; however, this also adds a layer of
complexity onto an already complicated issue (e.g., how are the
weights assigned?) [29]. To simplify the problem, the criteria
could just be ranked and then a computational algorithm would
calculate the relative weights (RWs); a variety of rigorously analyzed rank-weight calculation methods could be used [30], [31],
some of which may perform better than others. Currently, there
is no application of combining MCDA techniques with rankweight methods to solve cybersecurity mitigation issues.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Vulnerability Mitigation Framework
Through Empirical Paradigm (CyFEr):
Prioritized Gap Analysis

Text: This system utilizes an 8-bit Programmable System on Chip (PSoC) microprocessor for several key advantages. First, the PSoC simplifies design and lowers system costs due to its configurable analog and digital blocks, along with programmable interconnect logic. 1  This architecture allows for the creation of customized peripherals like filters, amplifiers, Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs), and communication interfaces. Second, the PSoC's integrated sleep timer and Switch Mode Pump (SMP) circuit contribute to reduced power consumption. Finally, specific PSoC models are available that streamline the design of capacitive sensor keyboards, further simplifying the system's development.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: This paper introduces a key-binding biometric cryptosystem based on Juels’ fuzzy commitment scheme [6], designed to secure function-based online signature templates. The recognition performance achieved with this approach significantly surpasses that of parametric feature-based representations, which are commonly used in existing signature template protection methods, such as those in [5] and [7].
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: To efficiently control the system using the proposed Universal Remote Control (URC), an application program is required, as illustrated in Fig. 11, which displays function buttons for each device. When a button is pressed, a corresponding screen appears, showcasing the specific function, as shown in Fig. 12. The application program not only allows for individual control of appliances but also offers a scenario mode, enabling simultaneous control of multiple devices. For instance, a "movie" scenario mode can be used to close electric curtains, turn off lights, and turn on the DVD player with just one button press.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: An HNN with high storage capacity can efficiently retain authentication data while requiring minimal training time. The proposed authentication system using HNN can instantly and accurately retrieve the correct credentials for an authorized user. Our experimental results highlight the reliability and robustness of this authentication approach.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Most wind-powered generators are induction generators, which absorb reactive power during normal operation. This can lead to low-voltage issues in the power system. Additionally, integrating large-scale wind-powered generation into the utility grid alters power flow patterns and system dynamic characteristics [2]–[4]. During system impact studies, steady-state power flow must be analyzed under both normal and contingency conditions to identify potential transmission line overloading. Short-circuit currents must also be calculated before and after installing new wind generation plants to assess increases in short-circuit levels and determine if infrastructure upgrades, such as split-bus configurations or breaker upgrades, are necessary. Furthermore, dynamic simulations are required to ensure power system stability.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: Cybersecurity training is essential for the military? transition into a fully cyber-capable force. To address this need, the military has developed specialized cybersecurity training systems, known as cyber ranges. One of the earliest examples is SIMTEX (Simulator Training Exercise Network), initially created for the U.S. Air Force? training needs and later adopted as the operational platform for cybersecurity exercises like Black Daemon and Cyber Flag. SIMTEX provided virtualized hosts to simulate targeted information assets and used a VPN tunnel to isolate attack traffic across remote sites, enabling realistic and secure training environments for military cybersecurity operations.

Besides, offering practical cybersecurity training for local
and remote students poses some major challenges. Specifi-
cally, in a traditional classroom setting, a cybersecurity lab
can be established with a number of machines equipped
with relevant security tools and software packages. These
machines are typically interconnected via a network that is
isolated from the production network(s), either physically
or by means of a firewall. With the presence of local and
remote students taking the same course across multiple university campuses, we need to replicate such a setting. Coordinating, managing and maintaining the same setting
across campuses for students taking the same cybersecurity
course are usually costly and not viable.
Journal Name: Teaching Cybersecurity Using the Cloud

Text: This paper introduces a fundamental mathematical model for a hybrid energy market and demonstrates its potential through simulations. Section II-A outlines our method and its core assumptions. Section II-B details a single round of the trading process. Section III-A uses graphs to illustrate the trading process's general behaviors on a sample network with five constrained lines out of ten. Section III-C summarizes the overall trends observed from simulating our method on 102 different network configurations. Section IV concludes the paper and discusses areas for future investigation.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: The structure of this paper is organized into several key sections. Section II presents a literature review on the application of gamification in education, particularly focusing on its potential for enhancing cybersecurity training. Section III discusses how gamification can contribute to workforce development and identifies factors that drive improved cybersecurity measures within facility control systems. Section IV outlines the methodology employed for integrating game mechanics into the Network Defense Training Game (NDTG). Section V provides a practical use case demonstrating this methodology in action. Section VI elaborates on the specific scenario within the use case, showcasing how NDTG can be effectively utilized for cyber workforce development. Finally, Section VII concludes the paper, summarizing the findings and implications of the research.

Comparing signal-to-noise ratios between our new sensor and the SM-3 sensor, both installed in the same seismograph, reveals that our sensor is two orders of magnitude more sensitive. Furthermore, its ability to detect position shifts, unlike EMF-based sensors, allows for the detection of oscillating processes at extremely low frequencies, including quasi-static shifts. This capability is crucial for observing low-order free oscillations of the Earth's crust, long-duration tidal motions, and tsunami formation. Notably, it opens the possibility of revealing and studying earthquake formation origins in advance, a feat practically unattainable with other methods. Therefore, our sensor offers significant potential for seismic services in seismically active regions worldwide.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: Historically, manufacturing plants have operated in isolated environments, naturally forming air gaps that provided inherent security [3]. While Digital Manufacturing (DM) leverages information from diverse sensors and devices to optimize process and material flow, its distributed and collaborative nature introduces connectivity-related risks. A representative DM process workflow is depicted in Fig. 1. A significant portion of the pre-manufacturing phase is fully digitized, relying on computational resources and computer networks for design, simulation, and programming of manufacturing machine controllers. The DM system may integrate additive, subtractive, and hybrid manufacturing (HM) machines. This process flow necessitates continuous connectivity throughout the process chain. However, this connectivity introduces security vulnerabilities that require mitigation through both traditional and innovative cybersecurity solutions applicable to various stages of the process flow. This article utilizes the hybrid machine (HM) tool as a representative model for DM, analyzing associated cybersecurity risks, developing an attack taxonomy, and proposing novel solutions for the DM cyber-physical system.

The NICE Framework serves as a foundational taxonomy for cybersecurity workforce development by systematically categorizing roles into seven core domains, subdivided into specialty areas and specific job functions, each with detailed knowledge, skill, and ability (KSA) requirements. This standardized lexicon enables consistent role definitions across industry, academia, and government, facilitating targeted talent development, precise competency assessments, and alignment between educational programs and evolving organizational needs. By mapping over 1,000 KSA specifications to 52 distinct work roles, the framework provides granular guidance for hiring, training, and career progression while addressing critical workforce gaps in this high-demand field.

A cyber-net is a composite model formed by combining firewall and password models. These submodels are used to analyze compromised SCADA systems. Figure 7 illustrates a cyber-net based on computer network connectivity. This cyber-net contains modules representing various networks located at the power plant (boldfaced in Figure 7), substation, distribution operating center, and control center. Each module displays the firewall and password models specific to that network.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: Simulation results indicate that when the wind generator operates at 0.95 leading power factor (the worst-case scenario), bus G experiences undervoltage issues if line B is taken out of service following a disturbance. To address this issue, three improvement strategies have been proposed. Figures 14–16 illustrate the simulation results after implementing these recommended solutions.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: In 2019, Mouheb et al. conducted a survey on cybersecurity curriculum design, highlighting the various approaches universities take to develop and update their programs. The study categorized these approaches based on the primary focus of the educational institutions, which included educational, industrial, and defense perspectives. As a result, the methods adopted for curriculum design were influenced by each university's internal strategies, leading to variations that may not be suitable for other institutions. This lack of standardization is particularly concerning given the global cybersecurity workforce shortage, estimated at 4 million in 2023, and raises questions about whether graduates possess the skills that industry demands. The findings underscore the need for more cohesive collaboration between academia and industry to ensure that cybersecurity curricula are aligned with current workforce requirements and effectively prepare students for careers in this critical field.

We have successfully demonstrated a new RNG that leverages the significant current fluctuations of a MOS structure after soft breakdown. This RNG is a small circuit, requiring only about 20 logic gates and a few passive components. The random numbers it produces have passed rigorous tests, confirming their high quality and near-true randomness. This makes it a promising RNG for cryptographic security applications in mobile network services.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: Numerous studies have focused on enhancing the exchange of cybersecurity-related information among various parties, leading to the development of industry specifications that define information schemata and ontologies. These efforts also include guidelines that establish a common vocabulary and frameworks for sharing information, alongside online cybersecurity information repositories that facilitate diverse data sharing. While the proposed ontology in this context does not directly derive from existing works, it has been informed by them, providing a foundational basis for its development. Resources like NIST publications and frameworks emphasize the importance of securely managing information exchanges, outlining phases for planning, establishing, maintaining, and discontinuing such exchanges to mitigate security risks effectively. Additionally, platforms like Information Sharing and Analysis Centers (ISACs) and Threat Intelligence Platforms (TIPs) play a crucial role in real-time threat intelligence sharing, utilizing formats such as TAXII and STIX to ensure that exchanged information is both accessible and actionable.

The system's performance and the effectiveness of remedial actions taken after a contingency can be reasonably accurate if the actual operating conditions closely match the base cases used in simulations. In each scenario of system loading and transfer conditions, power generation is adjusted according to Taipower's generator dispatch rules to ensure transfers stay within the target MW bounds. The dispatch priority is determined by fuel type and other relevant rules. To determine remedial actions, prioritized tables for load and generator shedding are used. Generators capable of quick restarts are given higher priority for shedding. The sequence of load shedding is based on interruption costs, ensuring that loads with higher interruption costs are shed last.
Journal Name: A Risk-Based Contingency Selection Method for SPS Applications

Text: In this method, a "magnifying-glass" technique is applied to the chaotic state variables, which serve as the key sequence before being combined with the plaintext via XOR. This transformation amplifies even minor parameter mismatches. Specifically, a small perturbation results in a significantly larger amplified signal. Since the amplification factor is substantial, any slight variation in parameters is greatly magnified. Consequently, even a minimal mismatch leads to a large decryption error, producing a decryption key sequence that deviates significantly from the encryption key. This prevents successful plaintext recovery. Therefore, the "magnifying-glass" transformation effectively enhances the security of the chaotic communication system by making it highly sensitive to parameter variations.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: In conclusion, communication systems using analog transmission are sensitive to channel noise, which increases synchronization errors. DDF systems with complex nonlinear functions generate high-dimensional chaos but are also more prone to channel noise. Future work will explore digital transmission techniques, which are expected to significantly reduce synchronization errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: The 2018 revision of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF) [20] furnishes a quantitative and measurable risk mitigation strategy, enabling organizations to integrate cybersecurity activities into their overarching risk management protocols; this framework delivers universally applicable guidance, fostering a standardized and comparable set of cybersecurity guidelines and practices; despite its utility in establishing and evaluating organizational cybersecurity capabilities and hygiene, the NIST CSF does not constitute a dedicated cybersecurity incident playbook, thereby distinguishing its broader risk management focus from incident-specific response procedures.

The demand-side scheme (DSS) can be applied in two different situations. In the first scenario, when the utility has excess power capacity, it offers customers interruptible tariffs to reduce some of the power demand and lower operational costs during peak periods. The goal is to simultaneously minimize generation costs and maximize customer benefits [11]. In the second scenario, the primary objectives are to maintain system reliability and minimize disruptions caused by load interruptions when the system or a substation faces a capacity shortage. Since load management is highly effective in such cases, load interruptions become a suitable solution. However, because customers play a role in this process, the scheme must follow two key principles: ensuring customer satisfaction and maintaining system security. A mathematical model can be developed to represent this problem.
Journal Name: Demand Subscription Services—An Iterative Dynamic Programming for the Substation Suffering From Capacity Shortage

A RTF is measured using correlation between acoustic 
source signal and the received signal at specification

Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: The "Quartet" scenario was developed to simulate four cyberattacks targeting a fictional OT network, placing the player in the role of a facility manager responsible for defending the system. In this turn-based cyberattack simulation, players must configure the physical network environment and implement security policies to counter adaptive threats. The game presents a facility? network architecture with existing vulnerabilities, such as segmentation flaws, rogue devices, and missing firewalls, which players must address while managing a limited budget for security upgrades. The attacker follows a predefined sequence to launch cyberattacks, challenging players to identify and deploy effective protective measures. Designed to test cybersecurity decision-making in realistic attack situations, Quartet also serves as a training tool for facility operators and OT network managers by demonstrating best security practices through common network topology implementations.

The optimal pre-contingency operating state for the ESCOPF problem in the five-bus scenario is illustrated in Fig. 3. At Bus 1, the generated power is lower than the maximum limit of 160 MW that could be produced while still maintaining system security. This limitation is due to the significant load interruption that would occur if Generator 1 were producing at full capacity in the pre-contingency state. Under optimal pre-contingency conditions, Bus 2 experiences a load interruption of 0.29 MW, incurring a cost of $29 when line 1–2 is removed, as indicated in Fig. 4.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: Each power plant has unique production costs influenced by factors like size, fuel type, location, and age. As energy demand increases, the clearing price rises to match the cost of the most expensive supply. In cases of supply shortages, prices can skyrocket due to inelastic demand. During the 2000 California power crisis, price caps were implemented by the Independent System Operator (ISO) to address market power concerns. However, these caps led to a leader-follower effect without proper incentives. The imposition of blackouts indirectly introduced retail price elasticity, showing that even under normal conditions, markets can be manipulated to raise prices.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

It is important to note that the use of a particular method may
depend on the purpose of the intended analysis (e.g., connecting the results to a financial investment decision or developing a
risk calculation model). It is evident from Fig. 5 that the weight
distribution pattern is fairly similar in all the methods across
all criteria except the first ranked criterion. This difference may
be significant depending on the use of these data. For example, if resource allocation is to be performed based on these
weights, through the RR approach, the highest ranked criterion
(rank = 1) demands over ~25% of resources.
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity Vulnerability Mitigation Framework
Through Empirical Paradigm (CyFEr):
Prioritized Gap Analysis

Text: The automobile can be analyzed within two different scales concerning its operating environment. The first is a large-scale "system-of-systems" perspective, where cars function as parts of a broader transportation network, an interconnected information system, a global energy system (including fossil fuels, biofuels, and hydrogen), and an atmospheric chemistry system. At this scale, approximately 900 million vehicles exist worldwide (Fig. 1). Beyond being a physical and chemical entity, the automobile is increasingly integrating into a complex information network (Fig. 3), presenting new opportunities for electrical, electronic, and software-driven services.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text: Cyberwarfare has emerged as a pervasive threat, occurring globally and impacting various aspects of civilian and military operations. This new form of warfare not only disrupts military functions but also significantly affects daily life, necessitating robust cybersecurity measures. As the military increasingly relies on the private sector for cyber mission assurance, this dependence raises concerns about potential mission degradation due to the inherent secrecy of military operations. In response, efforts have been made to establish dedicated cybersecurity training systems aimed at internalizing essential skills; however, many existing programs lack the comprehensive support needed for effective training. To address these gaps, we propose ICSTASY, an interactive and immersive scenario-based cybersecurity training platform designed to provide holistic training features. Our study outlines the primary requirements and design principles necessary to overcome the challenges faced in developing such a system. Through the demonstration of our prototype, we illustrate the feasibility of delivering efficient and realistic cyber training applicable not only to military environments but also to the private sector, ultimately enhancing overall cybersecurity readiness against evolving threats.

The global demand for cybersecurity experts encouraged standard bodies and governments to monitor the workforce requirements constantly and to initiate framework developments. Moreover, these initiatives resulted in work role frameworks and comprehensive reports on workforce needs. Next, we present a review of the initiatives that are most relevant to this work.

Finally, we show in Fig.4 eye diagrams of the recovered messages using CM with 5% amplitude for the closed loop (left upperpanel) and the open loop(left bottom panel ) obtained with the authorized receivers. While the closed-loop authorized re ceiver perfectly recovers the message, the quality of the message recovered by the open-loop receiver is very poor. On the right side we show the eye diagrams after a simple linear filtering process performed on PT(t) with (top) a 5% message amplitude and (bottom) a 7.5% amplitude. While for the 5% amplitude the linear filtering is unable to detect the information, the encoded message can be detected for the 7.5% amplitude, highlighting that the information is not sufficiently hidden into the chaotic carrier.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: This paper introduces a novel asymmetric watermarking system designed to embed multiple watermarks while requiring only a single reference watermark for detection. This approach effectively counters attacks that attempt to estimate the embedded watermarks. The system generates embedding watermarks by randomly shifting the phase (clockwise or counterclockwise) of the reference watermark within the discrete Fourier transform domain. These generated watermarks are correlated with each other and maintain a consistent correlation with the original reference watermark. The paper also provides guidelines for selecting optimal system design parameters.
Journal Name: ASYMMETRIC WATERMARKING SYSTEM

Text: Passive attacks involve adversaries monitoring network traffic without actively disrupting it. By simply eavesdropping on transmitted packets, attackers can analyze and potentially decrypt the captured data to extract sensitive information. While the ultimate goal might be to obtain the secret key, most passive attacks focus on revealing the original messages or gathering intelligence for future malicious activities.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

In order to make our encryption system can be widely used
in the computer, we use 256 characters ASCII code, which includes 128 standard ASCII codes and other 128 that are known

and marks. When the ciphertext can be decrypted by correct key,
the message is exactly recovered as shown in Table I. Otherwise,

Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: Evaluating the reliability of electrical infrastructure systems (EIS) requires assessing both the system's ability to meet demand and its resilience to disruptions. Current methods model disturbances as probabilities but fail to capture how the power system dynamically reacts to these events. Furthermore, they typically analyze the system's stability only after it has reached a new steady state following a disturbance. Common techniques like zone branch, cut set, go, and reliability block diagrams lack the ability to provide metrics that account for the EIS's response over time when sudden disruptions occur.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: In the digital manufacturing (DM) ecosystem, information timeliness proves crucial for supporting lean production methods while ensuring both quality and productivity. The digitization process establishes communication channels connecting vendors with original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), while simultaneously linking various machines and processes within manufacturing and service enterprises (MSEs). Effective digital manufacturing requires seamless integration of cyber components (computing and communications infrastructure) with physical manufacturing processes and supply chains. The continuous flow of sensor data from multiple manufacturing plant locations?ncluding individual machines and interconnected machine networks?rives data-based decision-making that guides design modifications, manufacturing method calibration, and robot task programming including movement paths across factory floors. Securing these distributed, interconnected cyber-physical systems against diverse cyber threats demands innovative security approaches specifically designed for manufacturing environments. Potential cyber attacks range from product quality sabotage and intellectual property theft to debilitating ransomware incidents. Developing truly effective security solutions requires comprehensive analysis of attack surfaces, threat vectors, and potential countermeasures to enable secure, resilient, and scalable next-generation digital manufacturing systems.

Harmonized standards are European technical standards developed by recognized organizations such as CEN, CENELEC, or ETSI to align with EU legislation. These standards apply across all EU member states, replacing conflicting national standards. When correctly implemented, harmonized standards provide a presumption of conformity with legal requirements, allowing manufacturers and service providers to demonstrate compliance with relevant EU laws. Only those harmonized standards published in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJEU) are recognized for this purpose

Over the past decade, significant growth in the power system resulted from newly operational mining projects, leading to the addition of coal-fired thermal plants and combined cycle plants fueled by Argentine natural gas. However, the substantial size of these new units relative to the existing system caused operational challenges during their initial testing. Unexpected outages resulted in severe frequency drops, triggering load shedding by low-frequency relays.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text:
For instance, current cloud infrastructure is characterized by a three-layer architecture. Each layer is arguably
at risk from a range of vulnerabilities introduced either by programmers or service providers. The disparate handling of
data makes crimes such as cybertheft and cyber-fraud more
complex to track within cyberspaces [3]. More worryingly,
ubiquitous distributed computing eliminates the importance
of geographical boundaries, and this also makes it possible for

Hence, organizations are increasingly challenged by a wide
