of adopting Artificial Intelligence (AI) or intelligent agents
to combat them.
Journal Name:
Artificial Intelligence for Cybersecurity:
A Systematic Mapping of Literature

Text: This research has successfully defined the necessary content rights protection requirements for Digital Broadcast Home Server (DBHS) systems and developed a corresponding Digital Rights Management (DRM) system. We've introduced a method for synchronizing scramble key multiplexing with MPEG-2 Transport Stream (TS) video packets, ensuring that trick-play functionalities remain consistent with unencrypted content. This innovative DRM solution provides seamless viewing during live broadcasts and robust usage control for stored content. Furthermore, its architecture is inherently suitable for broadcast environments, which involve one-to-many content distribution.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI), cybersecurity, and blockchain technology represents an evolving domain with substantial capacity to redefine digital security paradigms. Conventional cybersecurity methodologies frequently encounter difficulties in adapting to the dynamic and intricate characteristics of contemporary cyber threats. AI has emerged as a potent instrument for augmenting cybersecurity capabilities through its capacity to analyze extensive datasets, identify anomalies, and facilitate real-time threat response. Nevertheless, the centralized architecture of numerous AI systems introduces vulnerabilities, rendering them susceptible targets for cyberattacks.

The decision-making processes in autonomous vehicles (AVs) heavily rely on machine learning (ML) models that analyze vast amounts of data from sensors and V2X communication systems to navigate safely, but this dependence introduces significant vulnerabilities that threaten passenger safety and system integrity. Adversarial attacks targeting perception systems can manipulate sensor inputs, such as altering road signs or obscuring LiDAR readings, leading to misclassification of objects or ignoring hazards, while communication channels can be exploited by attackers spoofing V2X signals to misdirect navigation or trigger collisions. Additionally, compromised electronic control units (ECUs) may allow hackers to inject malicious code, further jeopardizing critical functions like steering and acceleration. The integrity of ML models is also at risk, as adversaries can reverse-engineer algorithms or exploit hardware vulnerabilities to alter decision-making logic. To address these challenges, robust training frameworks that incorporate adversarial training, secure communication protocols utilizing cryptographic methods for message validation, and hardware redundancies such as multi-sensor fusion are essential. Furthermore, regulatory collaboration and standardized testing protocols are vital for identifying vulnerabilities before deployment, while emerging technologies like federated learning and quantum-resistant encryption present promising avenues for enhancing security. Ultimately, a coordinated effort among automakers, cybersecurity experts, and policymakers is crucial to establish unified standards and adaptive defenses against the evolving threats faced by autonomous mobility systems.

A simple wire loop of the same size as the Balise was then used to simulate jamming. This loop was fed by a function generator whose signal was first amplified. With this setup, two different attacks have been simulated: one based on Continuous Wave (CW), i.e., a single frequency tone (see Figures 3- 5), and one which involved a swept tone close to the up-link frequency.

To effectively counter evolving cyber threats, modern defense systems must demonstrate three key characteristics: (1) advanced intelligence capabilities, (2) operational flexibility, and (3) robust threat detection and mitigation frameworks. These requirements have driven widespread organizational adoption of AI-driven security solutions. This technological shift necessitates that both researchers and cybersecurity professionals maintain up-to-date knowledge of cutting-edge AI applications in digital protection. While existing literature has examined various cybersecurity challenges, our analysis reveals a significant research gap: no comprehensive, systematic review currently exists focusing specifically on AI methodologies in cybersecurity. Addressing this gap, our study conducts a methodical examination of AI techniques employed in cyber threat detection and prevention, offering a structured synthesis of current knowledge in this critical field.

The advantages of such a bilateral market are many. The possibility of setting the price in the contract directly between customer and supplier solves the problem of the allocation of payment specifically to each customer in an equitable way. Moreover, it allows increasing competition in the ancillary services market and, as a consequence, avoids the problem of shortfalls in supply of load following. The generator with a bilateral contract is compensated in a fair way for the service that it is offering and this could be good reason for generators to join the load following market. An increase in competition also arises because of the possibility that generators may be able to enter into bilateral contracts outside their CA, as shown in the previous section. This requires a communication network across Control Areas.
Journal Name: Feasibility of a Bilateral Market for Load Following

Text: Every device or endpoint in IoT and cyber-physical systems (CPS) contributes to the overall network attack surface, making them potential targets for cyber threats. Attackers can exploit vulnerabilities in these endpoints to gain unauthorized access, ultimately compromising the entire system. Communication protocols like WiFi, Bluetooth, and GSM facilitate connectivity between external devices and sensors but often contain security flaws that can be exploited. These weaknesses allow attackers to intercept communications, manipulate data, or take control of connected devices, highlighting the need for stringent security measures to protect IoT and CPS environments from malicious intrusions.

The NICE framework aims to establish a standardized lexicon for defining cybersecurity work roles by categorizing them into seven main groups. These categories are further divided into specialty areas and specific job roles, detailing the necessary knowledge, skills, and abilities required for professionals to perform cybersecurity tasks effectively.

In our analysis of the third security measure—training program adoption—we observed minimal differences between highly computerized and less computerized organizations in terms of actual program implementation. However, we noted some variation in plans for implementing such programs. Surprisingly, primarily paper-based organizations were more likely to have plans for adopting training programs. Many of the organizations studied were in a transitional phase, moving from paper-based to computerized patient data systems.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: Each neuron in a neural network operates based on an activation function, which determines the relationship between its input and output. The most commonly used activation functions are outlined in Table 1. The connections between neurons, represented by weights, are adjusted through a learning algorithm, as discussed in Section II-B. This process aims to minimize the error between the predicted output and the desired result, enhancing the overall performance of the model.

In time-frequency analysis, such as the Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT), a signal is divided into small time segments, and the frequency content of each segment is computed. This frequency content is represented as a magnitude spectrum, which illustrates the energy distribution across frequencies for a specific time segment.STFT-based features are widely used due to their efficiency, as they leverage the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm for rapid computation. The following features are derived from the short-time magnitude spectrum of the STFT transformation of the signal.
Journal Name: Acoustic Intruder Detection System for Home Security

Text: A dialing circuit, connected to a home telephone, can be triggered by signals from detectors like fire alarms. This trigger initiates two actions: first, it simulates lifting the phone's receiver for a set duration, enabling dial tone reception and dialing; second, it activates a sequential logic circuit to send digit pulses onto the phone line. We utilize this to dial the resident's mobile number upon fire detection. When the resident's mobile rings, they recognize it as a home call and understand a fire is present. They can then call back, using an additional digit as previously described, to activate a relay-controlled solenoid valve connected to a fire extinguisher within their home. This extinguisher can also be operated manually. If the resident is home and receives the call, they can choose to extinguish the fire manually or remotely via the phone.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

The estimation of equilibrium has been explored in a
smaller parameter regime [48], within which the dynamics
were known to be convergent while certain parameters were

Journal Name:
Using Event-Based Method to Estimate
Cybersecurity Equilibrium

Text: The security of certain Delayed Differential Feedback (DDF) systems can be compromised. Essentially, system parameters can be determined from time series data after making assumptions about the functional form of the feedback element's nonlinearity, as shown in references [16] and [17]. Many optoelectronic [13] and all-electronic [18], [19] implementations of DDF systems have utilized fixed nonlinearities with well-defined functional forms. Research has demonstrated that DDF chaotic systems can be decoded using curve fitting algorithms when the functional form is known [16]. Additionally, the algorithm that compromises DDF system security depends on determining the system's time delay. Recent numerical studies have indicated that security can be enhanced by modulating the time delay [20].
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text:
The load shedding scheme imposes costs on customers, which depend on outage expenses and the forced outage rate of generators. User outage costs can be roughly estimated based on the amount of power disconnected or a damage function [3], [4].
The system failure rate plays a crucial role in determining these costs, as each instance of load shedding results in an interruption expense. In this estimation, power interruption costs ($/MW) are considered more representative than nonsupplied energy costs ($/MWh).
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: By providing market signals to end-use consumers, they can adjust their loads and shift away from high market prices during times of power system stress. A demand-response program based on real-time electricity pricing can effectively link both the supply-wholesale and demand-retail markets.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: This paper focuses on wind farm penetration levels of 10% and 20% of peak demand. To achieve this, 22 and 44 wind farm sites, each with a 90 MW installed capacity, have been integrated into the conventional power system through 115-kV transmission lines at various locations near load centers across the entire system.
Journal Name: Design Optimization of Wind Power Planning for a Country With Low–Medium-Wind-Speed Profile

To address instruction variability, the same textbook and
core instruction was used in all four sections. Assignments
and exams were identical, and presentation materials were
the same, except where noted below. The course content covered threats and countermeasures to be applied to a variety
of nonspecific cybersecurity threats to systems and applications according to the CSEC framework. At crucial learning

testers and vulnerability scanners, writing cryptographic programs, and running static and dynamic code analyzers against
their code.
Journal Name:
A Study of Cybersecurity Education Using a
Present-Test-Practice-Assess Model

Text: The analysis of brute-force break-ins necessitates a probabilistic model that defines the relationship between the number of attack attempts and the likelihood of false acceptance. Therefore, establishing a probabilistic model for the angular distance, as given in (4), is essential. To simplify this model, we assume that all preprocessed palmprint images are clear and free of non-palmprint pixels, allowing us to disregard masks and normalization terms. While the same analytical results could be obtained using either the integer or bitwise representation of Competitive Code, the integer representation is chosen for clarity. Thus, for the following analysis, we focus on the angular distance given in (2).
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: To effectively manage the proposed Universal Remote Control (URC) system, a user-friendly application is required, featuring a graphical interface with function buttons as depicted in Figure 11. Pressing these buttons triggers corresponding function screens, illustrated in Figure 12. The application allows for both individual appliance control and comprehensive scenario-based automation. For instance, a "movie" scenario can be activated with a single button press, simultaneously closing electric curtains, dimming lights, and powering on a DVD player.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: In the above steps, if CW is not encrypted before transferring back to STB, the adversary can redirect the CW to another descrambler of the same type to descramble the program directly by eavesdropping the communication of the smart card interface, which is insecure. In the latter case that CW is encrypted, SK is important to keep the communication secure. However, in many current schemes, SK is always a fixed parameter, which greatly reduces the security since the pirates can take known plain-text attack by eavesdropping the communication. Moreover, without mutual authentication, the pirates can duplicating smart card or redirect the communication message of a legitimated smart card and STB to other STBs to entitle the unauthorized user to receive the charged program, which will cause a great loss for the service provider. So, dynamic SK and mutual authentication between STB and smart card is necessary.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: Research has explored collaboration between cybersecurity educational institutions and industry, but most universities have yet to establish active partnerships with the industrial sector. Despite a global cybersecurity workforce shortage estimated at 4 million in 2023, no concrete plan exists to bridge this gap. Additionally, surveys indicate that cybersecurity graduates may lack the specific skills demanded by the industry.

Effective cybersecurity training materials must go beyond merely listing technical topics in a checklist format, as such an approach fails to foster the behavioral changes necessary for improved cybersecurity responsiveness. Instructors face the challenge of addressing a vast range of environments, from small businesses to large corporations and government infrastructure, making it tempting to simplify training. However, research suggests that immersive methods, such as simulations and live activities, are critical for applied learning performance. These techniques engage learners in realistic scenarios, promoting deeper understanding and practical application of concepts like secure remote access, patch management, and the integration of physical and cybersecurity. By prioritizing experiential learning over static checklists, training programs can better prepare individuals to respond effectively to diverse cybersecurity challenges.

Random number generators (RNGs) based on natural noise sources, like thermal or shot noise, are available commercially. While these RNGs produce high-quality random numbers, they are bulky because the weak noise signals require significant amplification, making them unsuitable for mobile devices. Alternative RNGs using dual oscillators require less amplification, but they exhibit correlations between generated bits, necessitating post-processing that results in an inconsistent output rate.
Journal Name: Physical Random Number Generator Based on MOS Structure After Soft Breakdown

Text: The identification and security of vulnerable nodes within supporting infrastructures represents a critical prerequisite for realizing the economic and efficiency advantages offered by digital manufacturing. In subsequent sections, we outline the essential components of our case study hybrid manufacturing system and analyze potential vulnerabilities within the digital manufacturing context. Our examination of these hybrid manufacturing vulnerabilities serves as the foundation for developing a comprehensive taxonomy and proposing targeted solutions addressing digital manufacturing vulnerabilities throughout the remainder of this article.

Since the 1970s, control center architecture has evolved from a closed monolithic structure to a more open networked environment. With the growing adoption of standardized protocols, more utilities are transitioning to Internet protocol (IP)-based systems for wide area communication. The compatibility of standards has also reduced system deployment costs among vendors, improving system upgradeability. However, tighter integration may introduce new vulnerabilities. Risks associated with connecting SCADA systems to the Internet have been recognized [2]. The security concerns regarding information exchange between various power entities present greater challenges as cyber threats increase [3]. Growing reliance on Internet communications has amplified the significance and scale of this problem. Security awareness and personnel training for supervisory control systems are essential [4], [5]. A recent report comparing different security guidelines and standards highlights critical cybersecurity elements for SCADA systems [6]. Cybersecurity technologies identified in [7] address defense effectiveness. Recent research focuses on security interdependency modeling including deliberate sabotage, and improvements to power system information architecture and communication interactions [8]–[10]. SCADA test bed development effectively identifies power infrastructure cybersecurity vulnerabilities [11]–[13]. Reference [14] proposes an innovative approach using wireless sensor technology to evaluate transmission system mechanical health. Quantitative techniques for system interdependency development are reported in [15]. Model-based attack-detection techniques [16] exist to detect anomalies and recognize malicious electronic signatures.
Journal Name: Vulnerability Assessment of Cybersecurity for SCADA Systems

Text: This study focused on impulsive control, utilizing the framework of impulsive differential equations. We established sufficient conditions that guarantee the asymptotic stability of impulsive differential systems. These findings were subsequently applied to develop an impulsive control strategy for a specific class of nonlinear systems. This approach has the potential to enhance current techniques used in chaotic secure communication and chaotic spread spectrum communication systems.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Simulations revealed that if the wind generator operates at 0.95 leading power factor (the most challenging scenario), bus G will experience undervoltage issues when line B is taken offline after a disturbance. To resolve this issue, three improvement strategies were proposed. Figures 14–16 display the simulation results after implementing these proposed solutions.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: The study presents the lightweight matching-scheme finding Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MS-DDPG) as an innovative solution for optimizing node search and scheduling in distributed computing networks, particularly within the context of fog computing. This method addresses the challenges of identifying fog nodes with available space in virtual machines, which is crucial for effective resource allocation during task processing. Unlike existing approaches such as Q-learning, Deep-Q-Learning, and SARSA, which are resource-intensive and time-consuming, the MS-DDPG method leverages reinforcement learning to efficiently match resources and tasks while minimizing processing time and resource consumption. By adopting a lightweight framework, MS-DDPG enhances the adaptability of node searching in dynamic environments, making it a suitable choice for applications that require rapid decision-making and efficient resource management. This approach not only improves scheduling performance but also aligns with the growing demand for efficient computational strategies in complex distributed systems.

The goal of the problem is to maximize the expected value of social welfare, where "expected" is used in the standard probabilistic sense, accounting for all contingencies and the pre-contingency state. Social welfare is defined as the difference between consumer benefits and producer costs, with load treated as price-sensitive demand. The OPF (Optimal Power Flow) objective function includes pre-contingency social welfare, social welfare for each post-contingency state, generator ramping costs, and load interruption costs (an example of a market for interruptible load is provided in [7]). Each post-contingency state's social welfare is weighted by the probability of its associated contingency. Probabilistic approximations are made in formulating the expected social welfare function, with terms involving the product of probabilities of independent contingencies being neglected due to their negligible size.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: The study in [24] specifically targets the analysis of scientific literature addressing cybersecurity frameworks, standards, guidelines, and protective measures tailored for the nuclear sector, deliberately excluding safety-related considerations and the intersection of cybersecurity-safety co-engineering. By narrowing its scope to purely cybersecurity-centric resources, the work provides a focused review of defensive methodologies and regulatory approaches unique to nuclear infrastructure, though it leaves open opportunities for future research integrating safety-cybersecurity synergies in this high-stakes domain.

Information and communication technology researchers widely agree that information security (InfoSec) is of paramount importance. Various studies have explored ways to enhance InfoSec through malware detectors, intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDPS), sophisticated firewalls, and data encryption algorithms. While some argue that human behavior plays a crucial role in managing InfoSec risks, others contend that focusing solely on human factors is insufficient. Given the vast amount of data organizations handle, automation becomes a necessity. Therefore, achieving an optimal balance between human awareness, technological advancements, and policy management is essential for strengthening organizational security.

Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) are pivotal in integrating physical and information worlds, particularly in critical infrastructure, yet their deployment raises significant cybersecurity concerns due to the potential impact of cyber attacks on human safety, infrastructure, and the environment. The process of transmitting information from sensors to actuators over wireless communication expands the attack surface, making CPS susceptible to various threats. Traditional security measures have focused on preventing unauthorized access through cryptography and access control, primarily emphasizing attack detection. However, as adversarial tactics evolve, it becomes increasingly challenging to completely prevent attacks, highlighting the need for resilience in CPS design. Resilient CPS are engineered to withstand disruptions and maintain functionality in the face of adversaries, with machine learning (ML) algorithms emerging as a key methodology for enhancing resilience. Recent research in adversarial ML suggests that these algorithms must also be resilient to ensure effective protection of CPS. This article surveys the interplay between resilient CPS utilizing ML and resilient ML applications within CPS, concluding with insights into current research trends and future directions in this dynamic field.

A Content Key (Kc) is assigned to each content unit and is transmitted along with the content as an ECM section, known as the Kc distribution ECM. This Kc is located within the variable-length unit of the Kc distribution ECM, allowing for flexible selection of encryption algorithms and key lengths.Furthermore, the inclusion of Digital Rights Management Information (DRMI) alongside the Kc enables granular access control for stored content at the individual content unit level. To protect the integrity of the Kc distribution ECM, a tamper-detection code, specifically a Hash function (SHA-1) based code, is embedded within the encrypted area. This prevents unauthorized modification of key information and other data.The Kc distribution ECM can be delivered either multiplexed with the encrypted content or separately, restricting viewing access to specific timeframes. Because the Kc distribution ECM allows the Kc to be efficiently broadcast to multiple receivers, this DRM system is well-suited for content distribution in digital satellite and terrestrial broadcasting.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: Recently, there has been significant research on impulsive systems and impulsive control. Researchers such as Bainov and Simeonov, Lakshmikantham et al., and Lakshmikantham and Liu have explored the stability of impulsive systems using Lyapunov functions, requiring these functions to be nonincreasing across all switchings. Li et al. have relaxed this condition, allowing the Lyapunov function to be nonincreasing along a subsequence of switchings. Yang has derived sufficient conditions for impulsive control of nonlinear systems based on earlier work. Additionally, Yang and Chua, as well as Yang et al., have demonstrated innovative applications of impulsive control in secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications. Panas et al. have provided methods for achieving impulsive control in experimental settings.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Many studies use risk as a metric to represent the outcomes of assessment techniques, typically considering the likelihood of hazardous events and the severity of their consequences. Traditional Risk Priority Number (RPN), based on effect severity, occurrence probability, and detection difficulty, is commonly applied, with some studies extending it to include risk interaction. Others enhance risk assessment accuracy through fuzzy confidence interval numbers, generalized trapezoidal fuzzy numbers, and sensitivity analysis. Some approaches incorporate hazard severity, exposure levels, and system controllability, while others separately assess fairness risk, assurance risks, and attack-related factors like cost, difficulty, and detection probability.

In the literature, labs for cybersecurity training exist in different forms. One form is the traditional lab setting with
multiple interconnected physical machines, network devices and security appliances (e.g., firewall and intrusion
detection systems). Some of these lab platforms and testbeds are described in [1], [5], [32]. A major benefit of such
types of labs is the ability to provide realistic experience
with actual hardware equipment. In [62], a remote access to
a traditional security lab is provided to students with the
capability of remotely allocating, configuring, parameterizing, and managing physical machines and devices. However, as discussed in Section 5, such a classical approach has
many associated overhead costs and clear disadvantages
pertaining to setup, configuration, installation, scheduling
and management of equipment.
Journal Name: Teaching Cybersecurity Using the Cloud

Text: Many researchers have studied impulsive systems and impulsive control in recent years. In [2]–[6], the authors have considered the stability of impulsive systems by using Lyapunov functions and the Lyapunov functions are required to be nonincreasing along the whole sequence or subsequence of the switchings. In [1], Yang has obtained some sufficient conditions for the impulsive control of a class of nonlinear systems by using the results in [3]. In [7], Li et al. have also given some less conservative conditions for asymptotic stability of impulsive systems with impulses at fixed times and the results have been used to design impulsive control for a class of nonlinear systems by using the results in [3]. In [8]–[13], the authors have presented some interesting applications of impulsive control in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications. In [14], Panas et al. have given some methods for the experimental settings to achieve the impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: While attacking your own system is one of the best ways to assess its resilience against cyber threats, employing ethical hackers raises several ethical dilemmas. On one hand, ethical hacking helps uncover vulnerabilities, strengthen security, and train staff to respond effectively to attacks. On the other hand, concerns arise regarding trust, misuse of knowledge, and the potential for ethical hackers to cross legal or moral boundaries. Organizations must establish clear guidelines, contracts, and oversight mechanisms to ensure ethical hacking remains within legal and ethical limits while maximizing its security benefits.

In Conditional Access Systems (CAS), program information is scrambled using control words to prevent unauthorized users from accessing the content [1][2][3]. Authorized subscribers can descramble the program with the help of a smart card and a Set-Top Box (STB). Service providers charge a subscription fee by issuing smart cards to paid subscribers. Since most digital TV (DTV) broadcasting is unidirectional, there is no real-time authentication between the head-end and the subscriber. Therefore, service providers rely on authentication between the STB and the smart card to protect their interests. Secure communication between the STB and the smart card is crucial for system security, as it directly impacts the service provider's revenue. Key exchange is a fundamental part of this secure communication. Without mutual authentication, a single smart card can be used across multiple STBs of the same type, leading to issues like McCormac Hack and smart card cloning [4]. McCormac Hack occurs when the data line from the smart card to the STB is intercepted and redirected to another STB, mimicking the original smart card. Smart card cloning involves duplicating a legitimate card to create multiple illegal copies, allowing unauthorized access to programs. If pirates crack the key exchange process, they can extract key information from smart cards, enabling them to duplicate cards or redirect access to unauthorized STBs. It is estimated that media providers lose $100 million annually due to smart card breaches [5]. Secure key exchange with mutual authentication is essential to enhance system security and reduce revenue losses.
Journal Name: Secure Communication between Set-top Box and Smart Card in DTV Broadcasting

Text: Research indicates an increasing frequency of cyberattacks, and a growing body of literature provides tools for cyber risk assessment [3], [8], [52]. While the severity of individual cyberattacks may have stabilized [99], the estimated average cost remains substantial, at $229,000. The global financial impact of cyberattacks is estimated to reach hundreds of billions of dollars [70]. Consequently, approximately one-third of organizations are considering cyber insurance [65]. However, this may not be a feasible option for Social Enterprises (SEs), which often face significant financial limitations. Moreover, the efficacy of financial compensation in mitigating the impact of cybercrime on SEs, whose primary objectives are often socially oriented rather than profit-driven, is questionable. SEs are evaluated not only on financial performance but also on their societal contributions. Consequently, similar to the challenges in quantifying their social value [33], [47], [101], SEs encounter difficulties in measuring the comprehensive impact of cybercrime, thereby complicating insurance considerations.

Authentication is the process of positively verifying identity, be it
that of a user, device, or entity in a computer system. Often authentication is the prerequisite to accessing system resources. Positive
verification is accomplished by means of matching some indicator
of identity, such as a shared secret prearranged at the time a person
was authorized to use the system. The most familiar user authenticator in use today is the password. The secure sockets layer (SSL)
is an example of machine to machine authentication.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: Securing next-generation digital manufacturing (DM) systems is crucial due to the increasing cyber threats posed by interconnected supply chains and real-time data streams. Cyberattacks can range from ransomware and operational sabotage to intellectual property theft, with the attack surface expanding as manufacturers integrate cyber-physical systems. For instance, 71% of ransomware attacks targeted manufacturers in 2024, leading to significant downtime costs. To mitigate these risks, it is essential to adopt a zero-trust architecture that segments networks, implement AI-driven threat detection for real-time anomaly monitoring, and ensure secure-by-design updates for IoT devices. Additionally, hardening supply chains through rigorous vendor vetting and conducting resilience testing against potential attacks can enhance security. By integrating these adaptive cybersecurity measures into DM workflows, manufacturers can protect their operations while maintaining compliance with evolving regulations and ensuring the integrity of their production processes.

As critical infrastructure security evolves, the growing sophistication of cyber threats presents significant challenges, particularly for the power grid? modern technology infrastructure. Power transformers, once considered passive components, are now integrated with smart technologies and intelligent monitoring systems, enhancing asset management but also increasing cyber vulnerabilities. While existing research primarily focuses on smart grid cybersecurity using model-based detection methods, there is a notable gap in addressing the security of critical power components, especially power transformers. This paper fills that gap by exploring cybersecurity challenges associated with smart transformers, introducing a comprehensive architecture and a structured taxonomy of cyber-physical attacks. It provides an in-depth analysis of smart transformer topology, highlighting vulnerable components and the impact of potential security breaches. Additionally, the study discusses emerging cybersecurity threats for smart transformers, emphasizing the need to integrate advanced security measures into online condition monitoring systems to enhance resilience against evolving cyber risks and strengthen the security of power grids.

Over the past decade, cybersecurity has emerged as a rapidly evolving discipline that remains consistently prominent in public discourse due to escalating threats and cybercriminals' persistent efforts to outpace law enforcement. While the fundamental motives behind cyberattacks have remained relatively unchanged, the methodologies employed by malicious actors have grown increasingly sophisticated, rendering traditional cybersecurity measures insufficient for detecting and countering modern threats. In this context, advancements in cryptographic systems and artificial intelligence (AI) ?particularly in machine learning and deep learning ?demonstrate significant potential in empowering cybersecurity professionals to address these evolving challenges. This paper examines AI's dual role in enhancing cybersecurity solutions, analyzing both its capabilities and limitations while highlighting promising research directions for AI-driven cybersecurity applications across diverse domains. The discussion encompasses current implementations and prospective developments that could shape the future of cyber defense

Figure 3 shows the optimal pre-contingency operating state of the ESCOPF problem for the five-bus case. The generation at Bus 1 is below the maximum possible 160 MW that could be generated while maintaining system security, as previously discussed. This reduction occurs because of the substantial load interruption that would happen if Generator 1 were producing 160 MW in the pre-contingency operating condition. When operating at the optimal pre-contingency state, as shown in Figure 4, the load at Bus 2 experiences an interruption of 0.29 MW at a cost of $29 when line 1–2 is removed.
Journal Name: Optimal Power Flow With Expected Security Costs

Text: Despite the global cybersecurity workforce shortage, estimated at 4 million in 2023, most universities have yet to establish active collaborations with the industrial sector to address this gap. Surveys reveal that many cybersecurity graduates lack the skills required by employers, indicating a disconnect between academic training and industry needs. While initiatives like NAMTECH's partnership with Cisco and CISA's collaboration with educational institutions aim to bridge this divide by aligning curricula with practical industry demands, these efforts remain limited in scope. To effectively prepare graduates for the challenges of the evolving cybersecurity landscape, more structured and widespread partnerships between academia and industry are essential, ensuring that educational programs equip students with the relevant knowledge, skills, and abilities needed for real-world applications.

Impulsive control systems are found in a variety of real-world scenarios. Examples include systems for managing insect populations, where the number of insects and their predators are the state variables; chemical reactors, where the quantities of different chemicals are tracked; and financial systems, where market money supply and central bank savings rates are the state variables. Additional practical applications have been documented in other studies.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Additionally, it incorporates a method for selecting the most reliable signature traits. The proposed system delivers authentication performance on par with unprotected systems while significantly surpassing protection methods that rely on parametric signature features.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Autonomous assistant: The decision-making process
in AVs presents a significant security challenge. Autonomous

outside the vehicle. Communication between ICVs and the

Journal Name:

Text: This system utilizes an 8-bit PSoC microprocessor due to its advantages in design, power, and implementation. Configurable blocks simplify design and reduce cost by enabling custom peripherals. Its sleep timer and SMP circuit minimize power consumption. Finally, specific PSoC models streamline capacitive keyboard integration.
Journal Name: A Low Cost GSM/GPRS Based Wireless Home Security System

Text: Model Reference Adaptive Control (MRAC) is a key adaptive control technique. It defines the desired system behavior using a reference model, which dictates the ideal response to an input signal. An adjustment mechanism then dynamically modifies the regulator's parameters to minimize the difference (error) between the actual system output and the reference model's output. Achieving a zero error signifies perfect model following, where the system behaves exactly as the reference model dictates.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text:
Considering the rapid growth of EVs, user privacy has
become a critical issue. The bottleneck of information
exchange is when the vehicle is charging or when users
use software to interact with their vehicles. Vehicle actuators
gather sensitive data, and compromising this information compromises user privacy. Information leaks, such as location,
identification, payments, and driving habits, can endanger
privacy. For instance, in [23], the authors surveyed existing
techniques that address various privacy issues in EVs and
smart grids. In [24], the authors conducted an innovative study
regarding the privacy challenges affecting EVs and EVSEs.
Some studies tried to solve the privacy of users? payments. For
example, in [25], the authors presented a privacy-preserving
authentication and payment scheme, which is proven to have
a secure way of payment to preserve user identification and
privacy while making it feasible to trace the vehicle in case
of vehicle theft. Another critical privacy issue is user location,
examined in [26]. Some studies also concern an authentication
scheme for EVs connecting to power stations, such as [27]
and [28]. Thus, EV information privacy requires assessment.
Journal Name:
Evaluation Framework for Electric Vehicle
Security Risk Assessment

Text: Cybersecurity encompasses a comprehensive set of processes, human behaviors, and systems designed to protect electronic resources from cyber threats. Similar to Moore's Law, which predicts the doubling of components on integrated circuits every two years, cybercriminals are increasingly enhancing the effectiveness of their attack tools at a rapid pace, often for lower costs. Between 2017 and 2021, global spending on cybersecurity is projected to surpass $1 trillion, reflecting a significant increase in investment?lmost 40% from 2013 to $66 billion. This surge in expenditure highlights the urgent need for robust cybersecurity measures as threats grow more sophisticated and frequent, necessitating advanced solutions that can adapt to the evolving landscape of cybercrime.

Over the past decade, technological advancements have significantly enhanced communication protocols, making them more adaptable and easier to maintain, especially within open, high-speed architectures. However, the development of SCADA systems has introduced new cyber security concerns. The growing interconnectedness of computer, communication, and power systems has further increased security risks due to the complexity of these integrated infrastructures. While this integration provides operational and analytical advantages, it also amplifies vulnerabilities. Fortunately, ongoing technological progress offers solutions to address these shortcomings in current power and communication systems.
Journal Name: Cybersecurity for Critical Infrastructures: Attack and Defense Modeling

Text: Digital Manufacturing (DM) introduces critical cybersecurity risks by replacing traditional air-gapped systems with interconnected workflows reliant on sensors, networked devices, and real-time data exchange. While DM enhances process efficiency through connectivity, it exposes vulnerabilities across IT/OT converged environments, evident in the manufacturing sector? status as the most targeted industry, with 25.7% of attacks involving ransomware. Legacy OT systems, such as PLCs and IIoT devices, often outdated and unpatched, amplify risks, compounded by IT/OT integration expanding attack surfaces and enabling lateral movement for threats like intellectual property theft or production sabotage. For instance, 48% of manufacturers identify cybersecurity as the top operational risk, with ransomware costs averaging $4.45 million per breach. Hybrid manufacturing workflows, spanning additive/subtractive processes, face unique threats: compromised design files or manipulated robotic programming could disrupt physical production, while insecure remote access to controllers enables attackers to inject malicious code. Mitigating these risks requires solutions like zero-trust segmentation for OT networks, AI-driven anomaly detection in sensor data streams, and secure-by-design protocols for legacy system modernization. Addressing these challenges is urgent, as cyberattacks on manufacturers grow by 125% annually, driven by low cyber maturity and high downtime costs.

Collectively, SEs represent an influential sector of commerce
that are imbued with notable characteristics that make them not
only susceptible to cyberattack but also the organization and
the individuals with whom they engage have the potential to be
harmfully impacted by their effect. Their increasing presence as
socially and commercially viable and successful organizations,
for instance 52% of U.K. SEs grew their turnover in the last
year [81], may also be conspiring to raise awareness of their
vulnerabilities to those with malicious intent. Therefore, as
their popularity increases this may increase their prominence as
subjects of cybercrime: a trajectory that has been witnessed in
the growth of cybercrime against larger charitable organizations
Journal Name:
Antecedents of Cybersecurity Implementation:
A Study of the Cyber-Preparedness
of U.K. Social Enterprises

Text: Reliability evaluation of Electrical Infrastructure Systems (EIS) must consider both system adequacy evaluation and security analysis to determine how the system responds to various disturbances [3]. Current reliability methodologies model disturbances probabilistically but fail to model the power system's stochastic response [4], analyzing the system only under steady-state conditions after disturbances occur [5]. These techniques include zone branch [6], cut set [7], go [8], and reliability block diagram [9]. Using these approaches, it's impossible to develop indicators that incorporate the EIS's temporal response to sudden disturbances.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Therefore, the TSP needs a different objective function for networks with fewer constrained lines. An alternative objective function, which works well empirically, minimizes the absolute valueofthetransmissionservicechargesimposed.Thisfunction finds acceptable results because as the number of constrained lines goes down, the optimal nodal prices become increasingly uniform, thus requiring smaller locational price variation in order to achieve OPF. The two different objective functions have different characteristics. Maximizing the TSP revenue guarantees that the total social welfare of all of the participants increases, and that the TSP revenue is positive.5 Minimizing the absolute value of the transmission service charges does not have the same properties; it can result in lower total social welfare, and may even result in negative TSP revenue. On average, however, the min-absolute-value objective function facilitated the achievement of OPF in many of the simulated networks that were relatively unconstrained.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

The Internet has become more and more accessible over the
world in the last decades, going from 20% of the world
population with Internet access in 2005 to 63% in 2021 [1].
This amount represents 4.9 billion people using the internet. With this exponential growth, protecting internet users
and their data has become a concern textcolorbluefor Law
Enforcement Agencies (LEAs), research centres, and people
in general.
Journal Name:
PhiKitA: Phishing Kit Attacks Dataset
for Phishing Websites Identification

Text:
In addition to the importance of safety in civil aviation, the significance of cybersecurity in the
aviation sector cannot be ignored, and this fact has often been highlighted owing to frequent cyber-attacks
that denigrate victim(s) and also lead to political and economic controversies. Cybersecurity has recently
received a major boost, with the shift of air navigation facilities from analog ground-based systems to digital
space-based systems to accommodate the tremendous growth in air traffic density. Furthermore, most air
navigation facilities have open designs that tend to overlook security concerns. In this regard, identifying a
systematic methodology for aviation cybersecurity risk assessment is a key element in the identification of
potential threats, and assessment of their likelihood and risk levels, whereby risks can be reduced to tolerable
levels through appropriate mitigation measures. Existing review articles have not addressed cybersecurity in
all the various aviation systems, and have not considered a systematic methodology for aviation cybersecurity
risk assessment. This paper therefore presents a systematic qualitative and quantitative cybersecurity risk
assessment methodology for legacy and next-generation critical infrastructure in aviation systems, such as
air-ground communication, radio navigation aids, aeronautical surveillance, and system-wide information
management (SWIM). Our analysis shows that the communication, navigation, and surveillance systems
with the highest risk levels are very-high frequency voice communication, satellite-based navigation,
and automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast, respectively, while those with the lowest risk levels are
controller-pilot data link communication, ground-based radio navigation aids, and secondary surveillance
radar, respectively. Furthermore, the risk level of potential cyber-attacks in SWIM is medium.
Journal Name:
Studying Cybersecurity in Civil Aviation,
Including Developing and Applying Aviation
Cybersecurity Risk Assessment

Text: This paper pioneers the application of event-based estimation to cybersecurity equilibrium analysis, addressing inefficiencies in traditional periodic observation methods by triggering updates only when predefined conditions are met?educing observation costs by 98% while ensuring convergence and Zeno-free operation. Focusing on preventive-reactive defense dynamics, the study bridges the gap between theoretical probability-state models (continuous) and practical sample-state measurements (discrete), offering a scalable framework to approximate complex networked systems where equilibrium lacks closed-form solutions. By validating both global convergence and real-world applicability, the method provides a tractable tool for monitoring large-scale cyber-physical systems with minimal resource overhead.

Government operations are also not immune to cyberattacks.

global economy. For instance, international criminals entered

the systems of card-processing companies, the fraudsters were

Cybersecurity: Perceived Threats and Policy
Responses in the Gulf Cooperation Council

Specifically, the smart URC enables control over devices such as TVs, DVDs, projectors, lighting systems, electric motorized screens, and curtains. Additionally, with the integration of Wi-Fi and cameras, it is possible to manage heating systems, security and disaster management, spatial resolution, and real-time control information simultaneously.
Journal Name: Advanced Universal Remote Controller for Home Automation and Security

Text: In this note, we also examine the impulsive control of nonlinear systems, following the approach in [7]. We first establish a new comparison theorem. Using this theoretical foundation for impulsive differential systems, we derive less conservative stability conditions for systems with fixed-time impulses. These results are then used to design impulsive control laws for a class of nonlinear systems. Our method is applicable to a broader range of nonlinear systems and has the potential to enhance existing technologies in chaotic secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communications [8]–[13].
Journal Name: Less Conservative Conditions for Asymptotic Stability of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: As illustrated in Fig. 1(b), the authentication performance of the proposed system is compared against protected approaches from [5], [7], and [8], as well as an unprotected system that employs Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) as a classifier [14]. The proposed scheme outperforms the cryptosystems in [5] and [7], which use a signature representation based on 100 parametric features from [15]. Additionally, it improves upon the transformation-based protection method in [8], which utilizes function-based signature representation. Notably, the proposed system offers greater renewability than the methods in [5] and [7] by enabling the encoding of longer messages. While there is a slight performance loss compared to an unprotected DTW-based system—currently considered the best approach for signature authentication—the method effectively safeguards signature templates. It is important to note that signature recognition systems, due to their behavioral nature, typically do not achieve error rates as low as those seen with fingerprint or iris recognition. However, the obtained recognition rates are comparable to those of unprotected signature-based systems when evaluated with E=5 and the same dataset [15].
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text:
At the first communication level, the protocol depends on the meter and device providing the data. Digital meters in power systems typically communicate using protocols designed according to national regulations. For instance, the DL/T645-1997 protocol has been in use since June 1, 1998. However, some meters use their own proprietary protocols, while other controllable devices use industrial protocols like MODBUS.
At the second communication level, various international and national protocols are used in power systems, such as IEC 60870-5-101 and Q/GDW 130-2005 (specific to load-management systems). Additionally, some utilities have their own rules for remote data exchange, so the protocol used can vary depending on the utility.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: Security refers to a power system's ability to respond to sudden disturbances without interrupting supply. Security analysis must therefore evaluate inappropriate system responses, unnecessary device operations (such as protection devices), and/or malfunctioning subsystems when sudden disturbances occur. Any of these events impact the power quality and/or reliability of the electrical system, consequently placing the electrical infrastructure and associated industrial production processes at risk.
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Cybersecurity plays a crucial role in fostering technological growth and creating competitive marketplaces, ultimately leading to more efficient and prosperous societies. In our modern world, the aim is to simplify life while promoting innovation and entrepreneurship through constant efficiency, adaptability, and affordability, all supported by advanced technology infrastructure. However, maintaining public trust in cybersecurity has become paramount, as seen with companies like Amazon and Facebook, where trust is now a valuable commodity. As cybersecurity threats continue to evolve in sophistication, traditional security mechanisms often struggle to keep pace. The integration of technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) enhances threat detection and response capabilities but also introduces vulnerabilities due to the centralized nature of many AI systems. Conversely, blockchain technology offers a decentralized solution that can enhance data integrity and security, making it a promising avenue for addressing these challenges. By combining AI and blockchain, organizations can develop innovative solutions that not only protect sensitive data but also foster public trust in digital transactions and services.

To the best of our knowledge, this specific combination of methodologies has not been previously explored in the literature, making AAMD-OELAC a novel contribution to the field of cybersecurity.
