Many of the studied organizations were transitioning from paper-based to computerized patient data systems.
Journal Name: Incremental Adoption of Information Security in Health-Care Organizations: Implications for Document Management

Text: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) released the National Initiative on Cybersecurity Education (NICE) framework in August 2017 as part of Special Publication 800-181. This internationally recognized framework categorizes cybersecurity professions and is continuously updated to align with evolving workforce demands. The most recent version was released in November 2020.

Biometrics can be categorized into two primary subtypes: physical and behavioral. Physical biometrics are based on static body features, such as fingerprints, facial recognition, and iris scans. Behavioral biometrics, on the other hand, focus on learned gestures like signatures and keystroke dynamics. This paper suggests a more refined classification system for biometric signals, dividing them into stable and alterable categories. Stable signals are relatively constant and unchanging, while alterable signals are derived from an underlying stable biometric trait combined with a variable component.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: In a recent online publication [26], Joe Weiss draws attention to critical cybersecurity vulnerabilities associated with foreign-manufactured power transformers and other essential grid components. These power transformers, vital to electric grid functionality, face increasing susceptibility to cyber attacks from external threat actors. The grid's interconnected nature means that a single compromised transformer potentially endangers the entire system's integrity. Serious concerns exist regarding potential hardware backdoors embedded within these transformers, which could enable malicious actors to manipulate operational parameters and potentially trigger catastrophic failures. Despite these considerable risks, numerous utilities continue deploying foreign-manufactured equipment due to cost advantages, despite the associated security concerns. The industry's disproportionate focus on network vulnerabilities while neglecting hardware vulnerabilities compounds these risks to critical infrastructure, leaving essential components like power transformers vulnerable to concealed threats capable of causing severe system disruptions. This report emphasizes the urgent necessity for both utility industry stakeholders and government agencies to address these hardware-related security threats to effectively protect critical infrastructure assets.

The Open Core Protocol International Partnership (OCP-IP) standards incorporate protected transactions to enhance system security. By extending the standard OCP interface via layered profiles, a secure domain can be established within the System-on-Chip (SoC). This domain safeguards critical components like CPUs, memory, and I/O interfaces using hardware-software mechanisms such as secured interrupts, protected memory regions, and specialized processor instructions for secure mode access
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text:
Traditionally, manufacturing plants have been siloed
and naturally create air gaps making them secure [3].
On the one hand, DM exploits the information from
various sensors and devices to streamline the process
and material flow. On the other hand, the distributed
and collaborative nature of DM exposes it to risks that
come with the connectivity required to implement DM.
A typical DM process workflow is illustrated in Fig. 1.
A large part of the process before the actual manufacturing
step is completely digital and relies on computational
resources and computer networks for design, simulation,
and programming the controllers of the manufacturing
machines. The DM system may consist of additive,
subtractive, and hybrid manufacturing (HM) machines.
This process flow requires connectivity throughout the
process chain. However, connectivity poses a security
risk that needs to be addressed by traditional and
novel cybersecurity solutions that apply to various steps
of the process flow. This article presents the hybrid
machine (HM) tool as an archetype for DM, analyzes the
cybersecurity risks, develops an attack taxonomy, and
proposes novel solutions for the DM cyber?physical system.
Journal Name:
A Survey of Cybersecurity of
Digital Manufacturing

Text: In conclusion, analog transmission in communication systems is highly susceptible to channel noise, which increases synchronization errors. Due to the complex nonlinear functions in DDF systems, they exhibit high-dimensional chaos but are also more prone to interference from noise. Future research will focus on digital transmission methods, which are expected to significantly minimize synchronization errors.
Journal Name: Enhancing the Security of Delayed Differential Chaotic Systems With Programmable Feedback

Text: The imperative to address unpredictable real-world scenarios has necessitated the integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into complex networks of interconnected entities, specifically Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks (VANETs) [36]. These Intelligent Connected Vehicles (ICVs) are endowed with the capacity to establish communication with other vehicles, infrastructure, and pedestrians through diverse communication modalities, encompassing V2X (inclusive of V2N, V2V, V2I, and V2P) and Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC). However, ICVs are subject to a multitude of complexity and security challenges [37]. For example, in scholarly work [38], a descriptive analysis of DSRC and Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything (C-V2X) technologies and their respective architectures for V2X communication is presented. Concurrently, research [39] examines the evolutionary trajectory of communication technologies for V2X and ICVs, while elucidating the emergence of Internet of Vehicles (IoV) technology. Furthermore, threat vectors targeting ICVs include attacks directed at traffic light infrastructure [40], intrusions into communication channels and sensor tampering [41], and the security and privacy implications associated with C-V2X and DSRC communication technologies [42]. The security of V2X communication is of paramount importance, and numerous studies have investigated the inherent vulnerabilities within this transportation paradigm. Nevertheless, the cyber-physical nature of ICVs introduces augmented vulnerabilities to their communication frameworks [43]. Adversaries possess the potential to compromise vehicular power systems or controllers, thereby jeopardizing pedestrian safety through the injection of malicious code, malware, arbitrary code execution, and physical tampering with battery or controller components [44]. Therefore, a holistic consideration of both the physical and communication dimensions of ICVs is critical in order to maintain a secure transportation ecosystem within the domain of EVs.

Fast spinning reserve refers to power that can be delivered within seconds of detecting a significant frequency drop. In contrast, slow spinning reserve, while useful in reducing power deficits, is not fast enough to influence the minimum frequency reached during an event.A portion of the fast spinning reserve, adjusted by the reserve factor, is considered equivalent to load shedding in its effect on system response. Equation (1) presents a simplified dynamic condition where 
is a growing function of , the minimum frequency reached by a generating unit in area m following a sudden, large generation loss. Maintaining a minimum value helps prevent low-frequency transients from triggering additional unit trips due to low-frequency protection, thereby avoiding a cascading failure that could lead to system collapse.
Journal Name: SPINNING RESERVE, LOAD SHEDDING, AND ECONOMIC DISPATCH SOLUTION

Text: Learning methodologies can be categorized into two primary modalities: supervised learning and unsupervised learning. Within a supervised learning paradigm, the network is presented with a corpus of behavioral exemplars that have been pre-labeled. Conversely, in the context of unsupervised learning, the input data constitutes the sole informational resource for the learning process, and the network autonomously derives categorization schemes for the input patterns.

One approach to reducing design complexity and bridging the gap between advancements in manufacturing technology and synthesis/compiler technology is the reuse of previously developed Intellectual Property (IP). These IP blocks serve as foundational components for designers. However, designing such heterogeneous systems presents challenges, as it requires synthesis and compilation tools capable of efficiently utilizing the vast array of resources available to designers.
Journal Name: Secure Memory Accesses on Networks-on-Chip

Text: By providing end-use consumers with market signals, they can adjust their energy usage to avoid high market prices during periods when the power system is under stress. A demand-response program based on real-time electricity pricing offers a viable solution to bridge the supply-wholesale and demand-retail markets, allowing consumers to shift their loads accordingly.
Journal Name: AMI SYSTEM FOR THE DEREGULATED ELECTRICITY MARKETS

Text: These attacks involve crafting emails that appear authentic and sending them to legitimate systems, aiming to deceive unsuspecting users into clicking malicious links and revealing personal information. Such attacks leverage social engineering tactics, making emails seem trustworthy to manipulate recipients into compliance. Spear phishing, a more targeted variant, involves cybercriminals conducting detailed background research on potential victims to create highly convincing emails, often using trusted email addresses in the "from" field to enhance credibility and increase the likelihood of success.

Future enhancements could involve defining new metrics for selecting the most reliable signature traits, which would minimally impact the entropy of the binary representation and improve resilience against privacy attacks. Additionally, using alternative functions to represent acquired online signatures could further enhance the system.
Journal Name: Fuzzy Commitment for Function Based Signature Template Protection

Text: In their study, Meidan et al. utilized TCP/IP traffic network data to categorize unauthorized IoT devices using machine learning (ML) techniques, specifically employing the random forest (RF) algorithm for supervised learning. The authors assumed that their dataset adequately represented each device type on the whitelist, which included nine IoT device categories comprising 17 unique devices. They extracted 60 features from network traffic data, eliminating those with zero variance, irrelevance, or a tendency to cause model overfitting, ultimately focusing on the most relevant characteristics for profiling and identification. One device type was intentionally excluded from the whitelist to represent an unauthorized device. To test the classifier's transportability, the model was trained on two identical security cameras in one lab and evaluated with a different model in another lab. The classifiers achieved an impressive average accuracy of 96% in detecting illegitimate IoT device types, demonstrating the effectiveness of their approach in identifying unauthorized devices within a network.

Although historical data needed for simulations is lacking, the proposed steps demonstrate how the Market Monitoring Body (MMB) can monitor the market and align player interests with system reliability and security needs. The MMB can collect reliability data, which market players might consider proprietary, and use it to ensure system security and control energy services. This approach helps manage market dynamics effectively.
Journal Name: Leader-Follower Framework for Control of Energy Services

Text:
A very common and actually the most basic attack is the
analysis of encrypted packets. In such an analysis, the
adversary wants to obtain information only by interpreting
ciphertexts. A secure cryptographic system must ensure
that it is not possible to gain any inappropriate information
(plaintext, key, statistical information). Additionally, it must
be provided that an attacker cannot decide whether an
encrypted packet corresponds to a specific plaintext or not.
In particular, in WSNs with a scarce domain of values, the
latter attack can very efficiently result in a deduction of the
plaintexts.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: The primary objective of this research was to explore ways to improve cybersecurity education by fostering deeper engagement and understanding among learners. Students who recognize the relevance and practical applications of the material tend to learn more effectively. To achieve this, the study proposes enhancing traditional learning models by incorporating real-world, gamified scenarios that encourage emotional and cognitive investment. Regardless of an organization? size or sophistication?hether commercial, civil, or governmental?lear, experiential programs that communicate real cyber threats can enhance engagement, knowledge retention, and practical implementation. Furthermore, the study highlights the importance of a proactive training approach (PTPA) to develop responsive actors who can apply their cybersecurity knowledge in critical situations. A key issue identified is the disconnect between user behavior and cybersecurity consequences?any individuals unknowingly infect their systems without understanding the root cause, leading to a disengaged and fatalistic approach to security. By employing a mixed-mode pedagogical framework, this study aims to bridge that gap, providing empirical evidence on how different instructional methods contribute to meaningful behavioral changes in cybersecurity awareness and response.

IoT communications must be secured, as large volumes of data are transmitted between devices, servers, and customers. Any compromise in confidentiality, integrity, or availability (CIA) can lead to severe consequences. Unprotected data streams create potential attack vectors, making devices vulnerable to data theft and other security breaches. Ensuring strong encryption, authentication, and intrusion detection mechanisms is crucial to mitigating these risks.

Recently, impulsive systems and impulsive control have been studied 
by many researchers. Bainov and Simeonov [1], Lakshmikantham et
al. [2], and Lakshmikantham and Liu [3] have considered the stability  
of impulsive systems by using Lyapunov functions and the Lyapunov  
functions are required to be nonincreasing along the whole sequence  
of the switchings. Li et al. [5] have relaxed this requirement and the   
Lyapunov function is only required to be nonincreasing along a subse-
quence of the switchings. Yang [6] has obtained some sufficient con-  
ditions for the impulsive control of a class of nonlinear systems by
using the results in [2]. Yang and Chua [7] and Yang et al. [8] have 
presented some interesting applications of impulsive control in chaotic  
secure communication systems and chaotic spread spectrum communi-   
cations. Panas et al. [8] have given some methods for the experimental
settings to achieve the impulsive controls.
Journal Name: Analysis and Design of Impulsive Control Systems

Text: Research on impulsive systems and their control has been a popular area of study recently. Several studies have examined the stability of these systems, often employing Lyapunov functions. These methods traditionally require the Lyapunov functions to decrease or remain constant across all or some switching points. Yang, in another study, developed criteria for impulsive control of certain nonlinear systems, building upon previous stability work. Others have also refined stability conditions for impulsive systems with fixed-time impulses, which they then applied to designing control for nonlinear systems. Furthermore, researchers have explored the practical applications of impulsive control, particularly in areas like secure and spread spectrum communications that utilize chaotic systems. Finally, experimental techniques for implementing impulsive controls have also been developed.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text:
Ethics aim at determining what is wrong and what is right, and
setting up standards of acceptable, moral behaviors in certain situations. Cybersecurity directly affects people?s wellbeing; this is why ethics play a prominent role in it. In the
context of cybersecurity, ethical principles are in fact at the
core of cybersecurity practices, as they refer to responsible use of technologies, in order to protect individuals and
ensure they live well [1], [2], [3], [4]. Although the ethics of
cybersecurity might seem to be simple - protect the data of
good guys, do not let the bad guys in - it can be surprisingly
complicated [5]. This paper discusses the results of a broad
Horizon Scanning campaign aimed at uncovering the anticipated, emerging ethical issues related to cybersecurity
Journal Name:
What Will the Future of Cybersecurity Bring Us,
and Will It Be Ethical? The Hunt for the Black
Swans of Cybersecurity Ethics

Text: IoT and cyber-physical systems (CPS) are equipped with various sensors that are crucial for monitoring and supporting system functions, but these sensors are highly vulnerable to attacks from adversaries, leading to significant security and safety threats. Critical sensors, such as global positioning system (GPS) signals, light detection and ranging (LiDAR) signals, and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data, can be compromised, resulting in severe consequences for device integrity and functionality. The exploitation of these vulnerabilities can allow attackers to manipulate sensor data or disrupt operations, highlighting the urgent need for robust security measures to protect these essential components of IoT and CPS infrastructures. As the reliance on these technologies grows, addressing their vulnerabilities becomes increasingly critical to ensure the safety and security of interconnected systems.

Several tasks remain to be investigated. We need to char acterize the network conditions under which the max-revenue objective function fails, and understand the behavior of the min-absolute-value objective function. Another issue concerns grid expansion. We know that our method facilitates grid ex pansion through capacity increases, since the TSP profits from increasing line capacity. However, we do not address the ques tion of detrimental grid expansion that may result in increased congestion rents [6]. The subject of transmission expansion is left for future research. Of particular interest is the question concerning the degree of market power exerted by the large end users in our method relative to the market power in a bundled centralized market, assuming all other conditions the same. This critical question is likely to determine how truly separable transmission service is from the energy service and it is left for future research.
Journal Name: Transmission Pricing of Distributed Multilateral Energy Transactions to Ensure System Security and Guide Economic Dispatch

Text: This paper examines our palmprint identification system, which utilizes the Competitive Code algorithm. We selected Competitive Code for brute-force attack analysis due to its superior accuracy and computational speed, as demonstrated by Zhang and his team, compared to other palmprint verification algorithms. Moreover, the version of Competitive Code implemented in this study has been enhanced to generate new templates when the original ones are compromised, effectively providing cancelable palmprint representation.
Journal Name: Analysis of Brute-Force Break-Ins of a Palmprint Authentication System

Text: An HNN, with large capacity, can store authentication information using marginal training time. The authentication scheme incorporating the use of HNN can recall information for a legal user’s ID and pass word instantly and accurately. Our experiments have demonstrated the usefulness and robustness of the proposed authentication scheme.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: Cybersecurity, conceptualized as an ensemble of procedural frameworks, human behavioral protocols, and systemic safeguards, serves to protect electronic assets, mirroring the exponential progression observed in Moore's law, which posits a biennial doubling of integrated circuit components alongside a reduction in manufacturing expenses, cybercriminals exhibit a parallel trend, effectively doubling the potency of their attack vectors at a diminished cost within abbreviated time frames, as evidenced by projections indicating a global cybersecurity expenditure surpassing $1 trillion between 2017 and 2021, and a near 40 percent increase in cybersecurity spending from 2013 to $66 billion, underscoring the escalating financial commitment to counteract the burgeoning cyber threat landscape.

Numerical studies have shown that the most secure and efficient method for transmitting and recovering small amplitude messages in all-optical chaos-based communication systems is using a closed-loop receiver scheme. In contrast, open-loop schemes require larger amplitude messages, which compromise security. The success of closed-loop systems depends on stable external or integrated cavities, similar to those currently under development. These cavities are crucial for maintaining the stability needed to securely transmit and recover messages.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text: To address the vulnerabilities of traditional password systems, a multi-layered neural network approach has been suggested. This method assigns a unique binary code to each user. The network is trained using these codes, along with corresponding user IDs and encrypted passwords. After training, only the network's connection strengths are stored for authentication. When a user tries to log in, the system retrieves these connection strengths, inputs the user's ID and encrypted password into the network, and verifies that the output matches the user's assigned binary code.
Journal Name: Password Authentication Using Hopfield Neural Networks

Text: When the primary emphasis of an acquisition is placed on task integration, the process of human integration may create obstacles and disrupt organizational identity. Conversely, when human integration is prioritized, operational synergies risk being delayed. Achieving a balance between separation and coordination is crucial across different sectors during an acquisition. Separation grants units the autonomy necessary to innovate and develop new ideas, while integration ensures the avoidance of redundant processes and supports a cost-efficient organizational structure. Striking this balance is key to maintaining both innovation and operational effectiveness.

HM tools are excellent archetypes of a DM building block.
They make a case to explain how traditional manufacturing is transforming into DM. This resulting transformation,
however, creates additional attack vectors for DM. The case
of an HM tool, therefore, allows identifying, analyzing, and
addressing the vulnerabilities from these attack vectors
before the widespread adoption of DM
Journal Name:
A Survey of Cybersecurity of
Digital Manufacturing

Text: We have developed a new class of super broadband, nano-scale shift, and cost-effective position sensors. These sensors extend the frequency band and enhance the resolution of existing vibrometers and seismographs by 10 to 100 times, depending on the base product model (such as the American KS-1/KS-54000 and FBA-23, European GS-13 and STS-1/STS-2, and Russian SM-3, which was compared with our sensor). The test model of the new sensor can convert vibrations of buildings and structures with amplitudes greater than 1 nm into detectable electrical signals. This high resolution is achieved because oscillators, which measure frequency with much higher precision compared to inductance or capacitance, are the most suitable sensors for high-precision detection. Consequently, a similar position sensor based on inductance-change detection of a lithographically-made single-layer flat coil shows a resolution that is three orders of magnitude lower [11].
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: In this letter, we propose a multiaccess communication scheme based on injection-locking [2] in conjunction with symmetric operation [6]–[10]. As shown in Fig. 1, two face-to-face MCSLs (Laser1 and Laser2) are injected by an external cavity semiconductor laser (ECSL) Laser3 with iden tical unidirectional injections (UIs). The feedback strength has been chosen such that Laser3 operates in a chaos regime. In this configuration, two types of synchronization, namely the synchronization between the MCSLs and the synchronization between the MCSLs and Laser3, can be achieved. For the former case, due to the identical UIs and the same levels of mutual coupling (MC), Laser1 synchronizes with Laser2 isochronally through symmetric operation [6], [8]. For the latter case, the MCSLs synchronize with Laser3 through injec tion-locking as that in common MS systems [4], [15]. Both of the two types of synchronization show strong CPF, hence, each MCSL can simultaneously communicate with Laser3 and its counterpart.
Journal Name: Multiaccess Optical Chaos Communication Using Mutually Coupled Semiconductor Lasers Subjected to Identical External Injections

Text: The relay register must retain the control bits (flags) of all other appliances while updating only the flag corresponding to the current command. This functionality is achieved using the circuit depicted in Fig. 3. The JK flip-flops, which serve as flag bits for the relay register, have asynchronous Preset (PR') and Clear (CLR') inputs, through which commands are applied. The figure illustrates a single flip-flop operation. The Enable (En) bit is derived from the decoded appliance code, while the ON/OFF·bit corresponds to the action code. For example, if a command is issued for the 5th appliance, the En bit of the 5th flip-flop is set to ·.·If the ON command is received, the ON/OFF·bit becomes ·,·setting PR·to ··and activating the flip-flop (··. Conversely, if the ON/OFF·bit is ·,·the flip-flop is cleared.
Journal Name: Analysis of Remote Control Techniques Employed in Home Automation and Security Systems

Text: The challenge of limited cybersecurity skills is further compounded by the high turnover of volunteers in social enterprises (SEs), which diminishes the long-term impact of any training initiatives. Moreover, SEs' close engagement with disadvantaged and vulnerable populations increases their exposure to social engineering attacks? particularly difficult threat to mitigate. These factors collectively support RQ1 by demonstrating that owner-managers acknowledge how the distinctive nature of SEs heightens their vulnerability to cyberattacks, especially those leveraging social engineering tactics.

CDA-based end-to-end encryption is much more
flexible for varying connected backbones over
different epochs. With hop-by-hop encryption, only
nodes storing the corresponding key can perform the
decryption and thus aggregate data. With CDA,
every node can be elected as an aggregator node,
since the aggregating nodes do not need to store the
key to operate on the incoming ciphertext message.
Thus, the election process per epoch is purely based
on the remaining energy levels of the nodes. CDA
provides confidentiality by not restricting these
aggregator-node-election algorithms. This increases
the robustness and reliability of the WSN.
Journal Name: A SURVEY ON THE ENCRYPTION OF CONVERGECAST TRAFFIC WITH IN-NETWORK PROCESSING

Text: To decrypt broadcast content, the Ks information is continuously sent to the receiver in the form of the Entitlement Control Message (ECM-Kw), alongside the encrypted content. Before transmission, the ECM-Kw, which includes Ks, is encrypted using a Kw that is typically updated monthly. The Kw itself is encrypted with a Km specific to each receiver and also transmitted. As depicted in Figure 2, the ECM consists of a fixed unit and a variable unit. The fixed unit carries fixed-length information, and a portion of this unit along with the entire variable unit is encrypted to secure the data. The Ks is contained within the fixed unit of the ECM-Kw.
Journal Name: A DIGITAL RIGHTS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR DBHS

Text: The global demand for cybersecurity experts has prompted standard bodies and governments to continuously monitor workforce requirements and initiate framework developments. Notably, the World Economic Forum highlights a pressing need for 4 million additional cybersecurity professionals to address the talent gap, which could escalate to 85 million by 2030, potentially resulting in $8.5 trillion in unrealized annual revenue due to cybersecurity skills shortages. Despite this urgent need, many universities have not yet established active collaborations with the industrial sector, leading to concerns that graduates may lack the necessary skills required by employers. Reports indicate that while the cybersecurity workforce grew by 12.6% from 2022 to 2023, the overall growth has stalled, with significant gaps in capabilities persisting across organizations. Initiatives such as the NICE Framework aim to bridge these gaps by aligning educational outcomes with industry needs and promoting a more diverse and skilled workforce. As the cybersecurity landscape continues to evolve, it is crucial for educational institutions and industry stakeholders to work together to develop comprehensive strategies that address both current and future workforce challenges.

In the coming decades, electronic controllers, micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS), and nanoscale electrochemical sensors and actuators will be crucial in reducing vehicle emissions. These components will support electrochemical processes that minimize hydrocarbons and carbon and nitrogen oxides in exhaust emissions. Currently, electronic controllers, sensors, and actuators facilitate a multi-stage process that treats exhaust gases from the combustion engine to the tailpipe, ensuring that pollutants are captured and converted into cleaner emissions.
Journal Name: Scanning Advanced Automobile Technology

Text:
StealthNet [5] is a US Army-funded LVC (Live-VirtualConstructive) platform for cyber-related testing, evaluation,
and training on the Army?s tactical networks. StealthNet
contains emulation models of cyber attacks such as jamming,
DDoS, and worm propagation to determine the impact of
cyber threats on tactical networks. StealthNet, in particular,
provides simulation models for wireless tactical networks,
enabling LVC co-simulation for cybersecurity training in
tactical networks.
Journal Name:
ICSTASY: An Integrated Cybersecurity Training
System for Military Personnel

Text: Artificial intelligence algorithms play a pivotal role in cybersecurity and attack detection, often outperforming traditional intrusion detection systems like Snort or Suricata in certain scenarios. This research evaluates the characteristics of well-established machine learning algorithms commonly used in IDS applications, first proposing a categorization method for cybersecurity datasets that groups records into distinct clusters. Using this framework, the study systematically examines which neural network architecture (multilayer or recurrent), activation function, and learning algorithm yield the highest accuracy for each data category. The findings identify the most relevant and representative data subsets for intrusion detection while determining the optimal machine learning configuration to maximize detection performance and minimize computational overhead, thereby enhancing the efficiency of cybersecurity systems.

This article aims to identify critical data that need protection against cyber-attacks in networked manufacturing machines, considering whether the production technology is subtractive or additive. High-tech industries, such as aeronautics, automotive, and medical, often use both methods. Additive manufacturing builds products layer by layer, enabling complex designs, while subtractive manufacturing removes material from a solid, preserving material integrity for greater durability. The study also assesses the business impacts of cyber threats on these manufacturing processes.

In a meshed power system, a key characteristic of protections is that load and fault currents can flow in either a counterclockwise or clockwise direction [13]. To model Protection Networks (PNs), coordinating protections in such systems is essential. Defining protection zones for distance relays is a critical aspect of specifying the operating sequences of main and backup protections in power transmission systems using PNs [13], [21]–[23].
Journal Name: Power Systems Security Evaluation Using Petri Nets

Text: Knowing the location of a fault, whether transient or permanent, is crucial for the efficient operation of a power system. Accurately locating a transmission line fault helps reduce repair time and, consequently, the outage duration of the affected line. Identifying and eliminating weak spots, such as weak or dirty insulators that often cause transient faults, is also possible. Fault location is valuable for analyzing protective relaying schemes, as it allows for the accurate determination of zero sequence impedance, which is typically challenging to calculate.
Journal Name: A NEW TRANSMISSION LINE FAULT LOCATING SYSTEM

Text: With a single-sourcing approach, an organization relies exclusively on one vendor for the integration of its IT systems, outsourcing all maintenance and troubleshooting tasks to that vendor. This strategy reduces the need for a large in-house IT staff, as the effectiveness of the organization's IT systems hinges on the capabilities of the chosen vendor. Additionally, managing contracts with a single vendor is less complex compared to dealing with multiple suppliers, as the scope and significance of these contracts tend to be greater. Consequently, the operational efficiency and functionality of the client organization become highly dependent on this single vendor, leading to increased reliance and potential vulnerabilities should issues arise with that vendor.

While previous research has significantly advanced the understanding of security standards adoption and implementation, challenges remain in streamlining compliance efforts. Identifying similarities between standards can help organizations reduce redundant work, simplifying the compliance process. This approach not only decreases implementation time but also lowers the costs associated with meeting multiple standards. The primary aim of this research is to evaluate widely adopted security standards across key industries, highlighting the benefits of recognizing overlaps between them. By doing so, it seeks to demonstrate how aligning similar requirements can enhance efficiency and effectiveness in cybersecurity practices.

The adoption of a single-sourcing strategy frequently compels organizations to implement systems that deviate from established business workflows, necessitating substantial re-engineering efforts encompassing procedural adjustments, policy modifications, and the enforcement of novel system utilization standards; conversely, a best-of-breed (BoB) approach facilitates the selection of vendors whose systems align more closely with existing organizational processes, thereby minimizing disruptive changes; the inherent process alterations associated with single-sourcing, however, introduce potential security vulnerabilities, as malicious actors may exploit weaknesses arising from procedural redesigns, while non-malicious employees, grappling with these transitions, may inadvertently commit security errors, thus exacerbating the risk landscape.

Wind-powered generators are primarily based on induction generator technology, which typically absorbs reactive power during normal operation. This absorption can lead to low-voltage problems within the power system. Furthermore, integrating large-scale wind generation into the utility grid alters both the power flow patterns and the dynamic characteristics of the system. As part of the system impact study, it is essential to analyze steady-state power flow under both normal and contingency conditions to identify any potential overloading of transmission lines. Additionally, calculations of short-circuit currents must be conducted both before and after the installation of new wind generation facilities to assess any increases in short-circuit current levels and determine if infrastructure upgrades, such as split-bus or breaker enhancements, are necessary. Dynamic simulations of the system must also be performed to verify the overall stability of the power system.
Journal Name: System Impact Study for the Interconnection of Wind Generation and Utility System

Text: An effective approach [1] integrated automated mapping with facilities management and a geographic information system to prevent distribution transformer damage caused by overloading. A pulse-width modulation-based control scheme [2] was introduced for the ILM to effectively reduce system peak load. However, utilities must establish agreements with customers by offering price discounts or incentive rates to form interruptible load groups (ILGs). The appropriate incentive rates for customers were explored in [3] and [4]. Additionally, a dynamic tariff [5] was proposed for demand-side management (DSM), presenting a real-time pricing strategy to help industrial end-users maximize their profits.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT

Text: Authenticators can be classified into three main types: secrets (what you know), tokens (what you have), and IDs (who you are). A password is an example of a secret, which can be a word, phrase, or personal identification number. Despite their widespread use, passwords have vulnerabilities. The primary issue is that short, mnemonic passwords can be easily guessed or cracked by determined attackers, while longer, random passwords are challenging for individuals to remember.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text:
Repudiation denotes irresponsibility of actions performed. For example, demand response (DR) schedules
and incentives exchanged among the power grid and DR
provider using the OpenADR 2.0 protocol are digitally
certified and acknowledged [21]. As a result of this
certification, the likelihood of denying any malicious
actions of the DR provider is reduced. It also implies
that the concerned party is responsible or aware of the
actions performed in its device or service
Journal Name:
Cybersecurity of Smart Electric Vehicle Charging:
A Power Grid Perspective

Text:
Cloud computing platforms can be highly attractive to conduct course assignments and empower students with valuable
and indispensable hands-on experience. In particular, the cloud can offer teaching staff and students (whether local or remote)
on-demand, elastic, dedicated, isolated, (virtually) unlimited, and easily configurable virtual machines. As such, employing cloud-based
laboratories can have clear advantages over using classical ones, which impose major hindrances against fulfilling pedagogical
objectives and do not scale well when the number of students and distant university campuses grows up. We show how the cloud
paradigm can be leveraged to teach a cybersecurity course. Specifically, we share our experience when using cloud computing to
teach a senior course on cybersecurity across two campuses via a virtual classroom equipped with live audio and video. Furthermore,
based on this teaching experience, we propose guidelines that can be applied to teach similar computer science and engineering
courses. We demonstrate how cloud-based laboratory exercises can greatly help students in acquiring crucial cybersecurity skills as
well as cloud computing ones, which are in high demand nowadays. The cloud we used for this course was the Amazon Web Services
(AWS) public cloud. However, our presented use cases and approaches are equally applicable to other available cloud platforms such
as Rackspace and Google Compute Engine, among others.
Journal Name: Teaching Cybersecurity Using the Cloud

Text: Based on our current understanding of existing research, a cost-efficient blockchain technology, task scheduling, and Cyber-Physical System (CPS) scheme tailored for Industrial Internet of Healthcare Things (IIoHT) healthcare applications, that incorporates both execution and blockchain costs, has not yet been presented or proposed. Existing blockchain schemes, including Ethereum, Corda, and Fabric, primarily focus on security aspects, neglecting cost optimization for practical healthcare applications. Conversely, existing cost-efficient scheduling schemes aim to minimize execution costs and address malware attacks. However, the dynamic cybersecurity requirements of blockchain technology necessitate additional resources and time, resulting in processing costs for healthcare applications that are largely overlooked in the current literature.

A comparison of the signal-to-noise ratios for the new sensor and the SM-3 sensor, both installed in the same seismograph, reveals that the new sensor is more sensitive by two orders of magnitude. Additionally, the new sensor's ability to detect position shifts allows it to identify the onset of oscillating processes at very low frequencies, starting from quasi-static shifts, which is not possible with EMF-based sensors. This capability is crucial for detecting low-order free oscillations of the Earth's crust and observing tidal motions and tsunami formation over several hours. Consequently, it may enable the early detection and study of earthquake formation origins, a feat that is practically impossible with other methods. Our solution holds significant potential for meeting the technical needs of seismic services supported by governments in the world's most seismically active regions.
Journal Name: NEW PRINCIPLE OF OPERATION SEISMIC DETECTOR OF NANO-SCALE VIBRATIONS

Text: We have shown that the image authentication scheme SARI is not secure when the same key is used to authenticate even a relatively small number of images. In order to overcome this problem, we suggest a simple “salting” mechanism, much like the one used in UNIX password authentication. Appending a salt along with the image digest would require an attacker to possess an impractically large number of images authenticated with the same key in order to produce counterfeit images. De pending on the application, the number of bits in the salt can be controlled to make the attack we describe infeasible. The salt mechanism we propose is very simple and adds a relatively small number of fixed bits to the digest produced by SARI. Fur thermore, the mechanism we propose, in fact, is quite general and can be used in a variety of authentication techniques pro posed in the literature in order to circumvent attacks of the type proposed here and in [11]
Journal Name: On the Security of the Digest Function in the SARI Image Authentication System

Text:
In order to identify the threat from malicious sites, the
online security community has created blacklisting services
to help detect harmful websites. The blacklist is a database
that contains a list of all URLs already known to be malicious. URL blacklisting has been shown to be effective in
some cases [2]. However, the attacker can make use of them by easily fooling the system with changes to one or more
components of the URL string. Inevitably, many malicious
sites are not blacklisted because they are either too new or
were never or erroneously assessed.
Journal Name:
Detecting Malicious URLs Using Machine Learning
Techniques: Review and Research Directions

Text: While the Internet offers numerous advantages, the absence of a strong cybersecurity infrastructure leaves the global IoT network vulnerable to attacks and malicious activities. In recent years, research on IoT-related cybersecurity has grown exponentially, reflecting the urgency of addressing these challenges. This paper conducts a comprehensive literature review by analyzing relevant studies from five major academic databases?EEE Xplore, Web of Science, ACM Digital Library, INSPEC, and ScienceDirect?o assess the current state and future research directions in IoT security. The review identifies key cybersecurity countermeasures and techniques applied across various industries while highlighting emerging challenges and opportunities for researchers and practitioners. A total of 433 articles from IEEE Xplore since 2013 were reviewed, confirming that cybersecurity is an increasingly critical topic in IoT research, as indicated by the growing publication trend in this field.

At the receiver, a demultiplexer separates the Packetized Elementary Streams (PESs) within the scrambled Transport Stream (TS) and isolates the control data, namely the ECM and EMM. The EMM, verified by its digital signature, is decrypted using the Master Private Key (MPK) stored in the authorized smart card, yielding the Authorization Key (AK). Similarly, the ECM, also verified by its signature, is decrypted using the AK to retrieve the Control Words (CWs). These CWs are then fed into the same Pseudo-Random Generator (PRG) used by the server, synchronized via the server's synchronization signal, to generate the identical pseudo-random sequence needed to descramble the TS. The smart card, inserted into the receiver, securely stores the authorization data, including the MPK, necessary for control data decryption. The MPK is initially programmed onto the smart card by the service provider, who can subsequently update it remotely.
Journal Name: A Scalable Key Distribution Scheme for Conditional Access System in Digital Pay-TV System

Text: Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) bridge the physical and digital realms, offering transformative potential for critical infrastructure?et their vulnerability to cyberattacks poses severe risks to human safety, infrastructure integrity, and environmental stability. The wireless transmission of sensor-to-actuator data expands attack surfaces, challenging traditional security approaches focused solely on intrusion prevention via cryptography or access control. As adversaries grow more sophisticated, merely detecting attacks becomes insufficient; modern CPS must prioritize resilience?he ability to maintain functionality despite disruptions. While machine learning (ML) has emerged as a key tool for building resilient CPS, recent adversarial ML research reveals that these algorithms themselves must be hardened against exploitation. This article provides a comprehensive survey of two intertwined challenges: (1) leveraging ML to enhance CPS resilience, and (2) fortifying ML models against attacks when deployed in CPS. By synthesizing cutting-edge countermeasures and identifying unresolved gaps, we equip readers with a roadmap for advancing both resilient CPS design and trustworthy ML deployment in critical systems, concluding with actionable research directions to address evolving threats in this high-stakes domain.

Authentication confirms the identity of a user, device, or system entity, often required before granting access to resources. This verification relies on matching an identity indicator, like a pre-shared secret established during authorization. Passwords are the most common user authentication method, while protocols like SSL facilitate machine-to-machine authentication.
Journal Name: Comparing Passwords, Tokens, and Biometrics for User Authentication

Text: We have introduced a novel digital chaotic secure communication system that incorporates a magnifying-glass concept to amplify observed errors caused by parameter mismatches. Additionally, an impulsive control strategy with piecewise-constant intervals is used to synchronize chaotic circuits. The proposed system integrates elements of both conventional cryptographic schemes and chaotic secure communication techniques. Our system demonstrates high sensitivity to parameter mismatches, enhancing its security.
Journal Name: A NEW CHAOTIC SECURE COMMUNICATION SYSTEM

Text: The recent report on "Definition and Classification of Power System Stability" is highly welcomed. The existing stability concepts are well-defined and comprehensive, detailing various phenomena that lead to instability. These phenomena include: 1) rotor angle instability, 2) voltage instability, and 3) frequency instability. Recent developments suggest that there may be a need to introduce an additional phenomenon to cover all practical instability scenarios in power systems.
Journal Name: Closure of The Coordinated Automatic Voltage Control of the Italian Transmission Grid

Text: Our numerical simulations indicate that the most effective method for transmitting and recovering low-amplitude messages, which are essential for security in all-optical chaos-based communication systems, is to use a closed-loop receiver scheme. Conversely, open-loop schemes require larger message amplitudes, which compromise security. In practical applications, successful chaos-based communication with a closed-loop receiver depends on using stable external or integrated cavities, similar to those being developed currently.
Journal Name: Security Implications of Open- and Closed-Loop Receivers in All-Optical Chaos-Based Communications

Text:
Due to the increasing complexity of software and communication interfaces, IoT and cyber?physical devices are more
vulnerable to various kinds of attacks. Cybersecurity breaches
in such systems are likely to incur several privacy and security
issues. Appropriate safety measures and effective and robust
cybersecurity solutions are mandatory to combat any threats or
attacks. Below, we outline some common security risks associated with IoT and CPS where ML algorithms rely on data
collected from such IoT/CPS systems.
Journal Name:
Recent Advances on Federated Learning for
Cybersecurity and Cybersecurity for Federated
Learning for Internet of Things

Text: The proposed algorithm was practically tested on the LJ36 feeder of the Dar-Gun substation. The autoregressive moving-average (ARMA) model was used to predict the feeder load. As shown in Table I, the forecasted load for the LJ36 feeder is based on the ARMA (2,1) model. The highest forecasting error is 6.22% at the 13th hour, while the lowest is 0.35% at the 9th hour, with an average forecasting error of 3.23%. The duration curve of the forecasted load is illustrated in Fig. 3. If the feeder load surpasses 6600 kW, load shedding must be implemented to ensure system security. The load shedding pattern is detailed in column 5 of Table I.
Journal Name: A MODEL REFERENCE ADAPTIVE CONTROL STRATEGY FOR INTERRUPTIBLE LOAD MANAGEMENT
